HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE REACTION; 
Many Listeners Are Reassured By Tough Talk

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. McFADDEN 

 BODY:
Many Americans still shaken by last week's attacks applauded President Bush's call last night for a new spirit of perseverance and unity in the face of terrorism, saying they supported a long, sustained campaign against shadowy terrorist forces around the world.
 In interviews during and after the president's televised address to the nation and to a joint meeting of Congress, scores of Americans said they were reassured by Mr. Bush's pledge to hunt down and root out terrorist cells and to punish nations that harbor them, even though it might take months or years. 
 "He's delivered the message that everyone needs to hear," Bruce Marks, 34, a lawyer, said after watching the speech with a cheering crowd of 150 people at Tobacco Road, a blues bar in downtown Miami. "He's spoken directly to the terrorists and reassured Muslims worldwide that we won't tolerate the extremists." 
Many Americans acknowledged that they had been frightened by the terrorist attacks and left with a profound sense of vulnerability, and they praised Mr. Bush for what they called a strong and effective speech that eased their fears and gave direction to the nation. Some even called it inspirational.
Others, however, said the speech lacked what they had expected -- solid information about the terrorists, about what they had done and about what the United States planned to do about it.
"I wish that the terrorists had been described a little more as not just people who hate us, and that he had elaborated a little more on the conditions that led to them hating us and what we anticipate doing to keep people from being terrorists," said Annabel Conrad, 36, an education consultant in Memphis. "It was pretty superficial."
And a few expressed downright dissatisfaction.
"I felt at several junctures that he was exhibiting a lot of the arrogance that I think has gotten the United States in a lot of trouble in the past," Christian King, 60, of Dennisport, Mass., said. "We seem to have this sense that we are tougher, stronger, smarter, bigger than anyone else in the world. It is not a good way to act."
Most of those interviewed approved of Mr. Bush's performance, but said they were no clearer on the issues than before his speech.
"I thought President Bush seemed to be in command, in control," said Nat Drake, a Seattle accountant who watched the speech at a hotel lounge. "He struck just the right tone. Very grave."
But Laurie Zencey, a merchandiser from St. Louis, said enlightenment was lacking: "I know terrorism is the enemy. I understand that. Everyone understands that. But exactly how do we go and root that out? It's not like fighting Japan or Germany or World War II. I'm not sure he showed us the road map for how exactly we should fight and how we'll beat the enemy."
Many said they were aware that swift retribution against those responsible for the attacks probably was not possible, and that military strikes against terrorist bases or nations that harbor them might have to be surgical rather than overwhelming.
On a day when American forces were on the move -- ships and planes heading for the Persian Gulf and reservists to stateside posts -- some Americans said they opposed indiscriminate bombing of Afghanistan for harboring Osama bin Laden, the Islamic extremist widely suspected of being behind the attacks, and insisted that the targets be limited to proven terrorists, and that the proof be made public.
Nine days after the attacks in New York and at the Pentagon left nearly 6,000 people dead or missing, and deeply wounded an already fragile economy, many Americans spoke of Mr. Bush's speech as a missed opportunity, although some said they were encouraged by his vow to join Congress in an economic stimulus package.
"I would have liked to have heard more about the economy in his speech," Marie Somers, 52, a Web development manager in South Orange, N.J., said. "There are a lot of people who are close to retirement who are watching their portfolios go down the tubes. There were a lot of very important financial analysts lost in the attacks and who knows where the country is headed economically from this."
Carl Kelly, 66, an accountant in Memphis, agreed that the speech short-changed the economic aspects of the disaster.
"I think he should emphasize more that the economy is strong and the country will remain strong," Mr. Kelly said. "I think he should have said more about how the state of the union is strong and the economic strength of our country, not only tonight but during these past days, that we've taken a hit and we're going to come back strong. I was looking for that. I want that reassurance."
Many of those interviewed called Mr. Bush's address a careful balancing act -- an effort to prepare the nation for a military effort that could last months, but without raising unrealistic expectations about delivering quick results or crushing blows.
But most Americans said they were favorably impressed, at times even emotionally moved, by Mr. Bush. 
In Longmont, Colo., a dozen customers at Riley's restaurant listened intently to the speech, applauding occasionally amid a small forest of American flags stuck in empty beer pitchers.
"Bush is like his dad, he has a big heart," said Cyndi Morris, a painter and artist. "I believe God has sent us an ark in Bush. We're all going to get through this together, side by side. I feel a lot better after hearing him. I think he knows how to pull us together."
Dottie Everett, a Democrat who grew up in Boston, said her opinion of Mr. Bush had changed during the course of the speech. "I think he did a great job of presenting his case to the people," said Ms. Everett, who admitted she was apprehensive about a protracted, open-ended war. "Honestly, before this speech I didn't think he was that literate. But he did a wonderful job tonight."
In a show of bipartisan unity, Democrats in Congress bypassed an opportunity to offer a televised response to Mr. Bush's address. "We want enemies and the whole world and all of our citizens to know that America speaks tonight with one voice," Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, said.
A few Americans found fault with what they called the president's overly simplistic characterization of the struggle to come -- presenting it as a battle between good and evil, between the forces of freedom and the forces of fear. 
Still, many found much to commend. "He was very inspirational," said David Britt, 20, of Crystal City, Mo., who watched the speech with 60 members of the Beta Theta Pi fraternity at the University of Missouri in Columbia. "I think everybody is scared by what happened. I think President Bush made everybody feel better."
Merle Gross, 59, a manufacturer of women's clothing, said in Chicago that she agreed with much of what Mr. Bush said but called him a "flawed communicator" who had missed a crucial opportunity. 
"He just doesn't have the passion," she said. "He's just not convincing. I couldn't buy a car from him. The default expression on his face is such an unfortunate one. I hope that I'm not a typical American in my response."
In Santa Monica, Calif., a bastion of liberal politics, even people who had voted for Al Gore said they had found encouragement in the president's speech. Ed Gomez, a bartender at the Broadway Bar and Grill, said he especially liked Mr. Bush's reference to the importance of showing respect for Islam and Arabs.
And Howard Smith, a computer executive from Malibu who was at the bar, said: "This is his best speech because he's talking from his gut. I think he was pretty much right on with the specifics. He's laid out 'Here's what we're going for, here's what we're going to do.' "
At another bar in Rye, N.Y., Lynn Bygott, 33, of Fairfield, Conn., joined in praising Mr. Bush, saying, "I'm very proud to be an American." 
Another patron, Jack Briganti, 40, an accountant from Rye, found the speech admirable. "The look in his eye was very serious," he said, referring to Mr. Bush. "There is a small percentage of America, maybe 20 percent, that does not want us to attack. I, for one, don't want to see innocent people killed."
"But to get our point across, there has to be some bloodshed," Ms. Bygott said.
"Yes, there has to be some," Mr. Briganti said.
Nearby, Jason Morey, 29, a chef, said: "I'm speechless. I thought it was the best thing I've ever heard. It terrified me. It's our generation's turn to stand up for what our country is about. I'm afraid this will be a lot longer and a lot bigger than people think. But it absolutely has to be done."

HEADLINE: Disney Shares Drop 8% On Sale of a Big Block 

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Shares of the Walt Disney Company fell more than 8 percent yesterday as Goldman, Sachs & Company sold 135 million shares, amounting to almost 6.5 percent of the company, at below-market prices.
 Goldman bought the shares from Sid Richardson Bass and Lee Marshall Bass, the Texas investors, to meet a margin call, according to a spokesman for the Basses. 
 Brokerage firms and investment banks often require investors to sell shares to help make up for the value of securities the investor has bought with borrowed money. 
After acquring the shares, Goldman sold them for $15 each. Disney said it bought 50 million of the shares. The buyers of the other 85 million shares were institutional investors, according to Goldman. As of last month, Disney had almost 2.1 billion shares outstanding.
On Monday, Disney sold $1 billion in bonds. It was not clear yesterday whether Disney sold the bonds with knowledge that Goldman would soon be trying to sell a huge block of the company's shares.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange, Disney's shares dropped as low as $15.50 before closing at $16.98, down $1.52. The closing price was the lowest in more than six years.
Disney's stock, like shares of many media companies, has languished this year as the economic climate cooled and as the advertising market retreated from the heights it achieved during the dot-com boom. Disney properties like the ABC television network depend on advertising.
And like the shares of many media companies, Disney's stock has fallen sharply this week as advertisers have retreated further after the terrorist attacks.
Disney is also affected by the decisions of thousands of tourists to cancel their travel plans. Disney runs resorts including Disneyland and Disney's California Adventure in Anaheim and Walt Disney World in Florida. The Walt Disney World resort includes the Magic Kingdom, Epcot, Disney-MGM Studios and Disney's Animal Kingdom park.
On Sept. 10, the day before the attacks, Disney's shares closed at $23.58. Since then, their price has fallen 28 percent.

HEADLINE: Merrill Lynch Names Leader For Brokers 

BYLINE:  By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Merrill Lynch said yesterday that it had named James P. Gorman, a former consultant at McKinsey & Company who moved to the firm in 1999, as head of its brokerage unit. 
 Mr. Gorman's promotion was expected. 
 For more than a year he served as E. Stanley O'Neal's top lieutenant, managing the firm's 15,000 brokers. In July, Mr. O'Neal was named president and chief operating officer. 
"James Gorman has been the No. 2 executive in the U.S. private client business, leading our nationwide advisory force," said David H. Komansky, the company's chief executive, and Mr. O'Neal in a joint statement. "He will continue to provide energetic and visionary leadership in his expanded role." 
With the economy sagging and financial markets shedding billions of dollars in market value since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, Mr. Gorman faces significant challenges as he assumes his new position. 
"The most immediate challenge is this horrible environment," said Richard Strauss, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs. "The things you need to do are so immediate that at this point you are reacting to what is happening. At this point, he will be practicing damage control." 
Mr. Gorman, a native of Melbourne, Australia, said that his goal in the near term was "to provide continued stability and calmness in the wake of last week's tragedy." 
Mr. Gorman is no stranger to Merrill's retail operations, even though he has never sold stock and has been on the firm's payroll for only a little more than two years. 
Before joining the firm, Mr. Gorman spent a decade at McKinsey. His primary client during that period was Merrill Lynch. He said yesterday that 60 percent of his time had been spent advising the firm's retail operations. 
"I have never sold a share of stock," he said, "but I have probably been in more retail offices than almost anyone in the industry." 
Mr. Gorman is not the first executive without a brokerage background to head Merrill's retail operations. Mr. O'Neal was an investment banker at Merrill before he moved to the retail side. 
Mr. Gorman joined Merrill Lynch in July 1999 as executive vice president and chief marketing officer. Since May 2000, when he was tapped to manage the firm's brokers, he and Mr. O'Neal have led a shift toward focusing on wealthy investors. Mr. Gorman was also deeply involved in developing a new pay structure for brokers, which is expected to be introduced in October. 
Mr. Gorman is a graduate of the University of Melbourne, where he earned bachelor's and law degrees, and Columbia University, where he received an M.B.A. He will continue to serve as an executive vice president and a member of Merrill Lynch's executive management committee. 
Merrill's stock price, which has been in a downdraft for much of the year and has been hit hard since the market reopened after the terrorist attacks, fell again yesterday. Its shares closed at $36.01, down $2.49.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE MILITARY CONTRACTORS; 
Beneficiaries of the Military Buildup Await Their Orders

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 

 BODY:
Early last week, Frank C. Lanza, the chief executive of L-3 Communications, an aerospace and communications company in New York, received a not-too-surprising telephone call from military officials.
 "They asked us, 'Can you do the following things, and how long will it take you to do it,' " Mr. Lanza said. "They are in the planning process. And they need to know about our ability to deliver certain products." 
 That planning process is about war: the Pentagon is preparing a shopping list for the global struggle against terrorism promised by President Bush. As a result, scores of military contractors, from giants like Lockheed Martin to smaller companies like L-3, could be among the corporate beneficiaries of the devastating attacks of Sept. 11. 
Even as those assaults have sent the stock market plummeting and caused havoc for much of American business, prospects for the military-industrial complex are looking stronger than they have in years.
Overnight, political opposition in Congress to huge increases in Pentagon spending has vanished, along with concerns about dipping into surplus Social Security funds. Consequently, what had seemed to the industry like a disappointingly small military budget just two weeks ago is now climbing toward unanticipated heights, providing a lift for military contractors and a quick Keynesian stimulus for the economy.
Beyond the buildup for war, winners and losers in the race for Pentagon money will also be determined by the outcome of Secretary of Defense Donald H. Rumsfeld's efforts to transform the military. His goals have included improving intelligence, expanding long-strike capabilities and making the forces lighter, faster and more high-tech. 
But the process has faced stiff resistance from some commanders and lawmakers who fear Mr. Rumsfeld wants to starve programs for modernizing conventional ships, planes and howitzers to nurture untried products, like space planes or remotely piloted submarines.
"The services are going to want to try to use some money to address their modernization needs," said Jacques S. Gansler, an under secretary of defense in the Clinton administration who now teaches public policy at the University of Maryland. "And that's where you get a conundrum over whether to buy a new tank, or equipment you'd like to have for 21st-century warfare against terrorists. You'll have a battle between those two options."
The budget numbers tell the story. Three days after the attack, Congress overwhelmingly approved $40 billion in emergency funds, with $10 billion to $15 billion for the armed services. In the next few weeks, Congress is also expected to approve, with little dissent, a $33 billion increase in the Pentagon budget, raising it to $329 billion for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1.
And before final votes on the 2002 spending plan are even cast, the Pentagon is expected to ask for an additional $15 billion to $25 billion. There is bipartisan support for that, too.
"Capitol Hill is prepared to do whatever the Pentagon wants," said Gordon Adams, a budget official in the Clinton administration who is now director of security policy studies at the Elliot School of International Security Studies at George Washington University.
Much of the initial wave of money will go toward rebuilding the smoldering hole left in the Pentagon by the hijacked airliner, paying for heightened security at military installations worldwide and preparing for retaliatory strikes. That will mean buying new bullets, cruise missiles, boots, reconnaissance equipment and spare parts.
But many analysts and military officials say they expect there to be a significant amount of money left over after those basic needs are met. The service chiefs and senior lawmakers will probably want to spend those funds on favored weapons programs, like Boeing's F-18 E and F fighters, United Defense's Crusader artillery system, and Northrop Grumman and General Dynamic's DD-21 stealth destroyer. It will not matter if those systems are not clearly useful in the war on terrorism, the analysts say.
"There is a heightened sense of danger out there," said Loren Thompson, chief operating officer with the Lexington Institute, a military policy organization based in Arlington, Va.
"There are increased resources," he added. "There is muted partisanship. And those three factors combine to improve the prospects of many defense programs, even those that don't appear immediately relevant to the current operations."
Whether that buying spree lasts will depend on the nature and duration of the military operation Mr. Bush orders. A ground war could help builders of armored equipment, like General Dynamics. A war fought mainly from the air could benefit Lockheed or Boeing. And a totally different kind of battle, where rooting out an elusive enemy will require intelligence and surveillance skills more than sheer firepower, could help companies like Northrop, maker of the Global Hawk, an unmanned reconnaissance aircraft.
Yet the influx of money soon to flow from Capitol Hill seems certain to trickle down to a wide array of military contractors, big and small.
"A rising tide does lift all boats," said John Williams, a spokesman for the National Defense Industrial Association, a trade group representing 900 military contractors.
There will be new purchases of explosion-proof windows and doors for the Pentagon and other military buildings. Spare parts and maintenance contracts will grow as more ships, planes and helicopters undergo the relentless wear-and-tear of overseas deployment. 
Munitions makers can also count on new orders for items like cruise missiles and other kinds of precision-guided weapons. 
Companies like Alliant Techsystems, a munitions maker in Minneapolis, and Boeing, which makes highly accurate gravity bombs and cruise missiles, would be candidates for new orders. And there has been talk among military planners of speeding up a Raytheon contract to refurbish older Tomahawk missiles with Global Positioning Systems for greater accuracy.
That $414 million program to upgrade 644 missiles was started as an emergency contract after the Air Force ran short of Tomahawks during the bombardment of Yugoslavia in 1998 -- an embarrassment the Pentagon wants to avoid repeating.
"The prospects for smart weapons really look favorable," said William J. Frost, vice president for administration for the EDO Corporation, a New York-based company that makes targeting, radar jamming and sonar equipment.
But some Pentagon planners are talking about speeding up production of much bigger items as well, should the struggle be as protracted as Mr. Bush has predicted.
For instance, Mr. Rumsfeld has urged the services to increase the number of reconnaissance planes available for hunting down Osama Bin Laden's terrorist network.
One option would be to accelerate an existing Boeing program for equipping six C-9's with sophisticated surveillance equipment. Boeing has delivered the first four planes at an average cost of $54 million each. Now, the Navy has asked the company if it could expand production. Deena Weiss, a Boeing spokeswoman, said that would not be a problem. 
Some analysts and Navy officials also say that a prolonged battle overseas could require buying more carrier-based aircraft. Boeing is scheduled to deliver 39 of the F-18 E and F fighters in 2002.
"As ever, carriers are useful for a full spectrum of conflict," said Richard Aboulafia, an aerospace analyst with the Teal Group in Fairfax, Va.
The Pentagon is also planning to seek money to speed up a program, led by General Dynamics, to replace the 24 nuclear-tipped missiles on aging Trident submarines with 154 Tomahawk cruise missiles.
If Mr. Rumsfeld has his way in transforming the military, the biggest winners will be companies that build intelligence-gathering equipment, wireless communications systems, precision-guided weapons and missile-defense components. 
"At least on the face of it, you would think that the people who are strongly focused on surveillance and precision weapons would do relatively better," said Wolfgang Demisch, managing director with Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein Securities. 
Indeed, he added, "you could be looking at a significant reduction in available funds for ordinary military affairs and purchases." 
L-3, created out of a division of Loral after that company was purchased by Lockheed Martin, is cited by some analysts as the kind of high-technology company that stands to gain from Mr. Rumsfeld's new vision. It produces equipment that provides security for wireless communications and components for aircraft and airport security systems. The company also makes products that help intelligence officers scan, filter and analyze huge quantities of voice and electronic data.
Mr. Lanza said he was convinced that the impending mobilization, combined with Mr. Rumsfeld's plans, would hasten a realignment of Pentagon budget priorities away from cold war weapons toward the new technology his company produces. 
"Sept. 11 is going to change the landscape for this industry," he said.
National missile defense is another high priority of the Bush administration that seems to have gained political momentum from the terrorist attack, analysts say. 
"There is a clear linkage between terrorism and missile defense," said David E. Baker, a retired Air Force general who is now managing director for the Schwab Washington Research Group. "If these terrorists could get a hold of a missile and put some bad stuff into that nose cone and launch it on Manhattan, they would."
Before Sept. 11, Democrats on Capitol Hill were hoping to trim back President Bush's $8.3 billion first-year missile shield program and place tight restrictions on testing and development. But that opposition has softened, with many Democrats saying they have lost the stomach for a partisan fight -- even as they privately argue that a missile shield could not have prevented the attacks.
Contractors on the program include TRW, which builds satellites; Raytheon, which builds "antimissile kill" vehicles; Lockheed, which makes missiles and communications equipment; and Boeing, which in addition to building booster rockets is the lead contractor on the program. 
Indeed, for Boeing, military business in general has been a silver lining in an otherwise bleak fall. 
Last week, the company's stock price fell sharply in tandem with the airline industry's, and it announced plans for as many as 30,000 layoffs. But its military business, which accounts for about a quarter of its revenue, remains healthy.
"Boeing has taken a thrashing," Mr. Baker said. "But their military sector is pounding away like a Ferrari on all cylinders."
Many military contractors have been hesitant to talk publicly about their improved economic prospects. "This is such a gruesome way to make money," a lobbyist said.
But some companies have been openly lobbying for new business. Indeed, several executives have called the Pentagon directly in the last week to say they were prepared to ramp up production. One was Continental Electronics, a communication equipment company with annual revenue of $26 million. 
"We believe that our radio transmitters would be desperately needed in places like Pakistan," said John Uvodich, the company's president. "We are just trying to let people in Washington know that we are here to assist."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ECONOMICS; 
Already, Grim Statistics for New York Consumer Sales

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON and JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
Tidel Robinson had been thinking for weeks about buying a new DVD player, and now there was one on sale for just $99, down from $150, at the Electronics Outlet in Brooklyn's Fulton Mall.
 But Mr. Robinson, a plumber, had been laid off on Wednesday. Whether it was the World Trade Center collapse or just the weakening economy, he didn't know, but business was slow. "I've got my rent to pay, the bill for my baby at the day care center," Mr. Robinson said. He left the store empty-handed. 
 And so it goes in stores all over the metropolitan area. People are slowly returning to shops to buy what they must: groceries, school supplies, new sneakers for the children. But the big-ticket items -- cars, jewelry, huge-screen televisions -- are moving slowly, if at all.
"We're doing necessary things like fixing watches," said James Yune, who with his wife, Susan, owns Rye Jewelers in Westchester. But his customers, he said, "are not making major purchases."
The direct consequences of the trade center disaster are bad enough, but the drop in consumer sales may prove drastic as well. Economists are forecasting citywide retailing losses of as much as $15 billion, according to Marc Goloven, an economist at J. P. Morgan. "There is significant concern that many small retailers, especially in Lower Manhattan, will be unable to survive," he said.
The problems ripple out from ground zero. Joe Lopane, the manager of Mayer Volkswagen in Larchmont, said that two prospective buyers had changed their minds.
"One was someone who survived the catastrophe, but he worked near the World Trade Center, and no longer has a place to work and he couldn't really be thinking of a car," Mr. Lopane said. He added that the other buyer had requested a transfer back to Tennessee because "he no longer wants to work in New York City."
Mr. Lopane said he really could have used the sales: the dealership sold only nine cars last Saturday, a day when it usually moves 15.
Across the country, consumers who were already shaken by the weakening economy and the plunging stock market seem shell-shocked at the destruction of the trade center and worried about war. As they did while awaiting the onset of the Persian Gulf War, consumers are keeping their wallets closed.
The National Retail Federation, a trade group, forecasts that sales during the quarter ending in December will rise only 2.2 percent, compared with last year; a 4 percent rise had been predicted earlier.
While it is too soon for hard-and-fast figures or accurate predictions, economists agree with anecdotal evidence suggesting that the declines are most severe in and around New York. That fact has not been lost on Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who on his weekly radio program yesterday urged New Yorkers and out-of-towners to fill up the city's empty stores, even if it means buying their Christmas presents early.
Some of what is going on has to do with Wall Street, which was in trouble long before the events of Sept. 11. Most of Wall Street's businesses, including those selling stock for companies that were merging, ground to a halt this year, and the stock market has fallen so far that it is where it was about this time in 1998.
Firms have started to shed employees (the Wall Street head count fell by 1,600 in August alone, according to the New York City comptroller's office). And most analysts expected the layoffs to accelerate unless the market rebounded or the economy picked up steam this month. Neither has happened.
That helps explain why New York consumers' confidence -- their faith in the future and willingness to spend -- has fallen far more sharply than that of the nation as a whole, according to the Siena Research Institute near Albany, which surveys New Yorkers in conjunction with the University of Michigan.
And that was in August; the September figures are certain to be worse, said Douglas Lonnstrom, the director of the institute. "We had a reeling economy, and this tragedy on top of it can't be good," he said. "I think it will be quite a while before we see improvement."
Not every store was empty this week. At CVS in the Garden State Plaza in Paramus, N.J., workers continued to buy "junk food and soft drinks," the assistant manager, Miguel Hernandez, said.
Which is only to be expected, said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Economy.com. Stores that sell the basics at low prices, like Wal-Mart, should do pretty well in the foreseeable future, he said. As for those that sell luxury items: "They're doomed. They're toast."
To be sure, the trade center disaster has prompted some people to splurge. Like Barbara Summers and her husband, Maurice, who last week were at a Potamkin car dealership in Manhattan signing the papers to buy a $35,000 gold Cadillac Escalade they had longed for.
"If you have the money, why not spend it?" asked Mrs. Summers, who fled her office in Lower Manhattan through smoke and ashes after the twin towers were hit by the two airliners. "You might not be able to spend it next month."
George Rios wishes there were more people like Mrs. Summers. A salesman at Potamkin, he works on commission, and the week of Sept. 11 he did not make one sale. "It hurts," he said. "I can't pay my bills."
For the most part, even people who have been spending have been doing so rather reluctantly. Rita Smith of Rye Brook was willing to buy sneakers for her 6-year-old, but she was not planning to make her usual pilgrimage to the Neiman Marcus in White Plains to pick up some fall clothes for herself. She does intend to buy bottled water and other survival items to keep at home.
The drop in sales is hard on clerks, who make some or all of their money from commissions. Three salespeople raced to help a visitor at the Bernini menswear store in the Garden State Plaza this week. Sales have fallen by about 60 percent since Sept. 11, said the manager, Aiden Swedan.
But, she said, she understood why her usual customers -- businessmen looking for suits -- were not shopping. "You don t want to buy," she said, "when people around you are busy crying."

HEADLINE: H.M.O.'s Plan to Drop Medicare, Calling Fees Too Low 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 

 BODY:
Health maintenance organizations serving at least 475,000 elderly and disabled people will pull out of Medicare next year, the trade association for the industry announced today.
 The H.M.O.'s said federal payments were too low to cover their costs. 
 In a separate development, the health insurance program for federal employees and retirees announced that its premiums would soar 13.3 percent next year, the largest increase since the late 1980's.
The federal employee program is the largest employer-sponsored health plan in the United States. It is considered an accurate reflection of what is happening throughout the private health insurance market. 
"Employers all across the nation are looking at the prospect of double-digit premium increases in 2002," said William E. Flynn III, associate director of the federal Office of Personnel Management, who supervises the program for nine million federal workers, retirees and dependents.
The federal employee program is often described as a model for government and private health plans. But still, Mr. Flynn said, the average premium -- $5,880 next year, for subscribers and the federal government together -- will be 50 percent higher than it was in 1998.
The changes in Medicare and the federal employee program all point to a resurgence of health care inflation.
Karen M. Ignagni, president of the American Association of Health Plans, which represents H.M.O.'s, said, "With health care inflation running at 12 percent and Medicare reimbursement capped at an increase of 2 percent, you have a mathematical formula that does not work."
The H.M.O. decisions raise questions about the future of President Bush's policy to revamp Medicare by giving private health plans a much larger role.
In June, Thomas A. Scully, administrator of the Medicare program, said the administration wanted to double the number of Medicare beneficiaries in H.M.O.'s by 2005. In a brief interview today, Mr. Scully said he had no immediate comment on the latest withdrawals.
Today's announcements follow three years of turmoil in the insurance market for Medicare patients. Since January 1999, H.M.O.'s have dropped more than 1.6 million Medicare beneficiaries. About 5.6 million people, or 14 percent of the 40 million beneficiaries, are now in H.M.O.'s.
People dropped from private health plans can return to Medicare's original fee-for-service program or can try to enroll in other managed care plans, if any are available in the area where they live. But the traditional Medicare program does not cover outpatient prescription drugs, as many H.M.O.'s do.
PacifiCare, the biggest Medicare H.M.O., said it was dropping 64,200 of its 1.1 million Medicare beneficiaries in California, Texas, Arizona and several other states. ConnectiCare said it was pulling out of two counties in Connecticut, Hartford and New Haven, where it serves 24,700 Medicare patients. 
Aetna said it was dropping 38 percent of its 277,000 Medicare beneficiaries, including many in New Jersey and Pennsylvania. But it said it would remain in New York City, Philadelphia and some parts of New Jersey, including Bergen, Essex, Hudson and Camden Counties. Medicare payments are higher in some urban areas than in many rural and suburban counties.
Deborah R. Hoyt, a spokeswoman for ConnectiCare, said: "Seniors love our program, and we would have loved to continue offering it. But we can't afford the financial losses anymore."
Several H.M.O.'s remaining in Medicare said they would cut benefits or increase premiums and co-payments charged to Medicare beneficiaries next year.
Harvard Pilgrim Health Care, which serves 37,000 Medicare beneficiaries in Massachusetts, said it would soon begin charging a monthly premium of $60, which is a $25 increase over the current amount of $35.
Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Massachusetts, which runs an H.M.O. for 40,000 Medicare beneficiaries, said its premiums would rise by amounts ranging from $25 to $40 a month. The premiums now range from $110 to $135, depending on where a person lives.
Two House Republicans influential on health care policy, Bill Thomas of California and Nancy L. Johnson of Connecticut, said they would push legislation to encourage H.M.O.'s to enter or stay in Medicare. "Low reimbursements" are a major problem, said Mr. Thomas, the chairman of the Ways and Means Committee.
But Representative Pete Stark of California, the senior Democrat on the panel's health subcommittee, said numerous studies had found that Medicare was already paying H.M.O.'s more than it would spend for the same patients if they were in the traditional fee-for-service program.
"How much will it take to keep H.M.O.'s in Medicare?" Mr. Stark asked in an interview. "We've already given them huge payment increases."
Diane Archer, president of the Medicare Rights Center, a consumer group based in New York City, asked, "How can we justify spending more and more government money on health plans that are serving fewer older and disabled Americans in fewer places?"
Beneficiaries will soon receive detailed information comparing the costs, benefits and other features of health plans available to them in 2002. Medicare officials originally said it would be impossible to mail out such data, but they agreed to do so last week, after a federal district judge ruled that they were in "blatant violation" of federal law.

HEADLINE: Europeans Pledge To Spur Economies 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: LIEGE, Belgium, Sept. 21 

 BODY:
European Union finance ministers are standing by a commitment to balance their budgets in coming years while doing what they can to stimulate the economy.
 "The tragic events in the U.S. have increased the uncertainties and downside risks for global growth," said the ministers and the European Central Bank president, Wim Duisenberg, in a statement released at a meeting here. 
 The prospect of a long slowdown and higher military and security costs are putting added strain on the European governments' budgets. France, Germany and Italy say they will not meet this year's deficit goals.
Growth in the dozen countries that share the euro slowed to its weakest pace in four years in the second quarter. European airlines and insurers have warned that the attacks on the United States will also hurt their earnings.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: HOLLYWOOD; 
Tension and Caution Arise In Entertainment Industry

BYLINE:  By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, Sept. 21 

 BODY:
The line of cars stretched beneath the ornate archway and down the sloping entranceway to the Paramount Pictures lot this afternoon. Studio guards were being more scrupulous than usual about checking those trying to get into the compound.
 At the Warner Brothers lot, up and over the Hollywood sign in Burbank, three gates were closed and the lines into the few remaining access points were long and slow-moving. Studio tours were canceled, and shows scheduled to be taped in coming days before a studio audience will perform to dark, empty seats. 
 At the 20th Century Fox lot just southwest of Beverly Hills, barricades were put into place this morning, forcing motorists to slow down and carve a serpentine path toward the main guard gates. Studio officials warned workers to expect delays getting into work and to plan on staying on the lot through the day. 
The cause of all of this tension was a warning that the Federal Bureau of Investigation had passed along to studio executives on Thursday of an uncorroborated threat that a Hollywood studio might be the target of a bombing attack in retaliation for any strikes by the United States against Afghanistan. 
Bureau officials met with studio executives in Beverly Hills and outlined the threat and what steps might be taken. This was all being done "in an abundance of caution," a statement from the bureau said.
The precautions caused delays, "but everyone seems fine with it," said Jeffrey Godsick, Fox's executive vice president for publicity and promotions. "The feeling is, it's more inconvenient but, you know, it's a good inconvenience."
The waves of apprehension that had first centered on the nation's air transport system are, 10 days after the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, beginning to move into other arenas of public life, including the entertainment industry, which produces the movies and music that many terrorists organizations see as decadent cultural imperialism. The fears are also felt in cultural venues where large groups of people might provide tempting targets.
"The noise level is very high," said Brian Jenkins, a terrorism expert at the RAND Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif.
At Lincoln Center in New York, security officials said that all bags were being checked and that guards were posted at each garage entrance. It is the same at the Art Institute of Chicago, where under a new policy all bags, purses and parcels are being searched at every entrance. 
"We felt it was important for us to do," said Eileen Harakal, a spokeswoman for the museum. 
In Orlando, Fla., guards were checking bags and purses at Walt Disney World's four theme parks, and more uniformed guards and plainclothes officers were inside. "We have stepped up security because of the circumstances," a spokeswoman, Leslie Goodman, said. 
Visitors' bags are being searched at nearby Sea World, too. "If we provide a good level of security, it makes our guests feel safe," said a Sea World spokesman, Nick Gollattscheck.
Shelley Mansholt, assistant vice president for public relations for the MGM-Mirage chain of Las Vegas resorts, said the company had posted extra guards at loading docks. Unattended bags from group travelers now must go through special checks. And everyone at the upcoming Janet Jackson show at the MGM Grand's Garden Arena, or any other shows at the site, will have to pass through metal detectors.
But officials at other entertainment venues -- including many cinema chains and live theaters -- said they were continuing with business as usual for now.
"We really aren't doing anything differently," said Claude Binder, general manager of the Steppenwolf Theater in Chicago. "The most we can seat is 700, if both theaters are full, and that doesn't necessarily present itself as a threat."
Proper caution is probably wise, Mr. Jenkins, the terrorism expert, said, and without knowing the source of the threat to the movie studios, he said there seemed little reason to believe the terrorists responsible for the Sept. 11 attacks were now going to engage in a campaign of bomb threats.
"Most terrorists, and certainly the ones we are confronting today, are not interested in giving warning," he said. "They are interested in killing people."
Most bomb threats, except in countries with large indigenous terrorist movements, tend to come from adolescent pranksters or disgruntled employees, Mr. Jenkins said. 
Such threats, though, almost always increase after major terrorist incidents because "they are an inspiration to a certain category of lunatic," he said.
As news moved through Hollywood on Thursday about the F.B.I. warning, anxiety spread around the offices, soundstages, screening rooms, commissaries and nightspots where the entertainment industry works and gathers. 
"It's like people who had been really tense under the surface now had something to focus their anxiety on," one studio marketing executive said.
Mr. Jenkins said random terror lost its effect very quickly because "there is nothing that anyone can do, so life assumes a curious normality."
He noted that during the London Blitz people continued to go to the movies. 
"Theater went on," Mr. Jenkins said. "Even in the darkest hours of full-scale, ongoing war, people lived their lives, and entertainment was not merely something that people enjoyed. It becomes important. It becomes something they need."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Share Prices Plunge 14% for the Week, Second Worst Ever

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
America's stock markets fell again yesterday, ending one of the worst weeks in their history, as many investors moved their money out of stocks and into less risky assets in the face of a deepening economic slump.
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average posted a 14.3 percent loss, its largest since the Great Depression. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which includes the largest publicly traded American companies, ended Friday just above its low of Aug. 31, 1998, the last time fears of a worldwide recession overwhelmed Wall Street. 
 Both military and economic worries are driving the sell-off, analysts say. President Bush's speech to the nation on Thursday night raised fears that the United States might face a long and difficult conflict, further undercutting corporate and consumer confidence. Page C1. 
The economy, which was sputtering before Sept. 11, has almost certainly entered a recession, possibly a deep one, many economists say. Corporate profits are plunging, and hundreds of thousands of employees in airlines and the travel and tourism industry stand to lose their jobs.
In addition, traders and institutional investors, especially those who work in Lower Manhattan, may be more tired and frightened than other Americans, since the securities industry was one of the chief targets of last week's attack, said Abby Joseph Cohen, chief United States investment strategist for Goldman, Sachs.
"This was an attack on the United States and the business community and the financial markets, and many of us who work down here are feeling it," said Ms. Cohen, whose offices are only a few blocks from the former site of the World Trade Center. "There's a weariness."
The Dow Jones industrial average closed yesterday down 140.40 points, or 1.7 percent, at 8,235.81. The S.& P. 500 fell 18.74 points, or 1.9 percent, to 965.80, and the Nasdaq composite index skidded 47.74 points, or 3.3 percent, to 1,423.19.
For the week, the Dow dropped 1,379.70 points, or 14.3 percent; the S.& P. 500 gave up 126.74 points, or 11.6 percent; and the Nasdaq composite index fell 272.19 points, or 16.1 percent.
The loss for the Dow eclipsed its plunge in October 1987, when the index lost 13.2 percent in one week. But that week included Black Monday in which the Dow lost 22.6 percent.
"There are two consequences to what's happened," said William Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs. "There's a big blow to corporate profits."
In addition, the possibility of a deepening recession and a lengthy military conflict has led investors to sell stocks, in which they can lose their entire investments, and buy bonds and money market accounts, which keep their principal safe, he said. In effect, investors are demanding a bigger premium for the uncertain returns of stocks than for the protections of bonds and other guaranteed investments.
As a result, the prices of short-term Treasury notes, considered among the safest financial assets, have soared since Sept. 11. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, has fallen to 2.86 percent from 3.5 percent before the attack. The yield on the 10-year Treasury note has fallen to 4.69 percent from 4.84 percent before the attack. Swiss francs, considered a haven in uncertain times, have also risen against the dollar and the euro.
A premium for safer investments makes sense, given the possibility of a severe recession, Mr. Dudley said. He urged the government to step in quickly with new spending to help the economy recover from last week's shock. On Thursday, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, said Congress should wait before authorizing more spending.
"If the government doesn't step in, you're probably talking about a long and deep recession," Mr. Dudley said.
Yesterday's action was tumultuous, although the trading systems at the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq stock market held up under the strain. Under pressure from the expiration of many options contracts, stocks plunged in the morning. They recovered quickly when General Electric, the world's biggest company by market value, said that it would meet its profit goals for 2001 and 2002 despite the economic slowdown.
After falling below 8,100, a loss of almost 300 points, at 10 a.m., the Dow industrials soared over the next half-hour into positive territory. But the averages could not hold their gains as selling pressure mounted. The Dow quickly lost almost 200 points and stayed between 8,150 and 8,250 for most of the rest of the day.
While individual investors bought stocks yesterday, their purchases were overwhelmed by sales from institutional investors, according to data from Bloomberg Financial Markets. Big mutual funds may have been selling shares to prepare for possible redemptions by their shareholders, said Michael Strauss, senior economist at Commonfund, which manages $30 billion.
All three indexes are now far below the peaks they set early last year during the heady days of the Internet bubble. The Dow is down 30 percent from its high of 11,722.98, set Jan. 14, 2000; the S.& P. 500 has given back 37 percent from its high of 1,527.46, set March 24, 2000. The Nasdaq has fallen 72 percent from its high of 5,048.62, on March 10, 2000. No major stock index in the United States has dropped as much as the Nasdaq since the Depression.
Now stocks may be close to a bottom, Mr. Strauss said. "As bad as things are right now, we may end up producing a better economy a year from now," with the help of increased government spending and lower interest rates, he said.
In addition, some institutional investors will need to buy stocks early in October to "rebalance" their portfolios, he said. Many institutions try to keep a fixed percentage of their assets in stocks, bonds and cash. For example, a common split might be 60 percent of a portfolio in stocks, 35 percent in bonds and 5 percent in cash. If stock prices fall, stocks will become a smaller percentage of the portfolio. To keep the portfolio in line with its target, an institution will need to sell some bonds and buy stocks.
Most big investors do this rebalancing at the beginning of each quarter. Since the fourth quarter begins Oct. 1, stocks may get a lift then, Mr. Strauss said.
In addition, the Securities and Exchange Commission said yesterday that it would continue to allow companies great freedom to buy back their own shares through next Friday. That move could help prop up prices, although it did not seem to do so this week.
Other professional investors said they believed that the sell-off might be almost over, at least in the short run. Tobias Levkovich, senior equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, said that stocks fell almost 15 percent in the five months from the invasion of Kuwait to the beginning of the gulf war.
"We've done that in a week," he said. "We're near the bottom."
Michael Clark, head stock trader at Credit Suisse First Boston, said the market and its participants ended the week strained to the maximum but relatively upbeat. Credit Suisse First Boston handled four times its normal trading volume yesterday, he said. 
He said he was encouraged that American markets had such an orderly opening, after what he called a meltdown in Europe, and were able to rally at midday.
He added that he would not soon forget how Wall Street had pulled together to get the markets open and keep them running all week. "There was a camaraderie that seldom exists in this place where they tell you that your only friend is your dog."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Dow Posts Its Worst Loss Since the Great Depression
America's stock markets ended one of the worst weeks in their history, as fears of a deepening recession led many investors to move their money out of stocks into less risky assets.
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average posted a 14.3 percent loss, its largest since the Depression. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 140.40 points yesterday, to 8,235.81. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which includes the largest publicly traded companies, ended yesterday just above its low of Aug. 31, 1998, the last time fears of a worldwide recession overwhelmed Wall Street. The S.& P. fell 18.74 points, to 965.80, while the Nasdaq composite index fell 47.74 points, or 3.3 percent, to 1,423.19. Page A1. 

Congress Approves Airline Bailout
Congress passed a $15 billion package to bail out the country's ailing airlines and provide relief to aviation insurers. It also agreed to set up an open-ended federal fund to compensate victims of last week's terrorist attacks. The plan was approved by the Senate, 96-1, and by the House, 356-54, late last night. A1.

Congress provided government-backed liability coverage for the airlines, averting a looming halt to flights provoked by a big cutback in war-related passenger jet insurance following the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington. The decision came after governments in Britain, Germany and other European countries provided similar breathing room. C5.

G.M. in Deal for Control of Daewoo
General Motors announced an agreement to take a controlling interest in the company that will emerge from the bankrupt Daewoo Motors for $400 million. The new company will include two plants in South Korea and two more overseas and is expected to eventually have $5 billion in annual revenue. C2.

Morgan Stanley's Profit Falls Again
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company said its profit fell 43 percent to $705 million and revenue was down 16 percent at $5.27 billion in its third quarter as a prolonged stock slump cut trading commissions and investment banking fees, and extended the Wall Street firm's slide to four consecutive quarters. C3.

Northwest Air Will Cut 10,000 Jobs
Northwest Airlines plans to eliminate 10,000 jobs, raising the number of job cuts at the nation's largest airlines to more than 70,000. Northwest's chief executive, Richard H. Anderson, said the airline had no choice because it cut the number of flights. An official of the flight attendants union accused the airline of trying to create pressure for a bailout package. C5.

G.E. on Track for Profit Growth
General Electric is on track to deliver double-digit earnings growth this year, despite a looming recession and pressure on its insurance and aerospace businesses after last week's terrorist attacks. C2.

Microsoft Delays Release of Xbox
Microsoft, following the pattern that has been set by rivals making new game systems, postponed the North American release of its Xbox to Nov. 15 from Nov. 8. C15.

Japan Discloses Plan for Bad Loans
The Japanese government unveiled its long-awaited program to clean up bad loans, hoping to mollify foreign and domestic critics before Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi flies to Washington on Monday to meet President Bush. In the new plan, the government promised to set up a fund to buy the bad loans, which are estimated at $368 billion, from the banks, but financing plans were sketchy. C2.

More HMO's to Pull Out of Medicare
Health maintenance organizations serving at least 475,000 elderly and disabled people will pull out of Medicare next year because federal payments are too low to cover costs. A8.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: MARKET PLACE; 
Confidence, in the Economy and the U.S., Is the Long-Term Issue

BYLINE:  By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
As the Dow Jones industrial average suffered its worst week since the Great Depression, attention inevitably gravitated toward those who were selling stocks, and why they were doing so. But the far more important issue in the long run will be whether this crisis damages confidence in the American economy and in America itself.
 The biggest sale of the week was a $2 billion block of stock in Walt Disney. That sale was made for the same reason that uncounted other sales were made even though many Americans felt that it was their patriotic duty to support the stock market in the face of terrorism: The seller needed the money, and had no choice. 
 The sale was made by members of the Bass family of Texas, a family that has been viewed as one of the richest in the world. They had borrowed too much money to make investments that had lost value, and they faced margin calls like any other overextended investor.
Other sales no doubt have been made, and will be made in the future, by investors who have lost their jobs and simply need to sell securities to generate cash to live. None of that selling, painful as it may be for the sellers and perhaps for the stock market, reflects a real change in investor sentiment.
The shock of the attacks has almost certainly slowed the economy, and will create a recession if one is not already under way. But easing by the Federal Reserve and spending on reconstruction and defense by the government will stimulate the economy, and the recession will end at some point. Stocks typically begin to rise several months before the end of a recession, and that gives reason to hope that the worst of the stock market fall is behind us.
But after those factors have faded, the more important long-term question for the stock market will remain: Will fundamental attitudes about investments and about the American economy be changed by this disaster and what follows?
"A lot of people have learned over the last 10 or 15 years that the stock market always bounces back," said Stanley Shopkorn, formerly head of equity trading for Salomon Brothers and later a hedge fund manager. He recalled that there was no such confidence back in the mid-1970's, when Wall Street suffered its worst bear market since the Depression.
That was also the last time that all the major economies of the world -- the United States, Europe and Japan -- were in recession at the same time. Japan is in recession now, the United States probably is, and European economies have been slowing and could enter a recession soon.
Then, Mr. Shopkorn recalled, stocks traded for 5 to 10 times estimated annual earnings, valuations that are far below even the depressed valuations of the current bear market. Investors who had flocked to stocks in the late 1960's had become completely disillusioned.
The mid-1970's were also the last time that the future of the United States seemed bleak to many people. Then the entire Western world had been thrown into recession by a surge in oil prices, inflation was rising and many believed that the economic future belonged to the oil producers. Few if any people believed that the American stock market was sure to be an excellent long-term investment. 
In recent years, investors around the world have come to believe that the American economy is the most dynamic in the world and therefore a place they have to invest. It is widely accepted that stocks are virtually sure to go up, at least in the long run.
The really important issue is whether what happens in coming months and years will make people think that America is losing its preeminence and is becoming a relatively risky place to invest. A prolonged, bloody and inconclusive war against terrorism probably would bring lower stock market values even if the economy is growing again. Investors could come to have less confidence in the future of the American economy, and that confidence plays an important role in determining how much money is invested in stocks.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended this week down 14.3 percent. Some of that decline was inevitable, given that world markets had fallen about 5 to 15 percent after the attacks while the American market was closed. But it also reflected both forced sales and sales from people worried that the war being proclaimed in Washington would not be a success. A country that felt invulnerable now wonders if, where, and when the next attack will come.
There have been few comparably bad weeks in the past. Even in the 1987 crash, when the Dow fell 22.7 percent on one day, by the end of the week it had recovered to be off just 13.2 percent for the week.
This is just the third fall of more than 14 percent since the Dow took its present form during World War I. The worst, a decline of 15.5 percent, came in the week ended July 21, 1933. Then the economy was mired in the Great Depression, and a speculative recovery in the market was collapsing. Almost as bad was the week ended May 17, 1940, when the index dropped 14.2 percent. The news then was that the French army was collapsing.
One thing common to both times was a sense that the future of America and the world seemed dim. World economies had collapsed by 1933, and attempts at recovery had failed. In 1940 Adolf Hitler's Germany was triumphant, and it was far from clear that he would ever be stopped.
Those worries proved to be wrong, although in each case it took years to become clear. If the American stock market is to return to the optimism it was demonstrating less than two years ago, it will be necessary for investors to conclude that fears about the long-term success of America are as unfounded now as they were in 1933 and 1940.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-6

Britain Reinstates, Again, Direct Rule in North Ireland
Britain suspended Northern Ireland's three-year-old government and reinstated direct rule from London for the second time in two months, in an effort to forestall yet another crisis over the fulfillment of the 1998 Good Friday peace accord. The decision puts the province's Parliament on hold indefinitely. The first suspension, in August, lasted only one day. A6

Spending for Missile Defense
Senate Democrats backed down on missile defense, agreeing without dissent to restore $1.3 billion in spending authority for developing and testing antimissile systems that they had planned to cut from the Pentagon authorization bill. A3

Mideast Cease-Fire Holds
The cease-fire in Israel clung to life, despite scattered reports of violence and even though Prime Minister Ariel Sharon once again called Yasir Arafat, the Palestinian leader, a terrorist. Despite this characterization, Mr. Sharon said he would allow a meeting between Mr. Arafat and Foreign Minister Shimon Peres if the Palestinians delivered 48 hours without violence. A Sharon aide said a meeting might be held on Sunday. A3

Taiwan Party Ousts Leader
The Nationalist Party of Taiwan expelled Lee Teng-hui, its former chairman and the island's first elected president, after he endorsed a rival party and made increasingly harsh assertions that the current Nationalist leaders were selling out to Beijing. A5

Mad Cow Disease in Japan
A test has shown that a Japanese cow slaughtered in August carried mad cow disease, the Ministry of Agriculture said, confirming the first known case in Asia of the illness, which earlier ravaged Europe's cattle industry. (AP)

Police Storm Prison in Peru
The Peruvian police stormed a maximum-security prison in the Andes, overpowering a group of leftist Shining Path rebel inmates who had seized control of a wing of the building and held it for more than a year, the government said. (Reuters)

World Briefing A6

NATIONAL A7-8

Senior Pentagon Analyst Is Accused of Spying
Federal authorities charged the Pentagon's top intelligence analyst for Cuba with spying for the Cuban government. The analyst, Ana Belen Montes of the Defense Intelligence Agency, the Pentagon's intelligence arm, was accused of providing Havana with highly classified information, including American assessments of Cuban military readiness. Ms. Montes entered no plea when she appeared before a federal magistrate in Washington. A7

H.M.O.'s to Quit Medicare
Health maintenance organizations serving at least 475,000 elderly and disabled people will pull out of Medicare next year, the trade association for the industry announced. The H.M.O.'s said federal payments were too low to cover their costs. In addition, the health insurance program for federal employees and retirees announced that its premiums would soar 13.3 percent next year. A8

Ruling on Nursing Home Layoffs
One of the nation's largest nursing home chains illegally laid off at least 350 employees after a 1996 strike in Pennsylvania, the National Labor Relations Board has ruled. The board said the layoffs at 15 nursing homes operated by the company, Beverly Enterprises of Fort Smith, Ark., stemmed from a "corporate-level union animus." (AP)

Settlement in Murder Case
The assets of a millionaire who paid to have his former wife killed will be given to her six children and other relatives, a district judge in Austin, Tex., has ruled. The ruling was part of an out-of-court settlement in a lawsuit by relatives of the woman, Sheila Bellush, 35, against her former husband, Allen Blackthorne, 46, who is serving two life sentences. (AP)

His comments seemed likely to encourage the effort to seek a suspension of the term-limits law. A10

Schundler, is criticizing New Jersey's response to the World Trade Center attacks and has released his own plan to improve the state's defenses against terrorism. BUSINESS DAY C1-16

Stocks Plummet Again
America's stock markets fell again yesterday, ending one of the worst weeks in their history, as fears of a deepening recession led many investors to move their money out of stocks and into less risky assets. The Standard & Poor's 500 index, which includes the largest publicly traded American companies, ended Friday just above its low of Aug. 31, 1998, the last time fears of a worldwide recession overwhelmed Wall Street. For the week, the Dow dropped 1,379.70 points, or 14.3 percent, its largest drop since the Great Depression; the S.& P. 500 gave up 126.74 points, or 11.6 percent; and the Nasdaq composite index fell 272.19 points, or 16.1 percent. A1

G.M. in Accord on Daewoo
General Motors formally announced an agreement with the creditors of the bankrupt Daewoo Motor Company, of Seoul, that will give G.M. a brand and a substantial manufacturing foothold in Asia at a bargain price. General Motors will pay $400 million for a controlling interest in a new company to rise from Daewoo's ruins. C2

Japan Unveils Bad-Loan Plan
The Japanese government unveiled its long-awaited bad-loan cleanup program, in a campaign intended to mollify foreign and domestic critics before Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi flies to Washington on Monday to meet President Bush. The government promised to set up a fund to buy nonperforming loans from banks, but gave only a few sketchy details about how the fund would be financed. C2

Microsoft Delays Game Console
The Microsoft Corporation, following a pattern of delays and shortfalls by the makers of video game consoles, postponed by one week the North American release of its Xbox game. Some analysts said the delay resulted in part from problems in shipping after last week's terror attacks. C15

HEADLINE: Afghans Can Be Our Allies 

BYLINE:  By Barnett R. Rubin; Barnett R. Rubin is director of studies at the Center on International Cooperation at New York University.

 BODY:
As the United States plans an attack against Osama bin Laden and the Taliban regime that continues to shelter him, we need to recognize that destroying Afghanistan will accomplish nothing. The Soviets, the Islamic militants we once armed, and the Taliban and their Pakistani backers have already done so. About a third of the capital, Kabul, is as ruined as the World Trade Center.
 Ordinary Afghans have already suffered for years from wartime devastation. Increasing the suffering could fuel more terrorism. A successful American operation against terrorism based in Afghanistan would have to help people there establish a legitimate government and rebuild their country. 
 Despite the Taliban decision yesterday not to hand over Mr. bin Laden, the suggestion the day before by the Afghan clerics that he leave the country voluntarily may reveal dissension within the leadership.
After all, Afghans did not join that movement in order to wage war on the United States in defense of foreign terrorists. Rather, they were hoping to address the chaos in their country through the imposition of strict Islamic law. Over time, elements of the Taliban developed close ties to non-Afghan militants, but not all want to destroy Afghanistan on their behalf. A month after the Soviet collapse ended aid to Afghanistan's Communist government, its top military commanders mutinied. Some Taliban commanders may similarly now have their fingers to the wind.
The Taliban's chief sponsor, Pakistan, terrified by the consequences to itself of a possible American attack on Afghanistan, should be using all its resources to induce the Taliban leadership to deliver the wanted men. And we must ensure that our own need to respond to last week's horror does not lead us to take actions that stir up Afghan nationalism that will only bolster the Taliban leadership and the foreign extremists to whom it has given safe harbor.
The United States and its allies must also work with two other focal points of Afghan politics: the United Front, the armed resistance led by Ahmed Shah Massoud until his recent assassination, and exiles working with the former king, Zahir Shah, now in Rome, who are trying to convene a loya jirga, or a traditional Afghan assembly. Together, these two forces combine leaders of all the country's ethnic groups. And individuals within them are trying to work together on Afghanistan's political future.
The United Front's forces are in areas dominated by ethnic minorities, but some now involved with Zahir Shah, including former mujahedeen, might also be able to raise troops, including recruits from the predominant Pashtun ethnic group in whose territory Mr. bin Laden's followers are largely based.
This would require international support. The United States should ask Pakistan to guarantee full freedom of action to Afghan leaders who appear capable of establishing a stable government that will meet minimal international standards. In return, these Afghans should acknowledge Pakistan's concerns by, for instance, settling the two countries' longstanding border dispute. The United States could also accede to Pakistani requests for economic aid and debt relief in exchange for agreeing to these and other conditions, like those relating to American military access.
Simply overthrowing an objectionable government, as the Communists were overthrown in 1992, is not enough. The result then was the anarchy that gave rise to the Taliban and created opportunities for foreign terrorists. This time, the United States and other countries must push for a more stable outcome by planning now for the reconstruction of an Afghanistan governed by legitimate authorities, possibly with the assistance of the United Nations. This would give Afghans a stake they now lack in the global community. It would also allow the new government to secure the country and win the cooperation of local people in rooting out terrorists.
This will take time, but President Bush has said that he intends to win this war against terrorists and those who harbor them, not engage in halfway measures. To do this, he will need Afghan leaders with a sure knowledge of the country and popular support. Historically, those who have invaded Afghanistan have met ignominious ends. Mr. bin Laden and his allies may hope that they can draw the United States into the same trap that devoured the Soviet Union. If we lash out militarily without a political plan for Afghanistan, they could achieve this. But we can frustrate their hopes if we recognize that the Afghan people can be our firmest allies in this fight.

HEADLINE: 43% Decline in Morgan Stanley Earnings 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter & Company reported a 43 percent decline in third-quarter earnings yesterday as a prolonged stock slump cut trading commissions and investment banking fees, and extended the Wall Street firm's slide to four consecutive quarters.
 The firm, which was the largest single tenant in the World Trade Center, said its short-term business outlook turned "decisively negative" after the terror attacks last week. 
 While nearly all of the firm's 3,700 employees at the twin towers escaped without harm, revenue from trading and investment banking activity are likely to slow further, the chief financial officer, Stephen Crawford, said in a conference call. 
"It's been an enormous emotional crunch at a difficult time," Mr. Crawford said. Investors have taken a wait-and-see attitude with their portfolios, but "it's unlikely that they will pick up until there's more clarity on the economic front."
For the quarter ended Aug. 31, Morgan Stanley earned $705 million, or 62 cents a share, down from $1.25 billion, or $1.09 a share, a year earlier.
Excluding a charge of $30 million for paying down debt, earnings were $735 million, or 65 cents a share, in the latest quarter.
Analysts surveyed by Thomson Financial/First Call had forecast earnings of 64 cents a share. Morgan Stanley's stock rose $2.46, to $40.08 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Revenue fell 16 percent, to $5.27 billion from $6.31 billion.
The firm expects the trade tower disaster to cost in the range of $150 million, much of which will be covered by insurance, Mr. Crawford said. Many of the affected employees have been relocated, but sales to individual investors have already fallen 20 percent since the attacks.
Even before the attacks, major Wall Street firms were in a profit slide because of an extended slump in trading activity and in mergers and acquisitions.
Revenue in Morgan Stanley's individual investor division slid 20 percent, to $1.1 billion, as trading activity by individuals remained "sharply below last year's levels," the firm said.
Advisory fees from investment banking slipped 30 percent because of a "sharp decrease" in global merger activity that began last year, and underwriting revenue fell 34 percent as issues of new stock tumbled.

PERSON: Neil D. Levin 

HEADLINE: Neil Levin, Executive Director Of Bistate Port Authority, 46 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WYATT

 BODY:
Neil D. Levin, the executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, the landlord for the World Trade Center complex as well as the operator of the New York City area's three major airports, port facilities, bridges and tunnels, died on Sept. 11 in the collapse of the twin towers.
 He was 46 and lived in Manhattan. 
 Mr. Levin was appointed to the Port Authority leadership in March by Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and Acting Gov. Donald DiFrancesco of New Jersey, who jointly oversee the Port Authority. Previously, Mr. Pataki had named Mr. Levin to the top jobs in the state banking and insurance departments. 
Mr. Levin's office was on the 68th floor of 1 World Trade Center, which was the first tower to be hit by a hijacked airplane and the second to collapse. Mr. Levin's exact location at the time of his death is not known.
Mr. Levin, who grew up in Atlantic Beach, N.Y., received a bachelor's degree in economics from Lafayette College and a master's in business administration from the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University's Graduate School of Business.
After getting a law degree at Hofstra University, Mr. Levin went to work as counsel to the securities subcommittee of the Senate Banking Committee, headed by Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. While there, Mr. Levin helped to draft the Insider Trading Sanctions Act of 1984, which came in reaction to the trading scandals that shook Wall Street in the early 1980's.
Mr. D'Amato and Claudia Cohen, the entertainment reporter who was then his girlfriend, arranged a blind date for Mr. Levin and Christine Ann Ferer, a contributing style correspondent for NBC. They were married in May 1996. In addition to his wife, Mr. Levin is survived by his mother, Gloria, of Atlantic Beach, N.Y.; a brother, Stanley, of Westchester County; and his wife's two daughters from a previous marriage.
In seven years as chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board of New York, Mr. Levin helped oversee the bank's transition from a regulator of financial institutions to a profit-seeking business. The New York office of the bank board offers financing to housing and community development lenders in New York, New Jersey, Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
In 1985, Mr. Levin joined Goldman Sachs & Company; he was promoted to vice president two years later. He assisted federal agencies with investment banking and was an adviser to Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the federal home loan programs. 
In 1994, Mr. Pataki, whose election campaign was supported by Mr. D'Amato, appointed Mr. Levin the state's superintendent of banks. In that position, he had oversight of 4,500 banks, thrifts and other financial institutions within New York State. He also helped oversee the initial stages of the state's inquiry into the actions of Swiss banks during World War II. In 1997, Mr. Pataki appointed Mr. Levin superintendent of the State Insurance Department and head of the Commission on the Recovery of Holocaust Victims' Assets.

HEADLINE: Kuwait Emir in London Hospital For 'Limited' Brain Hemorrhage 

BYLINE:  Agence France-Presse

DATELINE: KUWAIT CITY, Sept. 21 

 BODY:
Kuwait's emir, Sheik Jaber al-Ahmad al-Sabah, was flown to London today for medical treatment after suffering a brain hemorrhage, state television reported.
 Sheik Jaber, 73, had suffered a "limited" brain hemorrhage, state television said, but was "stable" and was being flown to London to complete his medical treatment. 
The report said that the emir was fully conscious and that his condition did not require intensive care. 
 King Fahd of Saudi Arabia sent a separate hospital plane to accompany the emir's flight to London, the kingdom's official SPA news agency reported.
According to the Constitution, the crown prince and prime minister, Sheik Saad al-Abdullah al-Sabah, becomes head of the small, oil-rich state if the emir becomes incapacitated.
Sheik Jaber was hospitalized earlier today and slipped into a semicomatose state, but later regained consciousness, a Kuwaiti political source said.
Sheik Jaber became emir in 1977. He has ruled during Kuwait's worst modern crises -- first an economic crash, then the invasion by Iraq in 1990 -- but even those events could not overshadow his popularity.
The interim leader, Sheik Saad, 71, has headed successive governments since 1978, but has also suffered health problems recently and underwent colon surgery in early 1997.
Since then he has been delegating extensive authority to Sheik Sabah al-Ahmad al-Sabah, the first deputy prime minister and foreign minister. 
Sheik Sabah, who is the emir's brother, is third in the ruling hierarchy and has effectively been running the emirate's day-to-day affairs, particularly since February, when the current cabinet was formed.
The emir's government strongly condemned the attacks last week on the United States, and subsequently put the armed forces on alert. It is linked by a defense pact to the United States, which has around 4,500 troops stationed in the emirate.
