HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
Japan Will Set Up Fund to Purchase Bad Loans From Banks

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 21 

 BODY:
The Japanese government unveiled its long-awaited bad-loan cleanup program today, in a campaign intended to mollify foreign and domestic critics before Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi flies to Washington on Monday to meet President Bush. 
 The official tally of nonperforming loans on the hands of Japanese banks is now put at $368 billion, but many analysts say the true figure is much higher. 
 In the new plan, the government promised to set up a fund to buy those loans from the banks, but gave only a few sketchy details about how the fund would be financed. With an International Monetary Fund auditing team expected to arrive here this fall, the government also promised to monitor bank-loan portfolios more strictly. 
"We wanted to send a message that we are taking aggressive steps in dealing with bad loans," Heizo Takenaka, Japan's economy minister, said today.
Investors seemed unimpressed. The benchmark Nikkei 225-stock index fell 2.3 percent, to close at 9,554.99. Shares of two of Japan's largest banks, Mizuho Holdings and Sumitomo Mitsui Banking, fell nearly 5 percent today, a day after Standard & Poor's lowered its outlook on the long-term ratings of seven major Japanese banks to negative from stable.
"The market needs a stronger message," said Yoshinubu Yamada, a bank analyst for Merrill Lynch Japan, in an interview this evening. "That's why the market went down. The market seems to expect some form of public support."
Hakuo Yanagisawa, the country's chief financial regulator, reiterated the Koizumi government's stance against using tax money to solve the loan problem. "If we use public money to cover losses, it will be tantamount to injecting public funds into banks."
Mistrust of Japan's banks extends from the International Monetary Fund to the corner noodle shop owner in Tokyo. With new rules limiting deposit insurance to $75,000, due to take effect in March, about half of the 4,300 households included in a recent government survey said they had shifted their deposit to a bank they regarded as more creditworthy.
For banks, Japan's falling stock market amounts to more than a vote of no confidence. Another regulatory change will force them to list their stockholdings on their books at whatever they are worth next Friday, when the first half of Japan's fiscal year ends. Since the fiscal year began on April 1, stocks have fallen by about one-third, deeply eroding the banks' capital in a way they can no longer gloss over. Analysts estimate that the banks face booking about $40 billion in losses under the new rule, much of it from "old economy" investments dating back to the 1960's and 1970's.
"I think there is an awareness that the time is over for talk, and the time is now for action," Horst Kohler, managing director of the International Monetary Fund, said on Thursday.
In the short term, action is expected to lead to higher unemployment, as Japan struggles with its fourth recession in a decade. Today, Kobe Steel announced that it would lay off 25 percent of its 14,000 workers over the next 18 months. On Thursday, Mitsubishi Electric doubled its expected job cutbacks to 2,000 workers, and Minolta said it would shut a factory and lay off 2,500 workers, most of them in Japan.
More jobs will undoubtedly be eliminated when the government privatizes six public corporations and the operations of Japan's three largest airports, under a plan announced today. Decisions on whether to sell or shut down seven more government-owned companies, including four construction companies, will be made by the end of the year, the government said.
Referring to the privatizations, regulatory changes and plans to clean up bad loans, Jason Rogers of Barclays Capital Japan said, "These measures do show a genuine intent to confront the problem seriously, but we have to see the actual implementation of it before we get too excited."
After a decade of dragging out the death throes of companies that would be deemed terminal elsewhere, skepticism has become deeply rooted among foreign financial observers here.
Two weeks ago, in the 25th-anniversary edition of The Asian Wall Street Journal, editors took their hand at writing the news for the year 2026. The Japan item started: "In a resolution passed by the Diet in Tokyo on a voice vote, legislators agreed that the recession that began some 35 years ago had become a 'problem.' "

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AIRLINES; 
Toll Mounts As Northwest Plans to Cut 10,000 Jobs

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it would eliminate 10,000 jobs, pushing to more than 70,000 the number of job cuts the nation's largest airlines have announced since the terrorist attacks last week. 
 The Northwest Airlines Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest carrier, disclosed the 19 percent reduction in its 53,000-member work force as Continental, American and several other airlines began sending out layoff notices just days after announcing large-scale cutbacks. 
 Many airlines have reduced their daily flight schedules by about 20 percent as their passenger loads dropped sharply after the terrorist hijackings. 
"This is a very painful decision," said Richard H. Anderson, the chief executive of Northwest. "However, the current operating environment dictates that we reduce our flying schedule significantly."
Delta Air Lines said yesterday that it would also announce job reductions soon. Delta has already said that it was reducing its flight schedule by 15 to 20 percent, indicating it might eliminate 12,000 to 16,000 of its 80,000 workers.
Taken with the announced layoffs, Delta's would bring the total number within the industry close to 100,000.
The large number of layoffs has stunned many airline employees and angered many union leaders.
Pat Friend, president of the Association of Flight Attendants, called the layoffs unnecessary and accused the airlines of trying to create political pressure on Congress to approve a multibillion-dollar bailout package for the industry.
Saying the layoffs were worsening the crisis caused by the terrorist attacks, Ms. Friend said: "The tactics of these airlines are un-American. Their greed and antipathy toward workers are needlessly going to hurt thousands more working families."
Union officials at Northwest said they hoped to minimize the number of layoffs by urging many workers to take voluntary furloughs during which they would receive unemployment insurance and continued health insurance.
In recent days, both American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, and United Airlines have said they would eliminate 20,000 positions each, while Continental said it would cut 12,000 jobs and US Airways, 11,000. Smaller airlines have also said they will layoff workers.
Continental plans to close its flight attendant base in Los Angeles and its 950-employee reservations center in Denver.
Officials at several other airlines said they did not know which cities and regions would be hit hardest by the job reductions, depending in part on which workers take voluntary furloughs and on the geographical distribution of the companies' seniority lists.
Under union contracts at many airlines, the most junior employees are to be laid off first.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ECONOMY; 
Corporations Ask Bush to Move Fast on Offering Stimulus Package

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 

 BODY:
The nation's largest corporations urged President Bush today to act immediately to help the faltering economy, putting pressure on the White House to rethink its plan to wait several weeks before deciding on the need for additional tax cuts and government spending.
 In a letter delivered to the White House, the Business Roundtable, which represents 150 multinational corporations in most major industries, said the terrorist attacks last week threatened what was already a weak economy and that the federal government should respond quickly with a stimulus package. 
 "We believe that the economic stimulus should be broad based, have an immediate impact, stimulate demand and spur both consumer and business spending alike," said the letter, which was signed by the group's chairman, John T. Dillon, the chief executive of the International Paper Company.
"This action should be taken as quickly as possible; quick and decisive action will send a positive signal to both the markets here and abroad," the letter said. 
The group drafted the letter after an hour-and-a-half conference call on Thursday among executives from nearly every part of the economy, like oil and gas, consumer products, railroads, financial services and automobiles. The call took place after it became clear over the last few days that both the administration and Congress had decided, partly at the behest of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, to hold off for a week or two before trying to assess whether the economy needed more help.
Asked about the pressure from the business group for fast action, Kenneth W. Dam, the deputy Treasury secretary, said in an interview that while there had obviously been a shock to the economy, it was by no means clear that emergency action on a stimulus package was necessary.
"Is this an economic problem or a reconstruction problem?" Mr. Dam said. "It's important not to rush to judgment on that."
But other business groups also signaled to the White House today that the economy was in an increasingly perilous state and that it should not delay in acting to reverse the decline in economic activity and confidence.
Among them was the National Association of Manufacturers, which sent the White House a letter proposing a detailed plan of tax cuts for individuals and corporations.
"There's no question but that the overwhelming majority of the business community feels that prompt action is necessary, in part to provide additional stimulus to the economy, but, in addition, to strengthen business and consumer confidence," said Jerry Jasinowski, the manufacturing group's president.
Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee on Thursday that it was too early to know how much damage the economy had sustained in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon and that it was therefore premature to settle on a policy response. Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said at the hearing that the administration had the same view.
But with airlines and other companies laying off tens of thousands of workers and with nearly every industry feeling some aftershock from the attacks, there is growing political pressure on Congress and the White House to take some action.
A survey of its members by the National Association for Business Economics concluded that the economy was now in recession. The survey, released today, said the economists projected growth of 0.2 percent in the current quarter -- 1.2 percentage points lower than in their previous estimate -- followed by a decline in growth of 0.5 percent in the fourth quarter, 2.8 percentage points below their previous projection.
The economists cited "a drop in consumer confidence following the terrorist attacks that will prompt a consumption slowdown."
A survey released today by the Conference Board, a business research group, found that nearly half of Americans thought that the economy was headed toward a recession.
In its letter to Mr. Bush, the Business Roundtable said it was concerned "that the events of last week will further threaten what was already a slowing economy and significantly dampen consumer confidence."
The letter also noted that the weakness in the American economy could feed into, and be worsened by, a global slowdown in economic activity. "A stimulus package quickly implemented would help to shore up the global economy," the letter said.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE DISCOURSE; 
Will Real Life Supplant Desire For Reality TV?

BYLINE:  By ALESSANDRA STANLEY 

 BODY:
It seemed this week as if the World Trade Center disaster, like a plague of Egypt, had stripped off layers of the city's narcissism and venality, leaving grief-stricken, fearful residents cleansed of the era's more frivolous preoccupations.
 Friends e-mailed one another a poem by W. H. Auden that begins: 
PUB-DATE: September 1, 1939
I sit in one of the dives
On Fifty-second Street
Uncertain and afraid 
As the clever hopes expire
Of a low dishonest decade:
Waves of anger and fear
Circulate over the bright
And darkened lands of the earth,
Obsessing our private lives;
The unmentionable odour of death
Offends the September night.
Change seemed inevitable and in some ways even right. 
But was it lasting? For those fortunate enough not to have lost a relative, friend or home in history's worst terrorist attack, a new debate seeped into the city's discourse: are the devotees of surface pleasures merely stunned or forever chastened?
Many asserted that a society obsessed with celebrity and all that glistens would move past its fixation on tabloid articles about Lizzie Grubman and Ben Affleck's doings. There would be no need to manufacture peril with familiar reality shows like "Survivor" and "Fear Factor." The world, and its real dangers, would suffice. David Halberstam, who won a Pulitzer Prize for his reporting on Vietnam, observed on "Charlie Rose" that the binge and self-absorption of contemporary America had reached its limit. Quoting John F. Kennedy, he warned that the country was in for "a long, twilight struggle."
Tom Brokaw, the NBC anchorman whose best-selling book about World War II, "The Greatest Generation," helped spur a nostalgia boom for more heroic times, noted that people who yearn for what he described as "a more authentic experience" should be careful what they wish for. "We are not going to put 18 million men into uniforms or stop making cars to produce tanks," he said. "But there is no question that we have been making whoopee in this country, and that is coming to an end."
Graydon Carter, editor of Vanity Fair, pronounced the age of cynicism over. 
Christopher Buckley, a novelist and magazine editor, said: "It feels like a unique point in history, a cultural circuit breaker. This has had a great detrivializing effect: are we really going to keep talking about what Julia Roberts wore last night on yet another TV awards show?" 
Yet there were signs that the cult of celebrity would not die without a fight. Television has not changed, just adapted. Last night, most networks set aside their regular schedules to simulcast a star-studded benefit for victims of the terrorists called "America: A Tribute to Heroes" that cast Julia Roberts, Tom Cruise and George Clooney in an Academy Awards-style extravaganza refitted to match the mood of a nation in mourning.
"I see that show as my best defense when people say we are not interested in all that celebrity stuff anymore," said Jonathan Wald, executive producer of "Today," on NBC. "Anybody who says they know what the world is going to be like in six months is lying or deluded. I don't think you can say now that we won't ever again care what J-Lo is doing." 
As the nation grieves and the stock market plunges, conspicuous consumption seems tasteless and even reckless. Yet certain reflexes linger. An e-mail message that originated in Los Angeles and quickly found its way to Manhattan proposed a shop-athon to support the victims and the economy. It began: "On Sept. 20-23, in addition to your normal spending, buy one additional item, use one additional service and donate $20 to your favorite charity. I can hear the laughter now ('You want us to help America by shopping?')."
Urging recipients to buy boats, computers or even just a newspaper subscription, the letter explained, "While New York prepares to mourn the World Trade Center victims on Sept. 23, let's give the survivors jobs and a brighter, secure future." 
Fashion Week closed down for a week after the attack, reopening with subdued shows that featured flags and red, white and blue ribbons. But after 10 days of struggling for an "appropriate" mode of expression, many in the industry reverted to fashion world tropes. 
"Designers are always impacted by their environment; how could they not think of this moment as they pick fabrics for next season?" Marylou Luther, editor of the International Fashion Syndicate, told The Associated Press. "If I were a designer, I would be working with NASA and perfecting clothes impervious to anthrax. I'd try to design clothes to solve the problems of our troubled world." 
The character of the "greatest generation" was formed over a decade that spanned the Great Depression and World War II. Can their children change their mores in just 10 days? 
Michael Kinsley, the editor of Slate, suggested that the more apocalyptic harbingers were proof that baby boom narcissism survived intact. "For most of us it's at worst too early to say whether everyday life will be permanently and dramatically altered," Mr. Kinsley wrote in an essay this week. "And there's something self-indulgent about assuming so, just as there was something self-indulgent about the hunger for 'change' in what we now regard as the pre-Sept. 11 Eden."
Human nature certainly did not change overnight.
As in any disaster, a few rats wriggled for position between the victims, volunteers and heroes. Some people looted the ruins of the World Trade Center. Wealthier opportunists raised Manhattan rents. Fearing a public revulsion, the Real Estate Board of New York sent a memo to its members on Sept. 14 reminding owners to "make deals based on market decisions as they were immediately preceding Sept. 11." 
Historians, perhaps understandably, preferred not to rush to judgment. 
"I am skeptical that this is a great rupture in the fabric of history," said Alan Brinkley, a professor of American history at Columbia University. "I think we have been overstating the long-term impact. A lot depends on what the international repercussions are. But a year from now, some things may be different, but we will not be in a different world. Right now, the terrorist attack was so traumatic it is hard to imagine that anything could be the same again. But bad economic times, which were coming anyway, will affect the character of our culture more than the disaster." 
Not everyone found solace in thinking that at least the worst excesses of the age were eliminated. 
"I think it's especially funny that the editors of Vanity Fair have become the new imams, spouting moral seriousness and declaring that all frivolity must come to an end," said Mark Horowitz, an editor at New York magazine. "If tourism, real estate and finance in New York collapse, then people will really be earnest and serious. If we lose our frivolity, that really is a victory for terrorists."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE APPOINTEE -- Man in the News; 
Rising Star in Crucial Job -- Tom Ridge

BYLINE:  By SARA RIMER 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Sept. 21 

 BODY:
Hours after United Airlines Flight 93 went down in southwestern Pennsylvania on Sept. 11, killing all 44 people aboard, Gov. Tom Ridge was at the crash site.
 Mr. Ridge, a Vietnam veteran, said there were no words to describe what he had seen, and asked Pennsylvanians for their prayers. Though he was visibly shaken, his voice was calm, his manner reassuring. 
 Returning to the area on Monday for a memorial service for the victims, he told family members that their loved ones had died heroes, and that their reported attempts to overpower their hijackers should inspire Americans to "be empowered, not helpless, in the face of evil."
Four days later, he is living out his words. Mr. Ridge, 56, was in Washington on Thursday when President Bush, in his address to a joint meeting of Congress, named him to a new cabinet-level post: director of the Office of Homeland Security, where he will coordinate the efforts of more than 40 federal agencies to prevent terrorist activities.
Back in Philadelphia, one of the most Democratic cities in the nation, fans at a Flyers hockey game watched Mr. Bush's speech on huge TV screens and erupted in cheers for the Republican governor.
Tom Ridge's moment has arrived. Last year, Mr. Ridge, a rising star in the Republican Party, was said to be Mr. Bush's choice of running mate, a selection that some people said was dropped because of Mr. Ridge's moderate position on abortion.
Now, instead of serving out his term until January 2003 and returning to private life, he will resign on Oct. 5 and head to Washington.
"This is the culmination of 22 years of friendship," said Al Neri, editor of the Pennsylvania Report, a political newsletter. "Bush is looking for someone he trusts. He's been looking for a high spot to put Tom Ridge in.
"He couldn't put him on the vice president ticket because of his position on abortion. He didn't give him secretary of defense because there was commotion from Cheney and Falwell. This time, the atmosphere was correct." 
Mr. Ridge's press secretary said the governor would not speak to reporters today. 
Republicans and Democrats alike heaped praise on Mr. Ridge. Senator John McCain, Republican of Arizona, a longtime friend of Mr. Ridge, called him "one of the most admirable men I've ever known."
Senator McCain and others said Mr. Ridge's experience as a successful governor of a large state, former prosecutor and Army veteran -- as well as his close relationship to the president -- made him well-suited for a difficult job.
"Tom has great personal skills," said Ed Rendell, a former Democratic national chairman who as mayor of Philadelphia worked with Mr. Ridge. "This position will intrude on the F.B.I., the C.I.A., the Justice Department. You're going to have to get all these agencies on the same page, without turf wars. Tom can get everyone pulling on the same oar."
Still, he said, the new post is fraught with hazard for Mr. Ridge.
"These groups don't have a history of working together all that well," Mr. Rendell noted. "You turn away 28 threats out of 30 from terrorist groups, and if two get through, you're going to get blamed for it."
The governor took the job, he said, "because of his personal relationship with the president and because Tom Ridge is a true patriot."
Mr. Ridge, the son of a meat salesman, grew up in a housing project in Erie, and went to Harvard University on a scholarship. After a year at Dickinson Law School, he was an Army staff sergeant in Vietnam, where he won the Bronze Star. He finished law school, returned to Erie and practiced law. He and his wife, Michele, have a daughter and son: Lesley, 15, and Tommy, 14.
Mr. Ridge's friendship with the Bushes dates to 1980, when he was an assistant district attorney in Erie County and became involved in the presidential campaign of the elder George Bush. It was then he met the younger Mr. Bush. Two years later, when Mr. Ridge ran for the House, a race he was expected to lose in heavily Democratic Erie County, then-Vice President Bush campaigned for him. Mr. Ridge won by 729 votes.
In 1993, Mr. Ridge ran for governor. Campaigning on a tough-on-crime platform, he won a closely contested, three-way race. He was re-elected by a landslide in 1998.
As governor, Mr. Ridge has cut taxes and cut regulations in an effort to help create a pro-business climate. He has tried to replace the state's faded industrial base with high-technology jobs, meeting with moderate success, Mr. Neri said.
Following Gov. John Engler in Michigan, and Gov. Tommy G. Thompson in Wisconsin, Mr. Ridge revised Pennsylvania welfare laws. He has also tried to reform public education, with efforts like teacher accountability and what critics call "back-door vouchers" -- tax credits to businesses that donate money for private-school scholarships.
"He's had two things most governors have never had -- hundreds of millions of surpluses every year, which he's inherited, and a good economy," said Terry Madonna, a political scientist at Millersville University in Lancaster. "He's been able to spend money, expand programs, raise no taxes, cut no programs, lay off no employees."
Mr. Ridge has also enjoyed seven years of Republican control of both houses of the State Legislature.
"He's never had to negotiate with the Democrats," Mr. Madonna said. "Where are the blood-and-guts decisions? He hasn't had to make those. That doesn't mean he can't make them."
At the time of the attacks, the governor was in Erie. Returning to Harrisburg, the state capital, Mr. Ridge entered a meeting of state officials already underway at the emergency operations center.
"There was confusion and anxiety," recalled Martin Horn, Pennsylvania's secretary of administration. "He walked into the room and imposed order on chaos."
"He set priorities," Mr. Horn added. "The priorities were to deal with the plane crash, to get search and rescue personnel to the scene, to provide immediate rescue to anyone who might have survived, and to assist the feds.
"He was insistent that the facts be reported," Mr. Horn said. "He said, 'We have to be strong, we have to be reasonable, we have to not create panic.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania will resign on Oct. 5. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE BAILOUT; 
AN AIRLINE BAILOUT

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ with STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 

 BODY:
Congress overwhelmingly passed a $15 billion package today to bail out the ailing airlines and agreed to set up an open-ended federal fund to compensate victims of last week's terrorist attacks. The plan passed by a vote of 96 to 1 in the Senate and by 356 to 54 in the House.
 The plan now goes to President Bush, who strongly supports the bailout. 
 Sponsors described the legislation, which also provides relief to aviation insurers, as crucial to the health of the nation's transportation system. 
"If we hadn't passed this package today, by Wednesday of next week, because of insurance questions and liability questions, a number of airlines would have had a number of their airplanes firmly on the ground," said Representative Roy Blunt, the Missouri Republican who helped write the legislation. "And they would have never gone up again." 
In establishing a victim compensation fund, the legislation sets no limits on the amount of money a victim can receive in economic damages and pain and suffering. Lawmakers said today that they had no idea how much the provision could ultimately cost, but with the death toll presumed to be in the thousands insurance experts said claims could easily rise to $18 billion. 
The fund is intended to protect the airlines from liability for damages and deaths on the ground, something airline executives and their lobbyists said was crucial to their financial well-being. It also tries to address the needs of victims. Victims and their families will have a choice of suing United Airlines and American Airlines, whose planes were hijacked, but they could avoid years of litigation by instead seeking compensation from the fund. No punitive damages would be paid from the fund. Lawsuits would be consolidated in Manhattan federal court.
Under the bill, an official appointed by the attorney general would handle the victims' cases and determine awards. If those figures exceeded benefits collected from other sources, including life insurance policies and relief funds, the government would pay the difference.
The government would later try to recoup some of its costs from the airlines' insurers, though it is unclear how much pressure the government would put on the insurers. Each of the two airplanes that crashed into the World Trade Center in New York carried $1.5 billion in liability insurance. The airlines, and their insurers, would still be fully liable for claims by survivors of the passengers aboard the hijacked jets. 
The president of the Association of American Trial Lawyers, Leo V. Boil, said the group, with 60,000 members, would provide free legal services to victims who go before the special master, a step likely to ease some lawmakers' concerns about lawyers profiting from the tragedy.
James P. Kreindler, a lawyer in the New York firm of Kreindler & Kreindler, which has been retained by some survivors, said the legislation gives wide latitude to both the Justice Department and the special master to devise a fair compensation plan. "This will be as good as the people who are appointed," he said.
Besides giving airlines cover on the liability issue, the bill also offers them $5 billion in cash for their immediate losses and $10 billion in loan guarantees to help persuade the capital markets to lend them money -- the money is not allocated over any specific time period.
A four-member board would be charged with overseeing the distribution of the loan guarantees. The board would be led by Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, or his representative, and would include Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill, Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta and the comptroller general.
The government would be permitted to share in a carrier's future profits through warrants, stocks or stock options.
With aviation insurers demanding big premium increases to continue providing liability coverage -- without which planes might be grounded -- the bill allows the federal government to reimburse air carriers for their higher insurance costs. It also shifts to the government responsibility for insuring carriers against terrorism for 180 days.
During the afternoon, senior executives from the insurance industry met with President Bush to warn him that they may need more government assistance if there are further attacks.
"The federal government has to backstop the impact on the industry arising out of terrorist activities," Maurice Greenberg, the chairman of American International Group, told reporters after the meeting. A.I.G. is a major aviation insurer and owns a leading aircraft leasing company.
Beyond the action today on Capitol Hill, President Bush said he planned to steer $3 billion of the $40 billion that Congress earlier provided in emergency funds after the terror attacks to increase airline security, including placing federal marshals on airplanes. 
The House and Senate are expected to act next week on legislation to deal with aviation security, which is also critical in persuading Americans to fly again. Many airlines are flying at about 30 percent capacity.
Neither Republicans nor Democrats were satisfied with the consensus bill, but Congressional leaders agreed that legislation needed to move quickly to offset airline losses.
Organized labor officials said the bill favored industry over workers and called it unconscionable that not a dime of the $15 billion would help laid-off employees. Many Democrats agreed and sought assurances that workers would not be forgotten in the weeks to come.
"Members of Congress appear poised to stiff airline industry workers in the bailout bill -- even as they award protections to airline executives for their golden parachutes," said John J. Sweeney, president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. 
The bill says that airline executives who make more than $300,000 may not make more money this year and next than they did last year. Plus, their severance pay cannot be larger than two years of salary.
Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader from South Dakota, and the House Speaker, J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois, said the House and the Senate would address concerns about displaced workers, perhaps as early as next week.
Some Republicans, meanwhile, expressed concern that the victim relief fund could cost the government untold sums, arguing that the liability issue should have been dealt with at a later date.
But, with Congress committed to working in a bipartisan way, most lawmakers were willing to set aside their differences and move forward with the bill.
"It's a mixed bag," said Senator Charles E. Schumer, a New York Democrat, who sought to include money for Amtrak and displaced workers in the package. "So if it's a mixed bag why am I up here supporting this bill? Because I think we're in a new era where everyone has to give a little bit. We are unified. We must keep that unity."
Some lawmakers from both parties called the bill too generous to the airline industry, saying it extends aid beyond their immediate and future losses and fails to take into account their precarious financial positions before the attacks.

CORRECTION-DATE: September 25, 2001

 CORRECTION:
A front-page article on Saturday about Congressional passage of a package to bail out the airlines and an agreement to set up a federal fund for victims misspelled the surname of the president of the Association of American Trial Lawyers, which offered free legal services to victims. He is Leo V. Boyle, not Boil.

GRAPHIC: Chart: "Picking Up the Tab"The House and Senate are voting on a bill to help the airline industry recover from the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. Provisions of the legislation include: $5 billion in cash and $10 billion in loan guarantees for the airlines. The $10 billion in loan guarantees will be distributed by a panel including Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, and two Cabinet secretaries. A special government compensation fund for victims or survivors of the attacks. The fund will be overseen by an appointee of the Justice Department. Applicants could file claims to the fund in lieu of seeking compensation from the airlines in court. Airlines' liability for the attacks will be limited to their insurance coverage. The government will assume all liabilities beyond that, as well as liability for any other attack in the next 180 days. In addition, $3 billion from the recently passed $40 billion emergency spending package will be used to help airlines meet stricter security standards instituted after the attacks. (pg. C5)

HEADLINE: World Business Briefing Europe: France: Havas Quits Bid 

BYLINE:  By Suzanne Kapner (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Havas Advertising said it would not pursue a $620 million offer for the Tempus Group, blaming a weakening economy and the attacks against the United States. 
That leaves the WPP Group the sole bidder for Tempus, the British media buyer. "To make a higher bid would be unreasonable in an environment which is getting worse by the day," Alain de Pouzilhac, chief executive of Havas, said. WPP needs approval of at least 90 percent of Tempus shareholders by Oct. 1. Suzanne Kapner (NYT)

HEADLINE: Abroad at Home; 
'To Thine Own Self Be True'

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY LEWIS 

 BODY:
"I ask you to uphold the values of America," President Bush said to Congress and the nation. That will be a fair test of his policy for dealing with terrorism as the policy unfolds: Does it uphold the values of America?
 Our government's actions both external and internal should be judged by that standard. Will any military action we take be measured and precise, in keeping with a concern for innocent civilians, or will anger and frustration lead to broader, less discriminating attacks? In attempting to root out terrorists within our borders, will we have a decent respect for privacy and due process of law? 
 Not only humanity and our fealty to law call for attention to those concerns. We have urgent reasons of self-interest to make sure that our struggle against terrorism sticks to American values.
Take the external first. The great danger here is that military attacks of too sweeping a character -- by the heavy U.S. bombers already sent to the Middle East, for example -- would play into the hands of the terrorists and their presumed leader, Osama bin Laden.
A noted military scholar, Sir Michael Howard, former Regius Professor of Modern History at Oxford, made the point compellingly in The Times of London a week ago. Tracing examples of terrorism over the last 130 years, he said one of the terrorists' principal aims has always been "to provoke . . . savage acts of suppression" that win sympathy for their cause.
Sir Michael said President Bush must be under heavy pressure "to respond in kind, and reply to terror with terror. . . . But were he to do so, he would only multiply the number of the enemies of the United States throughout the world. . . . The strategy of provocation would have won, and Mr. Bush would be playing out the script written for him by the terrorists themselves."
The New York Times reported the other day, in an important story by Patrick E. Tyler and Elaine Sciolino, that the Bush administration was divided on how sweeping the military response to the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington should be. Secretary of State Colin Powell was for a measured response, probably targeting Mr. bin Laden in Afghanistan. A faction led by Deputy Secretary of Defense Paul D. Wolfowitz wanted to attack Iraq as well.
An attack on Iraq would be intended to remove Saddam Hussein from power. (Right-wing voices on television have been urging just that, blaming President Bill Clinton for the fact that Saddam is still there. But of course it was the first President Bush who failed to remove Saddam at the end of the gulf war.) 
When George H. W. Bush decided not to move against Saddam, the gulf war coalition had 500,000 ground troops on the scene. The idea of undertaking such an effort now seems to me close to lunacy -- not only on military grounds but because it would arouse an Islamic backlash menacing to the governments of Pakistan, Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Jordan. 
In his speech to Congress President Bush did not lay out the scope of planned retaliation. He made forcefully clear that there would be military action, as there must be. But he also, wisely, spoke of financial and other steps against the terrorists. And he eschewed his earlier gun smoke rhetoric.
On internal issues, too, the president left the hard questions unanswered. He said law enforcement must have "the additional tools it needs to track down terror." But what tools? Proposals by Attorney General John Ashcroft for greater government powers of surveillance and detention have raised alarms among both liberals and conservatives. If Congress acts without real consideration and care, it could undermine the very quality of freedom under law that most of the world admires.
Americans, we passionately believe, are a humane people. We showed that in restoring wounded economies abroad after World War II, even those of our enemies, Germany and Japan. In due course I think we must make an effort of similar scale to relieve the poverty and misery that are seedbeds for terror in the Middle East.
But right now we need to make sure that we do not forget ourselves in our immediate response to the terrorists' criminal assault. President Bush used three words repeatedly in his speech: "freedom," "patience," "justice." They are the right words.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: COOPERATION; 
U.S. Sanctions On Islamabad Will Be Lifted

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 21 

 BODY:
The Bush administration moved today to reward Pakistan, its new partner in the war on terrorism, while European allies signaled their support by endorsing an American military response to the attacks on New York and Washington. 
 The administration told Congress today that it would soon waive economic sanctions against Pakistan and India that were imposed after they tested nuclear weapons in 1998. 
 Officials said the action was a reward for Pakistan's willingness to provide intelligence and logistical support for an American military response to the attacks.
The sanctions, which bar economic and military assistance to Pakistan and India, could be waived as soon as next week, a senior administration official said. 
The administration announced its decision as countries around the world rallied to President Bush's appeal to join the United States in the fight against terrorism.
At a special meeting of the 15-nation European Union in Brussels, leaders endorsed "an American riposte" to the attacks and approved proposals for Europe-wide arrest warrants and stronger laws against money laundering.
Suspects linked to the attacks were detained in Britain, and Germany issued arrest warrants for two others. Page B4. 
The European Union leaders issued a declaration saying: "An American riposte is legitimate. According to their respective means, the member states of the Union are ready to commit themselves to such action." 
Belgium's prime minister, Guy Verhofstadt, said European states were now prepared to join military actions "against states harboring or supporting terrorists."
Such military action became more likely -- and perhaps more imminent -- after the Taliban, the militant Islamic rulers of Afghanistan, today rejected any possibility of delivering the prime suspect, Osama bin Laden, a Saudi fugitive with bases in Afghanistan. 
The administration also gained support from China today. Mr. Bush met with China's foreign minister, Tang Jiaxuan, who "reiterated his determination to fight terrorism," said Sean McCormack, a White House spokesman. Mr. Tang told Secretary of State Colin L. Powell earlier in the day that China would share intelligence on terrorist groups.
Next week Prime Minister Jean Chretien of Canada and Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan are to meet with President Bush at the White House. 
Before the terrorist attacks last week, the administration was enthusiastically planning to waive sanctions against India. But it was hesitant about lightening the penalties against Pakistan. That hesitancy changed after the Pakistani leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, yielded to Washington's demands to allow his country to become a base for attacks against the prime terrorist suspect, Osama bin Laden, and the Taliban government in Afghanistan. 
In another show of support, Senator Joseph R. Biden Jr., chairman of the Foreign Relations Committee, who had opposed the waiving of the sanctions against Pakistan, changed his mind after Pakistan said it would support the antiterrorist campaign. 
Pakistani officials have indicated that they had no problem with sanctions being waived against its archenemy India. Before the terrorist attacks, Pakistan was concerned that the administration might move to lift sanctions against India. 
The administration was also discussing a large American aid package for Pakistan, a senior official said. "We're looking at a big number," the official said. "How much in cash and how much in debt relief is still being debated." The Office of Management and Budget had yet to make decisions on the size of the financial aid, the official said. 
On the sanctions issue, the under secretary of state for political affairs, Marc Grossman, informed congressional leaders that the administration wanted to exercise its right to waive the trade curbs. He found little opposition to the idea, which had been common knowledge for some days.
Indeed, a senior administration official said many members feared that General Musharraf's regime would collapse because of the opposition by radical Islamic leaders to the new alliance with the United States. 
At the moment General Musharraf seems to have his people's support. Pro-Taliban rallies have been routine and mostly mild. But whether that support would last if American bombs hit Afghanistan, a Muslim neighbor, remains to be seen. "There was a widespread feeling on the Hill that if Pakistan supports us, we should support them," the official said. 
The sentiment contrasts sharply to attitudes during the Clinton administration when the State Department vigorously opposed waiving sanctions against either Pakistan or India because they both possessed nuclear weapons. 
The crucial measure to be waived is known as the Glenn amendment, named after former Senator John Glenn, Democrat of Ohio, who pushed the law through after the tit-for-tat nuclear tests by India and then Pakistan in 1998. The amendment limits the ability of the United States to provide assistance. 
United States military assistance to Pakistan was already barred under a 1990 amendment proposed by former Senator Larry Pressler, Republican of North Dakota, in an attempt to stop Pakistan acquiring nuclear know-how. An earlier 1978 sanction, named after Senator Stuart Symington, Democrat of Missouri, was also aimed at preventing the ability of Pakistan to develop nuclear weapons. Both these earlier sanctions would be waived as well, an administration official said.
The quick moves to waive the sanctions coincided with plans announced this week by the International Monetary Fund to go ahead with a sizable loan for Pakistan. 
Successive governments in Pakistan, plagued by corruption, have had trouble meeting economic and financial goals set by the I.M.F. But the managing director of the agency, Horst Kohler, said this week that under a new finance minister, Pakistan had started to perform better. 
In Brussels, the mood among European leaders was resolute. The leaders backed proposals ranging from tougher law enforcement to more stringent financial laws, measures they had rebuffed or dithered about in the past. If the proposals are adopted, judges in Europe would be able to issue arrest and search warrants enforceable across the continent. Extradition procedures would be eliminated. 
All 15 nations of the European Union would adopt the same definition of "terrorist crimes" and assign them higher priorities. The proposal envisions a Europe-wide agreement on prison sentences, with life sentences the maximum. The death penalty is outlawed in the 15 countries. 
If the proposals all pass, a prosecutor in Italy, for example, could swear out a warrant for a British citizen and hand it over to the British police, ordering them to make the arrest and immediately bring the suspect before an Italian judge.
Currently, the Italian prosecutor would have to explain his case to a British prosecutor, confirm that British and Italian law match closely enough to make the act a crime in both countries, wait for a British prosecutor to get a warrant from a British court and make the arrest, and then file an extradition request. 
The changes will be incorporated in a detailed bill to be presented to a conference of European Union justice and home affairs ministers scheduled for Dec. 6. If the proposal passes then, all 15 member countries would try to bring their laws into line.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, left, with Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy at a European Union meeting in Brussels yesterday. (Agence France-Presse)(pg. B2)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: VOICES OF OPPOSITION; 
In Europe, Some Critics Say the Attacks Stemmed From American Failings

BYLINE:  By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: BERLIN, Sept. 21 

 BODY:
The killing of thousands in the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington last week has prompted great unity of purpose in the United States, cemented by shared outrage. President Bush has called on the world to unite against barbarism.
 While Europeans have expressed enormous sympathy and solidarity, often in emotional ways, they have also been divided in their responses. A debate has begun over whether the inconsistencies of American foreign policy, and the sheer weight of American dominance in the world, mean that resentment of the United States -- even, in extreme cases, hatred -- are inevitable. 
 There was no rejoicing or support in Europe for the killing of so many Americans. Many Europeans wept and the continent fell silent for a moment last week in remembrance of the dead.
But it has also become clear that some Europeans feel that ordinary Americans have largely floated on a tide of prosperity, triumphalism and indifference to the world since the collapse of the Soviet Union. Their view is that the United States has now been confronted with a sobering reality, and that it must try to understand. For those critics, Americans are now facing unsurprising retaliation from an important part of the Islamic world that considers America to have declared war on its faith.
The arguments are sometimes simple -- America should expect war in return for bombing Iraq regularly. Some Europeans also contend that many Americans have a blinding confidence in their own goodness and so do not see that the acts of the United States are regarded in many quarters as driven by the domineering pursuit of national self-interest.
European writers and intellectuals have pointed to a catalog of actions that include the bombing -- in reprisal for the terrorist bombings of two American Embassies in East Africa in 1998 -- of one of Sudan's two pharmaceutical factories on the challenged grounds that it was linked to Osama bin Laden, aid to Israel to buy weapons used against Palestinians, or even the American refusal to intervene to stop the mass killings in Rwanda.
Matthew Parris, a former Conservative Party member of the British Parliament, wrote in The Times of London, "The bigger they come, the harder they fall."
Disgusted by calls for quick revenge, Mr. Parris wrote: "Do they think a terrorist is like a pin in a bowling alley: one down, nine to go? Do they want to give Osama bin Laden his own Bloody Sunday? Do they not know that when you kill one bin Laden you sow 20 more? Playing the world's policeman is not the answer to that catastrophe in New York. Playing the world's policeman is what led to it."
Dario Fo, the Italian playwright and satirist who won the Nobel Prize for literature in 1997, said bluntly in a widely circulated e-mail: "The great speculators wallow in an economy that every year kills tens of millions of people with poverty -- so what is 20,000 dead in New York? Regardless of who carried out the massacre, this violence is the legitimate daughter of the culture of violence, hunger and inhumane exploitation."
There have been other voices that pointed to Mr. bin Laden's various enemies: not just the United States but also the autocratic Islamic governments that Washington supports, like Saudi Arabia, Egypt and Kuwait.
The Observer newspaper wrote: "America needs to recognize that, all too often, it poses as a champion of democracy while supporting regimes, such as that in Saudi Arabia, which have no proper respect for democracy."
Tariq Ali, a leftist British commentator, wrote that America was now about to wage war on Afghanistan, a country ruled by a religious movement, the Taliban, only as a result of Washington's proxy war against the Soviets.
Mr. bin Laden himself joined in that proxy battle, and became a hero partly because of that war.
"The underlying maxim is, 'we will punish the crimes of our enemies and reward the crimes of our friends,' " Mr. Ali said.
In an editorial, Le Monde wrote that America is also unreliable in the sense of appearing inconstant in its choice of allies. The United States, it noted, refused to help Ahmed Shah Massoud, the leader of anti-Taliban forces who died last weekend from injuries suffered in an assassination attempt. Yet it considers Saudi Arabia an ally, although that "is where the financial support of the Islamic radicals comes from."
Even in Germany, one of Europe's most pro-American countries, there was concern that NATO allies had somehow handed Washington a blank check. Die Zeit commented that, "The defender against terror must not act like a furious giant," adding: "The fear of U.S. hegemony is as deep-seated as the anti-American sentiment that bubbled up predictably after Bush came to power."
Anti-Americanism is almost a reflex reaction among some left-of-center French intellectuals, and there has been a predictable outpouring.
To the cry that "we are all Americans now," Marie-Jose Mondzain, director of the prestigious French National Center for Scientific Research, writing in Le Monde, retorted: "I don't feel at all American, but to the contrary feel redoubled in me all the reasons to condemn a world that sings along with a catastrophic president, who defends the death penalty and who has only disdain for the Middle East."
Such anti-Americanism is rare in Germany. But the composer Karlheinz Stockhausen, 73, called the attack on the World Trade Center "the greatest work of art imaginable for the whole cosmos," impressive for the imagination of the act and the precision of its execution.
His commentary was regarded with horror by a nation that has reached out to Americans with sympathy and support, and Mr. Stockhausen apologized, saying that his allegorical remarks had been misunderstood.

HEADLINE: Americans Don't Understand That Their Heritage Is Itself a Threat 

BYLINE:  By Caleb Carr; Caleb Carr, a novelist and historian, is a contributing editor of "MHQ: The Quarterly Journal of Military History."

 BODY:
We have heard a great deal of talk to the effect that the world will never be the same after the attacks of Sept. 11, that we are living in a new reality, and in one sense this is true. But this is not the first great and violent historical turning point that the United States has faced. In other words, to put it as Lewis Carroll's Mad Hatter might have, we have been in this new world before. 
 America experienced just such a prolonged moment during our own Civil War, when not only armies but also civilians were slaughtered in horrifying numbers because of a long-brewing clash between a dying, slavery-based agrarian society and a vigorous, newly industrial modern state. We weathered another during the days and years following Pearl Harbor, when the majority of Americans had no idea if or where Japanese planes might strike again and were later forced (as we have lately been) to reckon with enemies who were willing to engage in suicidal attacks to achieve their purpose. 
 Yet perhaps the most immediately pertinent of such precedents is offered by a much earlier conflict. In 1814, the United States was engaged in a bitter war, on land and at sea, with the greatest power in the world, the empire from which we had originally rebelled: Great Britain. 
Many analysts of the War of 1812 have tried to explain it as an economic or political conflict of limited importance. But it would have been hard to convince the American civilians who suffered what amounted to terrorist attacks by ruthless British raiding forces between 1812 and 1814 that the conflict was either limited or explicable. The British assaults were astoundingly savage: women and children were mutilated and murdered along with civilian men and soldiers in a deliberate attempt to break the American people's will to fight. These efforts reached their culmination in the last days of August 1814, when a squadron of British ships loaded with soldiers and sailors sailed into Chesapeake Bay and up the Patuxent River with a terrifying objective: to burn the city of Washington to the ground. 
The British force succeeded in this goal. By the night of Aug. 24, the White House, the Capitol, the Library of Congress and many other buildings emblematic of both the newborn capital city and the infant country itself were engulfed in flames. The government had been evacuated at the last minute, its officers (including President James Madison) scattering across the countryside. British action against remaining American soldiers and civilians continued to be, in many cases, merciless. 
The questions asked by Americans in the aftermath of this momentous event were some of the same that I have heard all over our city and country in recent days: Why here? Why this?
The War of 1812 had little to do with specific political grievances or economic rivalries. It was prosecuted by the British because of a deep anxiety over the spread of American democratic republicanism. Having seen the bloody anarchy that had overtaken France during its revolution and having watched the United States peacefully and dramatically multiply its territory through the Louisiana Purchase, the British Empire -- a stratified society still largely controlled by its aristocracy and constitutional monarchy -- had grown deeply fearful that the spread of American-style democratic rebellion would mean not only economic competition abroad but also uprisings at home. In short, the British gratuitously destroyed important structures in Washington (and killed many innocent people) because those buildings were obnoxious symbols of American values whose spread and propagation the London government feared would spell the disempowerment of their own. 
The British were right to fear as much, for in time it was indeed the rise of the United States that set the example for populations in colonies around the world to seize their own destinies and put an end to the imperial, socially regimented system on which British power depended. True, in the 20th century the United States and Britain would become allies in order to face the the common enemies of imperial Germany and, later, Nazi and Japanese totalitarianism. Nevertheless, it was the spread of American values that put an end to the colonialism and imperialism that were the practical and spiritual lifeblood of the British Empire. 
Similarly, it is the spread of American values -- individualistic, democratic, materialistic and, yes, in many ways crass and exploitative American values -- that terrorist groups and the traditionalist, socially repressive societies that support them now fear. This fear has driven them to emulate the British forces of 1814 by damaging and destroying a group of structures that are among the most familiar symbols of contemporary American power. 
Thus the why. But why here? Washington is perhaps understandable, but why New York?
The engine that runs the juggernaut that is expansionist American democratic capitalism (which is the force that opens the way for American cultural predominance) is housed, chiefly, in a comparatively few high-profile buildings at the southern tip of Manhattan Island. Americans look (or in the case of the World Trade Center, looked) on these buildings as some of the most distinctive symbols of all that our city and nation can achieve and have achieved.
Our enemies in this war, by contrast, looked at them and saw -- still see -- the death of their own values, their own ways of life, their effective autonomy. Such perception breeds both malice and fear. Inside those buildings, the people behind this attack believe, is where the end of the societies they come from and the values that they live by was and is being planned (whether consciously or not), and there is where the erosion must be stopped. The terrorist obsession with the World Trade Center was, in this light, not irrational. In fact it was, viewed in the context of a war of cultures, entirely understandable. 
That context must now be fully realized by our side in this conflict. We must all match the sudden comprehension and bravery of the hijacked passengers aboard United Airlines Flight 93, who, realizing that their plane was going to be used as a flying weapon of mass destruction, immediately rose to challenge their captors, thus sacrificing their own lives to prevent a fourth crash that could have killed thousands more Americans.
The people of this country, it has often been truly said, have a very bad sense of their own heritage, and New Yorkers tend to be among the worst offenders in this area. We have been known to pull down historic structures with remarkably little concern, to crumble and pave over our past in order to make way for what we hope will be an even more profitable future. But there are moments when we must overcome this blind tendency and look to our history for both inspiration and solace. We know in our collective memory the nature of this struggle; that understanding must now move from our subconscious to the very forefront of our minds so that we can accept the full dimensions of the conflict that will very soon engulf the lives of not only New Yorkers and Washingtonians but all Americans. 
Yes, this is war, and in all likelihood it will be a vicious and sustained one. What our enemies want is nothing short of an end to our predominance, and they will not forsake terrorism until either they attain that result or we make such behavior prohibitively, horrifyingly expensive. And this worst assault on the United States in its history happened in New York City because it symbolizes all that those same enemies loathe and fear most: diversity, licentiousness, avarice and freedom. Now, as we go about the process of adjusting ourselves to this new world of terrible conflict, we can and must take heart from that one seemingly paradoxical historical observation: both as New Yorkers and as Americans, we have been in this new world before.

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 9-23-01: Close Reading: Elements of Tragedy; 
The Bond

BYLINE:  By Roger Lowenstein

 BODY:
I was in Chicago, preparing a speech about uncertainty as an inherent part of business, when the need arose, obviously, to get back to the East Coast, to get home. 
 Mass transport had stopped, and the car-rental companies were booked. In another time, I might have put out a thumb, but all I could think of was to connect with other travelers, so I jogged to the Hilton nearby. A quartet of young to middle-aged businessmen were camped in the lobby. My luck that they had rented a van and were bound for New York, and doubly so that they were of a mind to share it. 
 Because I wanted to feel a part, I bought water and Snickers bars for the gang, but I needn't have; on Tuesday, you could connect with anyone. My companions were part of what is called the global economy; they worked for a company with a German parent that sold, I gathered, digitally enhanced machines all over America. Until a few hours before, each of them had been wining and dining clients at pricey restaurants. 
Now we were eating up highway in states I had seen before only from the air. We talked about the attack, of course, and we murmured into our cell phones. In Toledo, we stopped for gas; I looked at the other drivers in line, and they nodded as if to say, "I'm here for the same reason you are." 
As we rolled by the unrelenting scenery, we heard the same news, transmitted through distinct geographic filters: school closings in Chicago, people giving blood in Dayton. Commentators spoke of Pearl Harbor, but the country seemed too vast to believe it would all shut down or be shunted, ultimately, off its course. The farms in Indiana looked like giant combines; on the pastures in Ohio, the cattle grazed as ever.
The sky darkened, and somebody joked about finding a strip joint. But we were beyond that. The men were calling their wives, and nobody ingested anything stronger than Maalox and Camels. The oldest of the salesmen was frantically trying to learn about a colleague in the World Trade Center. The youngest was telling his wife to keep his kids away from the television. One by one, we lost our batteries, our technological connection. 
Inevitably, the men talked about themselves a little. I gathered that they liked their lives, their work. The oldest had been involved in bailing people out in Vietnam. They didn't want, any of them, to go back to that America of turmoil. 
We stopped for the night at a Holiday Inn in eastern Ohio. We went into a bar for dinner, and even with the televisions showing the awful footage, some locals were carousing with what struck us as too much gaiety. My companions had the grace to remember that perhaps we in the East hadn't paid enough mind to the tragedy in Oklahoma City; perhaps, I thought, that was one reason the president seemed slow to connect to this one. 
We hit the road early Wednesday and didn't stop until lunch at a Denny's, in the eastern part of Pennsylvania now. We ran into a caravan of businesswomen driving westward to Michigan -- our opposites, so to speak -- and it seemed that the entire country had reverted to a pretechnological form of travel. I sensed that they would be ready, if need be, to forsake even automobiles, but not the unceasing motion and energy of our wonderfully restless country.

HEADLINE: Traveling Like a Magnate 

BYLINE:  By ADAM CLYMER; ADAM CLYMER is the Washington correspondent of The Times.

 BODY:
THE other passengers had departed for a predinner nap, so sitting alone, sipping a cold, dry martini and staring at the unfolding Canadian Rockies, I could easily imagine being one of the people for whom this railway car was built 75 years ago -- a railroad magnate.
 For the Mount Stephen was more than the sort of premium observation car that Americans flocked to when they rode the Trans-Canada Limited to escape Prohibition on a trip to or from the West Coast. Paneled in Russian walnut and complete with a dining area and kitchen, it was built for daytime use by a director of the Canadian Pacific Railway, the line that tied Eastern Canada to British Columbia in 1885. Now it serves as the last of five cars of the Royal Canadian Pacific luxury vintage car excursion, the only passenger service Canadian Pacific now operates. 
 This was the Golden/Crowsnest Excursion, traveling 633 miles at a leisurely pace over three days and three nights, starting in Calgary, going north and west as far as Golden, British Columbia, south to Elko British Columbia, east to Lethbridge, Alberta, and then north to Calgary. 
The cars have been meticulously restored, and in the case of our sleeping car, the N. R. Krump, rebuilt. Dominating our walnut-paneled room were two 24-by-36-inch windows and views of the mountains. There were two single beds, fitted together in an L-shape, and for my wife, Ann, and me, a remarkable sufficiency of closet and drawer space in a 9-by-10-foot room. 
Though all quarters were about the same size, some had double beds and one upper and lower berths. All the rooms had good reading lights, but during the day, at least, we ignored our books to look out the windows. The private bathrooms, which have showers, all date to the rebuilding. 
But neither the cars nor a series of dramatic off-train excursions are the story; the Rockies are. Ann and I would stare at them for hours, either from our room or from the observation car.
We saw them clearly just before passing Banff on the first day of our trip, in late June. They were stony above the tree line, with patches of summer snow, and a bit more jagged than the geologically older mountains south of the border. There was no single peak that stood out -- only the sense that for hours we traveled in the midst of mountains whose elemental grandeur outshone the luxuries on board.
The train stopped that first night on a siding at Invermere, British Columbia, overlooking Windermere Lake in the Columbia River Valley. The 16 passengers (22 is capacity) collected in the Mount Stephen for cocktails and the chef Pierre Meloche's hors d'oeuvres, including a delicious smoked oyster concoction.
Dinner started with a zucchini and basil cream soup and continued through a very tender loin of venison with apricots and port wine sauce and a rich Canadian merlot, inspiring table talk. We talked less about who we were (mostly Americans in our 60's, with a Canadian couple and an Australian railway executive who had just retired and his wife) than about the scenery and the day, which had begun with bagpipers playing "Scotland the Brave" as we were piped (and poured, with a good champagne) aboard in downtown Calgary.
After traversing the Bow River Valley, past Banff and Lake Louise, and climbing the Rockies, we had crossed the Continental Divide and stopped at Field for a midafternoon nature walk around Emerald Lake in Yoho National Park (Yoho is a Cree word for "awesome"). We saw no wild animals, but Bruce Bembridge, a naturalist from the Chateau Lake Louise, had a sharp eye for wildflowers. He also took out his telescope to show us the site of the Burgess Shale paleontological dig of 1909, five miles away -- a remarkable pre-Cambrian find whose reinterpretation has altered thinking about evolution. 
After another 35 miles, the train turned south at Golden, leaving the Canadian Pacific's main line for a coal route that took us down the valley of the Columbia, long before it reaches the United States. Here, it was a vast wetland where Bruce pointed out ospreys and a red-tailed hawk.
The trip is expensive -- $4,995 a person (the price does not fluctuate with the exchange rate) -- but it is really all-inclusive, with no tipping and no extra charges for excursions, wine at lunch or dinner, or other drinks. The nights before and after the rail trip are spent at Calgary's spacious, comfortable Palliser Hotel, with dinner and breakfast included. 
The Canadian Pacific, which dropped out of the passenger business in 1970, started these excursions last year, and runs them from May to October. The trip we took is the most popular. There are also specialty tours, a biking-hiking combination and golf and fly-fishing trips.
The off-train excursions, five in all, each offered something beyond what a tourist could do on his own. My own favorite came the second morning, when we got off the train at Fort Steele and took a brief bus ride (a bus followed the train to take us on these excursions) to the Canadian Museum of Rail Travel in Cranbrook, British Columbia. Garry Anderson, the museum director, gave us a private tour through vintage passenger cars, many older than the ones on our train. The Curzon, an observation car with a lounge, a buffet and five staterooms, each paneled in a different fine wood veneer, was built in 1907, he said.
At the time, the Canadian Pacific was competing with United States lines like the Great Northern and Northern Pacific. Running between St. Paul and Spokane, even carrying United States mail, the Canadian Pacific's Soo-Spokane Train Deluxe, which included the Curzon, began on Soo Line tracks controlled by the Canadian Pacific, then on C.P. tracks across the Saskatchewan and Alberta prairies, and back into the United States on a line controlled by the Union Pacific. That train ceased operation in 1913 in a recession, but the Curzon was used on other runs. 
In 1919, Canadian Pacific created the Trans-Canada Limited, "the premier train in Canada, a deluxe hotel on wheels," as Mr. Anderson put it. The museum has a complete set of the Limited's seven cars. The most striking is the dining car, the Argyle, its tables set with Canadian Pacific china from different makers, including Minton and Limoges. The expensive restoration is not yet complete; the car has only 24 of the original 36 walnut and blue calfskin chairs. "We're looking," Mr. Anderson said.
The Trans-Canada Limited was canceled after 1930, but in its day it was the fastest transcontinental run, going from Montreal to Vancouver in 85 hours.
The bus took us 10 miles from the museum to a less meticulous, livelier restoration, the Fort Steele Heritage Town. First a gold rush town, then a Royal Canadian Mounted Police post, Fort Steele hoped to be a major railroad stop, but nearby Cranbrook won out around 1900 and Fort Steele withered away. 
A team of Clydesdales took us to restored buildings, including a working blacksmith shop where we pitched in to help the professionals. At lunch -- a simple beef stew followed by pie a la mode that made a break from the elegance -- we were the guests of Wynne Royer-Towers, an actress in period costume playing Mrs. Phugh, who pretended to take us for railway workers who could somehow influence the choice of where the region's Canadian Pacific hub would be situated. 
After Fort Steele, the train ran along the Elk River, where quite a few anglers were pursuing trout. We stopped on a siding with views across the dark gray waters of Lake Crowsnest and back up the track toward the rocky peak of Crowsnest Mountain. 
Cocktails that evening were served at trainside, and a duo played light airs on the violin and guitar as we relaxed in the twilight. Was I the only one in that opulent railroad baron setting who heard something ironic in one selection -- "Union Maid"? 
They played again, from a classical repertory, in the Mount Stephen after our dinner of roast corn-wild rice cakes with whiskey and sage-cured salmon, a wild mushroom and fresh herb cream soup, rack of veal with red bell pepper sauce, and a chocolate cake with fresh berries and orange sauce. It was all accompanied by a 1997 Casa Lapostolle chardonnay from Chile and a 1998 Louis Jadot Burgundy from Volnay. 
At breakfast the third morning, now back in Alberta, we found ourselves passing through a vast rockslide. It had a grim history. In 1903, 82 million tons of limestone slid off the face of Turtle Mountain, burying part of the town of Frank and killing 70 people. The rail line was reopened in three weeks, but the mountain remains unstable even now; a smaller slide occurred last spring, and the railroad monitors the area. 
We were now out of the Rockies, and our first stop that day was a site where Blackfoot Indians used to stampede buffalo off a cliff. It had been going on for 6,000 years before settlers and hunters began shooting the buffalo in the late 19th century. 
Angie Provost, whose Blackfoot name is Deer Woman, told us how warriors followed the buffalo for three or four days before driving them into a blazing sunrise and onto the rocks below, where a harvest of 30 animals provided meat, robes and sinews for bows that would last a band of 200 through the winter. The site, with an informative visitors center, is known as Head-Smashed-In Buffalo Jump -- a colorful name whose derivation has various explanations. 
The final stop, late that afternoon, was Spruce Meadows, a spiffy, expansive international show-jumping center at Okotoks, once isolated prairie but now a bedroom suburb of Calgary. Four riders training there put on a special jumping exhibition, and we were shown the barns and invited to enter a contest to name some foals. 
There, as at all the other stops except the nature walk, wheelchairs were provided (and pushed) for two of our group who needed them. The train's corridors were not wide enough for chairs, but my wife, recovering from a broken ankle, and another passenger managed with walkers aboard. 
If passengers want to imagine themselves in the heyday of these grand railroad cars, being a railroad director is not the only option. The office, a small room with a writing table and books in the Mount Stephen, is known as "Winston's cubby," because Winston Churchill retired there to smoke cigars in 1943, when as prime minister, he used the car for a trip from Quebec to Washington and back. 
Princess (now Queen) Elizabeth used the Mount Stephen to travel across Canada in 1951. Her parents, King George VI and Queen Mary, took the adjoining car, the Royal Wentworth, which has two twin rooms, a small dining area and a lounge, for a trip across Canada in 1939.
On the last morning's 28-mile run into Calgary, I got to live another fantasy, riding up front in diesel locomotive 1400 with the engineer, Larry Maskowitz, and the conductor, Richard Burris, not handling the throttle or the brakes, but blowing the whistle as we approached grade crossings. Two longs, a short, and a long.

Through the Rockies in luxury
 The Golden/Crowsnest Excursion is the most popular of four vintage rail tours offered by Royal Canadian Pacific. Others are golf, fly-fishing and bike and hike trips. The excursions run from May to October.
The Golden/Crowsnest is $4,995 (U.S.) a person (it does not fluctuate with the exchange rate), including all meals, wine and drinks, and overnight stays before and after the rail trip at the Palliser Hotel in Calgary, with breakfast and dinner. The train sleeps up to 22, with nine rooms for double occupancy. The N. R. Krump, the sleeping car (there are rooms on other cars), has two single rooms, and four with twin beds. All the cars are air-conditioned.
The dining dress code is business casual for breakfast and lunch, and jackets and tie at dinner. 
For more information and to make reservations call (877) 665-3044 or see www.cprtours.com.

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sept. 23 about a rail tour of the Canadian Rockies misspelled the name of the train's vintage sleeping car and misstated the name of Queen Elizabeth's mother, who once used another car, the Royal Wentworth. The sleeping car is the N. R. Crump, as the picture caption said, not Krump. The Queen Mother is also named Elizabeth, not Mary.

HEADLINE: MUSIC: THE AFTERMATH; 
Look Beyond Commerce

BYLINE:  By PAUL SIMON; Paul Simon is a Grammy Award-winning singer and songwriter.

 BODY:
THE events of last week, as unbearable as they were to witness, were ameliorated by the almost total absence of popular culture from the nation's airwaves. Award ceremonies and concerts were canceled. No blockbuster movies opened. No new television shows premiered. It was a temporary respite from the cultural din. Hyperbolic and aggressive selling was not only muted but also seemed, when one stumbled upon it, to belong to an already distant past made irrelevant by the tragedy of Sept. 11. Within this chaos, there was a deep if momentary silence that encouraged us to re-examine ourselves as a people and a culture. 
 What changes could and should occur? The nihilism and violence that are often found in our music and film should be recognized as the cynical entertainment that they are when contrasted with the reality of Sept. 11. The firefighters and police who worked 24-hour shifts were real-life heroes, completely alien to the popular culture's idea of heroism. Artists should feel comfortable with this non-show-biz reality, and let it be reflected in their work. The marketplace can accommodate these truths without losing money. Our notions of profit and value could be adjusted to allow for a greater degree of artistic questioning without an implication that such actions would automatically have adverse economic consequences. Artists could hold themselves to a higher standard of honesty. Corporate America should allow more voices to reach our ears. We are saturated with music and videos that have no relationship to anything but the bottom line. We should encourage the compassion and generosity that flowed reflexively to victims' families and communities in the last week to permeate our everyday lives. 
 It's too soon to predict the ways that the arts will change, but change is inevitable, catastrophe or not. We should recognize that seismic events impact on the creative process and that artistic and spiritual rebirth can follow a shattering experience.
