HEADLINE: FILM; 
At Home In Gritty England

BYLINE:  By PETER KOBEL; Peter Kobel is the managing editor of Premiere magazine.

 BODY:
AFTER two American films -- the underrated western "The Hi-Lo Country" and the charming romantic comedy "High Fidelity" -- the British director Stephen Frears returned to Britain for his most recent work, "Liam," which opened on Friday in New York. Like his first feature, "Gumshoe," which he made 30 years ago, "Liam" is set in Liverpool. But it's not as if he's returned to his roots. "Liam" follows the travails of a working-class Catholic family in the depressed 1930's; Mr. Frears was born far from the River Mersey, in Leicester, to an upper-middle-class Jewish family. But he is returning to a kind of filmmaking at which he excels -- small-budget movies (he likes to call them his "hooligan films") with good scripts and fine actors.
 This 60-year-old director couldn't be less like a hooligan, of course. Even though he wore a T-shirt and khakis for an interview in August, he was the epitome of an English gentleman: intellectually curious, self-effacing and unfailingly polite. When this writer ran out of notebook paper during lunch in SoHo, Mr. Frears began to rise, offering to go look for more. 
 Such instinctive empathy has helped him to create a widely varied body of work, whose characters range from street punks to aristocrats, from cowboys to criminals. Mr. Frears, alternately described as "a writer's director" or "an actor's director," offers at once a refuge for writers who hope to see their vision translated to the screen intact and an opportunity for actors to discover their characters. He is a sort of anti-auteur, and his collegial style, his openness to the experience of his collaborators, has afforded him the chance to imaginatively enter different worlds.
While Mr. Frears has worked in Hollywood with decidedly mixed results, much of his best work has been on small films like "My Beautiful Laundrette," "The Snapper" and "The Grifters." Quirky, funny or dark -- sometimes all at once -- they were made without the compromises demanded by big budgets. "The Snapper," a 1993 movie based on Roddy Doyle's novel in which a single girl gets pregnant but refuses to name the father, was budgeted at less than $2 million. "The Grifters" cost $4 million. "What we're good at," Mr. Frears said, making the British film industry sound a little like England during the Blitz, "is living in the cracks and surviving."
The same could be said of the characters in "Liam." Against a backdrop of Liverpool's cobbled streets and smoky pubs, the 7-year-old title character (Anthony Borrows) observes his family's slow, sad descent into poverty after his dad (Ian Hart) loses his job as a dockworker. Liam, who has a stammer, attends Catholic school, which more closely resembles a religious boot camp than an educational institution. His older brother and sister work -- he at the docks, she for the wealthy Jewish family that owns the docks. The father's helplessness makes him increasingly bitter and spurs him to join the fascist Blackshirts in a horrifyingly botched firebombing.
Firebombings and poverty: hardly the stuff of recent British hits like "Four Weddings and a Funeral" and "Bridget Jones's Diary." Those high-gloss takes on upper-crust or professional-class Britons, where everyone's teeth are fixed and even the most eccentric characters -- like the wacky Welshman in "Notting Hill" (Rhys Ifans) -- have been sanitized for international consumption, have pushed the British film industry into the international mainstream. Such movies, which prove that not all British filmmakers are living in the cracks, provoke a mixed reaction from Mr. Frears.
"I'm not a tremendous admirer of British film," he said. "People like Tim Bevan" -- whose Working Title film company produced those glossy hits -- "shock me. And he's a friend of mine. They've learned how to make films for export. Nobody ever knew how to do that. But it's not the view of Britain that I have."
When it comes to his native land, Mr. Frears, who describes himself and the director Ken Loach ("My Name Is Joe") as "heroic idiots," takes a much darker view -- if only because Mr. Frears's interests and vision encompass the contradictions and complexity of English society, warts, bad teeth and all.
"He's made stories about all classes," said Hanif Kureishi, who wrote "My Beautiful Laundrette," the tale of a gay romance between a white street punk (Daniel Day-Lewis) and a Pakistani (Gordon Warneke). "They're about black people, about Asian people, working-class people, upper-class people, about French people. The diversity in his material is extraordinary and very unusual." 
Mr. Kureishi, who meets Mr. Frears every Friday at a Notting Hill coffee shop to talk politics, sports and occasionally movies, said the vivid characters in "The Snapper" were a case in point.
"The girls are loud, they're tasteless, they're vulgar, they smoke, they drink, they have sex with anyone, but Stephen makes a film about that with real love," Mr. Kureishi said. "He loves their pleasure. He's not judgmental. His films are moral, but he's not a moralistic man. He likes anarchy, he likes pleasure."
"To me, his films are uniquely modern," said Martin Scorsese, who produced "The Grifters," referring to the early Frears movies like "Laundrette" and "Prick Up Your Ears," which is about the playwright Joe Orton, who was murdered by his lover at the height of his fame. What makes the films feel contemporary, he said, is the powerful way they reveal previously ignored parts of English society.
"I found them fascinating because it was a new view of England and a new England expressing itself on film, but also reinventing itself on film," said Mr. Scorsese, who also produced "The Hi-Lo Country." "I've always thought of his films, directly, as whether I've liked the people, whether I want to spend time with them. I didn't notice there was camera. I didn't notice that there was filmmaking. I just noticed that it was cinema about human beings and emotion."
Those who have worked closely with Mr. Frears say that the same respectful approach infuses his work ethic. Jimmy McGovern, the screenwriter for "Liam," said Mr. Frears had put him immediately at ease at their first meeting. "He said to me: 'I'm a middle-class Jew and this is a working-class Catholic film. I don't know anything about the world of this film, so I'll be guided by you.' " Mr. McGovern based his screenplay on Joseph McKeown's book "The Back Crack Boy" and his own memories of childhood.
But Mr. McGovern, speaking by phone from Liverpool, readily admitted that Mr. Frears had known more than he had let on. "I had originally written a scene in which Liam sees a prostitute at work and feels guilty about it," he recalled, his voice thick with a Liverpudlian accent. "Stephen said it isn't quite working. He was a wee bit vague -- he wouldn't impose anything. If there's a problem, the writer has to come up with a solution, which forces you back into your own psyche. I then came up with having Liam see his mother naked, which was a wonderful change."
Mr. Frears's long-leash approach works as well with actors. Mr. Hart ("Wonderland"), another Liverpudlian, agreed that Mr. Frears had allowed him a great deal of latitude. "He gives you enough freedom, he allows you the first go," said the actor, who was in New York recently for a run in Harold Pinter's "Homecoming." "He says: 'What do you think? I don't know anything about this. The reason I cast you is because you know more about it than I do.' He knows what he's talking about entirely, but you get the impression that you're doing it all yourself. He's a wily old fox."
Mr. Frears would no doubt deny any duplicity. "Well, I find that actors do know far more about it than I do," he said. "They're rather intelligent and have good instincts. So my preferred method is to conduct an intelligent conversation with them." As for writers, "All I can tell them is do it better," he said. "I can't come up with alternatives. If I could, I'd be a writer."
Mr. Frears began his career in the theater, where his consideration for writers -- and actors -- was instilled. The son of a doctor, he attended boarding schools and studied law at Cambridge. "That's what children of that class did," he said, noting that he had little interest in law. "I wasn't rebellious, just antisocial. Rebellion was too straightforward. I just sulked until I was 25."
HIS fascination with actors had begun at a theater in Nottingham when he was just a lad. "The actors seemed like the most colorful and exciting people I'd ever seen," he said. "I wanted to go and live like them. I was like a child at the circus."
After dutifully obtaining his law degree, he went to work at the Royal Court Theater in London. There, he met the director Karel Reisz, who asked him to be an assistant director on the offbeat 1966 film comedy "Morgan!" He also worked as an assistant director for Lindsay Anderson's movie "If," which starred Malcolm MacDowell as a boarding school rebel who foments a violent uprising. Mr. Frears said nostalgically, "I learned from the best." 
During the 70's, Mr. Frears worked mostly for the BBC, again for the best. At the time, directors like Ken Loach and Mike Leigh were making television dramas, and Mr. Frears directed several films for the small screen from scripts by Tom Stoppard, David Hare and Alan Bennett. "There was an underlying social seriousness with a connection to real life," Mr. Frears said.
In 1984, he returned to film with "The Hit," a gangster story set in Spain starring John Hurt and Terence Stamp. The next year came "My Beautiful Laundrette," shot in 16 millimeter for television and released to theaters, where it became an international art-house success. "We were just making a little movie," Mr. Frears said while walking through SoHo in New York. "We didn't know that it was going to change British film." The movie's portrait of London, seen through working-class immigrant neighborhoods, is dramatically different from the rarefied one in Merchant Ivory films.
In 1988 Mr. Frears released his most widely acclaimed film, "Dangerous Liaisons," which won three Academy Awards, for best adapted screenplay, art design and costumes. (Incredibly, this opulent period film cost only $10 million to make.) Mr. Frears was reluctant to pick favorites, but he admitted that this film, adapted by Christopher Hampton from his play, which he based on the Choderlos de Laclos novel about the sexual machinations of 18th-century French aristocrats (played by Glenn Close and John Malkovich), was among his favorites. "It's a sort of incredible film," Mr. Frears said. "When I watch it, I can't believe I directed it."
Mr. Frears, who described himself as "enormously self-critical," usually doesn't enjoy viewing his films. "It's too painful," he said. "Bits of your body have gone into them. You just remember the pain. You see them and think, 'I can't do it any more.' Either it's full of mistakes or it's wonderful. It's a disaster either way."
"Dangerous Liaisons" was Mr. Frears's first American film, but his luck with other Hollywood ventures has been spotty, perhaps because his directorial style is so foreign to a culture in which films can have multiple screenwriters and script doctors and actors are pieces of a jigsaw puzzle with smooth rounded edges. His 1996 misfire, "Mary Reilly," is a case in point. A reimagining of the "Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde" story from the viewpoint of Jekyll's housemaid, the film starred John Malkovich as the changeable Jekyll. But it was the casting of Julia Roberts in the title role that helped doom the project, heightening, or lowering, expectations but raising the budget to $40 million.
" 'Mary Reilly,' " Mr. Frears sighed, "was a tiny little story about a housemaid that got inflated into a big film. I stopped it three months before it started filming because the script wasn't right. But then I couldn't stop it a second time."
Though some of his films haven't flourished there, Mr. Frears said he loves Hollywood. "I've had such a wonderful time there," he said. "It's an exciting, hierarchical 18th-century economy, alive with sex and ambition."
Those extremes are also what have made him appreciate the niche he's carved for himself back home. "I've grown used to my modest station in life," he said. Such diffidence is typical, say those who know him well. Mr. McGovern recalled: "We went all down Merseyside scouting for locations, and at the end of that day, we ended up in a bar and it was just myself and Stephen. He says to me, 'Yesterday I buried my brother.' And he is the last survivor of his family. But he had kept that to himself all day. He's very English."

HEADLINE: IN BUSINESS; 
Hoping to Fill the Need for Office Space

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER

 BODY:
WITH 15 million square feet of office space in lower Manhattan lost on Sept. 11 and another 10 million square feet at least temporarily unusable, companies displaced by the attack on the World Trade Center are turning to suburbs like Westchester, where vacancy rates have been rising.
 Westchester has about five million square feet of office space available, county officials said. 
 For Westchester, and White Plains in particular, the relocation of Manhattan companies could mean that buildings still vacant from the recession a decade ago -- when many large corporations like I.B.M. downsized -- could be filled once again, said Salvatore J. Carrera, director of the county's Office of Economic Development and Real Estate. This also could provide the impetus for Westchester to start building again, he said. 
Among the companies looking in Westchester, brokers said, are law firms, investment banks and insurance companies. 
"There is an intense scramble to find new homes," said Kenneth Krasnow, regional managing director in Connecticut and Westchester for Cushman & Wakefield, a real estate services firm. He said companies are casting about for space in several areas, including Manhattan, Queens, Brooklyn, northern New Jersey and Fairfield and Westchester Counties.
Westchester has two big advantages: easy access by mass transit and available commercial real estate, he said.
Due to the slowing economy, the office vacancy rate countywide was up slightly to 13.1 percent in July from 12.8 percent the year before, according to Insignia/ESG, a commercial brokerage in Stamford. In the central business district of White Plains, the slowdown has been felt more acutely, with the vacancy rate in July at 18.9 percent, up from 16.9 percent the year before.
Companies seeking new space want it to be functional immediately, said Carl Austin, president of Austin Corporate Properties in Rye Brook. He said that his office has been inundated with calls and that sublets -- what he called "plug-in space" as opposed to raw space -- would be the first to go.
"The requirements are for immediate occupancy," he said. "Not only should the space be built out and ready to go, but there should be furniture in place. Companies displaced by the events of Sept. 11 want to put a key in the door and get their businesses up and running as quickly as possible."
In White Plains, Salvatore Campofranco, managing director of Reckson Associates Realty Corporation, said, "We may see the first tenants within a couple of weeks." Reckson is a real estate investment trust based in Melville, N.Y., that owns several buildings in Westchester.
Mr. Campofranco said displaced companies are asking about backup generators, dual fiber optics and electrical capabilities.
"There's a new level of awareness about emergencies," he said. "Habits are being changed because people are in a disaster recovery mode."
Mr. Carerra said his office is encouraging landlords and brokers to offer below-market rates to companies that need temporary quarters. In response, Mr. Austin said the displaced companies are receiving offers "to park themselves free of charge and figure out the economics later."
In general, rents in Westchester are significantly lower than those in Manhattan, with the average asking rent per square foot of $26.27 countywide and $27.16 in White Plains's central business district. In Manhattan the average asking rent is from $45 to $100 per square foot. 
In downtown White Plains, a number of spaces are ready for occupancy. The largest is Westchester One, an 850,000-square-foot building at 44 South Broadway.
"There is 450,000 square feet still available in the building, and most of that is ready to go," said Mr. Krasnow, whose firm is marketing space in Westchester One, the 30-year-old black glass structure that currently houses Oxford Health and I.B.M. Prodigy, the online company, was a tenant from 1997 until last year, when it was bought by Southwestern Bell and moved to Texas.
Another building, 445 Hamilton Avenue, which is owned and partially occupied by MetLife, the nation's largest insurer, would require work before it is ready for occupany, brokers say, but it has 260,000 square feet available.
Christopher B. O'Callaghan, a partner in McCarthy O'Callaghan Company, a commercial real estate company in White Plains that is marketing the MetLife building, said that in large part, how quickly offices can be ready depends on how fast phone lines can be installed.
"They can rent furniture and buy computers and supplies right away," he said, "but in order to be connected to the rest of the world they need phone service."
Another major block of space in White Plains -- 500,000 square feet in four connected buildings -- is available just outside the downtown area at 333 Westchester Avenue in the former Kraft General Foods Building. It is owned by Cohen Brothers Realty.
Charles S. Cohen, president of the company, said he could "accommodate tenants right away." Rents, he said, would be less than $30 a square foot. 
Another large block of space is Texaco's 725,000-square-foot headquarters in Harrison, which the company has decided to sell as a result of its merger with Chevron. The building on 107 acres is being marketed by Insignia/ESG, which would not discuss prices.
The building has been Texaco's world headquarters since its construction in 1977. Although designed for a single user, the four-story building could be reconfigured for a variety of tenants. That space is fully occupied now, and because the merger has yet to be completed, the Texaco building will not be available until the first of the year, said Steven P. Bardsley, managing director for Insignia/ESG.
For offices outside of White Plains's central business district, shuttle buses could be deployed to transport workers from train stations, Mr. Campofranco said. Reckson, for example, has space at its Tarrytown Corporate Center and at the Reckson Summit in Valhalla.
The Louis Dreyfus Property Group has about 6,000 square feet in Valhalla at Sutton Place South, said David J. Friedman, northeast regional vice president of the French-owned real estate company.
Another building being considered by displaced companies is 900 King Street, a former I.B.M. building in Rye Brook that has been empty since the early 1990's. Owned by Brickman Associates of Manhattan, the three-story, 201,460-square-foot structure on a 17-acre campus is being marketed at $27 a square foot. Except for its lobby, 900 King Street is mostly raw space, and it will take some time to prepare it for a tenant.
The Mount Pleasant Executive Center on Rockwood Road, a 383,000-square-foot building that was a former I.B.M. Latin American headquarters, is available for immediate occupancy.
In Yonkers, Michael Tarpey, a spokesman for Qwest Communications, said his company has 435,000 square feet of data storage space available for lease. In response to the slow economy of recent months, the Denver-based supplier of telecommunications services had stopped construction on a distribution center that it had planned to fill with more than $100 million worth of computers and other equipment for a Web hosting center.
The remaining commercial office spaces in Westchester are smaller. 
"In a perfect world, we'd want the space to be all in one location," Mr. Krasnow said. "Unfortunately, that's not the reality of the current market."

HEADLINE: If You're Thinking of Living In/Orange, Conn.; 
Family-Oriented Town With Farm Roots

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
EARLIER this month the Orange Country Fair, the two-day event that Orange residents say goes to their roots and defines their town, was held at the fairgrounds on Orange Center Road. The population of mostly business and professional people delights in harking back to the community's centuries-old farming tradition and once a year gives it its due.
 Cows and sheep and goats were judged; the doodlebugs (low-slung vehicles built from old car or truck parts) and tractors, horses and oxen pulled punishing weight loads; entertainers sang; snakes scared spectators in "the Largest Reptile Exhibit in the East;" and there were pony rides, prize-winning fruits, vegetables and flowers, and mountains of barbecued chicken. 
 Orange is clearly family-oriented. The town is 90 percent residential and very green, and it has what is regarded as one of the best school systems in the state and the hottest big box shopping strip in the region on Route 1. The town green is among the prettiest in Connecticut, and the 16-acre Little League complex has eight fields for girls' and boys' leagues, including this year's state champion Babe Ruth League. 
Of the few farms that remain, the 80-acre Ewen farm, family owned since 1820, grows succulent vegetables, fruit and old-fashioned flowers like amaranthus, cleome and celosia, sold at the roadside farm stand run by Jim Zeoli. 
Fieldview Dairy Farm, owned by the Hine family since 1639, is recovering from a disastrous fire but still grows 28 acres of corn and lots of hay and hopes to get its milk, butter, cheese and cream business back on track "as soon as we financially can," Walter Hine said.
Low dry stone walls that line many roads stand as reminders of the cultivated fields that dominated the land and economy until World War II. Now they provide frontage for well-maintained homes and a smattering of new construction.
ON Coram Lane, for example, next to the Great River Golf Club, the first of 17 homes on one-acre lots are to be built for an opening in about nine months. Classic colonials of 3,700 to 4,500 square feet with three, four or five bedrooms, three and a half baths and three-car garages will be priced from the high $500,000's to the high $600,000's. The development is called the Estates at Great River.
Toll Brothers has applied for permission to build 26 luxury homes at Ridge Road and Meeting House Lane. If approved by the town's boards and commissions, the houses will measure more than 3,000 square feet on one acre lots with city water, less than a mile from the Merritt Parkway. The project had a preliminary hearing last week.
With population growth at a minimal 3.1 percent over the past 10 years, Orange has developed an entrenched resistance to residential development. Only commercial or industrial construction that might ease the residential property tax burden is greeted with enthusiasm.
There are no grand estates nor million dollar homes in town -- at least not yet. Of nearly 5,000 existing dwellings in town, "less than 40 are on the market," said Frank J. D'Ostillio Jr., president of William Orange Realty. "We are very short of inventory." Prices range from the $200,000's for smaller older homes to the $700,000's for new construction.
Styles form an architectural record of the town's history, including antique salt boxes, early colonials, farmhouses, Victorians and ranches, and, he said: "We are getting our share of McMansions. Houses generally have gotten bigger -- 2,800 to 3,200 square feet." Minimum lot size is 40,000 square feet in the 65 percent of the town that is on the municipal water system, and 60,000 square feet with a well. Only the commercial and industrial areas have sewers.
"We've always been able to offer affordable homes in Orange," said Rita Palermo, sales agent with Arnold Peck Property World in Milford. "But it's a seller's market, and prices went up this year by 10 to 15 percent." She is showing a three-bedroom, two-bath raised ranch built in the 1970's available for $279,900 on almost three-quarters of an acre, and a five-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath bilevel house on one acre with a main level in-law apartment and inground pool for $359,900.
Many people who live in Orange still bear the surnames of 17th and 18th century settlers, and people who move there often do so because they know someone who lives there, or they grew up there, moved away and came back.
Three families who bought homes between May and July of this year are indicative of such connections. The Dedomenicos, lately of Hamden, knew the town because Keri Dedomenico grew up there and her husband, Fred, has a grandmother who lives there.
Donna and Paul Westlake are from Australia, transferred by his company. "His boss lives here," Mrs. Westlake said. Struggling to adapt to an alien lifestyle, they were pleasantly surprised to find homes in Orange larger and cheaper than in Sydney.
Wendy Price's family lives in Shelton, near enough for her father and her husband, Daniel, a New Haven cardiologist, to play golf at one of several local courses, which are privately run but, compared with many courses in the area, are neither expensive nor exclusive. Grassy Hill Country Club charges $250 a year for a preferred weekend tee time; on a daily basis the fees are $43 on weekdays, $53 on weekends, with a cart. Lunch and dinner are served on the premises. Orange Hill Country Club has a similar system and fees.
While the Prices looked for a house in surrounding towns, Mrs. Price said, "we like Orange -- it has that country feel, and prices are so much lower than the Boston suburbs we came from that we doubled our square footage. They paid $569,900 for their brand new 3,550 square foot house. A bonus was the reduction of Dr. Price's commuting time to work from an hour to 15 minutes. 
Top priorities for the first selectman, Mitchell Goldblatt, the first Democrat ever to hold the office, are control of growth and an in-town Metro-North railroad station. "New subdivisions are being proposed," he said. "That would mean the loss of more open space and wildlife. Consequently, we will be holding public hearings on increasing the minimum lot size to reduce the number of lots in a subdivision and minimize pressure on schools and services." In the past six years the town has bought more than 400 acres for conservation.
A train station, he said, "would be a great help to the region." Orange, in New Haven County, is midway between Milford and New Haven, the longest stretch without a station on the Metro-North New Haven line. The Connecticut Department of Transportation is considering a station in either Orange or West Haven, but claims it has no money at present. Meanwhile, a succession of environmental, parking and traffic studies and assessments of land costs and eminent domain possibilities are under way.
Orange was named in 1822 for William, prince of the royal Dutch House of Orange, who helped the colonists secure a charter in 1689.
Orange has an ecumenical smorgasbord of houses of worship, including the Church of the Holy Infant, Roman Catholic; Congregation of Jehovah's Witnesses; Saint Barbara Greek Orthodox Church; Zion Lutheran Church; Temple Emanuel, a Reform synagogue; Congregation Or Shalom, a Conservative synagogue; and Orange Congregational Church, which has overlooked the green since 1810 and is currently undergoing a $1 million restoration.
Entertainment opportunities include the 10-screen Showcase Cinema and the Orange Community Players, a 27-year-old group, which has about 100 dedicated members who produce three full-scale productions a year. Residents also have access in New Haven, only 15 minutes away, to the Long Wharf, Shubert and Yale Repertory Theaters; the Symphony Orchestra; museums; and art galleries.
Andrea Schiffrin, a past president of the Community Players, is trying to establish a performing arts center in town. Such a facility would also benefit the New England School of Ballet, which, lacking a local auditorium, will give its 10th "Nutcracker" this Christmas at the Parsons Government Center in Milford. 
A multitude of mostly free recreational programs take place at the High Plains Community Center, where an eight-lane indoor pool and fitness center are located, along with 63 acres of fairgrounds, nature and jogging trails, soccer fields, tennis and basketball courts, children's summer camp, July 4th fireworks, the annual four-day Firemen's Carnival in August and summer concerts at the gazebo. 
ALONG Route 1, among dozens of stores including Home Depot, Lowe's, Circuit City, Best Buy Electronics and Burlington Coat Factory are some of the more than 30 restaurants in town.
Orange takes unabashed pride in its schools. A large sign at the Peck Place Elementary School, one of three schools for Grades 1 through 6, continues to proclaim its 1998 Blue Ribbon Award for Excellence from the United States Department of Education. The Mary L. Tracy Preschool for ages 3 and 4 won in 1997. Racebrook School and Turkey Hill School did not choose to apply for the award, which was given to seven schools in Connecticut in 1998. 
"We focus on family," said Nicholas Tirozzi, principal at Peck Place School, "nurturing children individually according to their needs. We have an experienced staff -- 92 percent of our teachers hold advanced degrees and 30 percent are mentors for new teachers who go through two-year internships before they can become tenured in Connecticut." Spanish is taught from kindergarten through sixth grade, a strong music program includes choral singing at 7:30 a.m. in Grades 3 through 6. Each classroom has four computers, and children have access to a lab with 22 computers connected to the Internet. The ratio of teachers to students is about 1 to 20.
Upper-level students attend the regional Amity Junior and Senior High School in Woodbridge, serving Orange, Woodbridge and Bethany. According to Dr. Rolfe Wenner, the superintendent, of this year's 326 graduates at the high school, "95 percent go on to higher education, usually four-year institutions. Students are accepted every year in the National Merit Program and enroll in most Ivy League colleges and universities." 
The latest College Board scores of 511 in verbal and 557 in math are higher than state and national mean scores, but Dr. Wenner regards them as "only one indicator." Some students participate in oceanographic studies aboard vessels in New Haven harbor or fine arts at the Educational Center for the Arts in New Haven or internships at Yale in media, medical, financial and other disciplines. The state, school and parents share the cost. "Fine arts," Dr. Wenner said, "runs the gamut of photography, art, music, theater, and we place a heavy emphasis on independent thinking and developing technology skills." French and Spanish are in the curriculum; Latin, he said with some surprise, "is so popular at the high school that we are offering it in junior high."

Annual town budget meeting and other town meetings as required.CODES: Area, 203; ZIP, 06477.THANKS A MILLION: In 1956 Orange's first library opened in a vacant store, staffed by volunteers and operating at irregular hours. As the town grew and the library became a town department, the 9,500-square-foot space became obsolete. By the 1990's the Friends of the Library began applying for state and federal funds to build a new library. In 1992 the organization was astonished to receive a $1 million bequest from Marjorie Case, a resident who apparently had no heirs. As the story goes, in drawing up her will she recalled the kindness of a librarian who brought books for her to read at home during an illness. With the addition of other bequests and government grants, the new 23,500-square-foot $4 million Case Memorial Library, designed by the architectural firm of Moser, Pilan & Nelson, opened on Orange Center Road in May 1999.

SECTION: Section 14CN; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk; Pg. 3

HEADLINE: Office Space: Concern and Tact Included 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT A. HAMILTON

 BODY:
FOLLOWING the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center in New York City, American Express mourned for the 12 employees who are still listed as missing.
 The company also scrambled to accommodate customers by opening its offices on the weekends, providing emergency funds and travel services, and waiving late payment fees because of postal delays. 
 Amid all of this, American Express quietly began a search for space to replace its headquarters after the trade center was destroyed on Sept. 11, and within three days had signed a lease for 175,000 square feet in downtown Stamford. The deal was reached with the Landis Group, which represents the partners who own the building at 400 Atlantic Street.
Molly Faust, an American Express spokeswoman, said, "I'm sure they had an opportunity to get into a bidding war, but they did not." 
Real-estate experts say that the deal is only a harbinger of what will likely be a frenetic search for space in any office market close to New York, which in Connecticut would include offices from Greenwich to Westport. "For a market our size, this could have a very dramatic impact in a very short period of time," said Dean J. Shapiro of Insignia/ESG Inc. in Stamford.
Usually a company looking to expand or establish an office in a new location has plenty of time to look around, gauge the market and secure the best deal.
"These companies are all going to be looking for space available for immediate occupancy and a dial tone," Mr. Shapiro said. 
Throughout Connecticut, business groups, municipalities and state agencies have rushed to help some of the companies that were displaced after the trade center attack.
"Whatever New York needs, we're hoping to provide," said James F. Abromaitis, commissioner of the Connecticut Department of Economic and Community Development, who established a Business Action Team immediately after the terrorist attacks to coordinate efforts. "What we're trying to do is get an inventory of what space is available so if there are companies looking for temporary space, we know what's there to accommodate them."
Mr. Abromaitis said that his department and real-estate executives were stressing that their intentions are to aid New York companies on a temporary basis, not to lure them to the state permanently.
"It's not in any way an attempt to take advantage of the situation," Mr. Abromaitis said. "Hopefully we'll see those companies rebuild in New York and get back to business the way they should be. We need those companies to get themselves back on their feet, and certainly getting back to lower Manhattan would be their first choice. But we're going to try to do something in the interim."
But some real-estate executives said the lease arrangements could end up being long-term. Most landlords do not want anything less than a five- or 10-year lease. Then again, it could take that long for the Manhattan office space to be fully rebuilt.
"You could argue that they're all coming up here temporarily, but their employees could fall in love with the quality of life," Mr. Shapiro said. "On the other hand, I've lived in New York and I know the lure of the city, and he who bets against New York is a fool. New York has always been remarkably resilient."
Ed Tonnessen, executive vice president of the Albert Ashforth Company, also noted that trying to lure companies away from New York City would be detrimental over the long term to the suburbs, because the suburbs by nature rely heavily on a strong metropolitan area.
"A healthy New York City is vital to Westchester and Fairfield counties," Mr. Tonnessen said. "The suburbs exist as a result of New York. It might be a love-hate relationship, but there is a strong tie, so long-term I would not like to see anyone capitalize on this disaster and think that was great for the region."
Mr. Tonnessen said he received about a dozen telephone calls from brokers seeking space for displaced companies. He said he expected several announcements concerning moves by large corporations to Fairfield County within days.
Connecticut is scrutinizing the industry to make sure there are no attempts to raise lease rates unfairly. Oley Carpp, who heads the Business Action Team, said: "Anecdotally, we've heard a number of brokers in Fairfield County say that what the price was yesterday, that's what the price will be today."
Mr. Carpp said he had received numerous calls from commercial real-estate brokers telling him what their clients are going to need, or what they have available. He estimated that there is about 5 million square feet of space available in the lower Fairfield market area, in blocks from as small as 800 square feet to as large as 200,000 square feet.
The vacant office space in southwestern Connecticut amounts to less than half of the space that was demolished in Manhattan. But many companies have already begun to relocate to the New Jersey shore, which is closer, so experts expect there will be enough space to meet the demand.
"It's tough to put a number on how much we might be talking about, but it's not inconceivable that as much as a half-million square feet of office space could be absorbed in lower Fairfield County because of this attack," Mr. Tonnessen said. "But I must concede it's a sort of morbid way of doing business."
Fairfield County has long had one of the strongest office markets in the country, though there has been a softening in recent months from a vacancy rate that hit a low of 4 percent last year. 
A report issued last month by Newmark & Company Real Estate, a national firm, put the vacancy rate at 11.63 percent. The looser market has not yet had an impact on prices, however, Newmark said. The report put average rents at a record high of $29.06 per square foot, up from $27.76 last year, and sublet space at $31.57 per square foot.
Gino R. Partenza, owner of GRP Realty Inc. in Stamford, said that he had seen some interest, though mainly the inquiries seemed to be surveys by New York-based brokers to determine what was available.
"We've gotten probably six or seven e-mails from brokers asking us what we have or what we know about," Mr. Partenza said.
Most businesses, however, seem to be trying to make the transition as easy as possible, thus little attention has been given to properties at the eastern end of Fairfield County. But there was considerable interest in an 11,000-square-foot space Mr. Partenza represents in Ridgefield, which is furnished and fully wired for phones and computers.
"Most of them are just looking for space where they can move right in," Mr. Partenza said. "It won't be exactly what they want in most cases, but when there's an urgent need, you learn how to adapt."
Mr. Partenza said he had not heard of any company that had raised its rates as a result of increased demand, even though under most any other circumstances that would happen almost immediately.
"Nobody wants to be seen as trying to take advantage of this horrible situation," Mr. Partenza said. "I can tell you that personally I wouldn't be associated with anyone who's trying to gouge."
Many southwestern Connecticut real-estate brokers, however, have reported very light activity since Sept. 11. Richard F. Gretsch Jr., who owns a commercial real-estate company in Stamford, said he received one call about a 27,000-square-foot building he represents in Wilton.
"I've spoken to a couple of other brokers whose phones aren't exactly ringing off the hook, either," Mr. Gretsch said. "I think it might be a little early. A lot of these companies have been dealing with personal issues up until now, and they'll be turning their attention to space issues when they can."

GRAPHIC: Photos: The building at 400 Atlantic Street in Stamford where American Express will relocate after the World Trade Center attacks. At left, Ed Tonnessen, who said, "It's a sort of morbid way of doing business." (Judith Pszenica for The New York Times; Scott Mullin for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Streetscapes/McKim, Mead & White; 
A Skeptic's View of a Renowned Architectural Firm

BYLINE:  By CHRISTOPHER GRAY

 BODY:
MOSETTE BRODERICK has spent much of her professional life studying McKim, Mead & White for her book "When Architecture Could Fashion a Nation," to be published next year by Alfred A. Knopf. Mrs. Broderick, who teaches architectural history and is director of the urban design and architecture studies program at New York University, has gone through letters, bill books, clipping books, local sources and building records trying to better understand America's most famous architectural firm, the designers of the old Pennsylvania Station, the Municipal Building and much of the Columbia University campus. 
 And she says that the three partners were indeed remarkable men, and brilliant -- at attracting talented employees who actually designed much of the work traditionally ascribed to the hands of the partners. 
 "Charles McKim had little engineering or drawing skills," she said. "Stanford White was moody and impetuous, placed in an architect's office at age 16 by his parents just to get him out of the house. William Mead was aimless, and got in some sort of trouble at Amherst." 
But, she said, McKim and White "were out every night" after the firm's start in 1879 making contacts with "the first generation of American millionaires who set their eyes on a European sense of grandeur." The firm soon forsook the more humble shingle style it used for its early country houses and adopted the Renaissance style as its emblem, to match the internationalist aspirations of its clients.
What the principals did well, Mrs. Broderick said, was hire exceptionally skilled designers. McKim, she said, would call out individual details from architectural books to his draftsmen, who developed the actual design; Mead was the business manager; and White, as his wild nightlife gradually took over, would make hurried sketches in his hideaway in Madison Square Garden. 
"His draftsmen would come in in the morning," she said, "find him asleep, pick up rolls of sketches from his feet and try to incorporate them into the actual design."
The first important designer the partners hired was Joseph Morrill Wells, who left Peabody & Stearns in Boston to come to New York and designed important buildings for the firm -- among them the Century Association building on West 43rd Street near Fifth Avenue, which was completed in 1891 after his death, and much of the second Madison Square Garden, completed in 1892 -- until his death from tuberculosis in 1890.
"By that time, the firm was on a trajectory," she said. "They became a training ground for younger designers: Carrere & Hastings, York & Sawyer, Henry Bacon. Bacon did many jobs for White that White never even saw." After Wells's death, William Mitchell Kendall moved into his place, carrying out the design of buildings like the Harvard Club on West 44th Street and the University Club at 54th and Fifth. But Mrs. Broderick said that the most original work of the firm was behind it.
"They became, almost, parodies of themselves," she said. "Kendall was a mean, small-minded man who took precedent as his only cue; they began repeating themselves in the 1890's, and you can spot the details on their later buildings lifted directly from their earlier ones." Mrs. Broderick said, for example that the interiors of the Metropolitan Club reuse details for the Villard Houses.
By the early part of the 20th century, she said, the firm was coasting. "White was dying of kidney failure," she said, "in debt for far more than he could ever repay, $600,000, and became a salaried employee to save the firm from liability. But he just couldn't reduce his style of living." To support himself, she said, White began reselling antique furniture and mantelpieces, seemingly bought for a client but actually from his own collection, at inflated prices. 
White was murdered in 1906, McKim died in 1909 and Mead died in 1928. "From the 1910's until the 1950's McKim, Mead & White got these vast sinecures," Mrs. Broderick said -- "schools, university buildings like Harvard and M.I.T., public buildings, none of them very good. But they had put a spin on the way America perceived itself, putting it on a par with Europe."
But the firm remained the stopping place of choice for young architects, even if only for a short time. Wallace Harrison, who later designed the United Nations building, was one of the firm's hundred-odd draftsmen in the 1910's. "But the architects to go to for creativity in the 1920's were people like Harvey Wiley Corbett or Bertram Goodhue, although none of them were successful in establishing a really large office," she said. McKim, Mead & White was closed in 1961 by the late Walker Cain, who established a successor firm.
Leland Roth, the Marion Dean Ross Professor of Architectural History at the University of Oregon, has written several books on McKim, Mead & White and sees things differently. "There was still important work in the 1900-10 decade, like the Bank of Montreal and Penn Station," he said, "but after that the designs did lose a lot of their force." He has a more sanguine view of the original partners' design influence: "Over time, their hands-on involvement did diminish, but they each had their own personal assistant that they had worked with for years."
Mrs. Broderick grew up in Oyster Bay, on Long Island, and did not pay much attention to architecture until the 1970's, when she studied architectural history at Finch College on East 77th Street. 
"THE librarian, Mark Piel, took me over to the Womrath's bookstore and said, 'Give her anything she wants, and charge it to Finch,' " she said. "I got a feeling of the unlimited possibilities, that I could study anything."
On a walking tour, a professor stopped at 78th and Madison and pointed out two town houses designed by McKim, Mead & White -- the reserved, red-brick Rollins house, on the southwest corner, and the suave, orange brick Fish house on the northwest corner. 
After getting a master of arts degree in art history from Columbia, she got a job working with the architectural historian Henry-Russell Hitchcock, and was then commissioned to write a history of McKim, Mead & White's Villard Houses, at 50th and Madison. The book, "The Villard Houses: Life Story of a Landmark," was published by Viking Press in 1980 and written with William Shopsin. 
She had studied British architectural history -- "I didn't know a thing about American buildings," she said -- but the book project started her on a closer examination of the renowned firm. She was not interested in the traditional approach to their buildings -- understanding their historic precedents. "I don't care what a building is based on," she said. "That's boring." 
Mrs. Broderick said she feels that "When Architecture Could Fashion a Nation" will, for her, exhaust the McKim, Mead & White vein. She says her next book will be a block-by-block examination of Fifth Avenue, taking the reader inside each major house with photographs and written accounts. 
Despite the partners' remove from actual design of the buildings, Mrs. Broderick still sees them as tremendously influential. In addition to putting America on an artistic plane with Europe, the firm acted "as the interpreters of architecture, painting, decorative arts and antiquities." "But they reduced their own commitment to design," she said, "entrusting it to others. They became delegators, not designers."
Moreover, the United States has a marked advantage when it comes to demography. Japan's persistent economic problem is that consumers want to save more than businesses want to invest. One important reason for that, many analysts agree, is the combination of a low birth rate and a refusal to allow large-scale immigration. An aging population tends to save a lot in preparation for retirement, and it's hard to get businesses to invest all those savings when they know that the working-age population will be shrinking for decades to come. We have problems with an aging population here, too. But they are nowhere near as severe, and our working-age population is still growing steadily.
In one way, however, our situation is actually worse than Japan's. For the past decade, Japan has been an island of depression in a sea of prosperity, its economy stagnating even as other major economies -- ours in particular -- boomed. That was, you might say, quite an achievement. Our current problems, on the other hand, are shared by much of the world -- not least by Japan itself. 
In fact, Japan, which remains, despite all its problems, the world's second-largest economy and one of our biggest trading partners, has lately seemed to be on the verge of even deeper trouble: its slow-motion depression seems to be going into fast forward.
In the second quarter of 2001, Japan's economy shrank at an annual rate of more than 3 percent. Indeed, almost all observers believe that Japan was in a severe recession even before the terrorists struck. Aggravating the problem is accelerating deflation: the best measure of Japanese prices, the G.D.P. deflator, has been falling at an annual rate of 2 percent. Deflation adds to the economy's problems, because it gives people an incentive to hoard cash instead of spending.
If you think about this a bit, the story gets even worse. After all, prices are falling because the economy is depressed; now we've just learned that the economy is depressed because prices are falling. That sets the stage for the return of another monster we haven't seen since the 1930's, a "deflationary spiral," in which falling prices and a slumping economy feed on each other, plunging the economy into the abyss. It's pretty scary stuff, not just for Japan but for the rest of us. If Japan slides into the abyss, that will have a direct adverse effect on our economy dwarfing anything the terrorists did. 
Yet lately we seem to be living in a world full of dark clouds with potential silver linings -- and this one is no exception. The upside to Japan's troubles is that they leave us forewarned and to some extent forearmed. Think of it this way: without Japan's dismal example, economic officials in the United States might blithely dismiss the risks in our current situation, cheerfully proclaiming that prosperity is just around the corner. That, after all, is what Japanese officials did in the early stages of their slump. They didn't know that what did happen, could happen. We do. 
And Japan's woes have not only made us aware that depression-type economic problems can occur in the modern world, they have also led to a much better understanding about how to fight them. Without the example of Japan, economic thinking in the 1990's might have been entirely focused on the problems of prosperity. Questions like the causes of slumps and the options for dealing with them would have been a musty field, attracting the attention of only a few economic historians. Instead these questions have been a subject of intense debate, attracting the attention of some of the world's leading economists. (Full disclosure: I've been working on the Japan problem for several years. But the economists I actually have in mind are people like Lars E.O. Svensson, the Swedish macroeconomist, who has produced the most fully worked-out proposal for Japanese recovery.) And this debate has offered some fresh approaches to the problem. 
Not long ago, the two lines of defense against slump that I described earlier -- interest-rate cuts and deficit spending -- were pretty much it as far as economists were concerned. They seemed to be enough: interest cuts had ended every postwar recession, and deficit spending on a grand scale -- that is, World War II -- had ended the Great Depression. On the other hand, if they should turn out not to be enough, economists had few ideas about what might come next.
Now, however, it is widely understood that even if both conventional lines of defense fail, there is still a lot that you can do -- as long as you are willing to abandon conventional notions of prudence. For example, normal practice forbids central banks to invest in anything other than short-term government debt, for fear that decisions about what to invest in will become politicized. And since the short-term interest rate in Japan is already zero, there is nothing more that the Bank of Japan can do within the limits of normal practice. But given the economy's grave state, why not go beyond those limits?
For example, why not buy long-term government debt, which does not yet have a zero interest rate and therefore offers some additional traction? Or the Bank of Japan could print yen and use them to buy dollars; this would push the yen down, making Japanese exports more competitive on world markets.
Some economists have also suggested that an economy in Japan's situation can bootstrap itself back to prosperity through "inflation targeting." This means announcing publicly that you intend to push the economy into a state of persistent mild inflation, say at 2.5 percent per year, and that you will do whatever is necessary to achieve that end. If the announcement is credible, potential borrowers will be more likely to take a chance, believing that they will be able to repay their loans more easily, and consumers will have second thoughts about hoarding cash.
Such radical ideas were branded as irresponsible when they first came out but have since become respectable, almost mainstream. And that means that if the worst comes to pass, if the United States economy starts to show signs of the Japan syndrome, we won't be at a loss for ideas about what to do. Admittedly, it would be nice if Japan had actually tried any of these proposals and reassuring if they had been tried and worked. Alas, despite growing support within Japan, they have not been tried. The reason, I think, is fear -- fear of the unknown, fear of trying anything that might fail.
Fear of the unknown was presumably behind a bizarre recent outburst from Japan's finance minister. Earlier this year Junichiro Koizumi, a maverick and reformer who is intensely disliked by political insiders, was nonetheless chosen as prime minister by the ruling party in response to public pressure. Koizumi has promised that he will fix the economy. Koizumi is pushing "structural reform" -- measures like forcing banks to own up to their bad loans -- that will be good for Japan in the long run but will actually depress the economy in the near future. 
But there was hope that he would also press for unconventional monetary actions -- and some of his advisers have expressed support for such policies. They have been undercut, however, by the finance minister, Masajuro Shiokawa, who declared that this would "cause runaway inflation and send the economy spinning out of control." This at a time when the economy is already spinning out of control and is threatened with runaway deflation. Perhaps Shiokawa is still traumatized by the wartime inflation of his youth.
Meanwhile, the Bank of Japan, which directly controls monetary policy, has refused to do anything unconventional; incredibly, it refused to make any major changes in policy even after the terrorist attacks. This refusal, I believe, is rooted in a pettier kind of fear. After all, if the Bank of Japan were to engage in unconventional monetary policy, it might fail. It would be very embarrassing. It's far safer to declare that your institution has done all it can and that it's up to somebody else to find a way to make the economy recover.
Let's hope that in a similar situation, our policy makers would be bolder and more responsible.

The Nightmare Scenario
Let me be clear: I don't think that the United States is at any imminent risk of following Japan into deep slump. What I do fear is that a combination of factors -- the legacy of our bubble economy, the trouble in Japan and maybe the psychological impact of the terrorist action -- will drag us into a prolonged period of stagnation.
Here's my nightmare: America's recovery from its current slump, whenever it comes, is tentative and short-lived, because the business investment that drove our boom in the 1990's remains stagnant. Eventually the housing bubble bursts and we have another slump; then we have another weak recovery, this time driven by deficit spending, but that, too, fades out. Eventually we look around and realize that it's 2009, and the economy still hasn't fully recovered from the slowdown that began at the end of the previous decade. 
And we also realize that while the government's subsequent attempts to sustain the economy, mainly through tax cuts and subsidies to energy companies, have arguably staved off depression -- the unemployment rate has risen, but only to 8 percent -- they have also devastated the environment and left a huge government debt. The fiscal 2010 budget deficit is projected at $800 billion, and nobody has any idea how we will manage in a couple of years, when millions of baby boomers start collecting their Social Security checks.
Is this outlined situation an actual forecast? No, it's only a possibility. And the terrorist attack doesn't make it any more likely -- if anything, the fiscal response to terror should help give the economy a boost now, when there is a good chance of heading off the chance that we will slip into a Japanese-style trap. 
And even if this possible outcome starts to look a more likely one, we should not give up hope. For although Japan may have failed to come to grips with its long stagnation, that failure was not preordained. Many of us think that if Tokyo would show a bit more courage and imagination it could still turn its economy around. And if the worst happens and we find ourselves in a similar situation, so can we.
A truly worst-case scenario would be if the United States not only fell into a Japanese-style economic trap but also exhibited a Japanese-style unwillingness to do whatever it takes to get out of that trap. But I think, or at least hope, that our economic leaders would be bolder and more imaginative. The Fed, in particular, is a smarter institution than the Bank of Japan, with a lot more talent on hand, and historically has shown a willingness to take responsibility for the economy rather than interpret its job narrowly. 
So should we be worried about the world economy in the aftermath of the terrorist attack? Yes, we should -- but not because of the attack. In fact, I've been worried about the world economy for several years, ever since I realized that depression-style economic problems could happen in the modern world, and even here in America.
It has become a cliche to say that everything is different now. What worries me is the prospect that some things may be the same -- the same as they were here in the 1930's, the same as they have been in Japan for the last 10 years.
What would make things really different, in a good way, would be effective leadership that recognizes the gravity of the situation, does not fail to act for fear of political repercussions or, worse yet, try to exploit the crisis for political ends -- leadership that is prepared to try unorthodox remedies if conventional solutions fail. Do we have that kind of leadership? We may find out. 

CORRECTION-DATE: October 21, 2001

 CORRECTION:
The Streetscapes column on Sept. 23, about the architectural partnership of McKim, Mead & White, omitted the name of its successor firm. It was Steinmann, Cain & White.
A picture caption on Sept. 30 with an article about effects of the terrorist attacks on the American economy misidentified a damaged hotel near the World Trade Center. It was the Millenium, not the Marriott. The caption also misstated the number of people missing at the nearby Marriott. It was two, not none.

HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Let's Make a Deal: Bartering Gains a Bigger Role

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH

 BODY:
SEVEN times in the last three years, Dennis and Caroline Fritzsche have gotten away for luxurious vacations at the Franklyn D. Resort on Jamaica's north coast, and they are planning another this fall.
 The couple -- he owns and operates a children's party center in Valley Stream called the Looney Bin, and she works at home, raising their three children -- eagerly anticipate their Caribbean holidays, where for two carefree weeks chefs cook their meals, a nanny watches their children, and they are free to swim, lounge on the beach and otherwise enjoy themselves. 
 They get all this without paying cash. The resort accepts barter credits, which Mr. Fritzsche has in abundance, thanks to the many Looney Bin customers who ask to do business in trade rather than in cash. When Mr. Fritzsche wants to buy something for his business or home, he checks first to see who accepts barter credits. It turns out that thousands do on Long Island alone. 
Mr. Fritzsche (pronounced FRIT-she) is able to swap not only for the hotel stay but also for a limousine to take the family to the airport and for their airline tickets. 
Like many people who barter, Mr. Fritzsche tends to draw a distinction between cash and barter. An important barter principle is that whether cash or trade, the same price prevails, and barter credits, usually administered by barter companies, represent the cash value of the goods or services. Yet cash somehow seems more valuable, and the resort's barter policy accounts for his decision to stay there. "I would never in my wildest imagination spend my cash to stay there," he said, in a tone of voice that suggested the very idea was ludicrous. "I don't make that kind of money."
It's a two-way street. Mr. Fritzsche said that barter transactions help fill empty periods in the Looney Bin's schedule and promote his business: "People call me to book a party and say, 'My kid had a great time at the Goldstein party.' The Goldstein party was barter. So I know how I got their booking." 
In Plainview, Ken Frost, the president of B&C Office Furniture, said that many of his transactions were a combination of barter and cash. "All barter isn't a good idea," Mr. Frost said. "But if you work it properly and don't get in too deep, barter can be a good thing."
Lois Dale, the president of Barter Advantage, which has offices in Manhattan and Southampton, estimates that barter accounts for $16 billion in transactions each year worldwide. Krista Vardabash, the executive director of the International Reciprocal Trade Association in Rochester, said that as many as a third of all global transactions could be defined as barter. "Even frequent-flyer miles can be considered barter, if you want to define it that way," she said.
Barter companies make money in two ways: by charging a fee to join barter networks, which they build and administer, and by charging a percentage of the cash value of each deal, typically 5 to 16 percent.
Although bartering may be one of those activities that many people do but few will discuss publicly, it will probably grow in acceptance and visibility as long as the economy remains sluggish.
"Barter comes out shining at times such as these," Ms. Dale said. "Cash is tight, and people don't necessarily have the money to buy items like advertising, brochure production and other services. They're more open to barter, whereas in stronger times they'll insist on cash."
One problem with bartering is that it limits the pool of suppliers. And since credits have no value outside the barter network, credits not spent are credits wasted. 
"When you start to barter, you get customers coming through your door who normally wouldn't be coming through," said Marge Sasso, a vice president of the National Commerce Exchange in Jericho, a barter company that says it has 3,500 Long Island members. "But they're not paying cash. So it's easy to feel that you're giving something away for free, especially when you start to get inundated."
Companies most inclined to swap are those with perishable inventories. The category includes computer-related businesses and other high-tech companies whose products grow obsolete quickly, as well as service providers like broadcasters and hotels whose inventories lose value if not sold by a certain time. Barter allows such companies to sell their inventory without resorting to drastic discounts.
"We trade air time for everything from restaurant meals and limousine travel to air time on other radio stations," said Dave Widmer, the general manager of the Long Island broadcasting group includes WKJY-FM (KJOY) and three other FM stations. Mr. Widmer said that bartering allowed radio stations to salvage last-minute revenue from time slots whose value would otherwise evaporate. 
Of course, if a last-minute advertiser appears offering to pay with dollars, all bets are off. "We don't want cash customers to become barter customers," he said.
Michael V. Hollander, the president of the Long Island Convention and Visitors Bureau and a former general manager of the Long Island Marriott in Uniondale, said: "Maybe 10 percent of room nights on Long Island are barter deals. Much of it is in the form of swapping room nights for event sponsorship. The hotel gives some room nights and in return gets a banner placed in a stadium or arena as a sponsor. Or they give room nights in exchange for rental cars."
While purveyors of perishables have bartered from time immemorial, as have buyers who are momentarily (or chronically) short of cash, in more recent years bartering has emerged from its casbah origins to court mainstream acceptance. Eighteen years ago Congress passed legislation that established barter as the equivalent of cash for tax purposes. A new generation of barter company executives, many with Wall Street backgrounds, began to replace their older, sometimes rough-hewn predecessors. The increased legitimacy brought in more small business owners, traditionally the mainstay of barter, into the networks.
Many practitioners, sensitive to bartering's gray-market legacy, still hesitate to reveal their involvement. "I always use the term 'trade' rather than 'barter,' " said Ken Bove, the president of Dougherty, Clifford & Wadsworth, a media placement company in Huntington that does about $8 million a year in barter transactions. 
Still, many businesses need convincing. At the Huntington Chamber of Commerce, where the National Commerce Exchange initiated a program last year for chamber members, response so far "has been disappointing," said Ms. Sasso, the exchange's vice president. 
The answer may be time, and greater exposure. "People are less close-minded when you explain to them how it works," said Mr. Bove, the media trader. "Many companies won't even consider it. I think the old stigma may be lessened, but it is not entirely gone."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dennis Fritzsche says that barter fills out the schedule at his children's party center and helps publicize his business. He uses his barter credits for vacations in Jamaica. (Phil Marino for The New York Times)
