PUB-DATE: September 23, 2001
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 14CN; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 4114 words

HEADLINE: A Shaken State In Mourning 

BYLINE:  By JAMES SCHEMBARI; Kenneth Best, Darice Bailer, Nancy Doniger, Jane Gordon, Elizabeth Maker, Stacey Stowe, Christine Woodside and Joe Wojtas all contributed to this article.

 BODY:
HENRY AND TENSY VEGA of New Milford waited by the phone, helpless, knowing that their son, Richard, who worked a few blocks from the World Trade Center, was heading there that day, of all days, for a meeting in one of the towers. But what time was the meeting? He had never told them. Didn't he say it was on the 104th floor, near where the plane hit? So they waited for word in agony.
 The family of Robert J. Gerlich of Monroe also waited. He worked on the 94th floor of the north tower, just down from where American Airlines Flight 11 went in. After Thursday, with still no word, they found themselves referring to him in the past tense. 
 The Church of St. Michael the Archangel in Greenwich lost 11 members in the attacks. Our Lady of Fatima Church in Wilton lost five, four of them employees of Cantor Fitzgerald, the bond trading firm that lost so many of its employees. When the Wilton church held a memorial service that Friday, so many people attended that when communion was served, the church ran out. 
For better or worse, Connecticut is wedded to New York. Its economic might has sculpted so many of our towns and is responsible for much of the wealth that others constantly jab us about. Without New York, who would we be? Probably a lot more New England than many of us would want. New York is such a part of this state that when those planes hit the World Trade Center, it was impossible not to immediately realize that many of our neighbors were inside.
There are more than 60 people from the state either missing or dead, some of whom were on the hijacked planes. A mother and daughter from New London were on United Airlines Flight 175, which hit the south tower, on their way to California, where the mom was going to meet a friend. The friend was on Flight 11, which hit the north tower. Inside that tower was the mom's brother. Such relationships and coincidences were at work all day.

A Change of Schedule
Barbara Vandehei of Ivoryton is a flight attendant for American Airlines based out of Boston. Because she liked to work nonstop, cross-country routes, Flight 11 was a regular part of her schedule. But not on that Tuesday. With school starting for her children, she signed up for shorter flights during September so she could teach at church and volunteer at school. On Tuesday, she was in her daughter, Monica's, third-grade class.
She first heard about the attacks when her mother called. Then she heard from another American employee.
"My girlfriend from Boston called and said, 'Thank God,' and I said, "Don't tell me who was on that flight, because I'm volunteering at school today."
Later, her husband, James, picked her up at school.
"They had more details and he wanted to be with me," she said. "I walked out and that's when I lost it. He said that somebody had called that I needed to call back. A friend of ours was on it." That was Karen Martin, a flight attendant.
Ms. Vandehei and her husband got home at about 2 p.m. to find 32 messages on the answering machine -- all sorts of friends, family members and people she hadn't talked to in years, all calling to see if she was all right.
"I said I wanted to cry, before the kids got home," she said. "So I just sat there and cried. We decided we would pick them up from school so everyone could see I was O.K."
She added, "They were the worst two days of my life." She did her best to stay calm around her two young children and answer their questions, though she didn't want to be dishonest. So when they asked if she was afraid to go back to work, "I said, 'Yes, uh-huh.' I said, 'I'm not going back to work.' And my daughter said, 'But Mommy, you love your job.' "
She was due back to work that Thursday, but her flights had been canceled so she was able to delay her decision. Later that day, her father stopped by and thought she was home because she had called in sick.
"He told me if everyone calls in sick, then America is grounded, and then they win," she said. "We can't live in fear."
It was then that Ms. Vandehei decided she wasn't quitting and that if her next flight was canceled she would offer to take another one. Ms. Vandehei said she realized she wanted to keep working. She said that every day she works, she asks herself, "How many people can I help today?"
She went back to work last Tuesday.

A Matter of Time
Richard Vega, the son of Henry and Tensy Vega of New Milford and an underwriter for the American International Insurance Group just a few blocks away from the trade center, had an appointment with the Aon Corporation on the 104th floor of the south tower on Tuesday, but his parents weren't sure of what time, his father said. 
"It really was a kind of torture for us," said his father. "There was nothing we could do. We couldn't go there. We couldn't get through on the phone. All we could do was sit there and wait. It was the longest wait of our lives. I tried to keep it together, tried to think real positively that Rich was O.K., but my wife was really desperate."
The call finally came around 11:30 that morning, after Richard had made his way through the debris and stood in a long line to use a payphone at a midtown diner.
"You wouldn't believe the relief," Mr. Vega said, who found out his son's appointment had been scheduled for noon.
As it turns out, Richard was in his office when the first tower was struck.
"Everyone went outside and watched in total horror," he said from his office last Tuesday, his first day back since the attacks. "I almost threw up when I saw the people jumping out of the windows. When the towers went down it was complete mayhem. Everyone was running and screaming."
The Vega's other son, Henry, was at work in midtown at PricewaterhouseCoopers when the attacks occurred. He had an appointment at the World Trade Center for the next day, as he did every Wednesday.
"My oldest son missed it by a day and my youngest son missed it by a couple of hours," Mr. Vega remarked. "All I can say is thank God."

In Town for a Trade Show
Like Mr. Vega, Amy Toyen, 24, a native of Avon who lived outside of Boston, didn't work in the trade center, either, but had come to New York to demonstrate a software product of her company, Thomson Financial, at a trade show. She was on the 106th floor of the north tower. Engaged, she had recently picked out her wedding dress with her mother.
Her parents, Dorine and Marty, an executive with an engineering company in Essex and member of the Avon School Board, spent the days after the attack in a grueling nightmare of telephone calls and e-mails, a spot on the evening news with Amy's photo and finally, combing New York City hospitals for their daughter. There was never any news.
What there was were strangers who sent huge bouquets of flowers to their house, boys and girls from Renbrook School in West Hartford who traced their hands and wrote "right from the heart as only children can," said Mrs. Toyen, who has taught at the school for 16 years. There were also Amy's friends, young women who posted her picture throughout New York, on a Web site and who made call after call, desperate for any news of Amy.
"The good thing to come out of this is how many people want to help," Mrs. Toyen said, describing countless relatives, friends and strangers who offered assistance. "People we don't even know and people who knew her and loved her. They just want to do something.
"The only saving grace is she had a good life," her mother said in a voice hoarse with grief. "She had absolutely no regrets -- except it was so short. It should have been a lot longer."

'Don't Worry, I'm O.K.'
In Sherman, Larae Lang had just returned from a morning walk around 9:20 a.m. and the phone was ringing as she walked in the door. It was a friend calling to ask if her husband, Richard, was okay. 
"I said 'Why, what's up?' and she told me and I nearly froze. I went to call him, but I saw the answering machine was blinking, and it was a message from him saying 'The World Trade Center is burning, but don't worry, I'm O.K.' "
But that was at 9:15, before the towers collapsed. "I sat there with some friends, watching it all unfold on TV, in an absolute panic. All I could think was how close Rich's building is to the World Trade Center. It didn't look good."
Mr. Lang works for the New York Mercantile Exchange, whose offices used to be in the World Trade Center until the 1993 terrorist bombing of the building inspired the company to relocate just across the street.
Finally, the wife of one of Mr. Lang's co-workers was able to call around 12:30 to let her know her husband was heading north and was out of danger.
"I was on the trading floor when the first building was hit," Mr. Lang said. "I'm trained in C.P.R. and I'm part of an emergency response team, so I went immediately to get my gear."
"People were in the coffee room looking out at the north tower with binoculars. People were hanging out the window above the flame line, and saw what we thought was furniture flying out of the windows. Then all of a sudden the second plane hit the south tower, and huge chunks of wall and flames went flying everywhere. We evacuated and when we looked up again we realized it was people jumping out of the windows."
Mr. Lang tried to remain focused on helping people amid the mayhem and guiding people with a bullhorn toward an evacuation route.
"I kept thinking about my wife and our three kids," he said, choked up. "It was terrifying."

A Trip to California
On the morning of Sept. 11, Ruth McCourt of New London and her 4-year-old daughter, Juliana, boarded Flight 175 from Boston to Los Angeles. Ms. McCourt, 45, was planning to visit a friend in California and take her daughter to Disneyland.
Aboard Flight 11, also bound for Los Angeles from Boston, was Paige Farley Hackel of Newton, Mass., one of Ms. McCourt's closest friends. The three were planning to meet in California. Ms. Hackel's plane hit the north tower of the trade center, followed a few minutes later by Ms. McCourt's plane, which struck the south tower.
Inside the north tower was Ms. McCourt's brother Ronald Clifford, a New Jersey businessman who was in the lobby of the Marriott Hotel for a meeting. As he left the building, Mr. Clifford helped carry a badly burned woman to safety. He did not know that his sister, niece and Ms. Hackel were in those planes until he reached his home that night and talked to his family and Ms. McCourt's husband, David.
On Sept. 15 more than 500 people filled St. Matthias Catholic church in East Lyme for a memorial service for Ruth and Juliana McCourt.
"She believed the opposite of the people who killed her," Rabbi Carl Astor of New London said at the service. "Ruth taught Juliana how to love other people and how to create beauty so this should be our response. There will be a time for justice. This is the time for love." 

'The Whole Building Shook'
He's not in good shape; he's not sleeping, he's not eating, and he's constantly breaking down in tears," said Axel Hansen of his 39-year-old son, Glen.
Glen Hansen was working at his family's international freight company, the Hansen Shipping Agency, right across West Street from the World Trade Center on the morning of Sept. 11 and was caught up in the disaster.
"I'm having an extremely hard time dealing with it," he said from his home in Kent last Sunday. "I am truly a wreck."
Mr. Hansen said he was looking through files in an office, which looks out at the face of the World Trade Center, "when all of a sudden, kaboom, the whole building shook. I looked out the window and saw these fireballs, and I immediately thought our roof was on fire. I ran out of the office, hit the fire alarm, went down to the lobby and people are screaming and crying. I ran outside and looked up and said, "Oh my God, they blew up the World Trade Center. We're under attack."
Then, the second tower was hit. "I ran back in, screaming to everyone in the office, 'Get out of here!' "
Mr. Hansen and his colleagues watched in horror as the buildings crumbled and dozens of people jumped to escape the flames.
"There were bodies, debris, smoke everywhere," he said, struggling to hold back his sobs. "We started to head north as this cloud, this plume of smoke was coming like a locomotive behind us. The smell and the taste of that stuff was sick, like death."
Mr. Hansen was eventually able to walk 110 blocks north and then hitchhike to the Mount Vernon train station, making it home by around 4:30 p.m. He is seeking help from therapists and psychiatrists at New Milford Hospital and is finding some solace in prayer.
"I have gotten a total of nine hours' sleep since I woke up Tuesday morning," he said Sunday. "I'm a trained paratrooper and rescue diver, so I always thought I was a lot tougher than this. But, I'll tell you, I'm falling apart. All these things keep triggering these attacks of total terror: a plane flying overhead; the thunder storm we had the other night. Even the sound of an acorn falling on a tin roof made me jump through my skin."

He Went Back in to Help
Nearly a week after the attacks, Susan Gardner of Darien was still struggling to find a way to tell her two little boys that their father isn't coming home.
"She is going to grief counseling, and her therapist advised her not to tell them until she is ready," said Ms. Gardner's father, Kenneth Hecken of the town of Washington. "She is devastated, she's in extreme pain, but she's putting up a good front for the kids because she has no choice."
Christopher Gardner, 36, a senior executive at the Aon Corporation on the 104th floor of the trade center, has been missing since the attacks.
"We talked to one woman who saw him as they were trying to get out, but they parted ways on the 78th floor," Mr. Hecken said. "We got one or two unconfirmed reports that he got out of the building, but then went back in to help people. That's the kind of guy he was."
Mr. Hecken said his son-in-law was a joy in all of their lives. "I can tell you he was a real gem. I have never met a more wonderful person in all my life. He loved to sail, he was passionate about sailing. He was even more passionate about his wife and his children," Christopher, 3, and Alexander, 2.
Mr. Hecken said his wife, Audrey, was at the Gardner's house when the planes hit.
"She was babysitting for the grandchildren while Susan was at work" at Marsh & McLennan in midtown Manhattan. "Somebody called me, and I immediately turned on the TV and called Susan at her office. Unfortunately, she could see the whole thing from her office. She saw the collapse of the two towers and she just fell apart." 
Ms. Hecken runs Elysian Fields, a day spa in the center of New Preston, with her other daughter, Melissa Curtin of South Norwalk. The spa was dark and empty early last week, a sign on the door saying there's been a tragic death in the family.
"This has changed all of our lives forever," Mr. Hecken said. "All we can do is pray and hope that God can save the world." 

Hoping for a Miracle
Friends began filing the Darien home of Edward Francis Maloney III, who everyone knew as Teddy, as soon as word spread that he had been at work at Canton Fitzgerald on the 105th floor of the World Trade Center Tuesday. They stayed for days.
Mr. Maloney, 32, was outgoing, to the point where he typically asked the names of every person he met, from waiters and waitresses to store clerks. Neighbors on his former street in Darien proclaimed him unofficial mayor of the street, said a childhood friend, Trask Pfeifle. 
Mr. Maloney lived for his family, including his parents, Edward Jr., and Sally Maloney, and siblings. He was a devoted athlete, pursuing football, hockey and lacrosse in prep school, lacrosse in college, fishing, waterskiing and hockey.
"Everybody loved him," Mr. Pfeifle said. "We all know that out of these huge tragedies, miracles pop up. We're hoping for one of those."

Up Early and Out the Door
When Joshua Piver's friends used to visit him in New York City, he would often take him to the top of the World Trade Center, five floors above his office. 
The 23-year-old Piver, who grew up in Stonington, was in that office when the first jet crashed into the north tower. He has been missing since. 
Josh's sister Erika, 26, traveled to New York with some friends to bring a photo and description of him to the center set up to identify the missing. Mr. Piver's family soon found out he was not on a list of his company's employees who had escaped the building. They also called phone lines set up to find the missing and posted information about him on Internet sites and with the Red Cross.
Many of those friends that he taken to the trade center traveled home to Stonington on Sept. 14 to comfort Mr. Piver's mother, Susan, and attend a candlelight prayer service for all the victims at a local church. A few nights later about 30 of Mr. Piver's friends, many of whom live and work in New York City, gathered at a local home.
"He's the most easy-going, fun-loving guy." said Leah Dann. "Everyone got along with him. I've never known him to argue with anyone, even raise his voice. He's just the best. This has been a big nightmare."
A 1996 graduate of Stonington High School where he played soccer, Mr. Piver worked summers at a local boatyard. He graduated from the University of Vermont with a degree in economics in the spring of 2000. A few months later he went to work for Tradespark Inc., an energy company. It is part of Cantor Fitzgerald, the trade center firm that lost almost 700 of its 1,000 employees in the attack.
Mr. Piver lived with three friends and on the night before the attack they had celebrated signing a lease for a new apartment in Brooklyn.
On the morning of the attack Mr. Piver as usual was the first one awake and out of the apartment. A roommate, Dave Leeming, who had worked for the same company as Mr. Piver but had recently been transferred across the Hudson River to work on a project, said he last heard his friend in the shower before work. 
A few hours later as he and Mr. Piver's other friends heard about the attack on the north tower, they immediately began calling his office and cell phone. They only reached his voice mail.

'Very Private and Simple'
My dad was a really cool guy," said Matthew Gerlich, 19, of Monroe during an interview on Monday. "He was very private and simple, with no frills. But he had a really good sense of humor and loved sports."
Robert J. Gerlich, 56, an accountant who worked on the 94th floor of the north tower for the Guy Carpenter Company, a division of the Marsh McLennan insurance company, is among the thousands of missing people. He had returned to work Sept. 5, following hip replacement surgery.
Matthew said the family, his mother, Rochelle, and brother, Daniel, 22, remained hopeful his father would be found alive until Thursday when they realized no one had made it from floors 94 to 96. After Thursday, they began referring to Mr. Gerlich in the past tense. That was the last time they could bear to watch the TV coverage of the attack.
"The only thing we're grateful for is that he probably went out quickly," Matthew said.

A Family Trip
Right before Labor Day, Stephen Cherry of Stamford took his wife Mary Ellen and four children to Nantucket. The family was in the midst of building a new house, and Ms. Cherry told her husband that it was a bad time, that too much was going on in their lives. He insisted. For his birthday present, he said.
"I want my family," he told her, "to have this memory."
Today, Ms. Cherry is stunned at her husband's prescience. "He said to me, 'I need to do this,' " she remembered. "It was almost as though he knew something was going to happen."
Perhaps even more prescient, Mr. Cherry, a partner at Cantor Fitzgerald, called his wife at 8:42, a few minutes before the first plane hit. It was an atypical phone call. Mr. Cherry normally called her in the afternoon after the market had closed. "I'm hanging on to the fact," Ms. Cherry said, "that we said our 'I love yous.' "
Mr. Cherry would have been 42 this Tuesday. Most weekends he could be found playing golf with some of his four children, Jeremy, 14 and Peter, 13, Brett, 6, and Colton, 11 months.
"What I want people to know is how important his family was, how much he loved me and the kids," Ms. Cherry said. "Kind was an understatement for him. He always told the children, 'Treat people as you want to be treated.' And his family and all of his friends know that Steve was probably helping people at Cantor Tuesday before he would get out himself. I want people to know how special he was."

Dealing With Hijackers
Donald F. Greene of Greenwich was an engineer who worked for the Safe Flight Instrument Corporation, a White Plains company founded by his father, Leonard Greene, an inventor of aircraft safety instruments.
He was flying to Lake Tahoe, Calif. on Flight 93 to join his four brothers for a long-anticipated hiking vacation when the plane was hijacked. Although family and friends have no evidence, they are certain he was one of the passengers who fought the hijackers.
"Beyond a shadow of a doubt," Claudette Greene, his wife, said. "Anyone who knew him had the same feeling. We just know that, that day, he rose above."
The couple met at an arts fund-raiser with an aircraft theme. The event had come up short one plane, and Mr. Greene, who had not planned to attend, flew in one of his company's planes to fill the gap.
"He ended up at my table, Ms. Greene said. "He was wearing a tuxedo, I was all dressed up. Three years later we were married. It was like a Cinderella story."

'I'll See You Later'
On Sept. 8, one day after John and Margaret Iskyan celebrated their 16th anniversary, Ms. Iskyan walked into the old town hall in Wilton to shouts of "Surprise!"
Her husband had managed to pull off a 40th birthday party without her knowledge, keeping it quiet since he began the planning in May. 
A bond broker in government securities for Cantor Fitzgerald, Mr. Iskyan, 41, was known for both his thoughtfulness and his methodical nature.
"He planned everything he ever did well," said Bob Keeling, who is married to Ms. Iskyan's sister, Linda. "He was a very serious man, yet he had a great sense of humor."
The family often skied together in Vermont, where Mr. Iskyan had attended St. Michael's College and where he had met his wife. "Margaret often said if John could ski 365 days a year, he would," Mr. Keeling said. 
Mr. Iskyan was on the board of directors of the Wilton Lacrosse Association, and coached the lacrosse team on which his son, Peter, 12, played. The couple also have a daughter, Carolynn, 9. 
The day of the disaster, Mr. Iskyan was on the phone with a close friend from Wilton. "We're evacuating," he said. "I'll see you later." The friend wished him good luck. 
The family received a call early Friday that Mr. Iskyan's body had been located. "Margaret feels blessed that John has been found and we can have a service," Mr. Keeling said, a ceremony that was held last week. "And she is very concerned about those people who have not been found."

A Faint Message
The Saturday before the terrorist attack, Susan Wohlforth of Greenwich, her husband, Martin, and their 16-year-old daughter, Chloe, attended the 5 p.m. mass at the Church of St. Michael the Archangel on North Street in Greenwich, a mass they attended each week. The next Saturday, Susan and Chloe Wohlforth sat in the pew alone. Mr. Wohlforth, whom family and friends knew as "Buff," is among the missing and presumed dead. In all, St. Michael's lost 11 parishioners.
A managing director and bond trader for Sandler O'Neill & Partners on the 104th floor of the south tower, Mr. Wohlforth, 47, called his wife after the first plane hit the north tower to tell her he was fine.
"I think everybody should get out of there," Mrs. Wohlforth advised.
Calmed, she headed to the offices of the Junior League of Greenwich, of which she is president. After the plane hit the south tower, her husband called the offices before she arrived.
A secretary received a faint message. "This is Buff Wohlforth," he said, and asked for his wife. The connection then was severed.
"He was your all-American clean-cut good kid, handsome and witty, smart and kind," said Nancy Seaman, a childhood friend whose brother was friendly with Mr. Wohlforth. "I remember when my brother was sick with leukemia, Buffy would ride his bike over all the time to visit."
His greatest passion, say friends and relatives, was for his family.
"He was the best father, the best husband, and I couldn't be here right now except I believe he is with me," said Ms. Wohlforth, standing outside St. Michael's after mass let out. "I want people to know he was a great man -- not the only great man lost in this tragedy, but a great man nonetheless."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Hundreds attending a memorial service at the Church of St. Michael the Archangel in Greenwich. Flight 11, which went into the north tower, was normally a regular part of her schedule. Right, Robert J. Gerlich. (C. M. PUB-DATE: September 23, 2001
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 14NJ; Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 734 words

HEADLINE: JERSEY; 
From a Distance, A New Closeness

BYLINE:  By DEBRA GALANT

 BODY:
IT reminded me, I realized later, of "Sunday Afternoon on the Island of La Grande Jatte," the painting by Georges Seurat.
 The weather was perfect. People were strolling, talking in small groups, walking with children, even picnicking under a tree. And as in the painting, most of the people were looking in one direction. 
 The similarity ended there. The people I saw weren't looking at the Seine, but at the starkly altered skyline of Lower Manhattan. It was not Sunday afternoon, but Wednesday afternoon.
It was the day after.
The place was the Eagle Rock Reservation in West Orange, a park whose restaurant, the Highlawn Pavilion, is famous for its "heart-stopping views of Manhattan," or so says an old restaurant review.
People were gawking, having come to witness with their own eyes what they had seen on television or in the newspaper. Praying. Taking photographs. Paying homage. Being with other people. Taking it in.
Many had parked at a nearby bowling alley or diner or at the Kmart, since so many people had had the same idea that the police had stopped cars from entering the park.
Emer Pool, binoculars hanging from her neck, crossed herself.
"It's like a wake, being here," she said.
Next to her, her husband, Barry carried their baby in a Snugli. He had been maybe 100 yards from the World Trade Center when the second plane hit.
Though heart-stopping and wakelike, the scene was also a celebration. Wife, husband, baby. Alive, together, safe. A day in the park.
Joe Lacerenza of Mendham, an electrical contractor working near the reservation, came "just to take a look at the scene like everybody else." He had been at a seminar at the Marriott in East Hanover a day earlier, the day the world changed forever.
"You know that it happened," he said, "but you just have to come see for yourself that they're not standing there anymore."
Pam Wood, of Bloomfield, who came with friends, wanted the opposite.
"I don't want it to be real," she said. "I was hoping to come up and see something different."
Next to me, a man who preferred not to identify himself spoke with terse bitterness. An employee of Prudential, he said had at least five friends in the securities business who had not been accounted for.
He speculated on how disastrous it would be for the stock market and the local economy. "My quote is, 'I thought the stock market crashes in October,' " he said with a tight, grim smile.
Below us, 15 miles to the east, Midtown appeared bright and clear. There, in almost total clarity, stood the Empire State Building, a beacon from an earlier era. To the right, downtown was cloaked in a haze, an inexhaustible cloud of rising smoke.
Like everybody, I have been hearing the stories, each like a dot in the Seurat painting: the people who were late to work and never made it to the World Trade Center; someone with leukemia who had taken the day off because he was sick.
"Can you imagine?" one person asked. "Being lucky to have leukemia?"
My Poland Spring delivery man had left his route right after the first plane slammed the World Trade Center and took water close to the rescue scene.
At a Red Cross center not far from Eagle Rock Reservation, Gil Cisneros of Montclair, who was waiting to give blood, told of a phone conversation he had had with a friend on the 97th floor of the south tower just minutes after the first plane and just before the other one.
His friend told him she had been advised to stay where she was, and was nervously calculating what to do.
She is still unaccounted for.
Children, as we know, see things differently. In a week that is indelibly etched in the nation's consciousness, my 9-year-old son was distressed by the fact that Yankees games were canceled.
"Are we ever going to be allowed to be happy?" he asked.
Millions of stories. Everyone has one. And then there are the thousands we will never know. But everyone was somewhere when their heart stopped. Each of us, in that moment of shock, felt the distance between ourselves and the people we love, and calculated our chances of reunion. 
Some of us were lucky. The calculus worked out. We may walk around in shock, but we can still do it in a lovely park, even with those we love the most.
Georges Seurat changed the way we see the world. He anticipated pixels and television, and the discovery of the atom. Ultimately, his painting was about the fact that there is no substance. Just light, air, the present moment.

HEADLINE: POSTINGS: Four Parcels Ready for Development; 
New Focus on Queens West Office Sites

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
The Queens West Development Corporation has a site: four large parcels of waterfront property across the East River from the United Nations. And the site has a pre-approved project: nearly 2.5 million square feet of commercial and retail space. And the project has a designated developer: LCOR, the builders of 101 Hudson Street in Jersey City. And the developer has an architect: Kohn Pedersen Fox Associates, designers of the Ernst & Young headquarters being built at 5 Times Square. 
 What they had been waiting for was a tenant. 
 "I don't think they're going to have to wait any longer," Charles A. Gargano, the chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, said last week, as companies scrambling for space after the Sept. 11 attack began to turn their attention from immediate to longer-range needs.
Mr. Gargano said the commercial development of Queens West -- which was once expected to start sometime before the end of 2004 -- could begin by the new year. "We can get that site ready for people to move in within 18 to 20 months," he said.
To accommodate the most ambitious possible project, Mr. Gargano said, a fifth large development parcel immediately to the south of the LCOR site, originally intended for residential use, may be folded into the development, which would bring the potential total to 3.5 million square feet.
Also possible, he said, though less likely, would be to raise the established building height limits for Queens West to 700 feet from 400 feet. That could conceivably bring the commercial development potential to a total of 5 million square feet.
(Mr. Gargano's agency is the parent of the Queens West corporation, which includes representatives of the city, the borough president and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.)
Borough President Claire Shulman of Queens said she favored altering the master plan for Queens West however necessary to encourage rapid development: increasing density, expanding the commercial core, even raising the height limits, so long as it passed muster with the Federal Aviation Administration. "We should do whatever it takes to keep our economic base," Mrs. Shulman said.
The architects are "gearing up for this monumental effort," said Kurt M. Eichler, executive vice president of LCOR. He noted that the buildings could have trading floors up to 80,000 square feet and said if there were a way to increase density on the site, "it makes all the sense in the world."
The LCOR parcels take up 13.5 acres in the southern half of the 74-acre Queens West site, which is two blocks from the No. 7 subway line. To the north are the existing Citylights apartment tower, and residential sites controlled by AvalonBay Communities and the Rockrose Development Corporation (where the giant Pepsi-Cola sign stands).
"The icing on the cake is that you have a tremendous 24-hour environment that can be developed," Mr. Eichler said. DAVID W. DUNLAP

HEADLINE: In the Suburbs, Displaced Companies Are Gobbling Up Space 

BYLINE:  Elsa Brenner, Eleanor Charles, Antoinette Martin and Carole Paquette contributed to this article.

 BODY:
WITH a discomfiting mix of emotions, commercial real estate brokers in the suburban ring around the city have been repeatedly reaching for their insistent phones in recent days.
 In the days since the terrorist attack, brokers say, representatives of displaced companies have been constantly calling, seeking the choicest space available as close as possible to the local train station. In some cases, deals have been based on little more than a handshake, followed soon by the arrival of the first reverse commuters. 
 Reluctant to take advantage of the demand, some landlords are being flexible in their rents, the brokers say. At the same time, with expectations of a longer-term tight market, rental deals that had lingered in the talking stage have rapidly closed, and construction schedules have been expedited.

Connecticut
"I guess half a million square feet will be leased in Stamford by dislocated New York companies," said Ed Tonnessen, executive vice president at the Albert B. Ashforth agency in Stamford. "And they are throwing a wide net over Fairfield, Westchester and New Jersey, with a premium on speed."
Most of what is available in Fairfield is sublease space in Stamford, where companies expecting to expand took more space than they needed. The second-quarter vacancy rate this year was 13.68 percent. "And the rate was growing" until the terrorist attack, said Joseph McGee, a vice president at Connecticut's Southwestern Area Commerce and Industry Association.
Rents last year ranged from $25.91 to $34.68 per square foot. This year, before Sept. 11, they rose to between $27.84 and $40.19. Now, brokers agree, they are negotiable. Figures supplied by Insignia/ESG indicate that 2.1 million square feet is available in Stamford out of 5.5 million square feet for all of Fairfield County.
American Express was the first company to sign a major agreement, capturing the largest space in the city -- 175,000 square feet at 400 Atlantic Street. Scott Landis, head of the Landis Group, which bought the 500,000-square-foot building in December, would not disclose the lease terms. "We had 52 calls," he said. "There was no bidding war, no raising of prices -- just a handshake." American Express employees began moving in on Monday.
Deals are being made quietly, according to brokers, with people moving in almost secretly.
Zurich Reinsurance, whose Chase Manhattan Plaza and Cortlandt Street locations in New York are temporarily closed, took 6,000 additional feet at its 40,000-square-foot offices at Canterbury Green in Stamford, which the company says is now serving as its principal operating office. 
Last Friday Connecticut's Department of Economic and Community Development set up a team at the governor's office in Bridgeport. "We have done an inventory of available space," said Oley Carpt, director of the operation, "and we are receiving calls from brokers adding to the list on a daily basis." New York companies seeking information can call (203) 336-8700. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: In the Suburbs, Displaced Companies Are Gobbling Up Space 

BYLINE:  Elsa Brenner, Eleanor Charles, Antoinette Martin and Carole Paquette contributed to this article.

 BODY:
WITH a discomfiting mix of emotions, commercial real estate brokers in the suburban ring around the city have been repeatedly reaching for their insistent phones in recent days.
 In the days since the terrorist attack, brokers say, representatives of displaced companies have been constantly calling, seeking the choicest space available as close as possible to the local train station. In some cases, deals have been based on little more than a handshake, followed soon by the arrival of the first reverse commuters. 
 Reluctant to take advantage of the demand, some landlords are being flexible in their rents, the brokers say. At the same time, with expectations of a longer-term tight market, rental deals that had lingered in the talking stage have rapidly closed, and construction schedules have been expedited.

Westchester
In Westchester, as elsewhere, brokers' phones keep ringing. "It's constant," said Christopher O'Callaghan, a partner in McCarthy-O'Callaghan in White Plains. "There's a tremendous amount of activity."
At the county's Office of Economic Development and Real Estate, the director, Salvatore Carrera, said about five million square feet was available. Mr. Carrera, whose office is cooperating with the New York City Office of Economic Development and the Empire State Development Corporation, said he was encouraging landlords and brokers to offer below-market rates to firms needing temporary quarters.
There are two commercial buildings available in the county that could accommodate large companies. Cohen Brothers Realty has 500,000 square feet available in four buildings at 333 Westchester Avenue in White Plains. Charles Cohen, the president, said rents would be below $30 per square foot. The building was occupied by General Foods, which moved into it 44 years ago. The complex, at North Street and Westchester Avenue, has been empty since 1997.
The other large contiguous space is Texaco's 725,000-square-foot headquarters in Harrison. The company has decided to put the building up for sale because of its pending merger with Chevron. The glass-and-travertine-marble building sits on 107 acres. The property is being marketed by Insignia/ESG, which would not discuss prices. The building has been used as Texaco's world headquarters since its construction in 1977.
That space is fully occupied now, and because the merger is not yet completed, the Texaco headquarters will not be available until the first of the year, said Steven Bardsley of Insignia/ESG. Over all, the county had a vacancy rate of 13.1 percent at midyear. The county's average asking annual rent per square foot is $26.27. ELSA BRENNER

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; 
Finding Hope in the Timeless Tale of 'Romeo and Juliet'

BYLINE:  By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
WHAT part can theater play when life is in upheaval? At a time of grieving, do people feel comfortable about being entertained?
 Go to a show, political leaders tell us. Business as usual, economic advisors say. It is the entertainer's business, as the song goes, to "make 'em laugh." People have turned to entertainment when there is a national crisis, said Jed Bernstein, president of the League of American Theaters and Producers. 
 Still, last week Broadway theaters reported an 80 percent decline in ticket sales since the attacks, and one new musical, "Assassins," has been canceled. 
Even the McCarter Theater in Princeton, which is more concerned with taste than tourism, dropped "The Vienna Notes," by Richard Nelson, a play about a hostage crisis scheduled to open next month. "It would be insensitive of us to present the play at this moment in our history," said Emily Mann, the McCarter's artistic director.
The current production at the McCarter, which opened on Sept. 14, is indisputably a tragedy, but it could have been divinely chosen for the moment, for it fulfills the highest purpose of theater -- to enlighten and to purge, to create order out of chaos.
The play is about the human impulse to hate, and as much about the need to love. Ultimately, each audience member must reflect upon which force wins.
The play was written in 1595. It is called "Romeo and Juliet." Though you may have seen it before, after seeing Ms. Mann's new staging, you may not be so sure. At least you will see it anew. And that is the difference between timely and timeless.
"Classics give us comfort through perspective," said Bonnie J. Monte, artistic director of the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival in Madison, where a new production of "Tartuffe" by Moliere, directed by Paul Mullins, opened on Sept. 15.
"I'm a great champion of the classics," she added. "Rarely do I stray. They are a better road map to the future. New stuff is too immediate."
This season, there is less new stuff anyway, compared with recent repertories of New Jersey's professional theaters. Revivals are a safer bet than new productions, and safety may be the way to go, given that three theaters -- Crossroads in New Brunswick, American Stage in Teaneck and Luna Stage in Montclair -- will be dark all season, and one -- Forum in Metuchen -- is still juggling schedules and postponing plays, and does not appear to have a full lineup.
Meanwhile, many of the revivals are so familiar they might be called retreads. So unless those productions are revelatory, classical plays may prove more sustaining than ever in a disquieting time. 
The McCarter's production of Moliere's "Don Juan," which begins performances on April 30, is to restore material censored in the 17th century. Stephen Wadsworth, the McCarter's recurring gift to local theater, is both adapter and director. And Ibsen's "Peer Gynt" ought to be a new test of resources for the resourceful Two River Theater Company in Manasquan.
"Tartuffe" is the New Jersey Shakespeare Festival's first Moliere in the 11 years of Ms. Monte's tenure.
"At first, people think 'Tartuffe' is a trivial confection, and it is a miraculous comedy," Ms. Monte said, pointing to Moliere's satiric thrusts at hypocrisy, piety and false morality, and their relevance to recent conservative political views.
But for centuries, Moliere's classic has resonated with sadness, profundity, closeness to tragedy, and, in the words of Stendhal, "the probing of the depths of the human heart."
Moliere is no stranger to McCarter audiences, but Shakespeare was a first try for Ms. Mann. Classics endure because they represent and fulfill "a higher level," Ms. Mann said, referring to human truths, mythic status and satisfaction of the soul, terms that may sound lofty, if only because they are rarely encountered. That is why they are called classics.
Besides, she continued, "they're real, alive and never dated. And they have legs." 
Ms. Mann said the story of star-crossed lovers, "crushed under the weight of hatred is eerily appropriate to what's happening now." She added: "I am moving more and more toward the classics. There's a burning need to do them. After last week's horror, the whole cast dug deeper into the rivers of grief and the levels of beauty in this play."
The coming together of two feuding families in the final moments of "Romeo," after the sacrifice of their children -- Juliet was 14 -- to an inexplicable hatred, offers a ray of hope. That was an impression, often expressed, among young people, ages 10 to 17, at the first of five performances for students from local schools at the McCarter last Tuesday morning.
"You've got to believe that in light of what happened in New York," said Luke Palder, a 14-year-old ninth grader at Hopewell Valley Central High School. "The play makes you notice how petty all the fighting is."
"You know the families will drop it, and that wakes us up to the error of our own ways," he continued. "So you could adapt this to any time period."
Katie Kirnam, a 13-year-old ninth grader at Stuart Country Day School in Princeton, said "You realize how much more powerful love is."
"Ironically, two families hate each other, and it's love that brings them together," she said. "It's funny and it's sad."
Taj Pannell, 12, in the seventh grade at the same school, said: "The rivalry never ends. I want to say, stop it, stop the fighting, if it keeps happening the children will die."
Even the pace of Ms. Mann's staging, breath-stopping in both swiftness and sensuality, is true to the time line of a story that takes place in three or four days. The director rearranged passages and cut 1,000 lines. Though Lady Capulet and Lady Montague reach out and connect at the end, while their husbands do not, the lines of reconciliation that customarily close the play, perhaps on a note of false sentiment and contrived affirmation, are here not spoken.
Not that hope is dashed. But its possibility is more thoughtful and realistic. "A scourge on both your houses" are the last words in Ms. Mann's version, reinforcing Juliet's first thoughts ("My only love sprung from my only hate") and Romeo's early references to hope in misery and "love's heavy burden."
Brawls and swordplay are unstinting. The rush of rapture overtakes Romeo, played by an impetuously ardent Jeffrey Carlson, all "quivering love," and Juliet, played by Sarah Drew, petulant, giddy, incorrigibly girlish, willful and completely enchanting in a never-to-be-forgotten balcony scene.
Ms. Drew's exploration of a teenager's heart and her awakening to desire are defining, and from now on, indelible, aspects of Juliet. In embraces that astonish, these lovers embody passion and purity.
The cast plays in splendid harmony. Delicately touched by Donald Holder's lighting, the production is at once spare and sumptuous. After Tuesday's performance, expected titters from the teenagers in the audience during scenes of purposeful physicality alternated with stunned silences and gasps of recognition, as in a scene between Juliet and her mother. Later, Ms. Mann and the cast held a discussion with the students and teachers, who that day represented 11 schools.
Stephen Rowe, who gives a psychologically knowing performance as Capulet, Juliet's father, talked about his own daughter. 
"As parents, we do our best, but sometimes we're not listening to our kids," he said.
Karla Kling, a seventh-grade teacher at Stuart Country Day in Princeton, asked cast members to comment on the broader implications of the play, considering the violence in society today.
Ms. Mann replied that Shakespeare does not say why these families are "out to kill each other." "And it doesn't matter," she added.
She was talking about hate, and about love. Everybody listened and heard. What a morning.

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM; 
Time For theBoomers To Dig In

BYLINE:  By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears on the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
THINGS did not look good. The stock market was down to three-year lows. Many companies were reporting weak earnings and eliminating executive bonuses and hundreds of thousands of jobs. The unemployment rate had climbed to 4.9 percent and consumer spending had slowed.
 That's what the economy looked like before the world stood still on Sept. 11, not that many people can now remember that far back. I can. A friend of mine who had worked for her company for about 10 years was laid off when her company decided to outsource her job. Another friend, thrilled about a job that paid almost two-thirds more than her previous one, lost it when her company let several people go. As if that wasn't bad enough, after she hurriedly scheduled a doctor's appointment before her health insurance ran out, she was told that she had skin cancer. (She is receiving treatment, and has even found another job, but she had to settle for less than her previous salary.) 
 I wasn't hearing those kinds of stories a year ago, and now they may become worse. Previously, conversations were about our wealth and early retirement. My generation was like Snoopy dancing in joy on top of his dog house, head thrown back, not a care in the world. All of that now seems so long ago. The party appears over.
"It certainly feels like it is," said Michael Van Kleeck, a certified financial planner in Beverly Hills, Calif. "All the news is bad, unlike the beginning of 2000 when everything was rosy."
There is no telling how serious the long-term effects of the terrorist attacks will be on our spending and investing habits. Even before the attacks, baby boomers were becoming gloomier. A closer look at the Conference Board's consumer confidence index for August shows that while the index fell to 114.3, from 116.3 in July, the index for people under 35 and those 55 and over actually rose. It's the boomers who became more depressed. Households headed by 35- to 54-year-olds, a category that comprises mostly boomers, fell to 112.3 from 117.8 in July. 
Mr. Van Kleeck said the market decline had already led several of his clients to delay their retirement plans. Last week, though, he saw some signs of hope.
"I've had a few clients say they want to buy stocks to support the cause, but I tell them you never want to do emotional buying and selling," he said. "But it was nice to hear that."
James P. Gerhardt, 58, and his wife, Charlene, 55, of Valencia, Calif., had planned to retire in a few years. But Mr. Gerhardt, a computer programmer, was laid off twice in a year. They had sold a second home, avoided vacations, even cut back on playing golf. Mr. Gerhardt said his investment portfolio was worth about $300,000 in 1999 and rose to about $500,000 at one point last year. This year, he had given most of those gains back. In the days after the attacks, as the markets were closed, he debated what to do with his investments.
"After the disaster, knowing the market was going to take a hit, I was going to move into cash," he said. "But I reconsidered. I made a decision to ride it out and hope for the best."
PAUL ALLEN, 40, of Cortlandt Manor, N.Y., was laid off in early July and found another job by mid-August. But the layoff had been a shock.
"You know, everything is green and green and you're making more money than your parents," said Mr. Allen, a software salesman who works from his home. "You think you can work anywhere as long as you want. I didn't think I would be on the cut list. You never think it's going to be you."
But it has created an opportunity. Last weekend, he received a rollover check from his last company's 401(k) retirement savings account; he plans to put it back into the stock market as soon as the check clears. As the market fell before the attacks, he wondered where the bottom would be. Now, he said, he thinks the market has found it.
"What are you going to do, give up?" he said. "Put all your money into bonds? I want to retire, too."
So here we are, many of us looking over a precipice that wasn't there two weeks ago. As boomers, we have acquired the reputation of being a bit spoiled, a bit too cocky, so I would guess that our critics are watching to see how we now handle ourselves. Our parents dealt with the Great Depression and World War II with dignity and resolve. Now it's our chance to shine.
I'm confident that we will. We were taught by that generation, and if you gouge our surface, I believe you will find their ideals and strength underneath. We are much like our parents, and, because of their example, maybe even better.

HEADLINE: JERSEY FOOTLIGHTS; 
World Trade Center Benefit Concert

BYLINE:  By Karen DeMasters

 BODY:
The Citizens Redevelopment Corporation, a nonprofit economic development group in Asbury Park, and the city's most famous club, the Stone Pony, will sponsor a concert on Sept. 28 to benefit the families of fire, first aid and police officers who lost their lives in the World Trade Center attack. Proceeds will go to the Twin Towers fund set up by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York. 
 Highway Nine, formerly Sam Hill, a pop-rock band based in Asbury Park, will headline the show, which is scheduled to run from 6 to 9 p.m. The group, whose first album is due out in February, will play an acoustic set; local artists will be invited to join them on stage, said Eileen Chapman, a Stone Pony spokeswoman. 
 Admission is $20; tickets can be bought at the door. Anyone bringing a bottle of water, which will be taken to the rescue site in lower Manhattan, will receive a free drink. Karen DeMasters

HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW; 
Priorities In the Wake Of a Shattered Taboo

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
THE terrorist attacks that crippled commerce were unquestionably a defining moment in American history. Out of the horror are likely to come many changes, most of them painful, but a few beneficial. Years of resistance to government spending probably dissolved on Sept. 11. That is beneficial.
 Government spending has always played an essential role in market systems. It is necessary not only in moments of crisis -- like the present one, to rebuild Lower Manhattan or to save the airlines from a calamity beyond their control -- but also in more normal times, to carry out tasks that the private sector shuns. There is no profit in financing the armed forces or airport security or in raising unemployment benefits. 
The list is long and choices have to be made. Now that terrorism has suddenly given federal spending a higher priority than preserving the budget surplus, we have chosen to splurge initially on the military, on airport security, on saving the airlines, on helping New York. These are all worthy choices. But should we stop there?
Definitely not. Neither should we be indiscriminate. Quality, not quantity, is the goal, and there are guidelines. Respectable economic theory holds that government spending, properly directed, lifts the private sector and makes it more useful and profitable. Since the early 1970's, our rhetoric and many of our policies have ignored this synergy. Instead, we have pitted the government and the private sector against each other, with government portrayed as wasteful and inept and the private sector as the efficient source of prosperity and well-being. 
The stock market bubble, now burst, and excessive and profitless business investments, now weighing on the economy, testify that the private sector can go haywire. The enormously damaging terrorist attacks, coming on top of a sinking economy, may convince the public that a successful, enduring market economy requires that government and the private sector march arm in arm. 
"This is a big moment in American history, and the definition of a big moment is that things change, including attitudes toward public spending," said William Kristol, editor of the conservative Weekly Standard.
So some voice should be given to the few experts who have been quietly trying to figure out the most effective government spending. M. Ishaq Nadiri, a New York University economist, is a leader in this research. He would have the federal government spend billions to equip the nation's public schools with computers and Internet connections, thus augmenting human capital. If the installations were extended to state and local government offices, he says, there would be a gain in efficiency. And the flow of revenue would be a lifesaver today for computer manufacturers, software companies and other technology suppliers.
"You will have a fresh foundation for the future growth of these industries, as well as a modernized and more productive public sector," Mr. Nadiri said.
The A.F.L.-C.I.O. is pushing for an improvement in unemployment insurance, which now gives workers who lose their jobs roughly one-third of their old pay for a maximum of 26 weeks. Unemployment pay is increasingly important in a nation that has accepted layoffs as standard corporate practice. Adjusted for inflation, the benefits today are less than they were in the 1960's, and fewer workers are eligible. "The federal government is about to give billions of dollars to the airlines," said Thomas Palley, assistant director for public policy at the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "Surely some of that money should go to the laid-off workers."
MY own favorite for public spending is child care. There are parallels here to airport security. The terrorist attacks have brought people to the realization that airport security cannot be adequate when the security machinery is operated by poorly trained, diffident workers earning only $6 or $7 an hour. The airlines, which are responsible for security, make no profit from it, and turn over the work to subcontractors who profit only by shaving labor quality below acceptable standards.
High-quality child care is similarly profitless. Most families can afford only the low-cost variety. And yet the payoff from quality airport security and quality child care suggests that government money would be well spent -- improving the private sector -- if the subsidies permitted wages of $15 or even $20 an hour, attracting skilled people who took pride in their work.
That is my priority. More important are the priorities that would emerge from public debate. The terrorist attacks, for all their horror, shattered the taboo on government spending. Let us hope that this is a defining moment, as Mr. Kristol suggests, and that the taboo stays gone.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS; 
Susan Blinkhorn, Richard Gallun Jr.

 BODY:
Susan Corinne Blinkhorn and Richard August Gallun Jr., were married in the Adirondacks yesterday. The Rev. Milton Dudley, a Congregational minister, officiated at the Ausable Club in St. Huberts, N.Y.
 The bride, 35, will continue to use her name professionally. She is a freelance writer based in Chicago, specializing in food and travel stories. She graduated from the University of Wisconsin. 
 Her father, Thomas A. Blinkhorn of Washington, retired as a senior manager of the Europe and Central Asia regions for the World Bank. He is now a senior adviser to the bank. Her mother, Lois C. Blinkhorn of Milwaukee, retired as the book editor of The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel.
The bridegroom, 37, is the president and chief executive of bSwift, an online company in Chicago that works with employee benefits. He graduated from Williams College and Harvard Business School. He is a son of Katherine Paulsen of Milwaukee and Mr. Gallun Sr. of Aspen, Colo. His father is the senior vice president for mergers and acquisitions at Fiserv Inc. in Milwaukee.
Ms. Blinkhorn and Mr. Gallun met in November 1998 at a party in New York given by mutual friends.
"I was immediately struck by his rare combination of New York savvy and Midwestern nicety," said Ms. Blinkhorn, who like Mr. Gallun was then a Wisconsinite living in Manhattan. 
But at the end of the evening there was no exchange of numbers. Intrigued by him, Ms. Blinkhorn did a little research and found out the reason: Mr. Gallun had a girlfriend. She also learned that he had accepted a job offer in Chicago.
"I wrote Rich off as another good one who got away," Ms. Blinkhorn remembered.
Then, in May 1999, Mr. Gallun called her to ask a favor. His mother and stepfather, Norman Paulsen, were visiting New York from Milwaukee. Would she accompany him in taking them for a night on the town?
"I was suspicious of being a last-minute date replacement," said Ms. Blinkhorn, who did not know that Mr. Gallun and his girlfriend had by then broken up. "Still, dinner at the Gramercy Tavern and Bobby Short at the Carlyle, that was my kind of favor."
She met Mr. Gallun's party at the restaurant. But Mr. Gallun, who was to arrive straight from the airport, didn't appear for 45 minutes. When he joined the party, he saw that everybody was having a fine time.
"The fact that my mother and her husband were coming to town gave me reason to take the initiative and explore my interest in Susan," he said. "Besides," he added, "I thought they'd make me look good."
As it turned out, Mr. Gallun did not need them to pave the way for him. "At the end of the evening, I still didn't know if it had been an actual date," Ms. Blinkhorn recalled. "But I did know that this was the man I wanted to marry."

HEADLINE: COUNTERINTELLIGENCE; 
The Comfort of Sturgeon

BYLINE:  By Alex Witchel

 BODY:
IN the last two weeks, certainly, dinner parties have not been anyone's priority. They still aren't. But on Thursday night, when Jews across the country break the fast that signals the end of Yom Kippur, families and friends will gather to eat the bagels and smoked fish that customarily mark the occasion. And at 550 of those homes across America, one man will be the caterer: Gary Greengrass of Barney Greengrass in New York.
 This year, what Mr. Greengrass is sending by Federal Express overnight delivery are not just meals, but comfort -- proof that New York is still here and that the food so many people grew up with, food that means family and home and safety, will be on their tables as it always has been. 
 "It's a tradition that people latch onto," Mr. Greengrass said. "We're part of peoples' lives for whom it wouldn't be Yom Kippur without this food. So we're able to touch a lot of lives in a positive way and be there to make a better occasion, a nicer time." 
While many New York restaurants have been half-empty since Sept. 11, only two customers canceled their break-fast orders, Mr. Greengrass said. Because Yom Kippur is a High Holy Day, it will be observed no matter what. "People out of town are sad," he said, "but they've still ordered. This year it seems to have even more meaning to them to have family and friends around them than it has in the past."
In recent years, as American culture became increasingly celebration-happy in a buoyant economy, Yom Kippur, the most solemn day of the Jewish year, has turned, for many, from an intimate family gathering to a more expansive, open-house event. The idea is to kick off the Jewish New Year in style. Mr. Greengrass says his average orders in New York alone are for parties of 20 to 50 people.
But the World Trade Center attack has changed the face of some holiday plans. Barry C. Kleiman of El Cerrito, Calif., expected to have 60 people to his home this year, including his parents, who live in Philadelphia. He now expects 8 to 20. "Everybody here is melancholy," he said. "We can't begin to relate to what people in New York are going through. But getting our Barney package is bonding food for us. It means home, family, roots."
Family is also what defines Barney Greengrass. Founded by Gary's grandfather Barney in 1908, the original store opened in Harlem and moved to its current location at 541 Amsterdam Avenue at 86th Street in 1929. After Barney's death, his son, Moe, took over and is still in residence, though in fragile health. Gary now runs the store, which includes a small restaurant, and he supervises its tonier satellite in Beverly Hills, which opened in 1994 on the fifth floor of Barneys New York.
For the Yom Kippur break-fast, Mr. Greengrass fills 350 advance orders in New York, 75 in Los Angeles (many customers there skip the West Coast store and order direct from New York) and 125 in cities and towns in between as diverse as Savannah; Omaha; Kansas City, Mo.; and one of Mr. Greengrass's favorite addresses, Zephyr Cove, Nev. And that is in addition to the walk-in business in the New York store the day before Yom Kippur, when he usually counts 200 to 300 people.
Ed Levine, in "New York Eats (More)" (St. Martin's Press), writes of the food at Barney Greengrass: "The sturgeon here is a work of art; the smoked salmon is beyond reproach; and the homemade borscht, pickled herring and chopped liver are all first-rate." 
Also first-rate is the store's pristine packaging of its catering orders (white paper separates each slice of cheese, orange juice is fresh squeezed and each cheese blintz is handmade). Mr. Greengrass has been known to pick up the phone the day before Yom Kippur to apologize for the inferior quality of the chubs (baby whitefish) in the market that day, asking permission to substitute regular whitefish, instead.
That personalized service is why Jill Grey, a transplanted New Yorker living in Los Angeles, seeks out Mr. Greengrass. She and her husband, Brad Grey, the chairman of Brillstein-Grey Entertainment, have 60 for their annual gathering and expect to again this year. "We also include business people because there are a lot here working, without their families," Mrs. Grey said. "And the cantor comes to my house to break the fast, just for the sturgeon."
The cantor has good taste. Sturgeon sells for $48 a pound; Eastern nova, the milder, upscale alternative to low-down salty belly lox, is $35 a pound. "We slice 1,500 pounds of nova here," Mr. Greengrass said. "From this little hole in the wall."
Though the Beverly Hills store also fills advance orders (flown in from New York), it doesn't feel the same as New York. For one thing, its menu includes salade nicoise and grilled chicken quesadillas. Mr. Greengrass shrugged. "When in Rome," he said. "Out there it's fancy-shmancy. Here we're just shmancy."
He's right. With its stained wallpaper and linoleum floors, the store's decor conjures Grand Concourse Grandma circa 1940. Mr. Greengrass, 41, who last Thursday wore jeans and a polo shirt with a pen stuck between the buttons, was finally sitting down after the lunch rush. He didn't sit long. The phone kept ringing; not just with orders, but with customers and friends checking in after the trade center attack. Mr. Greengrass's brother, Barney, is a financial consultant at Salomon Smith Barney and works, fortunately, in Midtown. But even Barney, along with Mr. Greengrass's wife, Sharon, the chief financial officer of the Garnet Group, a hedge fund, helps assemble Yom Kippur orders.
"When I was growing up, my parents would come in days before to slice nova," Mr. Greengrass recalled. "The pressure is incomprehensible." For the week prior to the holiday, Mr. Greengrass will work each day until 1 a.m. On Tuesday he will come to the store at 8 a.m., supervise a temporary crew of 30, and go home on Wednesday at 5:30 p.m. He will take a shower and go straight to synagogue, where, he admits, he sometimes dozes. 
Because of the strain, he limits the orders he can take. "I'm just a little guy," he said, smiling. "What I'm knocking my brains out for, Zabar's probably does in an hour. But there's not the personal service we have here."
Scott Goldshine, general manager at Zabar's, says that his store fills 300 to 400 advance orders in New York. But anyone who has ever braved the crowds to shop there the day before Yom Kippur -- not to mention the day of, when the store remains open -- knows that the bulk of the business is walk-in. 
"They have their clientele and we have ours," Mr. Greengrass said. "Our repeat rate is in the high 90 percentile each year. Part of the satisfaction is making people happy, which we've done from generation to generation. It's a tradition I feel an obligation to uphold."
Rhea Isaacs, a native of Minneapolis, is one of many who are grateful. "I have 75 people to my house to break the fast," she said. "I had heard through my sister in New York about Barney Greengrass, and I started there with Gary's father, Moe. This year for the first time I'm also having them send corned beef, pastrami and rye bread because my 87-year-old mother, who was born in New York, asked if they would send a corned beef sandwich too. So, I'm going to make sandwiches that night and give them away as presents to everyone who'll be here." 
Her voice grew tremulous. "We're just lost, a lot of people here," she added. "And this is a way for us to feel connected to New York."

HEADLINE: SHADOWS ACROSS THE CITY; 
Many Buildings Stood Fast on Shaky Ground

BYLINE:  By ERIC LIPTON

 BODY:
THEY mobilized the afternoon of Sept. 11, a team of engineers that now totals more than 200, dispatched across Lower Manhattan to quickly, but responsibly, evaluate the structural soundness of more than 400 buildings near what is known as ground zero.
 The results so far: despite the destruction at the World Trade Center, most surrounding buildings had relatively limited permanent damage, the engineers said. 
 Thousands of windows were blown out, with soot filling offices and apartments. Falling beams and other debris hit a few buildings near the complex, including 140 West Street, 30 West Broadway and 3 World Financial Center. 
But the towers' collapse apparently did not cause enough ground vibration to knock buildings off their foundations or cause walls to move in a permanent or dangerous way, the engineers said. So far, none of the buildings outside the trade center complex have to be demolished, they said.
The New York Times obtained a copy of the city's results; the tally is preliminary and does not include all buildings that have been checked.
Buildings with limited structural damage could be closed for up to a year, although any estimate is difficult. Those that merely need cleaning and new windows could be closed for several months or up to a year. Others with little or no damage could open sooner. 
Much of this will depend on how long the trade center cleanup takes, and how that will affect access to other buildings. Engineers involved in the inspections expressed relief that the damage to other buildings was not as severe as it might have been. "This will enable a much faster schedule for the rebuilding and revitalization of the downtown area," said Richard Tomasetti, president of LZA/Thornton-Tomasetti, the lead engineering consultant, which is working with the Structural Engineers Association of New York on assessing the buildings. ERIC LIPTON

LENGTH: 1612 words

HEADLINE: High Society Goes Low Key: A Hard Time for Galas 

BYLINE:  By RUTH LA FERLA

 BODY:
SEPTEMBER is traditionally the month when New York's young swans, stalwart matrons and showiest donors dust off their ball gowns and begin to formulate strategy, focusing on concerns no more pressing than what to wear when vamping for the cameras, how best to burnish their social profiles and, in some cases, how to meet Mr. Right.
 But since the attack on the World Trade Center, New York's gilded set has reassessed those priorities or, for a time, has stowed them away. Some plan to stay home. Others who say they will attend the galas that stretch through December and then resume next spring are approaching them with unaccustomed gravity. 
 "I think coming out of this disaster first of all is a serious sense of charity," said Paul Wilmot, a New York fashion and society publicist. "Instead of 'Oh, I've got to go to this dinner at the Pierre -- so-and-so, my friend, is chair,' " he said with mock exasperation, "I think you'll find people will be much more dedicated, will stop looking at these things with such a jaundiced eye." 
And even for those still intent on doing well by doing good, Mr. Wilmot predicted, "recent events will take away some of the fluff that surrounds these charitable evenings."
"This is not the time for cynics," he said. 
Already, traditional events have been hard hit. Of more than a dozen planned before the disaster, at least six have been canceled or postponed. Those that vanished include a benefit for the Museum of Modern Art, a Ronald McDonald House dinner planned for October and a cocktail party given by Louis Vuitton and the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center as a curtain-raiser for the center's annual gala next May. "We had to make decisions," said Muffie Potter Aston, a planner of the party. "At the time, it seemed highly inappropriate to go forward with this kind of event."
For the engineers of Manhattan's premier galas, the customary obsessing over timing, menus, guest lists and decor has yielded to the more sober issue of whether many scheduled benefits can, or should, take place at all.
"The legs of the social season are a little wobbly," conceded Guy Regal, an antiques dealer who held a reception in his East 60th Street store Thursday night to honor the Lenox Hill Neighborhood House's shelter for homeless women.
The cocktail party, which heralds a benefit tour of Lower Manhattan homes to take place on Oct. 3, raised about $30,000 in pledges. "But it was hard to look ahead," Mr. Regal said, "too early to determine the future of an event that is not directly related to aiding fire, police and rescue workers and the victims' families."
Directly related events have been added in haste to the season's schedule, among them a Merchants New York East Side benefit for the United Way's Sept. 11 fund last Tuesday, and a cocktail benefit for relatives of lost Cantor-Fitzgerald employees and of firefighters last Thursday.
In addition, four major networks capitalized on their large audience last Friday by broadcasting "TV Helpline," a telethon celebrity benefit.
Since New York has always abhorred a vacuum -- especially the sort left by a string of cancellations -- the party will have to go on.
"In New York, the benefit world fills a particular need," said Simone Martel, an event planner. "Benefits to us in the 90's and the new millennium have replaced the Stork Clubs or El Moroccos of the 50's and the discos of the 80's. Benefits are the occasion when different communities interface," she said. "Otherwise New York is a really splintered place."
Anna Wintour, editor of Vogue, added, "People are not feeling like a big-time extravaganza, but they will go out." She is an organizer of one of the city's most lustrous events, the New Yorkers for Children gala, at Cipriani 42nd Street, to benefit the city's foster children, which was held Wednesday night.
"Parties will be more low-key," she predicted. "They will be very straightforward, appropriate for the time -- less about the social connotations and more about the charity." 
As Debbie Bancroft, a New York society figure, put it, "I wouldn't be surprised if we started going to quieter, more meaningful events." Ms. Bancroft, a board member of New Yorkers for Children, added, "In times like these, a sense of community is very important and people need support more than ever."
Stacey Palmer, editor of the Chronicle of Philanthropy, said she had noticed signs that people were thinking beyond their own immediate concerns.
"I think people are starting to ponder their own mortality and what kind of legacy they are going to leave," she said.
Many events still on the schedule in the coming weeks will be scaled down, with dancing, fancy dress and elaborate decor ruled out, and funds diverted to relief-related causes.
Old Guard institutions like the Metropolitan Opera have set the tone. The opera, whose official grand opening tomorrow night usually includes a seated dinner, canceled the meal. It also staged a dress rehearsal to benefit the families of victims, rescue and relief workers. The event was sold out. 
Still, planners coping with practical details found uncertainty epidemic last week. Carnegie Hall, which will hold its benefit dinner on Oct. 3, decided to donate a part of the proceeds to disaster relief.
Similarly, Tim Landi, vice president for external affairs of the New York Botanical Garden, said he and fellow planners had been doubtful about proceeding with an event planned for Tuesday.
"We wrestled for a time about whether to cancel our annual Rose Garden Dinner Dance," he said, "but decided to go on." The botanical garden will contribute all visitors' fees next weekend to a variety of disaster relief funds.
And the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals likewise decided to move forward, holding its charity gala last Thursday night at Doubles, a private club in the Sherry Netherlands Hotel. Part of the proceeds, originally designated for indigent pet owners, went instead to the A.S.P.C.A.'s newly formed Animal Disaster Relief Fund, for the rescue of pets abandoned in the crisis.
When the season's most feverishly anticipated evening, the New Yorkers for Children gala, for 720, went ahead on Wednesday night, it got a jolt of adrenaline when Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani appeared, to wild cheers and applause. The gross, about $800,000, went as planned to the city's programs for foster children.
Many guests found the evening overwhelmingly moving. "I thought there was an extraordinary atmosphere," said Oscar de la Renta, who organized the event with Ms. Wintour, Shelby Bryan and the actress Sarah Jessica Parker.
"When at the close we all sang 'God Bless America,' I could see tears in the eyes of a lot of people," Mr. de la Renta said. "For one time, it really didn't matter what people were wearing."
But Patrick McCarthy, chairman and editorial director of W, found the mood subdued. "There isn't the roar that customarily greets you on these evenings," Mr. McCarthy said, predicting that the muted atmosphere -- hushed conversations, monochromatic lighting, pristine white-on-white decor -- would be echoed at future galas. "There is no other tone," Mr. McCarthy said. "It's nice to get back to a bit of normalcy, but I do feel we will approach these events with some kind of temperance."
The soberness at the New Yorkers for Children gala also reflected widespread concern about whether the generosity would last, particularly for causes not directly related to the disaster. The consensus was that it was too soon to tell. 
"Nobody is asking for money right now -- at least none of my clients," said Toni Goodale, a society figure and chairwoman of Goodale Associates, which consults and raises money for clients that include Beth Israel Hospital, the International Center of Photography and Temple Emanu-El.
"In the short term, people have been very generous," said Dr. Larry M. Hawk, the president of the A.S.P.C.A., who attended his group's gala on Thursday night despite the death of his sister, Kathleen Nicosia, aboard American Airlines Flight 11, which crashed into the north tower.
Dr. Hawk acknowledged that for many charities it would not be business as usual. "There is a great concern about the effect on the economy -- the effect that this disaster will have on all nonprofits across the board," he said.
He told the guests at the dinner: "We're all being impacted by this tragedy. I'm flying tomorrow, unfortunately, to my sister's memorial service. I will not let it interrupt my life. I hope you will do the same." 
Yet interruption is inevitable. "There is a feeling that it's inappropriate to be asking people for things that are not related to the relief effort -- college alumni funds, hospitals, the lot," Stacey Palmer of the Chronicle of Philanthropy said. "We're getting calls asking: 'What should we do? What are other people doing?' Charities are in a hard place."
Allison Stern, organizer of a springtime benefit for the Wildlife Conservation Society, which runs the Bronx Zoo, acknowledged that she had reached an impasse. "Some of the calls I put out, I made before the disaster," she said. "I think a lot of people will support our event, but right now the committee is at a standstill."
Yet few charities have the luxury of abandoning their efforts. "A lot of the smaller organizations derive 85 percent of their revenues from these benefits," Ms. Goodale said. "If you stop the galas, you stop operations for the whole year."
But she did acknowledge how daunting it could be to try to carry on. "I don't want to call people back just yet -- not for at least a couple of weeks. People are still grieving," she said with a sigh. "I just can't make these calls anymore."
