SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 6

LENGTH: 1440 words

HEADLINE: Business; 
Corporate Planes: Perks or Necessities?

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD

DATELINE: WATERFORD, Mich. 

 BODY:
THE TRANSATLANTIC STAR, a 70-seat Airbus jet, is a conspicuous symbol of the 1998 merger that formed DaimlerChrysler, shuttling managers twice a week between the company's offices near here and Stuttgart, Germany.
 If there was any complaining about the expense of the plane and its pampered passengers, however, it is not heard now. The Star, which DaimlerChrysler parks at an airport in this suburb northwest of Detroit, has vindicated itself as a valuable corporate tool. 
 The hijackings by suicide terrorists on Sept. 11 paralyzed much of the commercial airline industry. But they also injected a huge dose of adrenaline into the already energized world of business aviation -- the fleets of private jets that corporate executives have been using increasingly in recent years. In the aftermath of the attacks, many corporations are expected to rely even more heavily on private planes -- through leases, purchases and fractional ownership deals that work like vacation time shares. 
"The issue of a heightened sense of security and safety certainly makes this mode of transportation more attractive to many people," said Jim Holcombe, senior vice president for marketing at the Gulfstream Corporation, a leading manufacturer of corporate jets that is based in Savannah, Ga.
William Curtis, chief executive of CurtCo Robb Media of Acton, Mass., publisher of The Robb Report, a monthly magazine about luxury products and services, said, "Companies are going to decide this is the time to have a jet."
More than 9,317 companies already own at least one jet, a 40 percent increase in the last 10 years, said the National Business Aviation Association, a trade group based in Washington. The number of planes used for business aviation has increased by two-thirds in that period, to 14,079.
Until Sept. 11, companies most often cited convenience as a reason for buying jets. "It's become a necessary business tool to be able to do business in a fast-paced economy," Mr. Holcombe said. 
Commercial air travel certainly costs less -- and may soon be even cheaper as airlines, desperate for customers, slash fares. But Mr. Holcombe and other representatives of private jet travel contend that price should not be a consideration. With a private jet, Mr. Holcombe said, "you can go when you want to go, and leave when you want to leave."
DaimlerChrysler's three planes -- it has two Gulfstream V jets in addition to the Airbus -- sit in a hangar 15 minutes from its operations in Auburn Hills, Mich. It takes 45 minutes to drive to Detroit Metropolitan Airport, the area's main airport.
Corporate jets are often regarded as perks of top executives, but 86 percent of the users are senior and middle managers, the business aviation association said. These jets can save many wasted hours that managers spend in airports, waiting for delayed flights, because the jets also are convenient places for meetings and allow officials to focus on work, said Jack Olcott, the association's president. "A business airplane is an office that moves," he said.
Moreover, it is an office that provides a level of passenger security that commercial airlines may not be able to match. "It is one of the safest forms of travel in the world," Mr. Olcott said. "You know who your pilot is, what's on board the aircraft, who's on board the aircraft." Often, security and customs officials at airports know pilots and passengers of private jets by name, because the same people fly so often.
That does not mean corporate jets are exempt from government scrutiny. Like commercial jets, private planes were grounded for two days after the terrorist attacks at the World Trade Center and the Pentagon. As of last week, a ban on private planes within 25 miles of the capital remained in force. If anything, security officials are taking extra precautions with executive jets.
Last week, passengers on DaimlerChrysler's Airbus jet waited two and a half hours in Stuttgart as police and border guards searched their plane, accompanied by bomb-sniffing dogs. Each piece of hand baggage was searched, said Michael Aberlich, a company spokesman. He said it was the first time he could recall such tight security at the company's private terminal.
For companies that do not want to buy planes outright, an increasingly popular option is fractional ownership of jet aircraft. The plans are somewhat like vacation time shares. They offer companies a share of a plane and provide pilots and crews.
The idea was conceived in 1986 by Executive Jet Inc., based in Woodbridge, N.J., and owned by Warren Buffett, the multibillionaire chief executive of Berkshire Hathaway. The concept was slow to catch on; only three customers signed up initially. But the robust economy of the mid-1990's, coupled with a boom in travel, led to a vast expansion. In 2000, there were 3,694 fractional owners of business aircraft, according to the business aircraft association.
Executive Jet's fractional-ownership clients range from celebrities like Tiger Woods to businesses like General Electric, Seagram, Texaco and Dow Chemical. 
Some companies that would like to have their own jets are resorting to fractional ownership because of the long wait to buy planes. Someone placing an order today for a Gulfstream V, which costs $42.5 million, might wait 12 to 15 months for delivery, Mr. Holcombe said. Even before Sept. 11, he said, Gulfstream had seen a surge in interest from people and companies for jets. 
Bombardier, the aircraft maker based in Montreal, has a three- to three-and-a-half-year waiting list for its new flagship plane, the $42 million Global Express, which can fly 14 hours nonstop, said Leo Knappen, a company spokesman.
In contrast, a fractional-ownership contract can be completed in days or weeks, depending on how many hours a company needs each year, and the planes it wants.
The least expensive contract at Executive Jet, which offers 12 types of planes, starts at $375,000 a year. That buys one-sixteenth of a Citation V, which seats eight people, and 50 hours of actual flying time, not the time spent waiting on the ground before or after the flight. Fifty hours would be the equivalent of 25 round trips for eight people between Boston and Washington. Besides that expense, companies pay a monthly management fee of $5,000, which covers insurance, the cost of pilot training and flight crews' salaries. Then there is a $1,325-an-hour occupation fee for using the plane, which, at 50 hours a year, comes out to just over $66,000 a year. The total annual cost for such a contract would be about $500,000.
Despite the price, Executive Jet has been signing up six to eight new customers a month and plans to expand its fleet of jets to about 1,000 by 2005, from 380 now, said Kevin Mitchell, senior vice president for marketing. Most customers sign up for 100 to 200 hours a year, drawing from a roster of 1,800 pilots that includes 10 past crewmen on Air Force One.
Others are competing for the same business, including FlexJet, a six-year-old company started by Bombardier, which has a fleet of 100 planes that will soon include the Global Express; and Raytheon, which has a fleet of about 100 aircraft. Despite a financial crisis caused in part by the downing of two of its jets in the terrorist hijackings, the UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, is adhering to plans, announced in June, to enter business aviation in 2002, with a subsidiary called United BizJet Holdings.
United BizJet will take delivery of the first of 200 planes next April, said Steven R. Fushelberger, its vice president for marketing. Some industry analysts are concerned that United BizJet will take away business from United Airlines, particularly in first and business class, areas where airlines still make money. "What I would want to hear from them is that they are going to treat the passenger who pays $5,000 differently than the person who pays $500," said Mr. Curtis, the Robb Report publisher.
OTHERS say the trend toward business aviation will subside as stricter security precautions at airports become routine and as passengers regain confidence in commercial airlines. Incentives like extra frequent-flier miles and airport club membership deals are likely to be offered to affluent travelers. "The airlines will try to keep these people," said Raymond Neidl, aviation analyst at the ABN Amro investment bank.
But, given the growth in business aviation, Mr. Fushelberger said, there are opportunities for his company, and others, to attract newcomers. "A lot of the low-hanging fruit has been picked, but look at the entrepreneurs, look at the executives and look at the travel they do," he said.

DaimlerChrysler has found that its jet fleet, based near its offices, above, in Auburn Hills, Mich., has become a valuable tool. PUB-DATE: September 23, 2001
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 14; Column 2; The City Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2826 words

HEADLINE: SHADOWS ACROSS THE CITY; 
Nine Miles Away

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ; Additional reporting was provided by Seth Kugel, along with Denny Lee, Tara Bahrampour and Jim O'Grady.

 BODY:
NINE miles lie between the World Trade Center and Highbridge, a Bronx neighborhood of 34,000 just north of Yankee Stadium. The streets here are a jumble of bright sunflowers, broken glass, six-story brick apartment buildings, neat row houses and sagging porches. An occasional rooster pecks at the sidewalks, most of which are cracked with weeds.
 By other measures, Highbridge seems more distant from the city's financial core. Although once a solidly middle-class neighborhood, Highbridge has a median family income of $20,700, compared with $48,200 citywide. The unemployment rate is nearly three times the city average. Nearly 40 percent of families in Highbridge are headed by single mothers. The neighborhood, once mostly Jewish and Irish Catholic, is largely Dominican and Puerto Rican. Most other residents are black. 
 News of the terrorist attack on the World Trade Center struck some Highbridge residents like news of another country. They could see smoke pluming in the sky, but the intimacy of the tragedy reached them by television. Others in the neighborhood witnessed the sick, hard rain of terror firsthand. Still others have yet to come home. 
But the story of how the attack on the twin towers rolled through this stretch of New York begins the same way it began at ground zero: with the clear blue of an average late-summer morning.
Tuesday, Sept. 11, 2001, started with the usual pilgrimages.
At 7:15 Al Smith looked out the window of his third-floor apartment on Anderson Avenue and called out to Gilbert Ruiz, who was on his way to work in the kitchen of Windows on the World. 
"Have a good one, man," Mr. Smith shouted as he waved goodbye.
At 8, Abdoulaye Kone, a pastry chef at Windows on the World, called his wife, Celestine, from work. Mr. Kone, who is from the Ivory Coast, told her he loved her and asked her to call him later to let him know how the children were doing.
At 8:30, the students at the Family Life Academy Charter School in the Latino Pastoral Action Center gathered for their morning assembly.
Then, at 8:48, the day abruptly changed.
A custodian from the Pastoral Action Center who had stayed home from work called in to report that a plane had crashed into the trade center. Isabel Gutierrez, director of the school, was in the assembly when her secretary told her the news. 
"I didn't say anything," Ms. Gutierrez said a few days later. "I did not want to alarm the teachers because they were dealing with the kids."
Dana Gerendasi, 26, a new teacher at the school, led her first graders back to their classroom. When she checked her cellphone messages just after 9:30, she heard her husband say: "Dana, it's me. I don't know if you heard, but two planes went into the World Trade Center, and ----" Then he was cut off.
After Mrs. Kone, the pastry chef's wife, took her son and daughter to school, she came home and turned on the television set. She saw an airplane crash into the building where her husband worked. "I immediately got on the train and I walked from 14th Street there," she said.

The Same Conversation, All Over the Neighborhood
By midmorning, Highbridge was strangely still. Delivery trucks did not bang down the pitted streets. The skies were silent. The salsa music that typically spills from windows could be heard only occasionally.
People pooled on street corners. One vast, dispersed conversation settled over the neighborhood. The words seemed familiar -- airplanes and television, God and war -- but the situation did not.
In this strangely focused public discussion, some turned to private metaphor.
"All I could think about was my video game, because that's the way I'd play it," said Glenn Wilson, 23, a construction worker who spent the morning with friends in front of the A&N Deli and Grocery on Ogden Avenue, listening for news. "I know strategic warfare. The Pentagon? That's the defense right there. The twin towers? You take out the money, how you going to build up? The next is transportation."
Police officers told business owners around 170th Street and Jerome Avenue to close up and go home. Jack An stayed because his liquor store is encased by bulletproof glass.
Members of a construction crew working at the Pastoral Action Center listened to the news in Spanish on their radios. The only television in the building was tuned to Univision, the Spanish channel. But Ms. Gerendasi, the first-grade teacher, does not speak Spanish. Her cellphone was not working.
"I couldn't even teach because I had to go out and keep crying," she said. She tried to stay calm. She told her charges: "Everything is fine. Your parents will explain everything to you."
News trickled into the school as parents picked up their children. Ms. Gerendasi heard that the United States Supreme Court had been bombed. The Pentagon was gone. Camp David had been bombed. The White House and the Empire State Building were next. The reservoirs were poisoned.
She hugged the children. She hugged the parents. She said she hoped to see them again. Then she went home to her husband.
The flow of people going home to Highbridge quickened in the late afternoon. Lucy Garcia, 50, an assistant manager of sales at J. P. Morgan Chase, arrived about 4, after a seven-hour walk. When the first plane hit, she had run out of her office at 5 World Trade Center and looked up at the sky.
"I saw this man falling," she said, her voice breaking. "It was so sad because as you see him falling from the window you see these little faces looking out the window. I was going: 'God have mercy on him. Jesus, please help that man.' He's like a little rag doll just falling out the window."
Ms. Garcia ran to a nearby post office to call her family. The phones didn't work. She took refuge in St. Peter's, a Roman Catholic church on Barclay Street.
"People were bleeding in church," she said. "St. Peter's was full." She and some co-workers bought sandals in Chinatown for the long walk north.
All day long, information flowed through Highbridge, an anxious breeze of truth and rumor: It was a goof. The pilot had a heart attack. My cousin didn't go to work. My father did. Two Arabs got stabbed. My baby came home. The roads were rivers of people. I walked and I walked and I walked. This is World War III.
Dark men came home white with ash. 
"I was white," said David Morales, who was delivering flowers on Church Street in Lower Manhattan when the first tower fell. "If I had had an Afro, I would have looked like Michael Jackson."
The Bronx suddenly seemed safer than Manhattan. Some people were afraid to leave. 
"I don't feel the Bronx is going to be hit, because the Bronx is full of poor people," said Sandra Joyner, who was shooting pool at the Equator Lounge on 170th Street.
Money didn't seem to matter anymore. But for some, race did.
"What about the Palestinians or the Koreans?" said a man who gave his name only as Leonard. "What about the Arabs? Since they're ready to die, what makes us think they aren't ready to blow up their own stores?"
Khalid Ahmad, 50, who works at the A&N Deli, had come to the United States from Yemen 30 years ago. Tuesday evening, a group of young men including Edison Alcantar walked into the deli and demanded of Mr. Ahmad, "You happy about what happened today?"
"I really went in there because they're Arabic," Mr. Alcantar said later. "To see what was on their mind. If they had been happy, I would have snuffed them."
Mr. Ahmad replied: "I told them you better watch your language because I'm an American. What am I going to be happy for?"
"Everybody comes from outside," he added, "and in America they live like a king. They come naked, and they make a living. America is the best country in the world. God bless America."
The day ended with a thick yellow sunset. The southern sky was scarred with smoke. Mr. Kone, the pastry chef, did not come home. Mr. Ruiz, who also worked at Windows on the World, did not stop by the San Miguel Superette to gather things for dinner, as was his custom. At 8:30, his son, Gilbert Ruiz Jr., taped a note to his father's door: "Pops. I was here to see you. I was worrying about you at the job. Call me. I hope you're all right. Your son. Love you, G. Ruiz Jr."
At 170th Street and Jerome Avenue, 50 people gathered in the darkness to pray.
"In the midst of this turbulence, this chaos, there is hope," said the Rev. Evenecer Martinez. "Governments offer their own hope, but our hope is in Christ. Let's make another cry for those who are suffering. New York is in mourning."
They pressed their palms to the sky and said: Come, Jesus! We are walking in the end of times.

The Aftershock Curls Its Way Through
Tomorrow came. Absence curled its way slowly through the neighborhood. Nearly everyone knew someone who had been touched, but often the connections were once or twice removed. It turned out that neighbors, cousins of friends, in-laws and acquaintances were missing. A woman from Sacred Heart Church on Shakespeare Avenue had not shown up for Mass, but no one knew her last name or her phone number.
For a few, absence cut closer. On Wednesday, Mrs. Kone and Gilbert Ruiz Jr. followed what would become a well-worn path: St. Vincent's, Bellevue, N.Y.U. Beth Israel, the Armory. They found nothing.
In the Jerome Avenue subway station, where the No. 4 train stops, rush hour was unrushed. People scratched their heads before a white board dense with service changes. They asked how to get to St. Vincent's and how to get to Brooklyn. At 8:45 a.m., the token booth clerk, Vanessa Halsey, had sold only $500 worth of fares. On a typical day, she would have sold $1,000 to $1,500.
Virginia Unisex beauty salon on Ogden Avenue was filled with talk of the tragedy.
Virginia Molina, who runs the shop, had spoken with her mother in the Dominican Republic. "My mother said she no longer wants to come here," she said. "They don't have this kind of problem in the Dominican Republic."
But Ms. Molina would not consider moving. "We are here in this country, which has supported us when we have most needed it," she said. "We are not going to run away."
Business was down 40 percent at the B&N Deli, 30 percent at Mr. An's liquor store on Jerome Avenue. But One Hour Photo Express, a few doors down, was doing well. Images of ash, twisted metal and rubble rolled through the processing machine. Pem Tenzin and his brother, Yashi Pelden, the owners, from Bhutan, said they had developed 50 percent more film than usual.
Newspapers sold out. A local funeral parlor went on standby.
On Thursday, the paralysis began to lift. Normal life had become an act of patriotism. People tried to work. Ms. Halsey, the token booth clerk, became hoarse explaining the changes in service. MetroCard sales were still down by 30 percent.
Schools reopened. En route to the Family Life Academy aboard the No. 2 train, Ms. Gerendasi sat near four Arabs. Everyone was staring at them. Then one of their cellphones rang. "Everybody screamed," she said. "I screamed because everyone else screamed."
Her first graders spent an hour talking about the tragedy. "I'm trying to teach them that it's O.K. to feel sad," she said.
She asked them what they wanted to be when they grew up. They answered: Firefighter. Policeman. Doctor. Hero.
The children drew pictures. Karina drew a tall building with an airplane crashing into it. Six faceless figures floated around the building. "Those are the people who died," she said. She also drew glittering red hearts. When asked why, she replied, "For God's love."
The firehouse of Battalion 17 on Ogden Avenue was draped with black and purple bunting. American flags blossomed. Olga Rodriguez bought one for her Delicioso Coco Helado cart. Bolivar Peguero hung one on his hot-dog and pastelito stand.
"Before this happened, I would have been surprised to see an American flag," said Denae Brewer, editor in chief of The Highbridge Horizon, a bilingual newspaper. "The Puerto Rican flags fly high. The Dominican flags fly high. But not American flags."
At 12:48 p.m. Thursday, El Cheapo Depot on Jerome Avenue sold its last American flag for $1.99.
"We are not the epitome of patriotism," said the Rev. Raymond Rivera, president of the Pastoral Action Center. "We're always talking about the government and how they lack resources for people of color, so usually I'm on the other side. But there was something about this week that made you think twice about that and really appreciate in this unprovoked attack some of the freedoms that we have."
Across the street from El Cheapo Depot, Mildred Smith, who worked in the financial district as an administrative assistant for Verizon, sat drinking a Bacardi and Coke in the Equator Lounge. She had seen people jumping out of the windows holding hands. "It was like rain," she said. She had seen the second plane hit. "It looked like a big black bird, she said. "It looked like death."
"It's something that happened," she said. "I had nothing to do with it, so I can't dwell on it in my mind. People I know got out."
Thursday night, Sacred Heart Church held a vigil for those who didn't get out. Mrs. Kone, who lives just down the street, happened to be walking by when she saw people gathering in the courtyard. Relieved to find she was not alone in her grief, she joined them for the Rosary. "I thought I was the only one on the block," she said.
Friday afternoon, Gilbert Ruiz Jr. went to the apartment building on West 165th Street, where his father had lived for more than a decade, to collect photographs and DNA samples. But Wallace Cooke, the landlord, would not let him in. "He could have been anybody with an ID, like those guys that got on the plane," the landlord said. "I could get sued for millions of dollars. I want my sons to own this building."
At 8 p.m., Mr. Ruiz was still standing on the street, talking to neighbors. A woman said that when her father died, she got into his apartment without incident. But Mr. Ruiz's father was not dead. He was just gone. "I'm next in line," said the son. "I'm junior. I'm supposed to lead the family now. I can't even do that."
One of his sisters had been beaten to death at the end of August. He was shaking.
"The world's in trouble right now," he said. The neighbors began to cry.

'Faith Is the Substance Of Things Hoped For'
The weekend came. Men called on God. 
"The world loves us with a cold kind of love," the Rev. Billy Jackson said on Sunday at the Second Southern Baptist Church on Jesup Avenue. "Loves us with unkindness. Loves us with not a gentle love but a love that's horrible. It is not a love from heaven."
Amad Igbara, a Palestinian who came to America 10 years ago and who, with his brothers, owns five stores in Highbridge, said: "Now everybody thinks all the Palestinians are terrorists. That's not good for us in the United States." He said he planned to take his wife and three children out to dinner last Sunday. It would be their first trip out of the house since the attack. "If anything happens," he said, "that's from God."
The routines of daily life reasserted themselves, sometimes from instinct, sometimes from despair.
"I understand life must go on, but the day it happened people were coming in to look for money to pay their rent," said Ms. Brewer, the editor of the local paper, which shares an office with the Highbridge Community Life Center. "It disappointed me."
Mrs. Kone swept leaves and garbage from the gutter in front of her apartment. Her husband stared out from "Missing" posters in her windows and at bus stops and storefronts. He did not come home.
A police office and a locksmith let Mr. Ruiz into his father's apartment. He left with his father's comb, hairbrush, toothbrush and toenail clippings.
Talk in Virginia Unisex beauty parlor shifted to lost jobs, Middle Eastern politics and sleeplessness. Local businesses like Mr. An's liquor store continued to suffer. 
"I don't know if I can pay rent this month," Mr. An said. "Usually by this time I'm very busy, but see what I'm doing here? Reading books."
Your's and Our's Cocktail Lounge had a wedding reception. The bride and groom walked over rose petals. People cheered. Flashbulbs popped. The bride's mother called for a moment of silence for the victims. The owner of the bar had lost his sister-in-law on the 84th floor of Tower 2. He sat quietly beneath the balloons.
Early last week, Mr. Ruiz's body was identified. He was buried on Thursday at St. Raymond's cemetery in the East Bronx.
Mr. Kone is still missing. None of his co-workers on the morning shift have come home.
"We believe he is alive because God makes miracles," said Mrs. Kone, whose husband was Muslim. "God's going to bring him out one way or another."
Other people waited too. They waited for war. They waited for peace. They waited for absence to ripen into death. They waited for the damage to be undone.
But the southern sky stayed empty. The smoke was gone. Nothing took its place.
In church, a pastor clutched his Bible. "Now faith is the substance of things hoped for," he read. "The evidence of things not seen."

 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 3; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 12

LENGTH: 1169 words

HEADLINE: PORTFOLIOS, ETC.; 
A Forecaster's Art Takes a Sharp Turn

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
LOUIS CRANDALL is slow to change his mind.
 It wasn't until he was inching his way down the stairs from the 25th floor of 1 World Trade Center that he decided: "Gosh darn it, I was not going to take the Delta Shuttle to Washington this afternoon. I was taking Amtrak." 
 When he got to the sixth floor, where the sprinklers were working, he said, "My socks got wet and I actually began to realize that I wasn't even taking Amtrak."
Mr. Crandall, who turned 43 the day after the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, is president and chief economist at Wrightson Associates. It is a six-member research firm that casts a respected eye on Federal Reserve policy and the Treasury market, makes economic forecasts and plays regularly in the game of predicting what economic reports will say. 
All his employees survived, but the destruction of his offices and many of the computer tools he used is making him change his mind about how he runs his business. The same is true for hundreds of other executives and companies.
Wrightson is coping with its own crisis by working to get the business back up. But Mr. Crandall sees a difficult time ahead for forecasters and, therefore, investors -- and not just because the immediate outlook is grim.
The attack on the world's financial capital, he said, has pushed the economy into unpredictable territory, rendering it nearly impossible to make intelligent use of the economic data for September and October and, maybe, even later in the year.
So even if he were publishing now, his stodgy computer-driven spreadsheets and 20 years of annotated notes on Federal Reserve policy meetings (all of which were lost) would be of little help and his routine of predicting economic indicators would be upset.
Speaking of forecasters, he said, "We have less value because we don't know what the numbers ought to say right now."
He added, "In this extraordinary emotional state, you can't draw many conclusions about what this particular number means about the broader economy and about trends going forward."
The uncertainty will make stock and bond markets more volatile and hazarding reasonable guesses about the future very difficult. Even how the financial markets would respond to an attack on the terrorists who did this is uncertain.
"The emotion of the tragedy will affect the numbers, but we don't know how," he said in an interview a week and a day after the tragedy. "Then that initial response will change, and so will the impact on the numbers."
Mr. Crandall has no choice but to change. His cherished routines and his old machines were all destroyed, and Wrightson, he said, can no longer be what it was: "a product that evolved very gradually for the last 23 years." 
It may not sound like much, but the loss of his antiquated spreadsheets and other forecasting tools will give Wrightson the opportunity to rebuild them in a much more useful form. He will review the format of his weekly newsletter and his daily online service. He will add real-time bond and money market prices to the Wrightson Web site.
"Even the extra congestion on New York City highways, making it harder for commuters in our firm to get in, is making us look at ways to build a virtual office," he said.
"This is getting a lot of people out of their ruts."
Such reassessments are being made around the country. "This does force a lot of people to think about how we are doing things, and once you do that, you think of things more than those related to the World Trade Center," said Richard F. Syron, chairman and chief executive of the Thermo Electron Corporation in Waltham, Mass. "You think of things you would not have thought of before," like smoothing out the company's shipment schedules.
IN the long run, these retoolings and refinements of businesses could help the economy by improving productivity and cutting costs. "Obviously, there are huge temporary short-term negatives and long-term negatives from this," Mr. Crandall said. "But in cold-blooded economic terms, this is one of the positives."
In the near term, the economic outlook is grim, which means third- and fourth-quarter corporate earnings will be down even more than expected two weeks ago.
"If we are lucky, were are back to a V" pattern for the economy, he said. The V pattern is based on the idea that the shock from the tragedy will send economic growth plunging as consumers stop spending and production is disrupted. But if those interruptions are temporary, the stage will be set for a sharp rebound, completing the second leg of the V, when the expected huge increases in government spending, and possibly more tax cuts, kick in.
Then the rally part of the V could give stocks a lift. As for interest rates, an end to the economic decline would probably send them higher, especially at the short end.
But Mr. Crandall said that if the consumer spending remained weak until the end of the year, there was less of a case for a V-shaped rebound, and "underlying attitudes may have been changed permanently."
Yet, he added, "I am no less optimistic than I was," even though he said he had learned that there was "more scope" for unpredictable events.
As of now, Mr. Crandall has no vehicle for distributing his views. He received new laptop computers on Friday and hopes to begin producing the weekly Money Market Observer sometime this week. While some people are working from home, Mr. Crandall and other of his colleagues are in a temporary office on Fifth Avenue, at 47th Street, at a company called Numerix, a partner with ICAP, the money and bond market broker that owns Wrightson. (ICAP was also in 1 World Trade Center and is now operating from temporary offices in Manhattan and New Jersey.) 
Because he doesn't think that he and other forecasters will be able to say much that is constructive about economic data for several months, Mr. Crandall will spend his time examining the outlook for the Treasury market as the government surplus shrinks and maybe disappears.
But he is still itching to print the next guess on what the unemployment rate will be in September and how many jobs will be lost.
"Who am I kidding?" he laughed, remembering that he said his analysis would not be worthwhile. "I have been forecasting the monthly unemployment rate for a couple of decades now. When I see the calendar getting to the end of the month, I cannot avoid looking at that."
The data will certainly not be as easy to interpret as what Mr. Crandall saw on the 12th floor of the World Trade Center, where he and many of the escaping workers stopped when they smelled diesel fumes in the stairwell and thought the way out might be blocked. "We got to a place where a TV was working, saw what the top of the building looked like and turned around and headed right back to the stairwell," he said.
When he left the tower, he went toward home. The Brooklyn Bridge was too crowded. He headed toward the Manhattan Bridge and made it home to Cobble Hill, Brooklyn, about two hours later. By then, the twin towers were gone.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
New Offices, Mixed Emotions at Fund Companies

BYLINE:  By REED ABELSON and ELIZABETH HARRIS

 BODY:
CHARLES ALBERS and Nikolaos Monoyios spent last week setting up the computer systems needed to manage their portfolios from makeshift quarters in central New Jersey, their temporary home after their offices at the headquarters of OppenheimerFunds were destroyed in the attack on the World Trade Center. 
 "Our space was vaporized," said Mr. Albers, who was on his way to work at the time of the attack. "I saw it fall before my eyes." 
 All 598 employees who worked there left safely. Now some 150 employees are working in the New Jersey office complex, the exact location of which the fund group requested not be disclosed.
While it was a difficult week for all mutual fund companies, it was excruciating for those that had been based at the World Trade Center. All companies had to restore operations after equity markets reopened on Monday after a four-day shutdown. Then fund managers had to navigate a treacherous market, with the Dow Jones industrial average dropping more than 14 percent for the week.
But some firms that operated at the trade center are missing scores of people. Fred Alger Management counts 35 of 55 employees at the World Trade Center among the missing, including Fred M. Alger's brother, David, who was the firm's president and chief investment officer. The firm's mutual funds and investments totaling $16 billion are running again under the management of Fred Alger, the chairman and president, and Dan C. Chung, the new chief investment officer and portfolio manager.
Fiduciary Trust Company International, a subsidiary of Franklin Resources Inc., has also suffered, with four employees confirmed dead and 83 missing after the collapse of 2 World Trade Center, its headquarters. Fiduciary, which managed $43.9 billion as of the end of June for large institutions and wealthy individuals, is not saying how many investment professionals are among the missing at this point, according to Lisa Gallegos, a spokeswoman for Franklin. The investments are being run from a disaster recovery site in New Jersey; employees there, as well as in the firm's existing office in Short Hills, N.J., will move to permanent space in Rockefeller Center by the end of the year, she said.
FOR others, all employees are safe, but scattered and tramautized.
At OppenheimerFunds, a unit of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company, which runs 65 mutual funds with $120 billion under management, all employees working at the firm's headquarters on five floors of 2 World Trade Center escaped. The entire group headed for the exits soon after a plane struck the neighboring north tower of 1 World Trade Center, said Andrew J. Mika, senior vice president for investment operations and administration, who descended 20 stories to the 12th floor when the second plane struck his building.
Now these employees face new concerns as they grapple with the violence of Sept. 11. To help them, the firm has enlisted professional crisis counselors and has provided rooms for reflection. Mr. Mika himself has sought advice on how to talk with his children, who now worry about his safety at work. 
Others, who have been moved to an undisclosed building in New Jersey, find it hard to go to work on its 22nd floor and were rattled by a fire alarm this week, said Craig P. Dinsell, an executive vice president of human resources. People need time to recover from trauma, he said: "This is a long and drawn out process."
Beyond the emotional toll are the practical concerns of finding offices. After the 1993 World Trade Center bombing, OppenheimerFunds set up an emergency office in New Jersey for some portfolio managers and traders. The backup site provides everything from computers to trading systems. This week, 90 percent of the employees were directed there and to other sites -- a second one in New Jersey, as well as offices in suburban Westchester County and in Connecticut. 
The fund group expects to move into offices at 498 Seventh Avenue between West 36th and 37th streets in Manhattan beginning next month, according to James Lacey, a spokesman with Massachusetts Mutual. While most analysts and fund managers are in the New York area, the bulk of the group's employees work in Denver.
Scattered operations can strain communications, said Geoffrey H. Bobroff, a mutual fund consultant and the president of Bobroff Consulting of East Greenwich, R.I.
"For a handful or so firms, the reaction is going to be quite difficult," Mr. Bobroff said. 
Citigroup Asset Management was affected when 7 World Trade Center collapsed. The building housed 2,500 Citigroup employees, including the asset management group, which occupied 350,000 square feet of newly refurbished space.
Although the firm successfully evacuated everyone, it has had to scramble for new space around the region.
"It was a real sense of emptiness," Thomas W. Jones, the chief executive of Citigroup Asset Management, said of the loss. "You go into this wonderful area with a beautiful building and not even 12 hours later it was gone."
Mr. Jones credits a disaster relief site in Rutherford, N.J., with allowing the firm to resume investment management of more than $400 billion. Tools from technology to research will let the 400 to 500 people in the portfolio management teams continue at that site for the next six to nine months, the time that Mr. Jones expects will be needed to develop permanent quarters. The remaining employees are being shifted to Stamford, Conn., and other offices in Manhattan. The firm is posting counselors at each site.
EVEN as the firms have solved the nuts-and-bolts problems about space and technology, their portfolio managers and analysts who were returning to work last week faced new concerns wrought by the Sept. 11 chaos: an even more volatile market.
Mr. Albers, who has managed money for nearly three decades and helps oversee $16 billion in investors' money, has been in no hurry to make bold decisions for the Main Street funds that he and Mr. Monoyios run.
"Frankly, our investment philosophy at times like this is that you don't want to jump into frenetic activity," Mr. Monoyios said.
As the two began running computer models, they chose not to do much in the way of trading. Instead, Mr. Albers focused on broad trends in the market. "The economic environment is changing very fast, and our models are picking up on the new data," he said.
He is considering whether to shift some of the portfolio from defensive stocks like utilities and health care to technology, auto and retail stocks that could benefit from a rebound.
"It has been a little hard for me to focus and concentrate on investment issues," Mr. Albers acknowledged. But, come Monday, armed with the information from his computer models, he expects to start trading more actively.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Transplanted traders from OppenheimerFunds worked at makeshift quarters in central New Jersey last week. The business had been based in the World Trade Center. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Teenage Bulls See Profits in a Time of Anxiety

BYLINE:  By MARY WILLIAMS WALSH

 BODY:
NIRAV PATEL'S friend pushed up to him through the crush of a high school activity fair on Thursday. His pal had only one thing to say to him.
 Airlines. 
 His friend, who is 17, was liquid, Nirav explained, having saved about $1,000 from his summer job. "He said, 'If I keep it in airline stocks for 10 years, I'll make a fortune,' " said Nirav, who is also 17 and is co-treasurer of the stock club at John P. Stevens High School in Edison, N.J. 
They are among the investors who almost literally cut their teeth on the world's longest bull market. For this generation of adolescents -- who still had training wheels on their bikes after their parents and teachers were pounded by the collapse of 1987 -- "recession" is a distant and somewhat theoretical condition.
These teenage investors, able to jump into the market because of the advent of online trading, where their ages need not be disclosed, did their research in cyberspace, rode the new-economy market of the 1990's to its top and kept the faith over the past year, when the market plummeted. High school investment clubs have remained popular, as students learn about the importance of earnings and other fundamentals. 
Still, Wall Street veterans always speculated that a real market panic would spook these teenage investors. Such untested optimists, the conventional wisdom went, would cut and run in a truly grizzly bear market. 
But even now, with the Dow and the Nasdaq shriveling and with the best economic minds forecasting recession, America's ultimate long-term investors are buying, if an unscientific sampling is any guide.
"The Vietnam generation is a little more cautious than we would be," explained Alexander Danielides, 16, a junior at the Bronx High School of Science who has been investing since he read "The Warren Buffett Way," the 1994 best seller, at age 9. "We have a fresher perspective. Instead of relying on what people used to think, we look and see what we think is important."
Let fainthearted 50-somethings race for the Treasury bill markets. Alexander has spent the past week creating a "top 10" list of equities that he thinks are poised to thrive in a time of public anxiety.
"With what just happened in the World Trade Center, right now, people need things like security systems," he said. "This is the time to buy them. Now. Ground transportation is going to become very important as people get over their fears of flight."
On Alexander's "buy" list, therefore, is Greyhound Lines, a subsidiary of Laidlaw. And because telecommunications played such a prominent role during the World Trade Center attack, he deems WorldCom a buy.
At the Branson School in Marin County, Calif., activities were just being organized for the new school year when the disaster struck in Manhattan and stock markets were shut down. The timing was propitious for Branson's stock club. Last year's members had cashed out their positions in Cisco Systems and Alcatel, and after the graduating seniors took their profits, the remainder of the money was left uninvested over the summer. While many clubs invest for the academic year, the young investors often have their own long-term portfolios.
"Right now, we're mostly in cash, which is a pretty positive stance," said Zachary Skolnick, a Branson School junior who has been trading since he was 14. "We're looking for buying opportunities."
Zachary, who is 17, also says cellular phone stocks have renewed promise. 
"Nokia seems to have gotten a positive boost out of the attacks," he said. But once the club has picked its meeting dates and pulled together its cash, Zachary said, he plans to advocate buying Wal-Mart Stores. 
"It's been talked about a lot how consumer spending is down, and how that could affect some retail stocks," he said. "But at the same time, I don't see any long-term trends in the negative direction. People are always going to be needing just the basic supplies that companies like Wal-Mart are going to cater to."
Some of the youngest investors are still picking stocks the way they did before the catastrophe: buying into companies with products they use and like. Denver Blackwell, an 11-year-old in Kansas City, Mo., who made his first trade at age 6, had just become sold on Linux products before the attack. He had a hunch that "people were just getting tired of Microsoft," he said, and he had tried Linux's operating system at a friend's house.
Now, Denver said, he is "in shock about what happened" and has lost money on Linux-related investments, but he has no intention of selling. Nor is he going to part with his Disney shares, even though some members of the fabled Bass family did just that last week. 
"I'm hoping that once this all goes over, it will ride back up, even higher," said Denver, who learned to trade by attending the Bull and Bear Investment Camp in Kansas City every summer for the last five years. Denver also plans to buy "something better in the next two weeks or so," he said.
"I think it might be a company like Nintendo," he said. "They're going to release a new product in December."
OTHER young traders are thinking not as consumers but as geopolitical strategists. In Edison, Nirav Patel is developing a midterm plan to buy stock in companies in stem-cell research. With virtually the entire United States population riveted on the terrorist attack and its aftermath, he figures, the recent commotion about stem-cell ethics will be forgotten and the field will take off, Nirav predicts.
"I think those stocks will be affected by that," he said.
While he waits for stem-cell research to develop, Nirav is trading in blue-chip companies whose stocks he believes were unjustly battered in the past week. 
"I'm still investing in Philip Morris, Johnson & Johnson, G.E., stocks that have gone down a little bit, so you can make the $5 or $6 on them," he said. "I don't think they should have dropped the way they did. It's a great buying time."
He has no illusions about quick returns -- young investors may have thought that way two years ago, he said, but not any more. 
Even the current talk of an imminent attack on Afghanistan, of possible reprisals and of a long, unpredictable war against shadowy international forces seems not to have fazed America's young bulls. Some are even taking encouragement from the very history lessons that give their elders chills.
"The way we've learned about it in school is that war brings money," said Steven Hopkins, 16, another Bull and Bear Investment Camp alumnus. "War is money. War brought us out of the Depression. I think it's all going to come back up again. People who are selling now are going to be sorry."

GRAPHIC: Photo: At 16, Alexander Danielides, a high school junior in the Bronx, has traded stocks for seven years. In the last week, he created a list of equities he says are poised to thrive. (Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Business; 
Continental's Blunt Leader Faces Crisis, Again

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER REINGOLD

 BODY:
AS the first hijacked airliner smashed into the World Trade Center on Sept. 11, Gordon M. Bethune, the chief executive of Continental Airlines, was at home in Houston, getting dressed for a routine board meeting. Minutes after the attack, his chief operating officer, C. D. McLean, called him with the news. Mr. Bethune ran to the television, only to remember that a contractor working in the backyard had accidentally cut the cable the night before. Mr. Bethune sped to work, where he joined some board members already massed in front of a television in horror.
 A former aircraft mechanic for the Navy and a commercial passenger jet pilot, Mr. Bethune, 60, knew the crashes had to be terrorist acts. "There is no way a 767 could inadvertently run into the World Trade Center," he said later. As the meeting continued, he scrambled to confirm that no Continental airplanes had been involved and that three employees who worked at 5 World Trade Center were safe. 
 Continental and its workers were spared, but Mr. Bethune's relief was brief. By commandeering and crashing four commercial jets in one day, the terrorists had hijacked the business models of not only the companies that lost aircraft -- American, a unit of AMR, and United, a unit of UAL -- but also of Continental and every other airline in the United States. The outlook for much lower sales and significantly higher security costs looked certain to turn a cyclical slowdown into a catastrophe.
Mr. Bethune, a plain-spoken Texas native, has long been famous for saying what others are thinking. So many people were not surprised when, four days after the attacks, he was the first airline executive to speak out about the pressures on the industry. But they were shocked by what he said.
He announced that Continental, one of only two profitable major airlines this year (the other was Southwest), would lay off about 12,000 employees, more than one-fifth of its work force, and cut 20 percent of its flights. He warned that new security requirements, along with the two-day shutdown of air travel after the attacks, could bankrupt Continental and other big airlines unless the government stepped in with a major aid package. The shutdown cost his company $90 million and the overall industry an estimated $1 billion.
"We're not going to be the first ones" to reorganize, Mr. Bethune said, "but we may decide to go as early as October." Last Monday, he chose not to make $69.4 million in aircraft financing payments, raising fears of default and leading to a downgrade of Continental's debt. The stock has lost more than 60 percent of its value since Sept. 10, closing Friday at $14.66. Mr. Bethune said he would make the payment before the grace period was up.
In addition to using lobbyists and layoffs to pressure Congress, Continental tried to enlist its frequent fliers. In an e-mail message last Wednesday, the company encouraged members of its OnePass program to "immediately call or e-mail your Congressman and urge them to pass vital relief legislation for the airline industry." To drive home the point, the message added: "Time is running out."
"This is not a handout," Mr. Bethune said in an interview, adding that airlines were unique because the government grounded all flights after the attacks. "No other industry was denied access to the market," he said. Airlines are vital to the economy, he added, and to everyday life. "You won't have an economy that works without us," he said. "If you were coming down here to the cancer treatment center, you weren't coming. If you ordered anything from Amazon.com, you didn't get it. Nobody went to visit their grandmother."
Mr. Bethune's sudden moves were followed by those of other airline executives, who together have announced layoffs of 79,000 workers in the last two weeks and have created a united front to seek government help. Together, they quickly gained the attention they were seeking. While some critics were galled to see an industry best known for fighting government control suddenly holding out a tin cup, it quickly became clear that no airline was prepared for a disaster of this scope.
Michael J. Linenberg, an analyst at Merrill Lynch, estimated that airlines in the United States would lose $6.5 billion this year, almost three times the loss he had forecast before the attacks. Next year, the industry will lose about $3.5 billion, he predicted, instead of posting the small profit he had estimated earlier. Continental said it had $900 million in cash on hand and was consuming $10 million a day since service resumed.
"There are no other sources of liquidity," said Robert L. Crandall, the former chief executive of American Airlines. "We have a problem."
FOR now, the tough talk seems to have worked. The House and Senate raced to approve as much as $15 billion in emergency aid, loans and loan guarantees for airlines. While that is much less than the $24 billion airlines had sought, it is likely to at least stop the hemorrhaging. "We have to give the financial institutions the signal that the government is standing shoulder to shoulder with the airlines," said Representative Tom DeLay, the Republican House whip whose district includes Continental's headquarters in Houston.
Not every politician showed support. Senator Ernest F. Hollings, Democrat of South Carolina, questioned the airlines' cry for help. "The airlines told us they were going broke long before these attacks occurred, while at the same time giving their executives $120 million in salaries and bonuses this year," he said in a statement.
With passengers afraid to fly -- on Wednesday, just 48 percent of Continental's seats were filled, near the industry average after the attacks -- Mr. Bethune and other airline executives have a long struggle ahead.
For Mr. Bethune, who led a turnaround at Continental over the last seven years, the sudden change of events was a crushing reminder of his first days at the airline. When he was named Continental's president and chief operating officer in February 1994, the company had just emerged from its second bankruptcy reorganization in 10 years. As he took the job of chief executive in November -- he was the 10th in as many years -- it became clear that the company would run out of cash within two months. At his first board meeting, he said the $750 million cash on hand was disappearing quickly, and he worried that he wouldn't have enough left to make a coming payroll. 
So, in a move that foreshadowed this week's events, Mr. Bethune went outside the company for help -- not to the government, but to Boeing, his previous employer. He persuaded Boeing to let it defer orders and to quickly wire back $29 million the airline had made in deposits. Continental survived its problems and turned a profit in 1995.
From that fast start, Mr. Bethune never looked back. He made a habit of silencing doubters, posting 25 consecutive quarters of profitability before Sept. 11. Continental earned $42 million in the second quarter this year.
"Gordon's done fine, but he started with a huge advantage," said Mr. Crandall, the former American Airlines chief. "He had lower costs than anyone else, because Continental had been through bankruptcy twice."
Bankruptcy, however, had created its own problems, including a resentment among employees whose union contracts were broken when the company reorganized its finances in the 1980's and early 1990's. But Mr. Bethune has managed to turn the airline into an enjoyable place to work by capitalizing on his outgoing, salty manner.
"He is a rare mixture of intelligence and profanity," said Darryl Jenkins, director of the Aviation Institute at George Washington University in Washington.
At the beginning of his tenure, Mr. Bethune began to offer employees cash bonuses when on-time arrivals ranked near the top of the industry. Other incentives would include new sport utility vehicles for some employees with perfect attendance, and family-friendly policies like discounted day care. Continental has been named one of Fortune magazine's "100 best companies to work for in America" the last three years.
A happy employee base led to satisfied passengers. In an industry rife with horrendous service, Continental has stood apart, winning first or second place in the J. D. Power & Associates customer service awards the last five years. The airline was first in on-time arrivals in 2000.
"He is a wonderful motivator of people," said Mr. Richard W. Pogue, a Continental director and a senior adviser with Dix & Eaton, a public relations firm in Cleveland. "Employees just really respect him and look up to him. I have dealt with many C.E.O.'s over my lifetime and he is one of the best I've ever seen."
Now, however, the scale of the proposed layoffs is threatening that tight-knit culture. Even with government help, Mr. Bethune is not likely to rehire those 12,000 employees anytime soon. And he faces the double challenge of motivating the employees who remain and making them feel safe when they know that they, too, could be targets of a terrorist attack.
Capt. Michael Hynes, a Continental pilot, said the uncertainty about knowing who would be laid off was hurting morale even more. "Everyone is really in a funk," he said.
"The only disappointment I've felt is that if the company was going to do this, couldn't they have done that homework in advance? I would have expected a little better than that."
To reassure employees, Mr. Bethune has been talking to them a lot, by phone to people who were stuck for several days in places like Halifax, Nova Scotia, or by expanding his regular companywide voice-mail messages. Although he usually records a voice mail weekly for the entire company, he has used daily messages to bring employees up to date on the latest information.
"I needed to give them reassurance that things were not coming to an end," he said. "I told them who I had talked to and the progress we had made so that all of us are aware of what we're trying to do. They like that. Adversity makes the trust more important."
On Tuesday, Mr. Bethune's voice mail talked about the day's meetings with Transportation Secretary Norman Y. Mineta and others, but he added a personal note. "I know that it has been tough for the last solid week," he told Continental's workers. "We have had just a lot of issues facing us and I appreciate all of your patience and consideration and also the way you have been able to handle the stress of all these situations."
Beyond keeping his workers motivated, however, Mr. Bethune must figure out how to fill Continental's planes again, and he must do it without the assistance of Greg Brenneman, the company's dynamic former president and chief operating officer. Mr. Brenneman, 39, left abruptly in May to return to a consulting company he founded several years ago. He declined to comment. 
Despite Mr. Bethune's assurances that Continental will not be the first to declare bankruptcy, it has some problems that put it in more of a bind than rivals like Delta Air Lines or American. Because it leases most of its planes rather than owning them, the company cannot use those assets as collateral. "Continental couldn't possibly get such lines of credit," Mr. Crandall said. "It had zero net assets."
Mr. Bethune responded that being able to borrow against aircraft was no longer much of an advantage. "If nobody wants to buy diamonds, you can't borrow off of diamonds," he said.
Continental's limited options partly reflect its bankruptcy history. But Mr. Bethune is an aggressive manager, and some recent decisions may have also reduced the company's wiggle room. "They had had some bank facilities and repaid them as they raised debt in other forms," said Philip Baggaley, senior airline bond analyst at Standard & Poor's. "Then they chose not to pay the cost of having those unused bank lines there. Now I imagine they regret it."
Another controversial decision came in January, when Continental bought back a controlling stake in itself from Northwest Airlines. Northwest acquired the stake in 1998 as part of a marketing alliance, but when that alliance ran into antitrust problems, Continental decided it was time to get out. It paid $450 million for the shares, a 29 percent premium to the market price when the deal was struck in November 2000.
The company also paid a $10 million fee to David Bonderman, a board member and financier who had sold the shares to Northwest in the first place and had the first rights to buy them back. The fee gave Continental the first crack at buying back the shares. But while the deal meant that Northwest gave up some control, it still received special preferred stock that lets it veto a merger by any airline with revenue greater than $1 billion, raising questions about exactly what Continental had paid for.
MR. BETHUNE responded that he considers the deal a huge victory for Continental and its shareholders. "They needed the money," he said, referring to Northwest, "and we needed to get the independence so we could have some upside in our share price."
He said the agreement ended Northwest interference in Continental's daily operations while still protecting the alliance.
Continental's decision not to make the $69.4 million payment for aircraft financing did not do much to bolster confidence, either, although Mr. Bethune's assurance that the loans would be paid within a grace period makes it look a lot more like posturing than a signal of an imminent default. 
At a news conference on Wednesday, the airline's president, Lawrence W. Kellner, said that even with a bailout, Continental was likely to bring in just half the revenue it had expected in the fourth quarter. Even before the attacks, he added, the company had revised its growth rate for this year to 2 percent from 6 percent.
Every analyst has a different take on each airline's plight, in part because the instability of the situation makes it difficult to accurately estimate how fast companies are spending cash reserves. But analysts took Mr. Bethune's threat of bankruptcy seriously. With high fixed costs for airplanes, salaries and fuel, airlines can rack up losses quickly when demand drops, and passengers have been scarce ever since the attacks. Mr. Linenberg, the analyst at Merrill Lynch, estimated that Continental had enough cash to remain in business for 40 days without a bailout or any passengers at all, while United had enough for 47 days and Delta, 67 days.
Mr. Jenkins of the Aviation Institute said he considered Continental the most at risk of the major carriers. Before Congress voted on the bailout, he estimated that the airline had only 15 days of cash remaining.
Though Mr. Bethune wants Continental's plight to be taken seriously, he bristles when he hears such numbers. He said Mr. Jenkins was "a nice guy, but he's wrong as hell."
If Congress approves the aid package, it will almost certainly dwarf the last major corporate bailout, the 1979 Congressional act that guaranteed up to $1.5 billion in loans for Chrysler. But Mr. Bethune said that there should be no comparison. "We're not talking about a company," he said, "We're talking about an industry." He said he told government officials that if they did not act quickly, "you're going to lose a lot more than you ever would have spent."
It is a little odd for Mr. Bethune, who loves to rail against government interference, to be soliciting government aid. "It bothers me a lot," he said. "It's not my favorite thing to do, but at the same time this is a war."
Mr. Bethune said he hoped that air traffic would be back to normal by next summer, but he acknowledged that the experience of flying was not what it once was. On Mr. Bethune's flight from Baltimore to Houston on Tuesday, even the first-class passengers used plastic forks and drank wine out of screw-top bottles. "Every time someone would get up and go to the bathroom, everyone would look to see what he was doing," Mr. Bethune said.
That tension is likely to linger for a long time to come.

HEADLINE: Investors Seek a Refuge, and Experts Do, Too 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM

 BODY:
THE stock market reopened to resounding cheers on Monday morning, but despite pleas from some Americans to rally around, the week ended on Friday was one of its worst since the Depression. All in all, three years of gains were wiped away, with the prices of most stocks closing at levels last seen in 1998, as investors of all stripes fled to bonds and other conservative investments.
 President Bush's address to Congress on Thursday night only reinforced Wall Street's most pressing concern, beyond human casualties -- when and how it will all end. 
 Many past crises brought sharp declines followed by recoveries in days or weeks, but the recent terror attacks seem to have marked the beginning of a war with an uncertain mission and duration and came to an economy teetering on the brink of recession.
For average Americans wondering how best to protect their savings, it may be small comfort to know that many experts are equally uncertain. Reliable predictions are as hard to find on Wall Street as a soaring stock. "Any effort to extrapolate the range of uncertainties, the economic implications, all of the common claptrap, will be profoundly different after we do something," said Michael H. Steinhardt, a famed hedge fund manager who retired six years ago from running money but is now chairman of the investment committee for New York University's endowment. 
"Once we do something, assuming it is successful, the psychology will truly change," he added. "Until that happens, the stock market doesn't have a chance in hell of going up."
Richard B. Hoey, the chief economist and investment strategist for the Dreyfus Corporation, asked and answered his own question: "Which economic forecast has this in it? There are no gurus."
Even Jeremy J. Siegel, a professor of finance at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania and one of the most noted market bulls, was dubious about the immediate prospects. "From a long-term standpoint, right now stocks are undervalued," he said. "That does not mean they cannot go down in the short run. One constant we know about is that uncertainty harms equity markets."
He added: "It is hard to see any sustained rise in prices until the uncertainty dissipates. Given the type of enemy we have, it doesn't appear this is going to happen anytime soon."
When the week was done, the Dow Jones industrial average had fallen 14.3 percent, to 8,235.81. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index had fallen 11.6 percent, to 965.80. The Nasdaq composite index fell 16.1 percent, to 1,423.19. Those are the levels of October 1998.
Much of the selling came, some investment advisers said, from companies and financial institutions that bailed out of large blocks of stock. Others said it was foreign investors, retreating nervously from a long love affair with the United States market. There were reports of wealthy financiers, like the Bass family of Texas, selling huge chunks of stock in a scramble to raise cash to pay off margin loans or other obligations. Others said the sellers were insurance companies preparing to pay the $30 billion to $40 billion of claims related to the collapse of the World Trade Center towers.
Given the declines, it was most likely all of the above -- and individual investors. They poured a record $66 billion into money market funds, one of the most conservative investments, in the three trading days before and after the World Trade Center crashes, according to AMG Data Services, which tracks money flows. Stock mutual funds suffered net withdrawals of $5.9 billion over the same period -- a substantial but not record amount -- and bond funds not devoted to high-risk bonds took in significant new money.
For those who were already pessimistic, the last two weeks offered much to reinforce their view.
"It's clear to me that we were already in a full-blown recession before the attack," said A. Gary Shilling, an economist and money manager who predicted last year that the Nasdaq would fall as low as 1,027. Even with the Federal Reserve cutting interest rates aggressively, he said, the economy will not recover until next year.
"In general, I would not be trying to catch falling pianos," Mr. Shilling said. For investors with cash now, he favors longer-term Treasury bonds. As for those who already own stocks, and plan to stay with them, Mr. Shilling says they will have to adjust their expectations to much lower stock market returns of 5 to 6 percent a year.
Seth M. Glickenhaus, the 87-year-old chief investment officer of Glickenhaus & Company, was even more bearish.
"The economic and political uncertainties are so great that one should buy municipal bonds if you need tax exemptions," he said, and government bonds otherwise.
"You should be 100 percent in bonds," he added. "If you are 22 years old, there may be certain groups of stocks you should look at that, for the long term, will be all right. But for the long, not the intermediate, term."
That said, fortunes and reputations have been made before by buying during bleak times. Carl C. Icahn, one of Wall Street's best-known financiers and corporate raiders, said that now could well be the time to make that decision. "I've been quite bearish for the last year, but I am starting to believe that the markets are becoming oversold," he said on Friday. "I intend to start buying in the next week or two."
Ronald Baron, chairman and chief executive of Baron Capital, said: "We're in the middle of a panic right now, and you're going to get opportunities you rarely see. There's tremendous opportunities to invest right now. People are going to travel again and it's going to be a lot sooner than you think."
"This is the end of the bear market," he proclaimed.
Somewhere in the middle is Gary L. Pilgrim, the fund manager and a co-founder of Pilgrim Baxter & Associates. He favors stocks of fast-growing companies and acknowledged that many investors might not have the staying power when stocks are falling, because of margin calls or the need for cash. But he expressed confidence that the markets would recover.
"You do have to recognize our world, our economy and our stock market have already recovered from every setback," he said.
David Dreman, who heads Dreman Value Management, said he did not know whether the stock market would continue to fall. But he has studied the performance of the Dow after 11 crises since World War II. On average, the index gained 30 percent from the bottoms hit after those events.
"There wasn't one year that it was down," he said. "There always seems to be an overreaction to a crisis."
Many experts who have devoted their lives to thinking about how best to balance risk and reward say that the events of the last two weeks, if not the market declines of the last year, reinforced the most obvious but most often discarded tenet of investing: be diversified.
Investors, said Mr. Hoey at Dreyfus, should not embrace any strategy based on a single scenario, be it the market dropping or rising. "There's really never the wrong time to adopt the right investment strategy," he said.
If American investors are looking for tough advice, they will get it from Sir John M. Templeton, 88, the noted investor who founded the Templeton mutual fund family. In an interview from his office in the Bahamas, he contended that this was not the time to rally around any single flag, at least as an investor. He said American investors had placed too much faith in domestic stocks, especially technology stocks, and should be spreading their bets.
Sir John recommends that most people keep up to half of their investment assets in Treasury bonds. A simple way to spread the remainder among quality stocks from around the world would be to buy a global stock index, like the Morgan Stanley World index, he said. Only young people who know they will not need money to pay for college or any major purchases for a long time should put the bulk of their assets into stocks.
"Every once in a while, people go through a period of excess optimism and then go through a period of excess pessimism," he said. The boom in technology stocks in this country in the late 1990's "was by far the biggest and wildest ever seen."
Even now, he said, American share prices are too high, about double historical norms. "Americans are amazing in how self-centered they are," said Sir John, a Tennessee native. "Nobody in Switzerland would dream of keeping all his assets in Swiss stocks."
Unfortunately, investing has many pitfalls that bewitch what seems like good sense. With so many investors looking now to bonds, they have drawbacks. As the prices of bonds rise, the yields go down, making them less attractive.
"Here's the problem for investors: short-term Treasuries yield about 3 percent," said William H. Gross, the chief investment officer of the Pacific Investment Management Company and the country's most prominent bond investor.
"What a bank offers has got to be close" to that, he added. "A lot of money is flowing into money market mutual funds, which are going to yield investors 2.5 percent. These investments are safe but don't provide returns."
Yields on Ginnie Mae bonds are more promising, at 5.5 percent to 6 percent, he noted, and are fully guaranteed by the government. Mr. Gross said he had been buying long-term Treasury bonds because their yields looked considerably more attractive than those of short-term Treasury bonds.
Perhaps the best advice from experts to individual investors is the most obvious: don't run too briskly in any direction during such pronounced volatility. The Chicago Board Options Exchange's volatility index peaked at 57.3 on Friday, the highest level since October 1998.
"A day or so after the event, we advised people to sit still," said Edward M. Kerschner, chief global strategist for UBS Warburg. "There is no way to reasonably assess the fundamental impact of this. If you truly were investing to retire and put the kids through college 10 to 20 years from now, the decisions you made two weeks ago are probably as rational as any."

HEADLINE: A Disaster for the Working Poor 

 BODY:
One of the tragic byproducts of the destruction of the World Trade Center has been financial crisis for thousands of unskilled, low-income employees who were displaced by the disaster. About 3,500 people who clean the hotel rooms and offices in lower Manhattan lost their jobs when the buildings that employed them were destroyed or closed for the cleanup. With salaries that average roughly $32,000 a year, most have little in the way of savings to fall back on. As New York struggles to recover from the terrorist attack, workers like these have to be among the priorities for help. 
 Some of these workers will receive health coverage, cash assistance and first choice of new jobs in their industry thanks to a special agreement between unions and contractors. Emergency clearing houses have been set up to help them find jobs, and the state has waived the seven-day waiting period for unemployment benefits. But those benefits will cover these workers for only six months, and replacement jobs will be hard to find at a time when hotels and other service-related businesses are cutting back in response to the lagging economy and drop in tourism. Given these special circumstances, the duration of benefits should be temporarily extended. 
 The disaster in Lower Manhattan has had grave consequences for other low-income workers whose jobs were nowhere near the World Trade Center. Half the unionized garment workers in Lower Manhattan were sent home without pay when the trucks that deliver partially assembled clothing to the sewing shops for finishing were unable to get to their factories because of the rescue effort. Most are now back on the job, but workers who earn less than $15,000 a year can be financially crippled by even brief periods of unemployment. Many speak little or no English, and have had difficulty understanding how to apply for help.
The drivers who normally ferry tourists and business people around the city are suffering, too. The union that represents many of the city's 11,000 black-car drivers says that business has been off by about 80 percent and that some drivers have gone a whole day without a single fare. The drivers may be helped by President Bush's designation of the city as a disaster area. This allows self-employed and part-time workers to receive disaster unemployment assistance. Unfortunately, it usually takes up to three weeks for either D.U.A. or regular unemployment checks to reach those in need. Everything possible should be done to reduce that waiting time.
The effects of this tragedy on the city's poorest and most vulnerable workers have been a little-noticed side of a disaster with so many terrible stories. But the displaced workers and their families will be struggling for a long time to recover from the attack, and they should not be forgotten.

HEADLINE: DataBank; 
Terror Makes Itself Felt on Wall Street

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY

 BODY:
There were calls for investors to stage a patriotic rally when the stock market reopened last Monday after a four-day shutdown in the wake of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. But stocks ended the week at their lowest levels in three years. 
 Even the Federal Reserve failed to stimulate the market after trimming short-term interest rates by half a percentage point. 
 Much of last week's trading was volatile, fueled by fears of a recession and of the scope of American military retaliation. Wall Street paid little attention to anything else.
 Companies ranging from Eastman Kodak to Adobe Systems, the software publisher, warned of disappointing profits in the current quarter. Perhaps the most optimistic news came from General Electric, which expected double-digit earnings growth in 2001.
 For the week, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1,369.70 points, or 14.3 percent, to 8,235.81 - its worst weekly percentage decline since the Great Depression. The Nasdaq composite index lost 272.19 points, or 16.1 percent, to 1,423.19. The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 126.74 points, or 11.6 percent, to 965.80. SHERRI DAY
