HEADLINE: Aftermath; 
The Prospect of a War Without a Wartime Boom

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
WHATEVER else they are, wars are usually good for the economy, at least in the short run. World War II completed the job of pulling the United States out of the Depression. Vietnam helped fuel a nearly decade-long boom during the 1960's.
 This time, however, someone forgot to tell the stock market. When Wall Street got back to business last week, the Dow plummeted 14.3 percent, its worst one-week performance since 1933. 
 This, as President Bush has said repeatedly, is a new kind of war. And it will be fought by a nation whose muscle derives in part from having a new kind of economy, one whose response to the war is unlikely to follow any previous script.
The attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon clearly dealt a sharp blow in the short run to commerce, the financial system and consumer confidence. The business expansion that began in 1991 and reached record length at the beginning of last year, bringing unemployment to 30-year lows and the federal budget surplus to a record high, may finally have come to an end. The airline industry teetered on the brink of financial collapse last week as planes flew almost empty.
Conceivably, some quick, visible progress on the military front, combined with credible efforts to ensure security at home, could lead to a rapid return to normalcy. But the prospects for such a benign outcome don't seem good.
It is hard to predict the effect a prolonged campaign against terrorism will have on a form of capitalism built around risk-taking, technological advances, lightning-fast reactions and a willingness to let goods, money and people move freely.
This is not going to be a conflict in which housewives flock to factories to build fighter planes. It may not even be one in which consumers, rather than going to the mall, sit around for weeks watching cruise missiles streak into foreign capitals on CNN.
But it could be one in which the national, and global, psychology, now more than ever a vital determinant of economic vibrancy, is affected for a long period. And despite the appeal to investors to buy stocks as a patriotic duty, financial markets, the modern economy's central nervous system, are almost sure to remain jittery if not depressed.
Consumers, suddenly fearful of losing their jobs or feeling poorer as their stock portfolios erode, could choose not to buy that new car or splurge on that blouse. The willingness to gamble, to invest time, money and energy in an idea, could be blunted, sapping the nation's entrepreneurial spirit. "If it changes the way we do business on a long-term basis by imposing risks on air travel, creating incentives to disperse financial activities and culturally making people more cautious," said Peter Morici, a senior fellow at the Economic Strategy Institute, a research organization, "then we're going to have a terrorist tax on growth. It would rob us of a piece of that new economy."
After dealing with the immediate crisis of keeping the financial system operating and getting Wall Street up and running again -- an effort that was encouragingly successful -- economic policymakers began trying last week to sort out all the uncertainty.
After initially rushing toward adoption of a big stimulus package, to be paid for out of a budget surplus that had previously been reserved for debt reduction, Congress and the White House pulled back abruptly last week. They did so largely at the urging of Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, who said there was as much risk in overreacting or choosing the wrong antidote as in delaying or acting too timidly.
The Fed itself acted forcefully after the attacks, cutting interest rates and making sure banks and investment firms had all the cash they needed. Congress and the administration hastily drew up and debated legislation to keep the airlines solvent. And there may still prove to be a need for a combination of new tax cuts and additional spending to spur more economic activity by individuals and businesses, Mr. Greenspan said. 
But the degree of help the economy needs cannot be assessed accurately for a few weeks, he said. And there is a risk, he added, that a rush to prop up the economy would prove counterproductive if the government could no longer afford to make good on its plan to pay off most of the national debt in the next decade. That would leave less money in the economy for investment in businesses, which would drive interest rates higher than they would be otherwise.
Mr. Greenspan's warning had the effect of torpedoeing an effort by some Republicans to push through a quick passage of tax cuts, including a reduction in the capital gains tax. 
THUS far, despite the mounting toll of layoffs, the loss of hundreds of billions of dollars in stock market wealth and a new consensus among economic forecasters that the United States has entered a recession, Mr. Bush and his team tried to emphasize the positive. Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill even suggested that it might be a good time to buy stocks.
But investors peered into the future, saw little to cheer about and sold. Companies began delaying or canceling expansion plans, and warning that they would reduce their work forces. Japan, which has been wallowing in a slump for a decade, looked more wobbly than ever, as did other industrialized and developing nations. If the United States falters, it will further hurt the international economic outlook -- which in turn will deepen problems at home.
Mr. Greenspan has devoted considerable time in recent years to studying the psychology of economic shocks and panics. One of the economy's strengths is that technology has allowed businesses, investors and consumers to spot change even as it is occurring and respond almost instantaneously. Such speed is usually a good thing. But sometimes, Mr. Greenspan has suggested, it blows our economic circuits.
"It has become evident time and again that when events become too complex and move too rapidly," Mr. Greenspan said in a speech several years ago, "human beings become demonstrably less able to cope. The failure of the ability to comprehend external events almost invariably induces disengagement from an activity, whether it be fear of entering a dark room, or of market volatility."
Right now the American economy seems to be poised at that doorway. And no one knows whether the lights on the other side are on or off.

HEADLINE: Aftermath; 
A City Transformed: Designing 'Defensible Space'

BYLINE:  By ANTHONY VIDLER; Anthony Vidler, acting dean of the Cooper Union School of Architecture, is the author of "Warped Space: Art, Architecture and Anxiety in Modern Culture."

 BODY:
THE terrorist attack on the World Trade Center is propelling a civic debate over whether to change the way Americans experience and ultimately build urban public spaces. Are a city's assets -- density, concentration, monumental structures -- still alluring? Will a desire for "defensible space" radically transform the city as Americans know it? 
 For more than a century, architects and urban planners have been trying to design better forms for the modern metropolis. Some, like Le Corbusier, reimagined the city in glass and steel, its transparent towers majestically spaced amid greenery -- prismatic objects in a vast urban park. Others, like Frank Lloyd Wright, envisioned it dispersed in "broadacres," spread across the fertile prairie, each citizen given a plot of land. 
 All these plans grew out of a desire to counteract what were seen as the central threats against life and happiness in the late 19th century: lack of light and air, unsanitary and overcrowded conditions and congested circulation that demanded the opening up of narrow streets and the restitution of "nature" in the form of green space, if not the dispersal of the entire city. 
Such dispersal has, in fact, been taking place since the 1920's, as the "metropolis" grew into the "megalopolis." The result was an uneasy compromise between clusters of skyscrapers in downtown redevelopments and suburban sprawl.
But the central city, for all its economic woes, has retained its strong attraction as a focus of public interaction, a center of trade, finance and consumerism. In recent years, cities like New York have seen a return to livability and a reconstruction of social and cultural services and neighborhoods.
The last decades, however, have seen a major increase in terrorist attacks on the public centers in Europe, the Middle East, and now the United States. Dispersal rather than concentration is being talked about as the viable pattern of life and work, where monumental buildings will give way to camouflaged sheds, or entirely scattered to home offices.
Urban planners are ill-prepared to respond to this new reality. Fear of aerial attack has actually preoccupied planners and architects since the First World War and its Zeppelin bombardments. At that time, decentralization was the watchword. -- a strategy that fit the polemics of the Garden City movement. Regional planning groups in Britain and America stressed the security advantages of "spread" cities. Le Corbusier, in consultation with former military officers, drew diagrams showing that his project for a "Ville Verte" or "Green City" was less susceptible to damage from above. Its wide parks and narrow bands of apartment-buildings offered smaller targets.
But all such plans were drawn up to counter the threat of external attack, rather than to protect against terrorism from within. Indeed, for many critics, security has been seen as a threat to liberty -- the surveillance society as a dystopia of secret cameras, invasion of privacy and the abuse of state power. If planners considered security, it has been in the service of crime prevention in the inner city or the retreat into gated "safe" communities of the suburbs.
Certainly the superficial result of the latest terror will be to confirm the dark images of metropolis drawn by the Expressionists in the 1920's, and popularized by Fritz Lang's silent masterwork, "Metropolis" -- the city as an untamed monster, a vision updated in the cyberpunk stories of William Gibson, movies like "Blade Runner" and the Japanese comic books, "Atari" and "Metropolis," whose ruined streets bear a disturbing resemblance to the devastation in downtown Manhattan. 
There will be an understandable impulse to flee. The "new urbanism" movement, with its low-density developments like Seaside or Celebration in Florida, designed to replicate small-town life in premodern America, will no doubt take the opportunity to denounce tall buildings as inherently mistaken. Certainly a number of firms will relocate outside New York in the search for space and security; maybe a number of New Yorkers will move to the suburbs. 
The experience of the rest of the world indicates however, that terrorism alone will not decrease the importance of city centers for the public life of societies. London, subject to terrorist bombings since the late Victorian age, to the ferocious bombardments of World War II and to the spill-over of the violence in Northern Ireland, has always rebounded with strength. Paris has been on the alert for terrorism since the Algerian War. Yet its museums, monuments and public spaces are continually filled. New York will be no exception.
For real community, as evident over the last week, is bred in cities more strongly than suburbs. The street as a site of interaction, encounter and the support of strangers for each other; the square as a place of gathering and vigil; the corner store a communicator of information and interchange. These spaces, without romanticism or nostalgia, still define an urban culture, one that resists all efforts to "secure" it out of existence.
Proposals have already been made that would change the nature of public space: closing off Times Square to traffic; limiting access to railroad terminals; increasing use of surveillance cameras; reducing access to parks; adding more cameras and security personnel in buildings. Such a world would hardly be worth living in and would inhibit the very contact through density that cities encourage.
Yet it is true that urban public life has suffered major onslaughts in the last 20 years, from the increasing privatization encouraged by reliance on Internet services to the expansion of the mall-effect -- whereby only the largest consumer outlets survive. In the current crisis, it is all the more important that the idea of public space, and its relations to urban community, be sustained. 
This is why it is urgent that planners explore new urban designs that learn from the difficulties of past utopias as well as avoid the nostalgia of anti-city programs. We should search for design alternatives that retain the dense and vital mix of uses critical to urban life, rethinking the exclusions stemming from outdated zoning, real estate values and private ownership, to provide vital incentives for building public spaces equal to our present needs for community.

HEADLINE: Aftermath: Innocence Lost; 
A Tragedy for an Optimistic Land

BYLINE:  By ANNE TAYLOR FLEMING; Anne Taylor Fleming is an essayist on "The NewsHour With Jim Lehrer."

 BODY:
IT has been said countless times on talk shows and op-ed pages, in shops and supermarkets, over the last stretch of days: America has lost its innocence. Politicians and pundits and the public -- in grief-stricken, sometimes angry voices -- have said the same. Americans, they say, have crossed some literal and psychic Rubicon into a darker, scarier world. And the nation mourns the loss of that innocence as it mourns its dead.
 On one level, the sentiment seems true enough. Nothing of this magnitude has happened to Americans before -- especially on our own soil. In that sense, America was new to this kind of horror. But "innocent" one day and not the next? This is not meant to be cheeky or a matter of word-play; that would be obscene at a time like this. 
 But this notion of innocence, the insistence on it, has also penalized the country, kept it locked into a vision of itself and its place in the world that brings harm, that keeps the populace from seeing things -- even this ghastly act -- in their true colorations and complexities.
That innocence helped keep the country from seeing clearly the hatred coming its way and trying to defuse or deal with it. Terrorists had blown up two American embassies -- had, in fact, placed a bomb in the World Trade Center in 1993. The terrorists in question were locked up, a bomb was dropped on an alleged pharmaceutical factory in Sudan and the nation moved on, taking scant precautions against future terrorism and re-embracing the good times. There was a full-tilt celebration of World War II, when Americans were more noble, self-sacrificing and (what else?) more innocent.
Americans have been serial innocents. Not just with Pearl Harbor, much referenced in recent days, but also with Vietnam, Watergate, even the 1950's quiz show scandals. Each time Americans have said, like abashed children: we've lost our innocence. Then that innocence is somehow redonned like an alias or costume. Morning in America. Rise and shine. Start the healing. Part of this, of course, is a sign of strength, the pragmatic, pick-yourself-up-and-dust-yourself-off fortitude now personified by the mayor of New York.
But part of it stems from something else, a need to avoid national introspection, not take on historical weight as it were.
"As a nation and a society, we do have very, very short memories," said Michael G. Kammen, a professor of American history at Cornell University. "We are not unique in doing so. Most societies repress bad memories -- that's a fairly normative thing -- and they commemorate and celebrate good memories. But I do think there are reasons why short memory and collective amnesia are more pronounced and more problematic in our society."
More pronounced, Professor Kammen said, due to the sheer number of newcomers with no shared history. "Polish-Americans might remember a segment of American history that's germane to them, and Jewish-Americans might remember the segment that's germane to them," he explained. "But there are not many Americans who have much of a sense of the overall collective past."
There is a darker current under the ahistoricism and determined innocence, the nation's desire to clean up the past, to distance itself from its self-inflicted scars. The country was founded on a trail of tears: American Indians killed, their land taken, and, of course, slavery, 300 years of it.
In the face of that, Americans still maintained a kind of willful innocence. It wasn't until the late 1970's, Professor Kammen points out, that the docents in Colonial Williamsburg even used the word slavery. Until then, the African-Americans were referred to as "servants," if at all.
There were many crises to test that assumed innocence: the Civil War, in which Americans killed each other in record numbers; the disillusionment after World War I that America had not made the world safe for democracy; the crash of 1929 and ensuing Great Depression that revealed such economic vulnerability; the cold war and Bay of Pigs; and on into Vietnam and Watergate -- more painful losses of innocence for being self-inflicted.
There seems, at times, an unbearable dichotomy between American goodness and badness. We don't seem to have a vocabulary for it, the juggling act of national self-image, in no small part because within each citizen -- left, right or center, Yankee stock or new arrival -- there is a sense of the magic gift that is America. It is encoded in the national DNA -- the story of the founding, those eminent fathers with their wisdom -- and there is a sense that Americans cannot bear, in a collective and personal way, any transgressions against that magic, cannot bear that they might have tarnished it. (Never mind that some founding fathers had complicated and checkered lives.)
So there is retreat back into innocence, back into what Professor Kammen in his book, "Mystic Chords of Memory," calls the "heritage syndrome," a sort of Americana gymkhana of memorial building (Washington is becoming choked with them), memorabilia collecting (think "The Antique Road Show") and flag-waving nostalgia (as in the recent World War II celebration). If the country is going to go back, then let it be done in an uplifting, myth-reinforcing way. 
WHAT is lost in this posturing is any grasp of the tragic. In its place is the cycle of innocence lost, innocent regained. Tragedy is not part of the national self-image. It is as if in leaving the Old World behind, Americans also left behind a tragic habit of mind, a sense of the complex and textured history that is the lot of any country. They would be different, better, newer forever.
But without that sense of the tragic, America is indeed "innocent," facing each new test or crisis with a combination of abashed patriotism and that feisty spirit. Without a sense of the tragic, its citizens are naked, unprotected, eternally childlike. 
So these days of recovery and shock are bereft of the added piquancy, the added sweetness of having lived with a tragedy and seen the sun shine again and the moon rise, of knowing that America has its own complicated past, complicated motives, and is part of the cycle of life and death and love and loss, no less than the older, scarred countries beside whom it now takes it place in history. Without that sense, that knowledge, Americans are apt to find themselves at more terrible risk, the (avenging) innocents abroad in an increasingly complicated, hostile and ever-shrinking world.

HEADLINE: Driving Through an Altered Landscape 

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE KREBS

DATELINE: DETROIT 

 BODY:
REVERBERATIONS from the terrorist bombings are still sending shudders through Detroit and other centers of a global auto industry that even before Sept. 11 was suffering from slowing sales and cutthroat competition.
 There have been a few encouraging signs -- like increased traffic in dealer showrooms, which were still-lifes in the days just after Sept. 11 -- as the industry prepares for its traditional October transition to a new model year. But the potential for war, recession and higher gasoline prices have deeply unsettled auto executives, dealers, assembly workers and just about anyone else connected to the industry. 
 "Sales are down 30 to 35 percent over the past week," said Van Bussmann, senior vice president of J. D. Power & Associates, the market-research firm, which has been tracking daily activity at 5,000 dealerships. "We haven't seen seeds of recovery, nor have we seen deterioration." 
Mr. Bussman has reduced his estimate of 2001 vehicle sales to 16 million, from 16.2 million before the attacks. That could still be the industry's third-best year, because only three months remain and sales were very strong in early 2001. Previously, analysts were predicting sales of 16.5 million to 17 million.
The auto industry accounts for about 4 percent of the nation's economic output, and a slump in Detroit usually coincides with a recession.
"Industry demand is now expected to be exceptionally weak for the next two quarters, at least, and the likelihood of any improvement beyond that time is highly uncertain," Standard & Poor's said last week.
To stir buyer interest and keep its plants running, both General Motors and Ford announced interest-free loans on all car and truck models in the United States. The announcements came after a visit to Detroit by Commerce Secretary Donald L. Evans and Labor Secretary Elaine L. Chao, who met with auto executives and union leaders to discuss ways to help the economy.
DaimlerChrysler said it would not follow the lead of G.M. and Ford, since it had cut prices on 2002 models just weeks ago.
Keeping factories running has already proved a challenge. Dependent on just-in-time delivery of parts, several plants had to shut down temporarily as trucks full of components -- from factories in Canada, Mexico and the United States -- were initially not allowed to cross national borders and then waited in lines for as long as 15 hours as vehicles were subjected to more rigorous inspections. Factories resumed production last week, and waiting times at the border dropped to an hour or two as National Guard troops were brought in to help Customs agents.
A prolonged sales downturn would accelerate the deterioration of automakers' balance sheets. Both S. & P. and Moody's warned that they might lower their credit ratings for DaimlerChrysler. The Chrysler Group, whose sales have plunged, was already losing money and struggling to meet cost-cutting goals. S. & P. also said the terrorist attacks "increase the likelihood" of downgrades for G.M. and Ford. Lower credit ratings make it more expensive for companies to borrow money.
Some automakers have halted air travel or limited it to essential trips. In some cases, employees who feel uncomfortable traveling are allowed to decline. Mercedes-Benz canceled a dealers meeting in Monaco next month.
News of the attacks in New York and Washington reached many of the world's auto executives at the Frankfurt Auto Show. Automakers quickly canceled or toned down their normally flashy events. A bomb threat forced the temporary evacuation of an exhibit hall. Executives were stranded in Germany for days.
In Detroit, Rod Alberts, executive director of the North American International Auto Show, said plans for the January show were moving forward. He said he was contacting organizers of shows in Chicago, New York and Los Angeles to propose a meeting on new security measures. Before then, the Tokyo show will provide a test.

HEADLINE: Reckonings; 
A Bad Week

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN

 BODY:
In late 1997, when South Korea suddenly found itself in economic crisis, there was a great upsurge of patriotism. Women offered their gold jewelry to the government, to help rebuild its vanished reserves of foreign exchange; millions of people cut back on their spending, feeling that it was irresponsible to buy themselves luxuries when the nation was in danger.
 Of course, this willingness to make sacrifices for the national good made things worse: the drop in consumer spending was one of the factors that pushed South Korea into an extremely nasty recession. 
 I mention this piece of recent history for the obvious reason: although CNN may be calling this "America's new war," at least so far the economic effects of the Sept. 11 terrorist attack look very little like those we usually associate with war, and very much like those we saw in the Asian financial crisis. After a terrible week in the financial markets, it's clearer than ever that the usually helpful instincts of a nation under attack -- the desire to give up some pleasures in honor of the victims, the feeling that having too good a time would be in bad taste -- are actually worsening the situation. 
So what's the answer? There have been some efforts to convince people that it is their patriotic duty to spend money. But I don't think that's going to work: it goes too much against the grain of human nature, against the feeling that tragedy demands sacrifice rather than self-indulgence. And the grass-roots campaign that took place before the market reopened, urging people to buy stock as a gesture of faith in America, has already backfired: anyone who patriotically purchased stocks got caught up in a market plunge that wiped out more than $1 trillion in wealth, while short-selling hedge fund managers who didn't let sentimentality get in the way of business did very well, thank you.
So this isn't the kind of problem that can be solved by voluntary action. It's up to the government to ensure that America's sorrow and nervousness don't turn into an economic disaster.
A first step would be some realistic rhetoric. I don't fault the Bush administration for initially using the language of war and revenge; an angry and grieving public would not have accepted anything less. Eventually, however, officials will have to make more strongly than they have the point that this is not going to be war as we usually understand it: there will probably be little impact on daily life for most people, few dramatic events and quite possibly no real catharsis.
A second step would be to accelerate the flow of government spending into the economy. One of the lessons of the Asian crisis, declared the I.M.F.'s Stanley Fischer, was that "Keynesianism is alive and well" -- increased government spending does help the economy. And the additional spending that will take place as a result of the attack -- $45 billion approved so far, much more to come -- will eventually give our own economy a significant lift. But there is now a risk that the "wealth effect" from last week's market plunge, the adverse effects of stock losses on consumer spending, will beat the fiscal stimulus to the punch. Let's get the government spending underway, please. 
True, Alan Greenspan cautioned us last week that "it is far more important to be right than quick." I'm not sure what he meant by that, so I'm not sure I agree. If he means that it's very important not to respond to the economy's weakness with a so-called stimulus package that locks in another round of permanent tax cuts, I definitely agree. As Mr. Greenspan pointed out, one risk to the economy is that a worsening long-run budget prospect will drive up long-term interest rates; that's the last thing we need. To limit that risk I would suggest the general rule that Congress shall make no laws in the heat of this crisis that affect either revenue or spending beyond next year. 
But in terms of immediate action, it may be more important that the money already in the pipeline be spent quickly than that it be spent well.
A final, optimistic thought: South Korea's recession lasted less than a year; by 1999 the economy was rapidly recovering. We ought to be able to do better.

HEADLINE: Bill in Brazil Would Allow More of Jungle To Be Razed 

BYLINE:  By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: BRASILIA 

 BODY:
A joint commission of the Brazilian Congress has approved a measure that would more than double the amount of the Amazon jungle that ranchers, loggers and miners would be permitted to raze.
 The measure, sponsored by a "rural caucus" of legislators, would weaken many restrictions on Amazon land use and eliminate other safeguards altogether. 
 Though the bill must be approved by both houses of Congress to become law, environmental groups are alarmed and have begun a national campaign to defeat it.
"This legislation is dangerous to the Amazon and to all of Brazil because it puts the government's entire program of sustainable development at risk," said Adriana Ramos of the Social and Environmental Institute, a research and advocacy group. "The initial vote reflects the intransigence of a rural lobby that thinks only of defending its own narrow interests at the expense of society." 
The measure, a new forestry code, would modify the government's current policy of requiring owners of land in the Amazon to preserve 80 percent of their property as forest. Instead of the 20 percent left for development, the new code would enable landowners to use at least 50 percent of their holdings for "productive purposes" once a "zoning study" granted approval.
"We have no objection to preserving the Amazon, which is, after all, part of the patrimony of the Brazilian people," said Senator Rubens Moreira Mendes, a leading member of the rural caucus. But the current restrictions, he said, "go too far in discouraging rational development and investment."
The draft code would also remove a longstanding provision that obligates landowners to replant deforested areas along riverbanks, allow them to replace some virgin forest with nonnative, commercially attractive species like eucalyptus, and redefine what constitutes jungle. 
President Fernando Henrique Cardoso opposes the changes and was able to thwart an effort to pass a similar bill in May. But his government's coalition in Congress has weakened since then and is likely to become more divided ahead of presidential elections a year from now.
"A lot of bad things can happen at the end of a government, and one of the things we are seeing in the eastern Amazon is a sense of a free-for-all, with nobody minding the store," Stephan Schwartzman of Environmental Defense said in a telephone interview from Washington. "It's kind of open season, and that kind of mentality could lead people in Brazil to do things they think could create some sort of electoral advantages."
The debate comes as the pace of deforestation in the Amazon, which is bigger than all of Western Europe, appears to be picking up. After reaching a record level in the mid-1990's, the destruction of tree cover slowed somewhat in 1999 and 2000, according to government monitors, as the Brazilian economy stagnated. 
But Brazil has largely recovered from that crisis, and the current Amazon dry season has been marked by drought. That makes felling or burning trees easier. 
"We have been seeing massive numbers of trucks and buses hauling laborers deeper and deeper into the jungle to cut down trees so as to create new cattle ranches," said Amarildo Gomes Pereira, who monitors deforestation patterns for the Roman Catholic Church's Pastoral Land Commission from the jungle town of Tucuma. 
The government is seeking to postpone a final vote on the proposal. But backers of the bill like Mr. Moreira Mendes are pushing for a quick decision. 
"The integrity of the most magnificent forest on the planet is a right of the many future generations of Brazilians who, unlike large landholders, have not been heard in Congress," the Minister of the Environment, Jose Sarney Filho, said recently. "It is up to the state and public opinion to undertake an intransigent defense of this right."

HEADLINE: Italians Hold Large Protest Rally After Parliament Clears Police 

BYLINE:  By MELINDA HENNEBERGER 

DATELINE: ROME, Sept. 21 

 BODY:
Thousands of demonstrators took to the streets here this week, just hours after Parliament approved a report absolving the police of wrongdoing during a meeting of world leaders in Genoa two months ago. The legislators acted even though reports of brutality there have never been seriously disputed.
 The crowds appeared Thursday to protest globalization, which was the target of the protests in Genoa. But they also protested against terrorism, NATO and a proposed tightening of immigration laws. 
 With the terrorist attacks in the United States, the protesters' concerns seem to have evolved since the Genoa meeting in July. That is partly because there is deepening support among Italians for police action to assure public order.
The new concerns of the left include a proposed law that would impose jail sentences on people repeatedly caught entering the country without proper papers.
Proposed changes in the way that white-collar crimes are prosecuted have also given the protesters a chance to mobilize opinion against the center-right government of Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi. His critics have complained, to little avail, that the law could have the effect of causing judges to throw out several accounting fraud cases pending against Mr. Berlusconi. 
In recent days, though, there has been some real debate over whether a provision in the same group of proposed laws, one that makes it more difficult to follow money trails abroad, might benefit terrorists.
An article in La Repubblica said today that Parliament might make it "so difficult to exchange information with other nations that it would hinder investigations into terrorism."
Despite a police raid in the middle of the night on protesters at the July meeting in Genoa, and the death of one protester, this week's government report defended the police, saying that in Genoa the officers "did their utmost, paying a high price in terms of risking injury."

HEADLINE: New Kind of Settler Finding a Way in Japan 

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Sept. 22 

 BODY:
With Japan's population set to shrink further and faster than that of any other economically advanced country over the next half century, foreigners like Steven Gan are acquiring something of the aura of pioneers. 
 As a rare Westerner who settled here for the long term, Mr. Gan neatly fills the bill for a government that realizes that Japan must attract people from elsewhere in dramatically increased numbers, and yet remains jittery about large-scale immigration. 
 What is more, as Mr. Gan has built up a successful debt-collection business here, he has shaken up what had been a cottage industry with an unsavory reputation, and perhaps injected a bit of vigor into the country's sluggish economy. 
"For most people the image of the Japanese collection industry is the yakuza, or mafia," Mr. Gan said. "But as a foreigner I've been able to get beyond that, and lend some legitimacy to the business. There are over 7,000 collection agencies in the United States, but when I started out there were only five or six in all of Tokyo. 
For years Americans have complained that Japanese culture was impenetrable, that companies here only wanted to buy Japanese and that after a polite initial reception, those who sought to settle down here were often made to feel less than welcome. But Mr. Gan, and other Americans who have started their own businesses, bought homes or even gone to work for Japanese companies, say that things have been changing subtly in this society.
With only 1.7 million foreigners in Japan, out of a population of 127 million people, the country faces a huge task in attracting the 600,000 immigrants a year that the United Nations estimates it will need in order to stabilize its population and prevent wrenching labor and fiscal crises. 
If nothing is done, according to the Japanese government's projections there will be 100 million people in 2050 and only 67 million at century's end. 
Of the foreigners who live here, a million or so are Korean and Chinese residents who have long complained of discrimination. Many of the other foreigners here are actually people of Japanese ancestry who immigrated to Japan from Brazil and elsewhere during the economic boom years of the 1980's.
Although Japan has recently set a priority of attracting skilled immigrants, and people who can make an economic contribution right away, there are only about 45,000 Americans living in the country, according to government statistics. Hong Kong, with a population of only six million, has roughly the same number. 
Though discrimination in housing and other areas, like the academic world, still exists, many of the new professionals from the West share the belief that the Japanese work world is not as impermeable or unfair as long reputed. Moreover, they say, the influx of outsiders is increasingly appreciated for introducing badly needed new ways of doing things.
After spending a year as an exchange student at a Tokyo university, Jake Adelstein transferred there outright. Though he got his degree and was offered a job with the Sony Corporation, he decided to try his luck with the newspaper industry's famously difficult hiring examinations. "I never believed I would be hired by a Japanese newspaper, especially a major one like the Yomiuri, and never on the same terms as a Japanese person," said Mr. Adelstein, who is 32. "People had told me that was just impossible."
He took a cram class to prepare for the exam. But when he showed up at the Yomiuri Shimbun for the first of his interviews in 1992, Mr. Adelstein said, "at the reception desk people kept hinting to me that I was in the wrong place."
Japanese labor experts say that cases like these suggest that although a national effort is just beginning, the country will be able to attract talented immigrants. "Japanese companies cannot find human resources within their own organizations anymore, and there are few people who move from business to business with the skills that companies need," said Jiro Nakamura, a professor of labor economics at Tokyo Metropolitan University, who said that Japan had little choice but to lure more foreign workers. 
William Stonehill, a Chicago native, also arrived in Tokyo planning to study, hoping to add a graduate degree in Japanese to one he had already earned in Chinese, and like Mr. Adelstein, he eventually decided to settle.
"When I looked around, I noticed that there were no imports here," he said. "I had studied watch making, so I got into importing Swiss watches and German clocks. It is like wildcatting. You don't need a license or anything, so I got into business, walked into a shop and threw some stuff on the counter and asked if they would like to buy any of this merchandise." 
Before he got his start in watches, Mr. Stonehill said he had worked as a door-to-door salesman, selling courses in English and "terrorizing housewives to buy stuff for junior." 
"You ask a lot of foreigners in business here how they got started here, and they'll say the same thing. Nobody ever told them that it was impossible, so they just went out and started a business."

HEADLINE: Unthinkable, And Now, Unspeakable 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL J. WAKIN 

 BODY:
Beyond the direct devastation of so many lives, beyond the economic hardships and changed routines and gashed New York landscape, the attack on the World Trade Center has reached into the quieter corners of our existence.
 It has changed our inner landscape, in the words we use, the way we see images, the way we think. 
 Obviously, the nation's news media and entertainment industry have embarked on a sweeping purge, whether delaying movies that involve terrorism or bombs in planes ("Big Trouble"), deleting shots of the towers in television shows ("Sex and the City"), discouraging radio stations from playing certain songs (Talking Heads' "Burning Down the House") or pulling ads that now could have double meanings.
People are doing their own interior editing. Words are bearing freight they never had to before. Imaginations are rendering certain images and sounds differently. 
"Every time I hear a large airplane motor, I look up," said Paul Fussell, an author and emeritus professor of English at the University of Pennsylvania. "I think we have a new 'sky consciousness.' Every time I look at a tall building in Philadelphia, I can imagine it as a potential victim."
"In the late Victorian period, there was almost no sense of disaster for ordinary people," said Dr. Fussell, who wrote "The Great War and Modern Memory" (Oxford University Press, 1975), an influential study of language and World War I. 
Dr. Fussell speculated that a new sense of language might also emerge. "How about what this is going to do to words as innocent as 'cement,' 'ashes,' 'parts' as in body parts, 'planes,' 'fuel' and so on?" he asked. "Each one of those is going to take on a partially negative and menacing implication."
Other disastrous events have changed perceptions of words and the human condition; it is difficult now to refer to a fire as a holocaust.
The writer Jonathan Rabb, who has written two history-based thrillers about plots to achieve world domination, says he has now become highly sensitive to the words he uses in conversation.
"At one point I was going to use the word 'towering,' like, 'He's a towering intellect,' and there was a hitch," said Mr. Rabb, who lives in Manhattan. "I went, 'Oh, do I want to use that word?' " 
Second thoughts and even dirty looks have followed phrases heard in conversation like "crash and burn" (as in fail), "shoot down" (as in nix an idea), "had a blast" (as in fun). One man on a city street was heard to say, "He folded like a house of cards." His friend said, "Bad choice of words, man."
The mundane has taken on new meaning. A 3-year-old boy at a Montclair, N.J., nursery school last week built a tower of blocks. As he innocently knocked them down, the teacher gasped in shock.
An eighth-grade science teacher at the Horace Mann School said she would eliminate a test question this year that asks students to calculate potential gravitational energy using the example of a tightrope walker between the World Trade Center towers.
Thomas A. Lucas, who is producing and directing a documentary for the Discovery channel about the Milky Way, has altered his script. To illustrate how large stars collapse into black holes, he had planned to use the implosion of a building as a light-hearted metaphor.
Humor, of course, was an immediate casualty. David Letterman choked up on air, The New Yorker published no humorous cartoons, and gallows humor was markedly absent from newsrooms. 
One Manhattan woman who used to tease her unshaven son for looking like an "Arab terrorist" said she would never make that remark again.
Rob Stevens, a record producer, and a market analyst, Paul Marsh, have for months been planning a call-in radio program that would take Wall Street to task with a mix of humorous banter and irreverent analysis. It was to begin Oct. 1 but will be delayed two weeks and then assume a more sober tone. 
"I haven't really laughed much since Tuesday," Mr. Stevens said. "It's just incredibly inappropriate."

HEADLINE: Chinese Creating a New Vigor in Russian Far East 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: ZABAIKALSK, Russia 

 BODY:
For a lesson in 21st-century geopolitics, come to this border town, until just a few years ago an outpost for Russian infantry awaiting a Chinese invasion. 
 Russian gun emplacements are crumbling now but the invasion is under way anyway: Chinese built the town's few new apartments, China Telecom connects the cellular phones, and Chinese traders hire busloads of jobless Russians to tote Chinese-made clothes and electronics through the Chinese-built border crossing. Maybe 1,000 of the 11,000 or so residents are Chinese, too. 
 The inescapable impression, here and elsewhere in the region, is of a land clinging tightly to its essential Russianness -- and slowly losing its grip. Along a stretch of Russian borderland as big as Western Europe, demographics, economics and, for the first time, history are all working against Moscow. 
"What we see in the Russian far east is the peaceful and slow colonization of all Russian territories in the area by the Chinese," said Alexei D. Bogaturov, the deputy director of the Institute of U.S.A. and Canada Studies here. "We have a grave problem, I think." 
Grave is a strong word, and many would dispute it. After all, decades of ideological and territorial disputes -- and a near war in 1969 -- have been settled and Russia-China relations are warmer now than at any time since the 1950's. In July the two countries struck a strategic alliance aimed in part at offsetting America's global dominance. 
One result of this sudden coziness has been a burst in trade. Chinese purchases of weapons, oil and timber have kept Russia's arms industry afloat and its trade balance healthy. Russian purchases of Chinese produce and clothing saved many from starvation and freezing during hard times in the 1990's. 
Overall trade jumped 40 percent last year alone -- albeit to a fairly puny $8 billion -- and could easily pass $10 billion in 2001. While all that may be good for Russia as a whole, it has so far overwhelmed its far east, given the gross imbalance along the border between a booming Chinese economy and this part of Russia that has perennially failed to feed, clothe and house itself. 
Though fabulously rich in timber, gold and coal, the Russian far east was long propped up by huge Soviet subsidies -- in the 1970's as much as half of all meat, dairy products and vegetables -- to keep the miners and loggers at work. For a long time, much of the economy also turned on the military's heavy presence in the border region. 
When Communism collapsed, so did the subsidies. The military all but disappeared, too, leaving a wreckage of near ghost towns behind. China has filled the vacuum. From Vladivostok to Zabaikalsk, Russians are coming to depend on the Chinese for everything from buildings to bananas to boomboxes. And that is unsettling even to the architects of the Sino-Russian reconciliation. 
President Vladimir V. Putin warned last year that the spread of Asian influence in the Russian far east placed Russia's very existence at stake. "If we don't make concrete efforts," he said, "the future local population will speak Japanese, Chinese or Korean." 
By themselves such fears are old hat. A scare swept the region in the late 1800's, when 75 percent of Amur region gold miners and 90 percent of Primorsky region railroad workers were Chinese. The difference is that in 1890 Russia was the expanding power, pressing its advantage against a China in disarray. Today it is the Chinese who are on the rise, and Russia a husk of its 1990 self. 
The Europe-size stretch of Russia along the border holds fewer than 6.2 million people, down 5 percent since 1991. The equivalent provinces on the Chinese side are home to 132 million -- and growing by a million a year. 
But what most bothers Russian experts is not the potential for Chinese immigration: right now, there are no more than 250,000 Chinese in the Russian border provinces. Rather, it is the inexorable spread of Chinese economic clout. In 1990, the economic outputs of China and the Soviet Union were roughly equal. In 2000, China's gross domestic product was four times the size of the Russian Federation's -- and the gap is widening. 
Mr. Putin's fear is that Chinese economic expansion will crowd out Russian commerce and political power unless Moscow repopulates and rebuilds this ravaged region first. But precious few Russians want to move here, and money for rebuilding is scarce. 
All that is painfully apparent in Zabaikalsk, a desolate cluster of concrete-slab buildings laid on the treeless plain just miles from where Russia, China and Mongolia meet. The original Trans-Siberian Railroad paused here before entering China on its way to the Pacific. Later, when the Soviets rerouted the main track within Russian territory, Zabaikalsk became the end of the line. 
It still is. Even though the railroad is again clogged with China-bound oil tankers and timber flatcars, Zabaikalsk remains a dust-whipped, one-street town where potholes outnumber people and the flies are thick as, well, flies. 
For Zabaikalsk residents, paradise begins 50 yards across the border, past abandoned Russian tanks and rusted barb-wire fences. There the Chinese have built a gleaming free-trade center, a small city of hotels, freight-forwarding offices, wholesale stores and pagodas. 
On the horizon, 10 minutes down a freshly paved highway in China, is the city of Manzhouli. Ten years ago a Chinese version of Zabaikalsk, it is today a staging area for Russian trade -- a forest of skyscrapers and cafes "where even the street sweepers have cellular phones," one Russian said enviously. 
"It's a beautiful city. I wish ours was like that," said a Russian woman who would identify herself only as Valentina. "The Chinese spend money on Manzhouli. All our money goes to Moscow -- or into the pockets of the people in charge." In local parlance, Valentina is a camel, a pack animal for Chinese goods. Customs rules allow visitors to carry up to 110 pounds of Chinese products into Russia duty free. Every day Chinese and Russian merchants hire busloads of camels to lug sacks of Chinese goods across the border for sale throughout the Russian far east. 
According to local immigration service officials, border crossings here jumped 50 percent last year, to 300,000. Many were camels making up to three trips a day. Most sacks wind up at the Chinese market and warehouse, a labyrinth of rusting metal shipping containers dubbed the Field of Miracles, after the Russian knockoff of "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?" 
"The trade is going pretty well now, but economically, the situation is pretty weak here," said Chen Zelin, who rents one of the shipping containers. "For me, it's bad because a lot of Chinese are coming here. Competition's increasing. But I think it's good for the Russians, because they make money, too." 
Russians do make money. Zabaikalsk's finest homes, in a dirt-road subdivision nicknamed Santa Barbara, belong -- tellingly -- to local customs officers. But the money has not flowed to where it is most needed: infrastructure and workers, and even if the infrastructure is built to support greater trade and the economy revives, few Russians seem willing to move here. 
The only group that is willing, it would seem, is the one already close by: the Chinese. 
In Chita, the ramshackle 313,000-person capital of the Russian region of the same name, the economy is hardly brisk. But two Chinese construction companies are busily renovating a government building and a hotel, and putting up apartments and even a bowling alley. 
"To say we don't have our own construction workers isn't quite right. It's a matter of business," said Aleksandr Novastinsev, the deputy governor for foreign trade in the Chita region. "The Chinese do high quality work. And it's quite cheap." 
A five-story hotel near downtown is crammed with Chinese traders, three, four and more to a room. Its six-room basement harbors 50 Chinese construction workers -- "but they're big rooms," one explained cheerfully. 
In an adjacent warehouse that houses one of Chita city's Chinese markets -- there are three -- 40-year-old Gao Min sells brassieres and women's tops, a far cry from her last job at a food stand in Tsitsihar, a northeast China metropolis. She arrived here in 1994 on a tourist visa. Her husband followed in 1995, and their teenage son in 1998. The three of them pay about $160 a month to live in one of the hotel's biggest rooms -- an 8-by-12 foot cubicle with two daybeds, communal kitchen access and a ceiling-high stack of portable stereos. 
"There's a lot more opportunity to earn money here," Ms. Gao said. "We go back quite often, and we come back either according to our tourist visas or my husband's commercial passport." 
Asked how long the family would stay, she said only: "We haven't decided yet. We'll see."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED; 
TV Benefit Audience Surpasses Oscars

 BODY:
Almost 90 million people watched at least some of a star-filled telecast on Friday night to raise money for injured victims and the families of people killed in the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon.
 Barbara Brogliatti, a spokeswoman for the event, said yesterday that there was no estimate on how much money was raised and that there would not be one until at least tomorrow. 
The money is for a fund established by the major broadcast networks, which would be administered by the United Way under the guidance of a board of broadcast network representatives. 
 The Nielsen Media Research audience measurement service said 89 million people watched the telecast for at least six minutes. At any given time, Nielsen said, the telecast had an audience of 59 million people.
The audience was far higher than that of the Academy Awards show in March, watched by 43 million people, but not as large as that of President Bush's speech on Thursday, watched by an average audience of 82 million people.
Called "America: A Tribute to Heroes," the telecast was the most widely carried program ever shown, available on more than 30 national networks.
The telecast featured celebrities like Jack Nicholson and Julia Roberts and had no commercials. Ms. Brogliatti said the costs of the event were low because nearly every aspect of the production was donated.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: IMMIGRANTS; 
Lifelines to Home, Severed in an Instant

BYLINE:  By SOMINI SENGUPTA

 BODY:
A man making his usual breakfast deliveries up and down the twin towers was the sole breadwinner for six of his relatives in a farming village in Morelos, Mexico.
 An information technology specialist from Rockland County was the anchor to whom poor distant cousins in a rain-drenched village in Bangladesh still turned in times of need. 
 A single mother in Jackson Heights, Queens, who cleaned the suites of an international money management firm scrimped so her nieces in Colombia could eat.
The terrorist attack on the World Trade Center has not only left families across the New York area in dire straits, both emotional and economic, it has taken away men and women who were lifelines for needy families and impoverished towns halfway across the world. 
Some of them wired money home as soon as they cashed their paychecks. When the well ran dry back home, they were the ones who covered college tuitions or pitched in for a cousin's wedding. They sent home blenders and television sets and sneakers for their children. Some of them were the human tugboats for their communities -- the first in their families to migrate, the ones to help friends and relatives gain a foothold later in the new land.
Beyond the dead and the disappeared, there are those who are now blind, burned, maimed or jobless. A great many of them have relatives who depended, in varying degrees, on the dollars they sent home.
"They had this line of money every week, every 15 days," said Brother Joel Magallan, a Jesuit who runs Asociacion Tepeyac, an advocacy group for Mexican immigrants. "Now they know they are not receiving anything from the United States, from New York City."
His observations could hold true for families in Bangladesh or the Dominican Republic or Ecuador -- any one of the poorest corners of the third world, where prosperity, and sometimes survival, depends on remittances from relatives abroad.
A State Department spokeswoman, Susan Pittman, said on Friday that citizens of 79 countries were among the trade center victims. According to the mayor's office, they included 91 Indians, 35 Dominicans and 15 Colombians, though those numbers may fluctuate. Consular officials from around the world have spent the last week making arrangements for family members to travel to New York to offer DNA samples and fill out paperwork.
When the trade center collapsed, Juan Ortega Campos, 32, was still paying off his passage fee from Mexico -- $100 every month -- from what he earned as a deliveryman for Fine & Schapiro, a deli on the concourse under the twin towers.
Some weeks, the tips were good; some weeks they weren't. But no matter what they were, Mr. Campos's routine was the same, said Miguel Garcia, his childhood friend and his roommate. Every two weeks, he wired money home to his wife, Luz Maria -- sometimes $500, sometimes more. Every few weeks, he picked up something for his children: a book, a toy, a pair of shoes.
All told, Mr. Campos supported six people back home in Jonacatepec, a farming village in Morelos: his mother, his mentally ill brother, his wife and their three children -- two boys, 13 and 11, and a girl, 8. He had no intention of staying here forever, Mr. Garcia said. Mr. Campos was setting aside some money to build a house back in Morelos. He called home every Monday and Saturday.
The last time was the night before the attack; he told his wife he was coming down with a cold, and she urged him to buy some Theraflu. "He was a very responsible parent," Mr. Garcia said of his friend. "He was the only one who worked. He used to work for everybody."
That is why, Mr. Garcia said, he helped his friend make the trip here. 
Mr. Garcia's task now was to pick up Luz Maria Campos at Kennedy International Airport and take her to the Family Assistance Center to fill out the proper paperwork.
Gloria Nieves, the youngest of 10 siblings, was the first to leave Cali, Colombia, for the good life here, said her 15-year-old son, Christian Reyes. The good life turned out to be a job cleaning the offices of Fiduciary Trust. It was a boon for many others: nieces, to whom she sent money back home; a sister she helped bring here; even a friend's relatives, for whom the first stop was Ms. Nieves's Jackson Heights apartment.
Ms. Nieves wanted her son to have a different life. She had goaded him into enrolling in a high school where he could take a specialized computer class. "She wanted me, of all things in the world, to become a network administrator," Christian recalled. "To have money and stuff."
Mohammed Shajahan, born and raised in Asadpur, a village in the wet, marshy southeastern corner of Bangladesh, was also the first in his family to make the trek to New York. He studied computer science at Pace University, ran a convenience store and worked his way up to a well-paying job as an information technology specialist at Marsh & McLennan.
Year by year, Mohammed and Mona Shajahan's family grew in Spring Valley, N.Y. Mr. Shajahan, 41, helped two brothers immigrate here, one from Bangladesh, another who had been working in the Middle East. He became a generous, stalwart member of the Rockland County mosque. He brought visiting relatives to the twin towers.
But his home never quite left him. There was always someone in the village -- a distant relative, a friend of the family -- who needed his help, his sister-in-law, Ruby Zigrino, said. For them, Mr. Shajahan was a source of sustenance. She guessed it was driven partly by his faith.
He took seriously the notion of zakat -- the Islamic mandate to give alms to the poor. "He was a very simple, very decent man, a generous man," Ms. Zigrino said. He planned to take his four children -- the eldest, 8, the youngest, 3 -- back home to Asadpur soon.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Mohammed Shajahan, shown with his wife and children, worked at the twin towers. He also kept close ties to his homeland of Bangladesh.

HEADLINE: Paid Notice: Deaths; 
DICKEY, JOSEPH DERMOT, JR.

 BODY:
 DICKEY-Joseph Dermot, Jr. Loving husband of Irene, devoted father of Joseph and Elizabeth, treasured brother of William and Walter and their families, and beloved nephew of Isabelle Lawson and Eileen McPeake died on Tuesday, September 11, 2001 in the World Trade Center tragedy. Joe, the son of Irish immigrants, grew up in the Bronx where he attended Fordham Prep High School. He graduated from The University of Wisconsin in 1972 and received an MBA from SUNY Binghamton. Over the past twenty years, Joe worked tirelessly to build a successful career on Wall Street. At the time of his death, Joe was a Managing Director of Cantor Fitzgerald, working in the Interest Rate Swaps department. He was on the 105th Floor of Tower 1, directly above where the first plane hit. Honest almost to a fault, generous and kind, Joe was greatly admired and respected by all who knew him. He was an eternal optimist and had an unforgettable passion for life. But Joe always measured his own success on how good he was to his family. And he was an exceptional husband and father. He taught them to embrace life, take on new challenges and to love the outdoors as much as he did. In their early years together, Joe introduced Irene to the city and took her on long strolls in Central Park. On Fire Island, Joe taught his children how to swim out past the break, how to stay on top and out in front of the ocean's barrels. 
He coached his children's basketball teams, sat proudly on the sidelines at Joseph's crew regattas, and never missed an opportunity to play the back nine with Elizabeth. A savvy New York sports fan, Joe took the kids to see the Knicks, Rangers and Yanks, and enjoyed catching the Wisconsin Badgers on TV and talking sports with those around him. Although Joe has been taken from us all far sooner than we were ready to give him up, the whole family feels blessed to have had him in our lives. His smile and laugh will remain with us forever. Please join the family on Friday, September 28th to remember and celebrate the extraordinary life of Joseph Dermot Dickey, Jr. A memorial service will be held at 10:30AM at St. Mary's Church in Manhasset, followed by lunch at Leo's, a local restaurant. In lieu of flowers, the family suggests a contribution in the memory of Joseph D. Dickey, Jr. to the families of the New York fire fighters who lost their lives trying to save our Joe and countless others. UFA Widows' and Children's Fund: 204 East 23rd Street, NY, NY 10010.

RUDIN, LEWIS

 BODY:
RUDIN-Lewis, 74 years old of New York City, co-chairman of Rudin Management Company, Inc. and Chairman of the Association for a Better New York. Died peacefully Thursday, September 20, 2001 in his home, surrounded by his loving family after courageously battling cancer. He was a great and special man who will be missed by his family, so many friends and the city he loved. We loved him dearly. He is survived by his adoring wife, Rachel, his brother, Jack, his children, Beth Rudin DeWoody, William Rudin and his wife, Ophelia, grandchildren, Carlton, Samantha, Kyle and Michael, nieces, nephews, grand nephews and cousins. Services will be held Sunday, September 23 at 10 A.M. at Central Synagogue, Lexington Avenue at 55th Street. In lieu of flowers donations may be made to: Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th Street, NY, NY 10022, 212-838-5122; Twin Towers Fund, P.O. Box 26999, General Post Office, NY, NY 10087; The Fund for Ophthalmic Knowledge, Inc. HEADLINE: L.I. @ WORK; 
Morton's Foresees a Loss

BYLINE:  By Warren Strugatch

 BODY:
 Morton's Restaurant Group (NYSE: MRG) of New Hyde Park said that revenues at its Morton's of Chicago steakhouse chain dropped more than 10 percent in the third quarter, compared with the same quarter last year, ending a decade of continuous quarterly revenue growth. 
 The company attributed the diminished revenues to cuts in corporate spending, reduced business travel and the continuing impact of the national economic slowdown. The company repeated an earlier warning that it expected to report a loss for the third quarter, which ends Sept. 30.

HEADLINE: Business; 
Defiantly, TheStreet Retakes The Street

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN D. GLATER

 BODY:
FOR many Manhattan bankers, brokers and lawyers who returned to work last week, the mission was to show the world they had not been stopped.
 Markets may have plummeted after the New York Stock Exchange reopened on Monday -- and throughout the week -- but denizens of Wall Street voiced a defiant determination to keep on doing what they had done before, only more successfully. 
 Many said they felt the attack that destroyed the World Trade Center was aimed at them, not just because it killed relatives, friends and colleagues, but because it seemed to seek to destroy their way of life.
"I'll be damned if I'm going to allow anybody to put us out of business or succeed in perpetrating terror," Joel Simon, a partner in Serko & Simon, recalled telling a colleague last week. The offices of Serko & Simon, a small law firm, were on the 33rd floor of 1 World Trade Center, but all lawyers and the rest of the staff escaped. 
"We're just anxious to do what we've done for all these years," Mr. Simon said in an interview last week from the law offices of Baker & Hostetler, which has provided Serko & Simon with temporary space. "That is the sense that I get from what's going on in New York these days."
Another investment banker, who did not want to be identified because he was working on a transaction, said, "We're doing deals, and we're going to keep doing deals."
By going back to work and continuing to buy and sell stocks, to negotiate and seal mergers and to find credit for corporate clients, the investment bankers and lawyers say they can best show the world that if the intent of the attack was to shut them down, then it had failed.
"That's the contribution I can make here," said Greg Fleming, head of the financial institutions group at Merrill Lynch. "A lot of the people on Wall Street aren't the people who are going to be part of some military response."
Mr. Fleming said that even in the aftermath of the attack, some investment bankers he supervises were ready to hop back on airplanes to meet with clients as necessary. So many staff members wanted to work at the firm's temporary offices in Midtown that their shifts had to be staggered -- the new office space was not big enough to hold everyone at the same time, he said.
The firm offered some evidence that bankers' determination was bearing some fruit: On Wednesday, Merrill Lynch underwrote the sale of $600 million in bonds for Canadian National Railway. The firm is also serving as financial adviser to RWE in its acquisition of American Waterworks, an $8 billion deal announced on Tuesday.
SO strong was the impulse to respond to the disaster, both to help and to send a message that Wall Street was still ticking, that Elizabeth T. Davy, a lawyer, left her 6-week-old daughter, Lily, and 3-year-old son, Colin, with a baby sitter and headed in to the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell on the Monday after the attack -- even though she was on maternity leave.
"That's the Wall Street way," Ms. Davy said. "I just trooped in there."
At J. P. Morgan, the investment banking arm of J. P. Morgan Chase, software and systems employees worked nearly 24 consecutive hours after the attack to get computer equipment running, said Geoff Boisi, co-chief executive of the firm. They switched to 12-hour shifts the second day after the attack, he said, and on Monday the volume of stocks traded was double anything the firm had ever handled.
The firm has closed deals even in the current hostile market environment thanks to the anger felt by many bankers, Mr. Boisi said.
But it is more than defiance, several Wall Streeters said. On trading floors and in conference rooms, there is a new esprit de corps, a feeling that everyone is, in the big picture, on the same side.
That attitude was reflected in displays of kindness, a little less of the hardheaded, take-no-prisoners attitude associated with doing deals, said Kenneth A. Lefkowitz, co-chairman of the mergers and acquisitions group at Hughes Hubbard & Reed. 
"Negotiations have been much more friendly," he said. "There's usually a certain back and forth; sometimes deals are collegial, but other times there are real discussions and there's some bitterness."
Last week, a lawyer negotiating a deal with him called and left a message wishing Mr. Lefkowitz a happy new year on Rosh Hashana. The same lawyer, he said, had been far more adversarial earlier.

SECTION: Section 9; Column 3; Style Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1482 words

HEADLINE: Gossip Holds Its Tongue 

BYLINE:  By ALEX KUCZYNSKI

 BODY:
TWO nights after the attack on the World Trade Center, Harrison Ford walked into Da Silvano, a favorite restaurant in Greenwich Village, with a woman on each arm. Mr. Ford has been a constant source of celebrity gossip because of his separation from his wife of 18 years. But what would have turned heads two weeks ago went totally unremarked.
 Sarah Jessica Parker, the siren of HBO's "Sex and the City," walked by the restaurant. No one blinked, said Silvano Marchetto, the restaurant's owner. 
 But a firetruck -- now, that was something to behold. 
As one slowed to a stop nearby, diners rose in a wave through the restaurant and its patios, clapping and whistling. The firefighters nodded solemnly as the truck drove past. Only then did the room begin to buzz with conversation. 
New Yorkers, jaded by celebrity, seem thoroughly tired of it for now. They are also shrugging off the industry that both sustains celebrity and feeds off it: gossip, as natural a part of New York as designer martinis and trophy wives. In the days immediately after the attack, the city's professional tattletales fell appropriately silent. The New York Post's most popular column, Page Six, by Richard Johnson, failed to appear for the first time in 25 years. And in a chastened statement, the eminent Liz Smith, whose syndicated column also appears in The Post and about 70 other newspapers, complained to readers of the trivial nature of her work at such a time. "I want to go somewhere and volunteer," she wrote. "To hell with gossip and entertainment."
Now the columns have hesitantly come back to life, but their bark is much diminished, both in terms of column inches and the viciousness of their tone. 
For 12 days, at least, columnists folded the tents they have long propped up so gaudily with speculation about which teenage star had breast implants and whose marriage of convenience was falling apart.
David P. Columbia, the editor in chief of both Quest magazine and of NewYork SocialDiary.com, a daily posting of Manhattan gossip, said he expects the genre to continue, but in a subdued (translation: boring) form for a while. "The real viciousness and sniping that has been going on for so long, that coy 'letting people have it and passing judgment,' that has been frozen for a while," Mr. Columbia said. "I think this has cleaned up our consciousness a bit." He added: "I don't know how long it will last but I hope it has some permanent effects." 
What happens to Anne Heche's alternate universes? And what of the episode the columns called "L'Affaire Grubman"? From Swifty's on the Upper East Side to Della Femina in the Hamptons, people seem embarrassed that they ever cared enough to read about it. 
"We all seem so superficial to have ever cared," said a woman whose name often appears in gossip columns and asked that it not be used. "It all seems shameful and stupid, that we had such tiny lives." 
Columnists and editors predict that the greasy wheel of gossip will turn again, of course, if only to serve as a distraction. But the immediate effect of Sept. 11 is a new, genial tone, and the Daily News columnist Mitchell Fink, Richard Johnson of The New York Post and MSNBC's Jeannette Walls said they have received fewer anonymous finger-pointing phone calls. The content often focuses on the budding generation of celebrities produced by the events of Sept. 11: Page Six' Sightings columns noted "Mayor Giuliani getting a standing ovation from everyone in Fresco's."
Linda Ashland, a former editor at Town & Country, said that she still reads the gossip columns but is more interested in the lives of real people. "I couldn't care less about celebrities," she said. "But I'm still reading all the columns. It's a part of life in New York." 
In The Post, the Page Six column was moved to the back of the paper after the disaster. By last Wednesday it had inched forward, although as of Friday it had not yet reached its standard slot, on Page 8. 
At first "the sheer gravity and weight of the story moved gossip toward the back of the paper, Col Allan, The Post's editor in chief, said on Thursday. "But in the last couple of days we have moved it forward because the paper is a destination for people who want to read gossip. So it has to have a significant position in the newspaper." 
Gossip's significant position in New York culture stems from its ability to separate the insiders from the outsiders, said Leo Braudy, a historian and the author of "The Frenzy of Renown: Fame and Its History" (Replica, 1996). 
Gossip, he added, is also a useful way to bring the rich and famous down a notch. People spread it to demonstrate the knowledge they have that others do not, and depend on it to humanize the famous, who appear impossibly distant and perfect. Now that the rich are just as vulnerable as everyone else, gossip about them has lost its punch. 
"Are you helping the world by passing on gossip and wondering who a better sexual partner for Anne Heche is?" he asked. "No. But I don't think the events have changed celebrity and gossip forever. I can only hope it gives us a sense of proportion. This is the fall. A fall of innocence. A fall into a different kind of awareness." 
Carol Wallace, the managing editor of People magazine, spent Friday morning with staff members, discussing how to move with sensitivity back into the celebrity grind. 
But this time with a difference: when a publicist called her last week, pitching a story that might have flown three weeks ago, about the wife of a famous actor and her battle with irritable bowel syndrome, Ms. Wallace turned the story down. 
"We're going to hold off on stories like that, I would think," she said. "The news right now is not pretty and it's not happy. Is some frothy, silly celebrity story going to appear in People magazine again? Yes. But we'll ease back into it." 
Though it's hard to draw parallels with the glory days of gossip, the 1940's (origin of canoodling and leggy starlets), once the United States entered the second world war, gossip columnists stopped training their sights on Hollywood and focused on the enemy. Walter Winchell, who started his career scooping the theater world, became such an influential voice during the war that Franklin Delano Roosevelt asked that he be excused from serving in the Navy so that he could continue writing his anti-Nazi columns. 
Celebrities similarly looked for ways to express their patriotism. Unlike today, many mingled comfortably with their admirers. "Jack Benny and Bob Hope were entertaining the troops, and you could go to the Hollywood Canteen and dance with a starlet so long as you were a man in uniform," Mr. Braudy said. "There was not the sense that they necessarily lived in this rarefied world." 
The fate of celebrities today may be determined by how the public perceives their responses in coming weeks, or how their image custodians counsel them, said Mr. Fink of The Daily News. 
"Who knows about someone like Pamela Anderson Lee?" Mr. Fink said. "She could lead a war bond drive. I just don't know."
Ms. Walls, the gossip correspondent for MSNBC, said that celebrities would be expected to play different roles in the culture now. "They have the ability to create a great sense of unity," Ms. Walls said, noting the large number of stars who were gathering for Friday's celebrity telethon benefiting the victims of the attack.
Mr. Johnson, whose typical recent items have included an upbeat report on prominent actors in a benefit performance to help children face the tragedy and an item titled "Bloomberg to the Rescue," about the mayoral candidate Michael Bloomberg's disaster relief efforts, said he was not sure how long all the goodwill would last. (Nanoseconds, apparently. He has already sharpened his tongue, calling Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani "a big star who's about to be unemployed.")
Even with the new spic-and-span intentions, some of the publicity pitches Mr. Johnson was hearing were the same-old, same-old.
"There was a total silence for a few days from the professional public relations people who normally try to feed the column," he said. "Then it picked right back up again." He turned down one "salute" -- he hung verbal quotation marks around the word -- to the spirit of New York, sponsored by a onetime Warhol-crowd icon. "It's at some sleazy discotheque," he said. "Yech." 
Leslee Dart, a public relations executive at PMK, who manages the public's perception of celebrities like Tom Hanks and Woody Allen, is confident that celebrities will survive, and that the gossip machine will bounce back to nurture or punish them. 
"The general gossip stuff is not going to be of much interest right now, but it will come back right to where it once was," she said. As far as celebrities, "we have canonized them," she said. "We have as a culture gone so far off the deep end I think we have no choice but to go right back to where we were."
