LENGTH: 1361 words

HEADLINE: Dazed Companies Sit on Their Wallets 

BYLINE:  By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
FOR the first time in 15 years, the England brothers have decided that their family-owned trucking company, C.R. England Inc., will not expand its fleet of 2,500 tractor-trailers. "After the terrorism," Dean England said, "nothing will entice us."
 Manpower Inc., the nation's largest supplier of temporary workers, canceled plans to open 40 new offices in response to the attacks on Sept. 11. "We were expecting a short recession -- over by March," said Jeffrey Joerres, the chief executive. "Our new horizon is next September." 
 Eastman Chemical, one of the nation's largest suppliers of material for plastics and paint, has not yet experienced a drop in orders, but expansion is delayed. "Any investment that was planned is at the very least postponed," said Earnest W. Davenport Jr., the chairman. 
American business, already pulling back as the economy weakened, is now cutting back even more, freezing the investment in new buildings and equipment that had contributed so much to the prosperity of the late 1990's.
Analysts are just beginning to notice the cutbacks. In the days after the terrorist attacks, they had focused on consumers, who curtailed spending immediately. Consumers appear to be gradually returning to more normal shopping habits, although they continue to be cautious about big purchases like cars and homes and extra spending on family outings.
Business, however, has moved in the opposite direction, and its retreat seems to be gaining momentum. The slowdown that hit the nation more than a year ago came mostly from a sharp cutback in business investment, not consumer spending. Now, thousands of companies, simply by waiting or avoiding additional investment, appear to be pushing the economy more deeply into a recession. 
Moreover, as the companies hit hardest -- airlines and aircraft makers, hotels and convention centers, computer manufacturers and car dealers -- lay off tens of thousands of workers, the damage to the economy will spread.
"In autos, in steel, in electronics, in farm equipment, in airlines -- everywhere -- business executives are too uncertain to go forward," said Nariman Behravesh, chief economist of DRI-WEFA, an economic consulting and forecasting service in Lexington, Mass.
Among forecasters, there is little doubt that the economy is shrinking. The discussion has switched to how long a recession will last and how steep it will be. Like most of the nation's forecasters, Mr. Behravesh has reversed his prediction that the economy would start improving in the second half of the year. Instead, he, like many others, now expects a slump to last at least through spring.
Uncertainty is overwhelming the economy in ways rarely experienced in the United States. David Collander, an economic historian at Middlebury College, says that companies are used to dealing with risks, but that the response to terrorist attacks goes beyond the normal range of economic theory. "The only thing economists and forecasters can do," he said, "is follow along and see what happens."
For the moment, the uncertainty has caused executives to delay investments until they have answers to some difficult questions: Will there be more acts of terrorism? What form will American retaliation take? Will consumers here and abroad adopt a bunker mentality?
Those concerns were evident in interviews last week with business managers across the country. The reaction, Mr. Collander said, is similar to corporate behavior during the Cuban missile crisis in 1962. That crisis and the uncertainty it generated hurt the economy, but the fear that the world was on the brink of nuclear confrontation lasted less than three weeks. The current crisis is open-ended.
When the uncertainty lifts, or corporate executives learn how to live with it, then the economy may come back stronger than ever, rebounding from the sharp decline in part because Washington is moving aggressively to cut interest rates and to expand federal spending.
For the moment, however, caution rules, even among companies that expect to benefit from the new atmosphere.
Allen J. Lauer, chief executive at Varian Inc., based in San Mateo, Calif., has divided the future into short term and long term. For the next three or four months, Mr. Lauer says, Varian, which makes instruments and vacuum pumps used in manufacturing high-technology equipment, will be cautious about how much it invests and how many employees it adds. 
Longer term, Mr. Lauer said he was counting on "a shot from stepped-up federal spending for weapons." Military contractors are big purchasers of Varian's products.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, was similarly optimistic on Thursday. "For the longer term," he told the Senate Banking Committee, "prospects for continued rapid technological advance and associated faster productivity growth are scarcely diminished."
A few companies see their operations as immune, even if uncertainty endures. Hospital companies fall into this category. "We will be continuing with a number of major capital expansions" to meet the needs of aging baby boomers, said Harry Anderson, a spokesman for Tenet Health Care, in Santa Barbara, Calif., which owns or runs 114 hospitals.
Wal-Mart displayed a similar spirit, going ahead with the opening of a new supercenter last week in Union, N.J., across the river from Lower Manhattan and within view of the ruins of the World Trade Center. 
"We are sticking with our expansion plans," a Wal-Mart executive said. "Sales have bounced back from last week."
But Manpower, based in Milwaukee; Eastman Chemical, in Kingsport, Tenn.; and C.R. England, operating out of Salt Lake City, are more representative of the new cautiousness chipping away at the economy.
So are small thriving companies like Burrelle's Information Services, which clips media references for corporate clients. It was about to expand two offices in Maine, adding to the 780 employees there. "We won't do that now," said Robert Waggoner, the chief executive of the company, which is based in Livingston, N.J.
Summarizing conference calls last week with several chief executives, Jerry Jasinowski, the president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said, "The freeze is on new capital investment, hiring and nonessential travel." For most companies, "it is a freeze, not a downsizing," he said. "Because of the emergency nature of the situation, you really want to avoid any new commitment."
Some companies are facing a more immediate crisis. Airlines, forced to cut back flights until more people are ready to fly again, have announced that they will eliminate 79,000 jobs, almost 12 percent of total employment.
The ripple effect is much worse, said David A. Swierenga, chief economist of the Air Transport Association. For every airline job that is lost, six or seven jobs disappear in related industries. These include, he said, "people who work in airports, at travel agencies, for aircraft manufacturers, hotels, resorts, Disneyland-like amusement centers."
THE terrorism has also jolted home builders, whose energetic activities have been, until now, a mainstay of the economy. Although new construction starts on single-family homes fell in August, they are still above the levels a year ago. That is mainly because builders, until Sept. 11, had been willing to build houses they have not sold in advance.
These "speculative starts" represent more than 30 percent of new single-family construction, according to the National Association of Home Builders. "Now some builders are telling us they will discontinue spec starts," said Michael Carliner, the association's vice president.
Centex Homes, based in Dallas and one of the nation's largest home builders, was already moving in this direction. Of the 22,000 houses that the company expected to build in its current fiscal year, only about 2,000 -- one month's supply at its current sales pace -- will be built on spec.
"If our perception is correct that sales will come down in the wake of what happened last week," said Lawrence Hirsh, Centex's chief executive, "then one month of unsold homes can quickly become two months. We are going to become more careful in our construction and sales."

HEADLINE: Suddenly, the Magic Is in Short Supply 

BYLINE:  By GERALDINE FABRIKANT with SETH SCHIESEL

 BODY:
ONE are the Mickey T-shirts and the Pooh paraphernalia. After the terrorist attack on New York, Disney stores in Manhattan swapped the colorful merchandise that usually fills their display windows for huge posters quoting the company's founder, Walt Disney: "Tomorrow will be better for as long as America keeps alive the ideals of freedom and a better life."
 Tomorrow may not be better, however, for the Walt Disney Company. Like many other companies, it faces the likelihood that the Sept. 11 attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon will cause a slowing economy to come to a stop. Public anxiety about further attacks and military reprisals is keeping people at home, with their wallets closed. 
 Not all businesses will be hurt to the same degree, but the evidence so far is that companies that rely on travel, advertising and retailing are in for a particularly rough time. Disney, because of its heavy investment in theme parks and hotels as well as broadcast and cable television, faces more uncertainty than its competitors. 
At the Epcot Center near Orlando, Fla., for example, acres of parking lots sit almost empty, as does Main Street at Disneyland in Anaheim, Calif. Advertisers are reluctant to buy television time while the nation's consumers are preoccupied by the prospect of war. And thousands of prints of "Big Trouble," a movie that Disney had expected to be a big hit, are in storage because the plot involves a bomb in a suitcase on a plane.
That explains in part why Disney's stock has slid 38.2 percent this year, to close at $17.89 on Friday, a larger decline than any of its big-media rivals. Even before the disaster, Disney was having problems, and the terror attacks only made them worse.
"Disney has been hit the hardest of the media companies due not only to its advertising exposure but the impact that safety concerns have had on park attendance," said Scott Davis, a media analyst at First Union Securities.
Adding to the company's concerns, the Bass family of Texas on Thursday had to sell $2 billion of Disney stock -- almost 6 percent of the total -- to cover its losses on telecommunications stocks. The sale has diluted the influence of the staunchest supporters of Michael D. Eisner, Disney's chairman, and put ownership of a flood of company stock in diverse hands. That is likely to increase speculation of a possible takeover, analysts said.
"It never even crossed my mind about getting taken over," Mr. Eisner said in a telephone interview on Friday.
More than half of Disney's revenue comes from businesses that depend on travel, including theme parks and cruises, or on advertising -- the two parts of the entertainment business that appear most threatened. The comparable figure for AOL Time Warner, by comparison, is about 25 percent.
Tourism is even more important for Disney's profits than it is for the company's revenue. The theme parks and resorts segment accounted for about half of the entire company's $1.12 billion in operating profit in the last quarter. Analysts said they think the resorts business is the unit most vulnerable to a slowdown.
Last year, Disney made a $920 million profit on $25.4 billion in revenue.
FACED with further potential declines, Disney, like so many other mainstays of corporate America, is simply trying to cope. But there is only so much to be done. On Thursday evening, after news of the Bass sale had roiled Wall Street, Mr. Eisner issued a statement acknowledging that the terror attacks had hurt the company's retail outlets, theme parks and resorts. But, he added, "as the nation slowly regains its equilibrium, so does Disney."
Disney's president, Robert A. Iger, said he believed that "it is too soon to judge the events which were previously unthinkable."
"Clearly there was an impact," he said, "but we don't think it should be used as a bellwether of what is to come. We believe that our businesses are resilient."
Mr. Eisner declined to quantify the company's near-term costs as a result of the attacks, including a loss of television advertising revenue. But he said, "I am an optimistic person by nature and that has not been knocked out of me by this."
In the past, he added, gasoline shortages, recession and other problems that have cut attendance have created "enormous" pent-up demand. "If we have a couple of months where fear holds people home, by the time that has subsided, the demand for our products is always greater than anything we had anticipated," he said.
Right now, however, Disney's distress stems from its commitment to theme parks, a commitment that rewarded the company handsomely when the economy was booming and Americans were eager to spend. Even as other big entertainment companies got out of the business -- Time Warner and its partners, for instance, sold the Six Flags chain to Premier Parks Inc. in 1998 for $965 million -- Disney doubled down, building new properties. For good reason, perhaps, the company has always seen its parks as an invaluable conduit for building lifelong loyalty and identification with Disney characters.
But as a result of higher fuel prices and the slowing economy, attendance at Disney's parks was already stagnating this year. In particular, its new California Adventure park in Anaheim, which opened in February, has not attracted as many visitors as analysts had expected.
NOW fears of more terrorist attacks are halting skittish travelers. As unthreatening as Mickey, Pooh and other Disney characters may be, many potential customers these days are finding home even more comfortable.
To be sure, some strong-minded tourists are exhibiting a defiant attitude and keeping scheduled visits. Kelly Gurick, of Blackwood, N.J., for example, was on her 25th visit to a Disney park. "I was a little nervous about getting on an airplane," she said, but she was determined not to be intimidated by terrorists. "I paid so much money, and they are not going to ruin my vacation," she said.
But terrorists are apparently ruining the vacations of many others. Disney does not release attendance figures for its parks, but one employee who spoke on condition of anonymity estimated that they were receiving only half the usual number of visitors. One tourist, Robin Senecal, 37, an interior designer who was born in Canada and has lived in New Zealand for 10 years, said she had never seen a theme park as empty as Disneyland when she visited last week. "The shops are almost empty," she said. "It's almost creepy."
Paul Pressler, who heads the theme parks and cruises business, said that visitors had been postponing rather than canceling visits, and that there had been some rebound since the tragedy.
The theme parks have security strategies in place, though Disney itself understandably tries to play down any possibility of violence, for fear it will frighten visitors. "There are plans for hurricanes and terrorism," said John Dreyer, a company spokesman. "When it is appropriate, we immediately put those plans into place. But there are some we prefer not to talk about."
Renae Callahan, a Disney spokesman, said that security had been increased at the parks, and that there were more uniformed guards than in previous months, with systematic searches of visitor bags and purses at entry points.
There is also the repeated assurance that Disney's parks have survived the downturns in travel after the Persian Gulf war and the California earthquakes and have always come back.
Others agree, as long as the parks are not directly affected. "The worst horrible nightmare that any theme park company has is that there will be some acts of violence," said Sidney Sheinberg, who was president of MCA Inc., which owned Universal Theme Parks in the 1990's. "Violence can destroy your friendliness to the public."
To cope with the financial problem at hand, Disney is trying to cut costs. At the Orlando parks -- Walt Disney World, Epcot, Disney-MGM Studios and Disney's Animal Kingdom -- 40,000 hourly workers have had their work weeks cut. Overtime has been eliminated and operating hours have been shortened. The Magic Kingdom is losing its magic after 7 p.m. instead of its usual 9 p.m.
At Disneyland, hot-dog stands, often reduced during off-peak periods, have been eliminated because there are not enough customers. 
But cost-cutting can help only so much at a company like Disney, because many costs at its theme parks are largely fixed. The company can dismiss some employees, but not too many or it risks corrupting what it calls the "Disney experience." And the parks cannot simply cut back on rides when business slows because guests pay for all of the attractions whether or not the park is packed. And whether a roller coaster is 80 percent full or 30 percent full, it costs about the same to operate and maintain -- especially for Disney, which prides itself on delivering a top-notch experience to each guest.
"When attendance is rising, Disney's business works terrifically because they are putting so many people through the theme parks, and they don't have to spend any extra money," said one veteran media executive familiar with Disney. "But it runs into problems when attendance drops, because they are stuck with those same costs.
"There is simply no way to calibrate supply and demand," he added. "It's not like a car company, where you can close a plant."
As a result, "the largest challenge, which is not controllable, is how fast the tourism volume comes back," said Richard A. Bilotti, a media analyst at Morgan Stanley. A comeback may be more difficult for Walt Disney World than for Disneyland, he said, because about half the people who go to Disney World arrive there by plane, and travelers so far seem reluctant to fly.
If one assumes that families will stay away from the theme parks in rough times, they may prefer to cuddle up around videos at home. That should benefit Disney, with its roster of evergreen animated hits like "Pinocchio" and "Alice in Wonderland." Next month, Disney will reissue "Snow White" on video.
But Disney cannot just saturate the market with re-releases. "Films cannibalize each other," Mr. Dreyer, the company spokesman, said, with each movie stealing a part of the audience from all others. Most of the classic collection is in constant release. There are 10 big titles, like "Cinderella," that the company re-releases on a staggered basis with great promotion. And "Atlantis," its animated adventure movie, is scheduled to come out on video this year.
In the immediate aftermath of Sept. 11, Disney has not stormed the video charts. In the week ended Sept. 16, Disney had one movie among the top 10 video rentals, one among the 10 best-selling videos and none among the 10 best-selling DVD's, according to Videobusiness.com, an industry Web site. Meanwhile, it has yanked "Big Trouble" from release for the foreseeable future. Though Mr. Dreyer said that decision would not cost much money, Disney has tied up millions of dollars of capital that is not generating any revenue.
At the same time, it borrowed $1 billion last week in a bond offering that it used in part to buy back some of the Bass stake. Disney now has $16 billion in debt, a larger load than it has ever previously carried.
Compounding the company's problems, the advertising market has softened considerably. About one-quarter of Disney's revenue comes from advertising, mostly through the ABC television network and the company's other broadcast and cable networks, including ESPN.
With the dot-com collapse and the general cooling of the economy, the advertising market has been lukewarm at best all year. Now, it is getting positively chilly.
"The problem is uncertainty," said Tom Wolzien, a media analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein. "Advertisers don't know quite how to deal with it. So instead of saying something that might come across badly and would leave a poor impression with consumers, they say nothing. Or they say that if consumers are not ready to buy, then why advertise?"
Mr. Bilotti of Morgan Stanley said he had been estimating that advertising revenue at the big four broadcast networks would grow by 2 percent this year. In the current environment, he said, he had revised that estimate to a 3 percent decline. For cable networks, he changed his estimate from 3 percent growth to a 5 percent decline.
The company is trying to turn the bad news into in-house marketing, using some unsold air time on its network, TV and radio stations to promote its parks, stores and films.
Disney's problems are worsened by the fact that ratings at ABC have tailed off badly as "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" has become more routine. The wild early success of that program may have even distracted ABC from developing new hits, according to analysts. Disney's premier cable channel, ESPN, is growing strongly, meanwhile, but may face difficulty in the future as overall viewing of sports declines.
Much like the theme parks, the network cannot simply cut costs without reducing the quality of the programs. "You cannot simply slash hours of prime-time programming," said a media executive who spoke on condition of anonymity.
THERE is less pressure to cut costs in cable programming because a portion of the revenue comes from subscriber fees. But at some of its networks, Disney is under heavy pressure to build revenue. Last August, it committed $5.3 billion to buy Fox Family Worldwide: $3.2 billion in cash and the assumption of $2.1 billion in debt. At the time, the purchase of the company, which owns Fox Family Channel, was considered very expensive at 35 times this year's $150 million in anticipated cash flow. Now, with the ad market even weaker, it has become that much harder to raise revenue and justify the purchase of the service.
That puts an even greater burden on Mr. Eisner to justify a strategy of sticking with programming assets, and buying at least some of them at high multiples. For chief executives like Mr. Eisner, who faced troubling economics at their own companies even before the World Trade Center debacle, managing out of this crisis will prove an exhausting task.

HEADLINE: Failed Disney Vision: Integrated City 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

DATELINE: CELEBRATION, Fla. 

 BODY:
Seven years ago, when the Walt Disney Company transformed the wetlands here into a suburb, executives promised to do their best to ensure that this planned community would not become as racially homogenous as many other towns. 
 To do that, the company placed advertisements in newspapers and magazines that catered to blacks and Hispanics, printed brochures featuring minority members and held a lottery for homes to ensure that developers could not discriminate based on race. Those efforts have been a failure. Even Disney officials say so. 
 The 2000 census numbers released this year say it all: the 2,376-resident community is 88 percent white in a county that is only 59 percent white; it is 1 percent black and 7 percent Hispanic in a county that is 6 percent black and 29 percent Hispanic. 
Immediately surrounding Celebration are neighborhoods and towns made up largely of black and Hispanic residents. This has placed Disney in the difficult position of having to defend its municipal creation. More than that, Celebration, just a few miles south of Walt Disney World, has become an example of a trend away from integration that social demographers say only became evident with an analysis of the census.
Diversity was an ambitious goal, said Peter O. Muller, an urban geographer at the University of Miami who has studied Celebration and cites it is an example of how people are increasingly seeking comfort in others who look like themselves. 
"The trend toward racial balkanization, particularly in the suburbs of the Sun Belt and other parts of the country, I think made it wishful thinking," Mr. Muller said.
Segregation has increased from 1990 to 2000 in almost every large suburban area, from Milwaukee to metropolitan New York, said the Lewis Mumford Center at the University of Albany, a research concern that specializes in demographics. What makes the experience here so striking is that the town was not immune to that pattern despite the efforts of Disney, which remains the primary force in running the town. 
In many respects, Disney went to extraordinary lengths to foster diversity in Celebration, which it built to fulfill Walt Disney's vision of an ideal community, at the same time that it wanted to expand into real estate. In late 1995, when the sales office for Celebration opened, Donald Killoren, the Disney executive in charge of the $2.5 billion, 10,000-acre development, emphasized the company's interest in economic and ethnic diversity. Mr. Killoren said that $600-a-month apartments would be built near $700,000 colonial revival houses and the community's sprawling golf course. He said the owners of the first 350 houses and 123 apartments would be chosen by lottery to prevent racial discrimination.
Disney officials had black workers in the sales office to help prospective black home buyers feel more comfortable. But fostering diversity in a real town has proved much harder than socially engineering a theme park designed by Walt Disney Imagineers. 
But few blacks or Hispanics attended the open houses or signed up for the housing lottery, and the community started off mostly white. Only 12 of Celebration's 1,093 houses and apartments are owned by blacks, according to the census, and the few minority workers who are seen here are mostly housekeepers and service workers. 
Some critics say they believe that Disney at best made several missteps, and at worst made a halfhearted effort to ensure racial and economic balance. These critics point to the fact that instead of building subsidized houses and apartments for low-wage earners, Disney gave surrounding Osceola County $900,000 to help area residents buy houses under $80,000. All of the money went for housing outside Celebration. Market forces have driven the prices on the rental apartments here to about $900 a month.
"I feel they left out diversity, and I feel they did it on purpose," said Viva Matthews, a black worker at an antique shop here, who lives 10 miles away. "I would not want to live here. They are not comfortable with us and I am not comfortable with them."
Milan Payne, a hotel worker in nearby Orlando who said he had looked for a place to live here but was uncomfortable with the atmosphere, summed up the sentiment of many blacks in neighboring communities when he said, "It's just amazing how the community keeps growing, but it does not get any more diverse."
But many demographers and experts in housing discrimination say that even the best intentions here would have been thwarted by the decade-old national trend toward suburban segregation, particularly in the South and the Sun Belt.
"They made a bona fide effort," said Edward J. Blakely, a black professor and dean of the Milano Graduate School of Management at the New School University in New York, and the co-author with Mary Gail Snyder of "Fortress America: Gated Communities in the United States" (Brookings Institution Press, 1997). "They were just thwarted by national trends, including the fact that when it comes to integration, being a pioneer is not an experience that a lot of people are looking to have anymore."
Robert Tennebaum, the real estate development director at the University of Maryland at Baltimore, who helped design Columbia, Md., a community noted for its racial diversity, said that Disney officials might have underestimated the amount of effort necessary. 
In Columbia, for example, officials paid both black and white families to move into different neighborhoods to keep areas from segregating, Mr. Tennebaum said. But the overarching problem here, he said, probably had to do with the new demographic trends.
"You would have a hard time doing a Columbia today," he added. "In the 1960's we were filled with idealism and even promised to create an open community before federal law required it. Some of that idealism has dissipated."
Perry J. Reader, the president of the Celebration Company, a Disney subsidiary that holds the majority of seats on the town council, acknowledged that Disney's efforts to bring diversity here had failed. "Even though we are not as diverse as we would like to be," Mr. Reader said, "I think it's encouraging that the community recognizes that." 
Asked what the company might do to address the issue, he said that officials were considering building cheaper housing for retirees. He said they had not decided what to do about the racial disparity. 
The issue of diversity has become so contentious here that it has been brought up in town hall meetings and on a Web site for community residents. In one exchange on the Web site chat room, a resident said he "can't complain" that there were few blacks or Hispanics here. 
"It is generally peaceful and quiet here and it even looks like the perfect American community," the resident wrote. "Our homes cost a lot more but any honest person would have to admit that part of the charm of buying here is living a life style that mimics what most American families could only hope to enjoy. No ethnic or racial problems in sight here."
Tobi Santagado, who is Jewish and lives here with her two children and husband, does not call her neighbors prejudiced, but says they are too quick to associate minority people with crime and blight. 
Ms. Santagado, who has diversity in the platform for her campaign to win a seat on the council, says she fears that Celebration's homogenous atmosphere will not prepare its children for the increasingly diverse world outside its white picket fences. 
"A black family toured a house on the block recently," she said. "And I said to the real estate agent that 'I hope you sell it to them, because we need somebody.' "

SECTION: Section 4; Column 1; Week in Review Desk; Pg. 8

LENGTH: 1221 words

HEADLINE: Aftermath; 
Forget the Past: It's A War Unlike Any Other

BYLINE:  By JOHN KIFNER

 BODY:
NO one, not Alexander the Great, not the Persians, not the Moghuls or the British or the Russians, has successfully occupied Afghanistan. It is a nation of warriors, where children glue broken glass to their kite strings to cut down other kites, boys are given rifles at puberty and old men keep thrushes in wooden cages trained not to sing, but to fight. 
 But it is Afghanistan that President Bush, in his speech Thursday night, pledged to attack unless it delivered up the terrorist mastermind Osama bin Laden. Mr. Bush warned Americans to expect "a lengthy campaign, unlike any other we have seen," in his fight against terrorism, and it will certainly be that. 
 American naval carrier groups are steaming toward positions in the Indian Ocean, and Air Force bombers are heading toward distant airfields to fight a shadowy foe flitting through the mountains in a deeply hostile land already so poor and so ruined by two decades of war that is virtually bereft of targets. 
It will not be like the gulf war, made to order for America's massive bombing, tank and helicopter attacks. And the economic and industrial might that helped carry the United States to victory in two world wars, while still a strength, is also, as the suicide airline hijackers showed, a vulnerability.
It's true that the president has a number of options at his disposal, but all are fraught with uncertainty. A lightning strike -- by helicopter-borne Marines, for example -- could swiftly take down what rudimentary government there is, but what next? Afghans have always rallied against outsiders, so it is unlikely that even those resentful of medieval Taliban rule would join a government set up by Americans. 
Special Forces -- the Green Berets -- will likely train and arm the anti-Taliban Northern Alliance, a former Green Beret commander said. But most of them belong to ethnic minorities, Tajiks, Uzbeks and Hazari, who are riven by infighting and who would be rejected by the majority Pushtun population. 
Then there are the Special Operations soldiers the Army does not talk about -- Delta Force and Direct Action Units among them -- capable of dropping in so-called snatch teams or snipers to hunt down Mr. bin Laden and his associates. But Mr. bin Laden may have already slipped into hiding among the neighboring Baluch tribesmen or in the lawless North West Frontier. And the members of his organization, broken up into small cells, are said to be spread across 60 countries. 
All of these options could have unintended consequences. Indeed, the whole problem stems from what the intelligence community calls "blowback," the unexpected, negative fallout from an operation. Mr. bin Laden and the Taliban government of Afghanistan are themselves examples of such unexpected consequences. They are the creations, in large measure, of the training, weapons and dollars funneled into Afghanistan by the Central Intelligence Agency during the 1980's to help seven Islamic Mujahadin factions, fierce mountain tribesmen, defeat the Soviet occupation.
"Military action in this atmosphere will have very damaging political results," warned Selig S. Harrison, a project director of the Century Foundation and expert on South Asia. "It's going to create a more poisonous atmosphere, with a very counterproductive impact in the rest of the Islamic world. It will lead to more terrorism in the future."
Afghanistan, for example, became a vast guerrilla training ground, and Arab volunteers who fought in the war, Islamic fundamentalists now called afghanis, spread out to new battles against Egypt, Algeria and other Arab governments. After the Soviet Union withdrew, these same fighters prepared to, among other things, try to blow up the World Trade Center.
 THEN there is Pakistan, the key ally President Bush is depending on in the hunt for Mr. bin Laden. Its intelligence service, Inter-Service Intelligence, or ISI, may know more about what goes on inside Afghanistan than anyone else. But Pakistan also neatly fits Mr. Bush's own definition of a state sponsor of terrorism. 
With Afghanistan falling into anarchy, Pakistan in 1994 essentially created the Taliban by backing Mullah Mohammed Omar, a one-eyed cleric who had been a fighter under one of the C.I.A.'s favorite commanders. They drew their recruits from radical young Islamic students in the refugee camps around Peshawar. 
Mr. bin Laden was not the only one to take advantage of the Taliban's training camps. In fact, when the United States fired cruise missiles at a camp near Khost in retaliation for the bombing of two embassies, it was actually being used by Pakistani military intelligence to train an Islamic guerrilla group called Harakat-ul-Ansar to fight against India in Kashmir. Another organization, mostly Pakistani, called Lashkar-e-Taiba, sponsored by the ISI, not only trains militants for the assassination of Indian soldiers and officials in Kashmir, but acts as a kind of secret police for the Taliban.
"The Taliban are basically an extension of Pakistan," said Mr. Harrison.
So the Pakistani government of Gen. Pervez Musharraf finds itself in an odd position. The Pakistan that General Musharraf took over in a military coup is only barely a state: impoverished, anarchic, awash in refugees, guns and drugs from the Afghan wars, whole areas under the sway of feudal lords or tribal chiefs, with daily gun battles reported in its newspapers. And radical Islam is a strong force. "Trust me," the general said in a television address in Urdu to explain his support of the Americans. But he risks an Islamic backlash that could sweep away his government. This in a country that Jane's Intelligence reported last year has 25 nuclear-tipped missiles.
And there are similar risks for other Muslim or Arab governments that the president seeks to enlist in his coalition against terrorism. America's key ally in the region, Saudi Arabia, for example, may be particularly vulnerable. Its legitimacy rests on its position as protector of the two holy places of Mecca and Medina and the interrelationship of the royal family with the ranking religious leaders. But its strict Wahabi form of Islam is the basis of Mr. bin Laden's own beliefs and younger clergy, much like Mr. bin Laden himself, are reportedly increasingly upset by the American military presence. In addition, there is unrest as economic difficulties undermine the once easy life in the kingdom.
Even language is a problem. President Bush at first spoke of a "crusade" against evil, a word the White House swiftly retracted when its implications became clear. In America, with perhaps a fuzzy recollection of Sir Walter Scott's novels, the word has a noble ring; in the Middle East, where historical memories run much longer, it has other connotations: bloody massacres of Muslims, Jews and Byzantine Christians. Indeed, Mr. bin Laden's favorite expression of rage is "American crusader forces." 
Mr. Bush's choice of words was more than a verbal gaffe: it shows the danger of allowing the struggle to be defined in Mr. bin Laden's terms, as a Holy War between Islam and the West, gaining him new recruits and supporters and thwarting Mr. Bush's efforts to form a broad coalition against terrorism.
And on Friday, the Muslim sabbath, mosques throughout the Arab world rang with defiance and cries of crusaders and jihad.

HEADLINE: Austro Turf 

BYLINE:  By Herbert Muschamp; Herbert Muschamp is the architecture critic of The New York Times.

 BODY:
Some people think that architecture critics are in the business of promoting their personal taste. In my case, the opposite is true. I write to get as far away from my taste as possible. This story is an exception, up to a point. There is one architect whose work reflects my taste and incites me to escape it at the same time: Adolf Loos. His designs embody the idea that, in the modern city, taste should be constantly challenged.
 Loos, who lived from 1870 to 1933, was a forerunner of what some now call minimalism. Today, he may be best known for his 1908 essay, "Ornament and Crime." Even before Mies van der Rohe introduced himself to the world with the Barcelona Pavilion, Loos championed an architecture of severe reduction. At a time when designers across Europe were enmeshed in the flowing tendrils of Art Nouveau, Loos hacked away the vines. Instead of inventing new decorative systems, Loos proposed eliminating decoration altogether. Architecture was, for him, a process of mental and cultural hygiene. 
 "Please be stronger than your past./The future may still give you a chance." -- George Michael, "Cowboys and Angels"
Sing that song again, mister! So what if there's no absolute progress in art? Some art helps us cope better as life rolls along. We don't have to keep rushing and rushing around, chasing one another in a fog, bumping into the same dumb furniture. Clarity is character. Even if architecture cannot reform society, it can clarify our vision of the status quo. Loos stands for this idea: a lucid view of self and others requires perpetual polishing of the lens.
Loos was a pivotal figure in the community of artists and intellectuals that flourished in Vienna's fin de siecle. He not only frequented the city's famous coffeehouses, but also designed one. You can visit Cafe Museum today, though little remains of Loos's design. Never mind. What matters are the echoes of the conversations that once transpired there. In those years, the city's best minds were often engaged by a pivotal set of issues. What is the proper relationship between private and public life? Between politics and the imagination? Between our inner and outer worlds? Freud, Schnitzler, Wittgenstein, Klimt, Hofmannsthal, Mach and others were stirring these deep thoughts around in their coffee.
Architecture reckons with the relationship between public and private on the material plane as well as the conceptual one. Buildings are hinges between interiors and the street. Loos clarified the function of the hinge in formal and spatial terms. It was, for him, a site of moral action, a place where self and society negotiate the boundaries between private rights and public responsibilities.
The American Bar, designed by Loos in 1907, is a most relaxing place to enjoy your private rights in public. A key landmark in the history of modern architecture, the tiny cocktail spot is also known as the K* rntner Bar and is just off K* rntnerstrasse in Vienna's inner city. When was a landmark ever this minute? As your eyes adjust to interiors darkened by deep mahogany walls, you realize that the place is even smaller than it appears at first: a band of mirrors at clerestory height multiplies its dimensions. Then when you take your seat at the far banquette facing the door, your eye is drawn up to a large panel of backlighted alabaster that dissolves the front wall into a shaft of sunlight caught by thinning clouds.
Overhead, the ceiling is coffered with marble. That's ornament up there, no doubt about it. Police! Police! But Loos was not opposed to ornament per se. His argument was with those of his contemporaries who sought to invent new decorative systems. Loos himself was not averse to employing ornamental devices that had passed into vernacular use. In this sense, his approach anticipated Robert Venturi's use of classical motifs. Venturian, too, is the stylized stained-glass American flag on the bar's entrance facade. Salute Jasper Johns.
The American Bar was an institution that flourished across Europe in the 1920's, along with flappers, jazz and beach resorts. The counter with stools in front, and bottles of booze behind the patron, imbibed the New World spirit as much as cocktails. Loos himself was indebted to the American idea. His approach to architecture was partly formulated during a three-year sojourn to the States after his student days. Like other Europeans, Loos was impressed by the scale and vigor of our industrial culture. Factories, grain silos, bridges: to European observers, such feats of engineering possessed the primitive vitality of archaic Greek architecture. His own designs aspire toward spartan simplicity.
Nowhere was this aspiration more fully realized than at Looshaus, the largest of his built works. Now home to the Raiffeisenlandesbank, the building was originally designed for Goldman & Salatsch, a swell gentlemen's tailor. It occupies a prominent site on Michaelerplatz, directly opposite the entrance gate to the Hapsburg imperial apartments. Reportedly, Franz Joseph was so disgusted by the view of the building from his windows that he permanently pulled the curtains. Looshaus also offended the young Adolf Hitler. In his watercolor paintings of Michaelerplatz, rendered when he was living in a homeless shelter, Hitler replaced Loos's building with an imaginary faux baroque edifice of his own design.
A period cartoon of the building shows Loos in a moment of inspiration as he gazes down at a storm-drain cover while walking down the street. But what a drain cover! Looshaus defines luxury as the 20th century later came to perceive it: fine materials, polished surfaces, sumptuous spaces, refined details. Even now, these elements are clearly legible as metaphors for the spiritual rewards of spartan living.
Access to Looshaus is limited today. And the present banking floor atmosphere is a far cry from that of Goldman & Salatsch, where Loos established a clear continuity between architectural and sartorial values. But you can still experience that continuity at the legendary Knize shop, built by Loos in 1913. Today, Knize sells sportswear made by other designers, as well as its own bespoke attire. The clothing is of refined, Loosian taste (I peeked inside last April and came away with three jackets), and the shop itself enjoys landmark protection.
From the small entrance facade and ground floor, to the sizable main floor upstairs, the impression is one of good grooming rather than design. The two shop windows flanking the entrance are discreet. Inside, a narrow aisle divides the sales counter from ceiling-high cabinets for shirts. Ascending the small spiral stair at the rear of the shop, you may imagine that you are trying on the world's first modern space for size.
Display cabinets, fitting rooms, dressing rooms, open storage areas for fabrics, seating areas with round tables and club chairs: though the spaces are devoid of overt machine-age references, they have a distinct nautical feel. With none of the ponderousness or medievalism of the Arts and Crafts movement, Knize is an essay on the aesthetic of craft. A new vocabulary takes shape amid the bolts of cloth. Economy of means, easy access to tools, openness to the eye, scale shaped to human form: it fits. It's me!
The store's atmosphere is British, but not stuffy. It is the Britain of navy uniforms, country wear, sports attire: the same sources that inspired Coco Chanel, in fact. With her scissors, Chanel once said, she had cut away all that was inessential in the creations of others. Loos might have made the same claim for his pencil. In fact, he was keenly interested in fashion. He wrote about clothes. British gentlemen's attire, Loos maintained, was the only suitable form of dress. Haberdashers were among his most important clients. Their advertising also supported publication of Das Andere ("The Other"), a polemical broadsheet that Loos put out in his early years. Loos's interest in fashion was in large part polemical. For him, architecture was not an art. Rather, it was analogous to fashion: an enlightened response to the material need for shelter, as fashion is a cultivated solution to the body's need for clothes. Architecture and fashion were not culturally inferior to art in Loos's eyes. Rather, both were tantamount to philosophy, or should at least take their cue from the world of ideas. 
Loos developed his ideas in tandem with Ludwig Wittgenstein, the brilliant philosopher who sought to refute all philosophical systems. In fact, it has been argued that Loos provided the basis of Wittgenstein's most influential theories. For Wittgenstein, philosophy was a little trick that the Greeks had played on us. All philosophical problems are essentially semantic problems. Clear away the rhetoric, and the problems disappear. "What can be said at all, can be said clearly," Wittgenstein insisted. "Whereof one cannot speak, thereof one must remain silent."
For Loos, the 19th-century debates over architectural style were so much rhetoric. Strip away the styles and a building will appear. Organize interior spaces and circulation; add walls, a roof, windows, doors and plumbing; decorate to taste; and move in. If you build it, architecture will come: this was the general idea. It was one of the main roots of what would later be called functionalism. In 1926, Wittgenstein co-designed a house in Vienna for his sister. (Thanks to the historian Bernhard Leitner, the house was spared demolition and has been restored to mint condition.) Wittgenstein's collaborator on the project was Paul Engelmann, a pupil of Loos's. Their design carries the master's spartan approach to nearly sadistic extremes. Glass doors and windows with thin metal frames, even floors of iron; the whole place feels like one big clang -- closer in spirit to Peter Eisenman than Adolf Loos.
A Loos interior, by contrast, is warm. Lots of mahogany. Oak. Pear wood. Walls and wood trim painted bright colors. Leather. Fur. Amusing lighting fixtures with lampshades of gathered silk -- intimations of Philippe Starck. Loos did not believe that architects should retain control over interior decoration, at least in private houses. He wasn't a Frank Lloyd Wright. You bought it, it's yours. Enjoy. The private and public realms, while overlapping, remain distinct.
Loos's approach is no longer Other. It is normative. It's Wallpaper, as sophisticated people, with some disdain, now describe the minimalist aesthetic promoted by that magazine. It's background. A snore. Black jeans, white T-shirts. "Real simple." Uniforms. I've decorated my version of it with splashy views of the Manhattan skyline, more books than I have room for, unkempt piles of writing and research material that litter every available surface. Housecleaning is a Loosian homage. Picking up the room excavates a neutral space that is ideal for an architecture critic who distrusts norms. It reminds me that norms do have a place. My place, in fact.

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS; 
Taking the Attack Personally After a Career on Wall Street

BYLINE:  By Raymond Hernandez; Raymond Hernandez reports from Washington for The New York Times.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
It was one thing to hear Jon Corzine on the Senate floor denouncing the terrorist attacks in New York and Washington, as many of his colleagues did. But it was quite another to hear him describe how the attack had touched him personally.
 "I worked for many years in that neighborhood that I saw buried in the rubble yesterday, and I fear that many whose paths I crossed suffered unspeakable horrors," said Mr. Corzine, who entered the Senate this year after a career on Wall Street, most recently as the chairman of Goldman, Sachs & Company. 
 More than anyone else in Congress, Mr. Corzine had many close friends and business associates who were in the World Trade Center at the time of the terrorist attacks and who are now among those missing and presumed dead.
More than that, Mr. Corzine is also among a small group of lawmakers in Congress who have had to be national spokesmen as talk of war brews while at the same time tending to the needs of constituents whose lives have been directly affected by the catastrophe.
Just last week Mr. Corzine estimated that as many as 50 percent of those who died in the attack were residents of New Jersey who commuted to work at the World Trade Center each day.
Mr. Corzine, a resident of Summit, said the losses in his town alone were staggering.
"There are a bunch of us for whom this mixes in personally, and it hurts," he said in an interview the day after the terrorist assaults.
Last week his mood was no less somber after touring the twisted, smoldering remains where the towers once stood and attending prayer vigils all over New Jersey.
"It's unimaginable," he said a few hours after paying a visit to the floor of the New York Stock Exchange. "It makes your blood boil. It really does. It makes you mad. You're overwhelmed by the devastation."
Apart from his comments on the Senate floor, he has been reluctant to talk about his personal experience, perhaps out of respect for the families of the victims. "It's hard for everybody," he says.
Like almost everyone else in the country, Mr. Corzine has been changed by the attacks. Only a few weeks ago, he was offering sharp criticisms of President Bush. Today he bristles at commentators who say the president has come across as inexperienced and unsure of himself.
"I don't think people who get into that game realize the burden that he's had to take on," Mr. Corzine said. Political battles, he said, are for another day.
More than that, Mr. Corzine now speaks with urgency about the need for Washington to step in and help bolster the nation's sagging economy in the attack's unsettling aftermath. His views on economic matters, after all, do carry some weight down here.
His stances on certain issues have changed as well. Only a few weeks ago, there was a great deal of tsk-tsking among Democrats like Mr. Corzine as the economy slowed, the budget surplus shrank and Mr. Bush faced the prospect of breaking his promise not to dip into the Social Security surplus.
The Democrats wanted to force the president to explain how he planned to pay for things -- a military buildup, a prescription drug benefit for the elderly or increases in education spending -- with the economy in a swoon and his huge tax cut on the books.
Democrats were sore that they had not been able to stop President Bush's tax cut from being enacted, and so they refused to offer him their own solution in light of the increasingly unstable economy. Let him stew, was their attitude.
But now Mr. Corzine says there is no place for such gamesmanship. He says Congress cannot afford to bicker about economic policy, and argues that the nation will need a huge infusion of cash from Washington to help rebuild from the attacks and to jump-start the economy.
He thinks that a large public-works programs could help make the difference, even if it means dipping into the Social Security surplus, a notion that was once taboo.
"We need economic stimulus now, fiscal discipline later," he said.
Mostly, though, he has been all over New Jersey in recent days: a memorial mass in Newark, a prayer service in Bayonne, a vigil in Edison.
"The real hard part," he said, "is that this has only begun."

HEADLINE: A City Rises to the Occasion 

BYLINE:  By STEVE STRUNSKY

DATELINE: JERSEY CITY 

 BODY:
IN one awful instant, this patchwork city that is part high-tech, part high finance and part third world assumed an even more integral role in the region's stability.
 In the early moments after hijackers slammed two fuel-laden Boeing 767's into the World Trade Center -- even before Jersey City straightened its shoulders and gave a shattered financial community a place to come to -- it lent New York a shoulder to cry on and a place for the weary and the wounded to seek comfort. 
 Only days ago Acting Gov. Donald T. Difrancesco signed an order making official what Jersey City had been doing on its own since those first stunning moments after the attack -- he created an Office of Recovery and Victim Assistance to coordinate the efforts of various state agencies and established a family assistance center for relatives at Liberty State Park here, where on the day of the assault 2,600 people were evacuated to a National Guard field hospital that had been hastily set up there. The center will allow families to register a missing person, provide DNA samples, speak with law enforcement and seek counseling, among other services. 
"While this is a New York story, it is also very much a New Jersey tragedy," said Mr. DiFrancesco.
By last Tuesday, Attorney General John J. Farmer spoke a terrible truth that most people had feared and assumed for a week -- that the state's losses were staggering, as many as 2,000 people.
From the first fiery moments of Sept. 11, 2001, Jersey City rose to the occasion, with hospitals providing medical care; schools and homeowners giving shelter to victims and evacuees alike; sending scores of police officers and firefighters to secure the scene of unspeakahble horror; and shipping a steady stream of volunteers and supplies from the same waterfront promenade in Jersey City's financial district that is now being called Wall Street West because of the number of firms that are relocating on this side of the Hudson River.
Today, this is a city brought more sharply into focus because of the bitter events of the past two weeks. In Jersey City's sizable Arab and Muslim communities -- in many instances quite distinct -- the usual tensions are giving way to more open animosity.
It was on Kennedy Boulevard, the main thoroughfare that slices through the city's largely Arabic section near Journal Square, that Sheik Omar Abdel-Rahman -- the Egyptian-born blind cleric who was the ringleader of the 1993 bombing of the World Trade Center -- preached at the Masjid Al Salam mosque.
The spiritual leader and the bombers are gone, jailed on conspiracy charges, but the mosque remains.
As recently as this summer, in a tape that was widely disseminated, Osama bin Laden -- a Saudi exile blamed for numerous anti-American attacks and the prime suspect in the Trade Center assault -- described the cleric as "a hostage in an American jail." He added, "We hear he is sick, and that the Americans are treating him badly." Then, addressing his followers, he shifted into an exhortation to martyrdom. "You will not die needlessly," he said. "Your lives are in the hands of God."
Five days after the hijacked planes slammed into their targets in New York and at the Pentagon, five Arabic men were seized in an F.B.I. raid on their apartment building on Tonnele Avenue here, just around the corner from the mosque.
Now, once again, a veil of suspicion by association -- unjustly or not -- hangs over Jersey City's Muslim community.
Afsha Sheikh, 10, her sister, Faiza, 11, are students at the Al-Ghazaly School, which shares an old brick building with a mosque on Park Avenue at the Islamic Center of Jersey City.
The girls, who live in Weehawken, were born in the United States, wear bell-bottom jeans, watch basketball and football and listen to rock music. They wear their hijabs -- the scarf that Muslim women cover their heads with -- only to the mosque and to school. But widespread suspicion that Mr. bin Laden, a former Saudi Arabian citizen, was linked to the attack made the girls fear anti-Muslim recriminations.
"When we heard it was the Saudis we were scared we were going to get killed," said Afsha, a fifth grader.
Her sister, Faiza, added, "Like, if it was Arabs, then we would get in trouble."
Their friend, Sarah Mohamed, 10, a classmate of Afsha's and every bit as much a product of American pop culture, said she experienced some anti-Arab backlash the day of the attack.
"When I was in the car, this little boy, he told me, 'God bless America,' " said Sarah, who was born in the United States, and lives in Jersey City. "He said it like he was laughing at me. I wanted to punch him. This is my country and I like it."
Sarah's mother, Karen Mohamed, who wears a hijab regularly, puts into even sharper relief how diverse the city's Muslim population is.
Ms. Mohamed, 37, was born Karen Corn in Chicago, and was raised a Baptist. Her mother was adopted by Christians after being born of Jewish parents. She met her Egyptian-born husband, Moustafa Mohamed, 18 years ago while the two worked for a car service in Jersey City, and they married soon afterward. It was several years later that she converted to Islam, though not because of any pressure from husband, she said, but rather because she finally felt the spirit of Allah in her heart.
Yet it was when she began wearing the hijab, she said, that people began to change their perceptions of her.
"You get a lot of stares," she said after the recent horrors. "I was driving my car, and one woman said, 'Go back to your country.' "
"O.K., I'm from Chicago, actually," Ms. Mohamed said. "My sister said, 'You're not going to wear that, are you?' "
"I said, 'Why not? I haven't done anything wrong.' "
With fear and suspicion rising to the surface now -- especially among Jersey City's patchwork population, Ms. Mohamed's friend, Kathie Shedeed, who also converted to Islam after marrying an Egyptian Muslim, commended President Bush and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani of New York for speaking out about unjustified attacks on Muslims reminiscent of how Japanese-Americans were mistreated during World War II. 
As recently as last Sunday, Ahmed Shedeed, the husband of Ms. Sheheed and also the director of the Islamic Center, was present when nearly 200 Muslims gathered at the center for a talk by the Jersey City Police Department urging them to notify police officers of any violence or harassment.
"Rest assured, with your cooperation, with everyone's cooperation, we're not going to have a problem," said Detective Abab Perez. "But rest assured, if we do have a problem, we're going to be behind you 100 percent."
The crowd gathered inside the center's small auditorium -- women on the right, men on the left -- applauded.
To be sure, in a world turned upside down, there is uneasiness.
Take Abdus Salaam Kahalil al Amin, who was at the gathering last Sunday. The 27-year-old truck driver, who is black, first gave his name as Kevin Austin. In a show of patriotism unique among the Muslims at the center that day, Mr. Austin, who lives in neighboring Bayonne, was wearing a red, white and blue bandanna tied around his wrist. While black and Arab Muslims generally get along, Mr. Austin said, he admitted feeling a complex set of emotions after learning of the attack and suspicions that Islamic fundamentalists were behind it.
"I'm a Muslim, but I'm also an African-American," Mr. Austin said. "So my emotions and my beliefs were in a crossfire, if you know what I mean."
Even within the city's ethnic Egyptian population, relations between Coptic Christians and Muslims are sometimes strained, and the suspicion that Islamic fundamentalists were involved in the attack seems to have exacerbated those tensions.
Among the volunteers loading supplies at a waterfront staging area a few days after the catastrophe were a handful of Egyptian-born teenagers with a group organized by the local chapter of Coptic Community Services. Mike Matthew, 18, who left Egypt when he was a year old and now attends the St. George and St. Shenouda Coptic Orthodox Church in Jersey City, was one of several young Egyptians who clearly had no love for Muslims from their homeland.
"The most that it affected me is that I'm Egyptian, but I'm a Christian and those people are Muslim, and they're giving us a bad name," said Mr. Matthew, a freshman at Hudson County Community College in Jersey City. "Our priest, he has a long beard and he wears a cross, but people confuse him with a Muslim, and they spit on him in the street yesterday."
Mr. Matthew went on: "I met this girl at my bank. She's a teller, and she's a Muslim, and she said, 'They're exaggerating this whole thing.' I was surprised and I said, 'Just give me my money, and I left.' "

Lending a Hand
The catastrophe has also brought out the best in people.
At the staging area at 70 Hudson Street -- site of a huge volunteer effort -- John Curtis and Beth Stark were taking a break.
The couple, who are among the thousands of young professionals to have moved to the waterfront in recent years, were loading bottles of Poland Spring water, Gatorade, Diet Coke, Purina Dog Chow, rubber gloves, breathing masks and other supplies onto New York City Police boats.
Mr. Curtis and Ms. Stark munched on cheeseburgers and Chicken McNuggets that were prepared at a mobile kitchen supplied by a McDonald's distribution center in Bedminster. The clear skies, steady breeze and spirit of cooperation made the atmosphere at the staging area seem incongruously festive. 
Ms. Stark, a 31-year-old graduate student, felt compelled to say, "I feel so selfish, like I'm out here trying to make myself feel better."
She and Mr. Curtis, a 34-year-old investment banker for CIBC World Markets in Midtown Manhattan, had moved to the city's historic Paulus Hook section near the waterfront directly across the Hudson from Lower Manhattan only a month earlier. But the twin towers -- silvery pillars of Modernism that turned to gold at sunset -- were so dominating that their presence had already been ingrained in the young couple's vision of New York. 
"I think one of the things that attracted us to the this area was having that view of the financial district and the trade center in particular," Mr. Curtis said. "You take them for granted. You think they'll always be there."
For those who live far from New York, time will dim the horror, but for residents in such riverfront towns as Jersey City, Bayonne and Hoboken, the trade center's conspicuous absence will serve as a constant reminder of the devastating loss.
Indeed, from some vantage points, the Trade Center and its sprawling financial district even looked like it was part of Jersey City, blending seamlessly into the budding skyline.
"It didn't look like there was a river in between, like we could just walk to it," said Daniel Lugo, 31, a freelance programmer and designer. 
The historic districts that make up most of downtown Jersey City -- Hamilton Park, Harsimus Cove, Van Vorst, Paulus Hook -- have neighborhood associations that are known in town for their vigilant, even aggressive, defense of the quality of life. An extensive e-mail network has helped them to thwart or scale back some development proposals and to obtain city funds for pet projects. It was through that same network that two activists, Geoffrey and Karen Elkind, helped spark the drive for supplies that ended up at the foot of Hudson Street, and recruited other downtown residents to lend a hand.
For instance, Mr. Elkind, a lawyer and former city council candidate who is chairman of the city's Downtown Coalition of Neighborhood Associations, sent an e-mail message to the Howard Stern Show on WXRK-FM. "Within about 30 seconds and lasting the next 10 hours we took phone calls with offers of assistance from across the country," Mr. Elkind said. "There isn't a state that hasn't called."
Mr. Elkind, whose organizational experience had in the past involved trying to tamp down building heights and nightclub noise, suddenly found himself in the thick of an unprecedented catastrophe. When he is not at his computer, the unassuming neighborhood activist may be found conferring with the staging area's burly coordinator, Lieut. Michael Louf, a veteran Jersey City Police officer who had his own personal connection to the trade center.
"I was an iron worker in 1968, and I worked in the building when they were building the place," said Lieutenant Louf, who, like many of his colleagues found it difficult to tear himself away from the rescue effort. "It got so bad I fell asleep on the toilet, so I knew it was time to go home."
It was an e-mail message from the Elkinds on the day of the attack that prompted two Van Vorst neighbors, Mia Scanga and Jennifer May, to go to the emergency room at Christ Hospital in nearby Hamilton Park, which treated 66 victims that day, to volunteer their town houses as overnight accommodations for victims who could not get back to New York. In all, about 600 of the injured were transferred to New Jersey Hospitals for treatment, including 150 to Jersey City Medical Center.
That night, Ms. Scanga's two guests included a financial consultant from North Carolina who barely escaped from the collapsing Marriott Hotel, where he was staying, and a man who had recently moved to Battery Park City from Boston. Ms. May, a product director for a shoe design company, took in a Queens woman and a Long Island man who worked in the financial district.
"I don't know, I was just, like, yeah, I can sleep two people, let's go," Ms. May said. "Actually, my husband was out of town, and I was a little nervous about that, because I have a baby, too. But I thought the circumstances were such that I didn't think I was putting myself at risk."
Despite the unusual gesture of kindness, Ms. May said she was surprised by the depth of her guests' gratitude.
"They didn't think that people like that existed," she said. "They were kind of reluctant to even take us up on it, and the woman who was assigning people was like, 'Look, they're here to help, let them help.' I just feel like I'm glad I was able to help them feel comfortable. It's still awkward -- imagine being in a stranger's home and just wanting to go home. I could barely sleep myself and I didn't even go through it."

Businesses Respond
One of the more prominent people on the waterfront, Ed Nicoll, president and chief executive of Datek Online Corporation, offered the 11-story building his company leases at 70 Exchange Place as a landing point for police officers and firefighters overcome by smoke as well as evacuees from Lower Manhattan.
For hours ferries, tugboats and police launches dropped people off at a pier in the shadow of the Colgate clock next to the office building. From there, some were treated by emergency crews while others rested on office chairs set up in the lobby, drank water or ate sandwiches provided by the cafeteria or called concerned loved ones from a bank of telephones that the company hurriedly set up.
Mr. Nicoll said he and his company's 1,000 employees watched the tragedy unfold from their unimpeded view of the smoky ruins across the river. When the financial markets closed, about half of Datek's employees chose to stay and assist the victims and rescuers.
Other buildings in Exchange Place had closed their doors and posted security guards to keep people out. When Datek ran out of bottled water, it was to these buildings that employees went -- with police escorts -- to raid their supplies. In addition, the company reached out to area restaurants for ice and cloths that they drenched with cool water and handed to those arriving from across the river.
"When the restaurants ran out of cloths, they sent tablecloths, which we ripped up into strips to hand out," Mr. Nicoll said. "We just wanted to help."
In the attack's aftermath, Datek also turned over the vacant 11th floor of its building to the police department, which used it as a waterfront command center, operated by officers who volunteered their time -- often after working regular full shifts. Mayor Glenn D. Cunningham, a former police captain and United States marshal for New Jersey, spent part of his time there, surveying the human chain of volunteers passing supplies on the promenade below. 
Countless small businesses, from pizza parlors to contractors, did what they could. After the Holland Tunnel closed to regular traffic on Tuesday, Chris Cho, the owner of a Gulf station near the tunnel entrance, said gasoline sales went from about 13,000 gallons a day to just a few hundred. Even so, Mr. Cho, 65, who lives in Westfield, offered to provide free fuel to the emergency vehicles that streamed toward the disaster site. City officials said that took pressure of the Public Works Department, which had been making its own pumps available.
"I don't want to brag," Mr. Cunningham said. "But Jersey City has really been the anchor for everything that's going on in there. And not just going in, but on the first day, everything coming out."

Need for Office Space
In addition to the massive loss of life and unspeakable suffering, Manhattan also saw 15 million to 20 million square feet of office space destroyed. For now, businesses have to relocate, and many will never return. Cushman & Wakefield, the commercial real estate firm, said that of the 395 million square feet of office space in Manhattan, about 30 million square feet were available as of last week. But clearly, not all of that space was suitable for the needs of all the displaced firms. 
Competition between New York and New Jersey in luring financial firms has long been a bitter issue dividing business and government leaders of the two states. In recent years as the New Jersey waterfront grew and flourished. Indeed, with increasingly sophisticated technology, New York has lost thousands of jobs to towns across the Hudson as companies sought cheaper land for its businesses and cheaper housing for its employees.
Yet regardless of the reality -- businesses need a lot of space quickly and are finding it in New Jersey -- it is a subject they dare not discuss for fear of coming off as vultures encircling the still-smoking ruins of the trade center.
Others -- even those who lost friends and associates -- feel less encumbered. 
"As a citizen of New York City, I would like to keep every corporation here," said Don Schnabel, vice chairman of Julien J. Studley Inc., a Manhattan-based commercial real estate brokerage. "What are we going to do? We lost 15 to 20 million square feet. The inventory for all of Manhattan is 300 million square feet. How do you deal with that? I'll answer my own question: Some of these companies will leave, and some will not come back."
Mr. Schnabel said his firm was seeking leases for clients in Jersey City, though he declined to say which ones. As for his own company, Mr. Schnabel said Studley would relocate some employees to its office in Edison.
Mr. Schnabel's own office was on the 86th floor of north tower of the World Trade Center. Two employees, including his secretary, Patricia Puma of Staten Island, were trapped there when the tower collapsed and are listed among the missing.
David Houston, president of Colliers Houston & Company, a Manhattan-based brokerage, said two million square feet of office space were leased in New Jersey in the week after the catastrophe, much of it in Jersey City and Newark, because of the PATH train service to Manhattan. But, Mr. Houston added, "I think the vast majority of firms that were impacted by this will not relocate to New Jersey."
Mildred Hanson, vice president of NAI James E. Hansen Inc. in Hackensack, said there had been subleases signed for more than a million square feet in New Jersey. She said her firm had received requests for blocks of 120,000 square feet, 320,000 square feet and 54,000 square feet.
"So far," Ms. Hanson said, "I would say, the strongest demand has been in Hudson and Morris Counties, but we think it's going to trickle into Bergen County."
It may have to. 
Richard LeFrak, president of the Lefrak Organization, said his company had leased 100 percent of the 2.8 million square feet of completed office space in the company's Newport complex here. And while the developer is currently putting up two buildings with a total of 2.5 million square feet, Mr. LeFrak said the space was already spoken for. Beyond that, he said, Lefrak does have plans to build another two million square feet of space, though that space will not be completed for at least 18 months.
In the long run, Mr. LeFrak said, the New Jersey real estate market would not gain from New York's loss. 
"Basically, in my mind, New York's misfortune is not New Jersey's fortune," he said. "It's all one region. If New York is weak, the whole region is going to be weak. You can't separate the two markets."
Goldman Sachs & Company, which was forced to relocate some employees from Lower Manhattan to its existing space in Jersey City, is currently building a 1.4-million-square-foot office tower here on the waterfront that would house more than 6,000 employees. At a proposed height of 821 feet, it would be the tallest building in New Jersey.
A spokeswoman for the company said last week that even in the aftermath of the disaster in which the two planes took aim at the skyscrapers, the company had no intention of scaling back. 
But Mr. LeFrak and others in the building trade suggested that companies might begin to shy away from high concentrations of employees at a single location, and even that landmark buildings -- economic symbols and thus potential targets -- might become less desirable. 
"If people have some diversity within the region, it gives them the flexibility not to be victimized by a single event," Mr. LeFrak said. "And the companies that are faring best are the ones that had that as part of their contingency, and Jersey City is a possible, logical option."
