HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE COVERAGE; 
Networks Move to Revive Foreign News

BYLINE:  By JIM RUTENBERG 

 BODY:
Only a month ago, Walter Isaacson, the new chairman of CNN, spoke expansively about the need to broaden the definition of news. Audience interest in foreign affairs was waning, he said, and so was interest in Washington.
 CNN -- acknowledged to be the last holdout among the major news networks in veering toward softer subjects -- would increase its focus on entertainment and technology, health and fitness, he said. Personalities -- stars -- would carry programming when news could not. "The goal should be to make the news smart, but also fun and fascinating," he said. 
 A month later, Mr. Isaacson and other news executives who echoed his sentiments are sounding like they have found religion, as if the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 had shaken them from a daze in which their focus was lost. Hard news, even foreign news, is back in vogue. 
"It's helped all of us regain our focus," Mr. Isaacson said of the attacks. "It's injected a note of real seriousness. And the things we think of doing to chase ratings now pale in comparison to the importance of doing this story seriously and reliably."
But the expressions of contrition seem convenient in the aftermath of the terrorist attacks, and the question remains: will the sentiments be converted into the hard cash it takes to finance foreign coverage?
That is the issue in corporate media offices where executives -- especially at the broadcast networks -- grapple with criticism that TV news had given foreign news the elbow for a decade, and had therefore failed to convey the importance of developments in the Middle East beyond those related to the fighting between Israelis and Palestinians. This, the reasoning went, left its audience ill-prepared to understand the dynamics that led to the attacks.
Some executives still wonder if the nation's attention span for the terrorist story will be short. Nonetheless, they are discussing whether to redeploy troops and revive heavy overseas coverage beyond what is necessary to follow current developments.
They will have a lot to revive. Before the attacks, television news was deep into a retreat from covering international affairs. According to the Tyndall Report, which monitors television news content, foreign bureaus provided only a third as many minutes of coverage for the evening newscasts on ABC, CBS and NBC in 2000 (1,382) than they did in 1989 (4,032), a high point.
The network news divisions have significantly cut the number of overseas bureaus they maintain and are relying heavily on dispatches from bureaus in London. For instance, ABC News had 17 foreign bureaus 15 years ago. It has 7 now, closing them in places like Damascus, Frankfurt and Warsaw. CBS said it had similarly cut back, and NBC said it maintained staff in 17 foreign sites worldwide but had significantly reduced its overseas staff. 
In an opinion article published in the French newspaper Le Monde last week, the president of CNN International Networks, Chris Cramer, wrote that many of the networks had traded international coverage for ratings, with "most of CNN's competitors focusing on U.S. news only."
He said those networks had "committed the worst crime of journalism" in "the failure to make the important interesting."
Network news executives take great issue with this. They say that the Tyndall Report did not take into account segments on news programs like "60 Minutes" and "60 Minutes II" on CBS and "Nightline" on ABC. But the executives did acknowledge that overseas coverage had been scaled back in recent years.
Many reasons are given for the retreat, ranging from the end of the Cold War, the more ruthless economics of television and a belief among TV executives that young adults care far more about the zone diet than the subtleties of Middle East diplomacy.
Andrew Tyndall, publisher of the Tyndall Report, said that foreign coverage slackened most when Bill Clinton became president. Elected on a domestic agenda, he generally scaled back overseas military activity, giving networks less reason to maintain overseas operations. 
And it is not as if international news has been on the top of the list of things that have interested news viewers -- it usually ranks low on surveys of what they want to watch.
"Generally what people look for in news are things that are relevant and salient and relate to their personal lives," said David F. Poltrack, executive vice president for research at CBS. "International news generally didn't fall into that category and therefore was somewhat down the list of the topics they wanted to see covered in the news."
Erik Sorenson, president of MSNBC, blamed a "national fog of materialism and disinterest and avoidance." Even after staff reductions, he said, TV news could have done more foreign coverage. But, he said: "The public interest and the newsworthiness of international news has been such that the networks didn't even use the resources they had overseas. It was a content issue. There was a decision made not to air these kinds of stories."
Those decisions were supported by slumping ratings. For instance, an ABC News prime-time special about India and Pakistan, "The Dark Horizon," in March 2000, did poorly in the ratings. It drew 7 million viewers, and a small share of young adults. The prime-time audience for ABC that year was, on average, 14 million.
Those figures became hard to ignore as the TV news business became more competitive -- with the Fox News Channel and MSNBC adding to an already crowded mix -- and as advertisers and even reporters who cover media put an ever larger importance on the young audience.
Mr. Isaacson said CNN was one of the networks that had lost its way. In the last year, the Fox News Channel began to gain on CNN -- which had stuck with its hard-news formula -- with a strong mix of opinionated talk-show hosts. So CNN's domestic network began to reverse course from so much hard news, arguing that, with some notable exceptions, there was none. Its executives began talking about building its own stable of opinionated and telegenic stars, knowing that, if needed, the network's vast international reach was there in times of crisis.
"In retrospect," Mr. Isaacson said last week, "when we had a period of no urgent news, we all -- all, and not just CNN -- probably spent too much time looking for different approaches that could attract higher ratings."
Of the attacks, he said: "I think this has been a wake-up call to the public and to all of us in the news business that there are certain things that really matter more than the latest trivial thing that can cause a ratings boost."
That may be the right thing to say in the current climate. But it will be a lot harder to sustain deeper foreign coverage, especially if viewer interest wanes. The advertising climate is already bleak. And coverage of military maneuvering overseas is costly. 
Tom Wolzien, a media analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, said a prolonged conflict could put added pressure on the networks to strike cost-sharing deals with one another and heat up talks already taking place at CNN and ABC and CNN and CBS. He said the broadcast networks are likely to need to increase their annual news budgets -- now an average of $300 million to $400 million each -- as much as 35 percent in years to come.
This all presumes a prolonged interest in foreign affairs. Whether public taste has taken a sharp turn for the long haul is hard to know. 
"A lot of things have changed in the world since Sept. 11," said Jeff Fager, executive producer of "60 Minutes II" on CBS. "People are going to want to know more about how the world is operating, what's going on outside our own borders and there's a lot of reporting to do."
But Paul Friedman, executive vice president of ABC News, said it was too soon to tell. "I just don't think there are any givens here," he said. "I don't know that the current interest will continue much beyond this story, however long it lasts."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE VOICES; 
Investors Try To Adjust To a New Set Of Realities

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, Sept. 23 

 BODY:
Voices around the country no longer talk of economic booms or Internet riches, of golden-hued nest eggs or second homes on beach property.
 In January 2000, the Dow Jones industrial average peaked at 11,723; it now has spiraled down toward 8,000. The Dow plummeted 1,369 points, or 14 percent, last week alone in its worst weekly decline since the Great Depression, with more than $1 trillion in stock market wealth wiped out. 
 In recent years investors typically responded to such sell-offs with optimism by buying on the dips and reaffirming their faith in the United States stock market. But today, after the worst terrorist attack in American history, they are shaken by the prospect of war, weakening consumer confidence and a looming recession. 
Individual investors are not fleeing the market entirely. Last week's heaviest selling came from large institutions. Underlying the near-term pessimism of individual investors is optimism about the long-term health of the American economy and the long-term returns of the stock market.
But right now, investors are adjusting to a new set of realities. In a dozen interviews over the weekend, investors appeared hesitant, uncertain and noncommittal. They said they did not want to buy on this dip; they wanted to wait and see what happened. They wanted to sit on their hands.
And so as a result, people like Barbara Levine, a real estate agent in Cleveland, are trimming back their hopes and expectations and coming to grips with a less prosperous America.
"Everything is collapsing around us," Ms. Levine said on Friday, contemplating the prospects of war, a recession and General Electric falling from $60 to $31 a share in the last year.
People like Ms. Levine, 52, are no longer thinking about early retirement. They no longer believe one of their inalienable rights is a rising stock market and a Goldilocks economy. 
A growing number of smaller investors are pulling back from the stock market, seeking more conservative alternatives like municipal and treasury bonds. 
If attitudes have changed, analysts say, it is because individual investors are starting to grow tired of watching their stocks sink.
Many of the hesitant investors are like the Kaminskys, Elliott and Charlotte, both age 67, and both dependent on stock market returns for some of their retirement living expenses.
Mr. Kaminsky took early retirement a few years ago. He still works part-time as a sales manager at Pierre's French Ice Cream Company in Cleveland. He thought he could get by working part-time, but the market drop may keep him on for many more years. 
"It's a killer," Mr. Kaminsky said of the market plunge last week. "I had $740,000 in my pension plan -- you know, what you call an I.R.A. It's now down to $450,000."
He and his wife, who still works some as a real estate broker, own their own home, a three-bedroom brick-faced cottage in University Heights, just outside Cleveland. They are hardly in desperate straits, but they're worried about the market collapse.
The cost of their prescription drugs alone is about $8,000 a year, they say. So they're already making changes. Perhaps they will drive instead of fly off to vacation. And things could change at home, too.
"Maybe we'll be driving one car instead of two," Mr. Kaminsky said. "And maybe I'll be keeping my job a little longer."
Barbara and Eddy Levine are in a similar situation. Mr. Levine, 61, sells insurance and his wife, Barbara, 52, is a real estate agent in Cleveland. They are both in sales, and they both have a sense that the tide is turning -- that consumers are losing confidence. And so are they. They just canceled a month of vacation in Coronado, just off San Diego, and they are sitting on their cash.
"I wouldn't put money in the stock market right now," Mr. Levine said. "I'm on hold."
He said many Americans were "emotionally still," and his wife agrees.
"I talked to someone in the office yesterday, and she hadn't made an appointment in two hours," she said. "People are waiting. The economy had been slowing down, and now people think it's coming to a halt."
Alan and Bonnie Kenyon, both retired teachers living in Mamaroneck, N.Y., said they sold stocks with lots of other people in the last month, even before the attacks. 
"I've pulled everything out of the market," said Ms. Kenyon, 70. "I left some cash in case something turns around."
The $150,000 they had in the stock index fund was pulled eight months ago. Three weeks ago the Kenyons pulled about $50,000 they had invested in individual stocks. Their money is being put in safe investments like money market accounts.
Ms. Kenyon, like so many other investors, is already talking about the end of the good old days. "Do you remember CMGI? You could make $2,000 in a day," she said, regarding the once highflying company that held investments in other Internet companies. What happens now? "I don't know," Ms. Kenyon said. "Maybe you put your money in C.D.'s, making 3.36 percent." 
That return is a far cry from the double-digit stock gains of the 1990's. "Yeah, but it's kind of good these days," Ms. Kenyon said.
She does not watch CNBC all day any more. Indeed, many investors said they were tuning out the market news on TV.
"I've withdrawn from what's going on," says Carol Potts, a retired crafts maker in Santa Barbara, Calif., who traded stocks and closely followed the market on the Internet in recent years. "The present is too overwhelming and depressing."
For a time, Ms. Potts, 59, said she could not bear to watch television or even check her portfolio after the market collapse was under way last year. She had bought technology stocks like JDS Uniphase and Juniper Networks -- stocks that have been crushed in the sell-offs.
Now, Ms. Potts and her husband, 55, are holding steady. They do not want to buy or sell. 
"Everything is as is," she said. "You either have to be a trader or an investor. And I don't have the temperament to be a trader."
The Potts are being more realistic in the aftermath of the stock market decline. They never spent beyond their means in the good times, but they are tightening their belts anyway.
"We are redoing our kitchen, but it's scaled down, and we're doing some of the work ourselves," Ms. Potts said, taking a break from sanding the kitchen floor. "It's not the $4,000 stove, it's the $1,200 stove."
Not everyone, however, is withdrawing from the market. Here in Chicago, an investment club that was started four years ago by a group of professional women is still hanging on.
The club is called "Ladies in Waiting," and its motto is "Get Rich Slow." The 17 women, who range in age from 30 to about 64, are investing in technology companies and blue-chip stocks with supreme patience. The big market plunge created a spirited debate last week, but the consensus was clear: buy more.
"We're an investment club and we ought to invest," said Virginia Sheldon, 63, who is a medical transcriber and a member of the club. "For me it's hard to imagine that in five years I won't have done better."
But for many investors, particularly people like the Kenyons, now at retirment age, the golden age of investing and of big returns and American invulnerability, seems to be over all at once.
"I told my daughter the other day that the 90's were so enjoyable," Ms. Kenyon said. "And now it's gone. I hate to say that because the good times can't be over. But they don't seem like they'll be back for 10 years."

HEADLINE: Former Communist Who Led Left to Victory in Poland 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WARSAW, Sept. 23 

 BODY:
Leszek Miller, Poland's next prime minister, has come full circle. Twelve years ago, as a member of the Central Committee of Poland's Communist Party, he watched it crumble in the face of protests led by Lech Walesa and the Solidarity movement. 
 Today, Mr. Miller, 55, and the former Communists enjoyed a sweeping victory that not only puts them back in power but also deals a potentially fatal blow to Solidarity. 
 Neither Mr. Miller nor his party, now called the Democratic Left Alliance, are calling for a return to old ways. He firmly supports Poland's entry into the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, and has vowed support for the American campaign against terrorism. 
Closer to home, Mr. Miller's top priority is to reduce Poland's big budget deficit. Far from wanting to extend the reach of the state, Mr. Miller has promised Poles deep cuts in government spending.
Like the departing Solidarity-led leaders, Mr. Miller is determined to win Poland's membership in the European Union, a goal that requires both market-opening measures and administrative reforms. Mr. Miller's main campaign slogan, "Let's restore normality and win the future," emphasized steady competence rather than bold new visions. 
The uncertainty about Mr. Miller, though, is about his intentions below the top level of policy. Will he cave in to pressures to shield and subsidize big troubled companies? Will he do anything to relax Poland's rigid job-protection rules, which business executives say have been a major obstacle to hiring? Will he muster the military resources to meet Polish promises to NATO? 
Mr. Miller will take power at one of Poland's most difficult moments since the collapse of Communism. Its economy, which had been growing by about 5 percent a year for the past five years, has stalled. 
The most immediate problem is the government's budget deficit, which has ballooned. Economists say the government will need to make deep cuts just to avoid setting off a panic among Poland's creditors.
Poland's success will have ripple effects across both Central and Western Europe. With 39 million people, Poland has Central Europe's biggest economy and is the region's biggest recipient of foreign investment. Any loss of its credibility is likely to rub off on neighbors.
Mr. Miller, a taciturn man who was trained as an electrician, has based his success on two major principles. The first was to establish the Democratic Left's credibility as a pro-Western party that would continue Poland's support for market economics. 
The second principle, and the one that was probably decisive today, was to promote competence. The issue was crucial because Solidarity had been plagued by infighting, defections and embarrassing political scandals. 
Mr. Miller, who was born on July 3, 1946, in Zyrardow and grew up in a poor family, was trained as an electrician and went to work at a textile factory. He joined the Communist Party in 1969, received a political science degree from the Higher School of Social Sciences in Warsaw in 1977 and rose rapidly on the basis of his organizing strengths. 
He became a member of the Politburo in 1989, just as the Communist regime was collapsing, and he took part in the "round table" meetings with Solidarity leaders that resulted in elections and the Communists' ouster. 
Mr. Miller was among the leaders who stayed with the party after its defeat, and he played a central role in helping to redefine it along the lines of Western Europe's social democratic parties. 
"It became clear the old system would never close the gap with developing countries of the West," he said recently. 
He has been a member of Parliament since 1990 and has served as labor minister and as interior minister during the past decade. 
Some analysts say Mr. Miller is little more than a skilled political tactician rather than a man of deep convictions or ideas. But even former Solidarity leaders say that he and his party are part of current mainstream. 
"The success of Poland's transformation is that the post-Communists began to talk the language of democracy and became part of the democratic process," said Adam Michnik, who was imprisoned for protesting against the old regime and is now editor of Poland's biggest newspaper, Gazeta Wyborcza.

PERSON: Solomon Sagall 

HEADLINE: Solomon Sagall, 101, Dies; Early Proponent of Pay TV 

BYLINE:  By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK 

 BODY:
Solomon Sagall, an early proponent of pay television, died on Sept. 6 at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital in New York. He was 101. 
 In the 1930's Mr. Sagall was among the first to seize on the commercial potential of technology for transmitting video and sound over the airwaves to remote screens, using it first to broadcast sporting events to paying audiences in theaters. 
 Later, waging a prolonged battle against broadcasters and theater owners, he became the leading prophet of what is now known as pay-per-view television.
His 30-year-long drive proved quixotic in the end. His own company, Teleglobe Pay-TV Systems Inc., sought to broadcast coded programming and charge customers a fee for the use of decoding devices attached to their television sets. Just as his plans neared fruition, his concept was overtaken by the advent of cable television. Although cable television was not exactly the revolution Mr. Sagall had in mind, his stalwart advocacy helped to bring it about.
The son of a Russian rabbi in the town of Podberzye, near Minsk, Mr. Sagall attended the University of Moscow before emigrating to Berlin after the Russian Revolution. He then studied economics and political science in Berlin and continued his education at the London School of Economics. 
"Dad went to four universities and spoke five foreign languages -- Russian, German, Yiddish, Hebrew, English and some French -- but he never got a degree," said Mr. Sagall's son, Joel, of New York. 
Mr. Sagall started his career as a journalist, writing in Russian and Yiddish for a Zionist newspaper when he lived in Berlin and continuing to write about Zionism as a freelance correspondent in London. 
But his life changed in 1929 when he read an article about a Hungarian engineer's invention for transmitting video images through the air. He immediately borrowed money to travel to Berlin to acquire the rights to the technology. Although he abandoned the technology almost immediately for a different system designed by a British engineer, Mr. Sagall had found his calling.
"When I was a Zionist, I was a visionary," Mr. Sagall often told his family, "then I became a televisionary."
Mr. Sagall started a company called Scophony to use the technology. Its first venture was broadcasting sporting events to four-foot-high television screens in two London theaters. Mr. Sagall's goal was to use television to make "every home a theater," with "television universities" and "news for breakfast," his son said. 
During World War II, Scophony shifted to the military industry and Mr. Sagall moved to New York. After manufacturing chemicals for the war effort and making televisions for bars and taverns, in 1957 he founded Teleglobe-Pay Systems, based on technology for transmitting coded programming. 
Broadcast networks and movie theater owners were firmly opposed to the idea of charging for television, fearing that it would threaten their businesses and deprive the public of free programming altogether. At their behest, regulators and lawmakers blocked the idea.
But Mr. Sagall maintained that charging a fee would elevate broadcast fare. "Television has largely become a kind of soporific, a mild narcotic having the effect of preventing the majority of the viewers from exercising their thinking faculties," he testified in Congressional hearings in 1958.
Mr. Sagall, meanwhile, began dabbling in theatrical production, partly as a source of programming for Teleglobe. His first production, in 1968, was "I'm Solomon," a translation of a play about the biblical King Solomon. It was a hit in Tel Aviv. But its popularity derived mainly from Hebrew wordplay, and the English production became an expensive flop. Mr. Sagall later staged a smaller production of a play in Yiddish.
By the 1970's, regulators had dropped barriers to pay television. Soon, however, Mr. Sagall's proposed system for broadcasting coded signals was overtaken by cable, which provided more channels. His company, Teleglobe, eventually licensed its pay-per-view technology to cable companies. 
In 1984, Mr. Sagall was elected a fellow of the Royal Television Society of London. He continued going to his office and pursuing other projects until health problems interfered last December. 
In addition to his son, Mr. Sagall is survived by two nephews: Sabby Sagall of London and Myron Sagall of Silver Spring, Md.
Throughout his career, his son recalled, "behind his back, they would say that my father was a Luftmensch -- a man who floats in air, a dreamer."

HEADLINE: Changes Called Likely In Policy on Immigration 

BYLINE:  By SUSAN SACHS 

 BODY:
As the nation takes a closer look at who crosses its borders and why, immigration policy could change in subtle but lasting ways, analysts say.
 In the last few years there has been an open-door policy toward foreign visitors and workers considered vital to the American economy. 
 But a heightened distrust of foreigners since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks could mean far fewer visas for the millions who come each year to study, work or visit, and more government monitoring of foreigners' movements once they arrive.
"We are going to try much more to reduce the opportunities for people to take advantage of the system," said Demetrios G. Papademetriou, a director of the Migration Policy Institute, a Washington research group. 
One long-range result may be broader government powers to detain and deport noncitizens based on their political associations or activities, measures the Bush administration has already proposed.
But the attacks' more immediate effect is likely to be an indefinite delay in the debate about whether to legalize the estimated eight million illegal immigrants in the country. Part of that debate concerned illegal Mexican immigrants and the push by Mexico to create a more fluid flow of migration back and forth across the border.
That issue has now been pushed into the background, though an administration official insisted last week that discussions with Mexico would continue.
Groups that fiercely opposed allowing illegal immigrants to become legal residents have recast their arguments to fit the new situation. Before the attacks, they argued that ineffective border controls and tracking systems had allowed illegal immigrants from Mexico to overrun the nation.
Hours after the attacks, a leading anti-immigration group, the Federation for American Immigration Reform, started to transform the argument. It issued a statement from its executive director, Dan Stein, who said, "The nation's defense against terrorism has been seriously eroded by the efforts of open-borders advocates, and the innocent victims of today's terrorist attacks have paid the price."
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, who has introduced legislation to provide American consulates access to the Federal Bureau of Investigation's criminal database, said the aim was to "ensure that our borders are secure and our laws are enforced." 
But, Mr. Kennedy added, "we need to move forward with our other immigration agenda, and that includes uniting immigrant families and uniting workers with employers."
In addition to laws to expand intelligence gathering, measures that might be considered include better automated border and port systems, improved intelligence cooperation and increased monitoring of foreigners. Some of these ideas have been discussed before and put aside as too damaging to trade or too expensive. Even now, many analysts say, the best response may be to improve existing systems for screening people trying to enter the country.
"The question is, how complete is the information that's in the database?" said Doris M. Meissner, who was immigration commissioner in the Clinton administration. "The lookout database has literally millions of names in it. But with terrorists, if you don't know who they are, their names are not going to be in there."
The last big revision of laws affecting immigrants and refugees was in 1996. Those changes resulted in much less mobility for asylum-seekers, who are more likely now to be held in detention centers while their cases are decided, and a substantial increase in Border Patrol and immigration agents at the land crossings, seaports and airports.
Improvements have also been made in checking the identities of immigrants against watch lists of suspects in crimes and terrorists, Ms. Meissner said. Immigration and consular officials already have access to some databases. And for most international flights, she said, airlines electronically transmit the passenger manifests to a data system in the United States to be checked against a lookout list while the planes are in the air.
New investments, some officials said, should be made to keep technology up to date.
"If we decide we're going to tighten the border between the U.S. and Canada, that means a lot more agents and inspectors and resources on the border," said Paul Cellucci, the United States ambassador to Canada. "It would be better to put those resources into law enforcement and intelligence. To expect that we are going to catch someone at the border is a needle-in-the-haystack situation."
Some of the most far-reaching changes called for in the 1996 laws were never enacted, but they may now be revived because they focus on the least regulated area of nonimmigrant visas. More than 100 people wanted for questioning in the attacks have been arrested on immigration charges, including staying longer in the country than their visas allowed.
The Immigration and Naturalization Service, for example, is only starting to put in place a computerized database of the estimated 500,000 foreigners in the United States on student visas.
The goal was to create a system for catching students who stay illegally after finishing their studies. But instituting the system was delayed for five years by disputes with colleges concerning who would collect fees. 
Similarly, a plan for a computerized system to catalog each entry and exit at the nation's borders was reduced last year after it was declared cumbersome and harmful to commerce. 
Discussion may now be revived about creating a so-called North American perimeter so that foreigners coming to Mexico, Canada or the United States would face similar visa and entry requirements. 
More uniform visa regulations, supporters say, would reduce the possibility that someone could fly legally into one country and then slip across a less vigorously patrolled land border into another. 
Other measures might limit some visas altogether. Some of the hijacking suspects had M visas, allowing them to enroll in technical courses. There have been calls to eliminate that category, though it accounted for only 6,107 visas last year, a tiny number of the total granted.
Nearly 4.2 million people were granted visas for tourism or business last year. Another 284,000 received visas to study at American universities.

HEADLINE: Nairobi Journal; 
Wily 77-Year-Old Is a Traitor to His Hair Color

BYLINE:  By MARC LACEY 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Sept. 23 

 BODY:
Gray hair has traditionally been worn as a badge of honor in Africa. Wrinkles constitute wisdom.
 But President Daniel arap Moi, who recently celebrated his 77th birthday, has prompted a furious debate among Kenyans -- and possibly a run on hair dye by asserting that gray-haired leaders like himself ought to step aside in favor of a younger, black-haired generation. 
 That Mr. Moi, who has held office since 1978, ought to retire is hardly a matter of controversy. Kenyans frustrated with the country's dismal economy, entrenched corruption and general sense of lawlessness speak openly about the need for a shake-up at the top. The United States and other donor countries have also made clear they believe that Kenya would benefit from an orderly transition into a post-Moi era. 
But Mr. Moi, who according to the Constitution must step down by the end of 2002, says that if he goes, all his gray-haired contemporaries ought to go with him. "People say that I am an old man because of my gray hair," Mr. Moi remarked at a recent public rally. "Then my age-mates who also have gray hair should quit politics."
The president has repeated the remark on various other occasions, leading to banner headlines in this society that has generally accorded great deference to the elderly.
One potential casualty of the new hair test is Vice President George Saitoti, a man whom Mr. Moi seems determined to keep at arm's length. Following the lead of the president, Mr. Saitoti's detractors have begun pointing to his salt-and-pepper hair as one big disqualification.
In the words of Julius ole Sunkuli, a minister in the office of the president, the 57-year-old Mr. Saitoti "cannot be described as a young man." The vice president's backers, however, have scrutinized his scalp and come up with a different conclusion.
"Although the vice president has some gray hair, they do not cover most of his head," Okech Kendo, a newspaper columnist, said in defense of Mr. Saitoti, one of numerous politicians eager to become Kenya's third president since independence.
Kenya's population is a youthful one, with perhaps 70 percent of its citizens under the age of 30. Yet many of those who, like Mr. Moi, are sporting some gray do not seem ready to cede power to their children and grandchildren.
Of course Mr. Moi, who enjoys power, may merely be engaged in an elaborate ploy to provoke alarm and so secure his position, for if every official of experience departs the prospects for mayhem are good.
"Half the world is governed by gray-haired men and women in a most sound and unimpeachable manner," argues Joseph M. Nyasani, a 65-year-old professor of philosophy at the University of Nairobi who is balding but, for now, has no discernible gray hair. "In Kenya, rather curiously, we are being told to lock up our experience and expertise the moment a few gray hairs begin to show."
Another theory among Moiologists, is that the president is casting aspersions on his contemporaries to ensure that rivals like Simeon Nyachae, a gray-haired former finance minister, do not succeed him in the State House. By handpicking a young, inexperienced leader, the thinking goes, Mr. Moi can maintain some of his influence even as an ex-president.
"It is highly suspect to demand that a certain generation should quit politics and go home merely to make room for the youth while at the same time other sectors of our social and economic life remain at the hands of the same 'old' people," Mr. Nyasani wrote in a recent newspaper commentary.
Others agree that age ought to be irrelevant as a presidential qualification. The next leader, they contend, ought to be someone who can stand above the often-bitter ethnic loyalties that divide the country, control the soaring crime rate and reverse the nation's economic free fall. After long being regarded as the star of East Africa, Kenya is now broke and broken.
"The president will come from God," asserted Njenga Karume, a member of Parliament, "whether he shall be a young or an old man."
As this spirited discussion over age, hair and governance continues, there are signs that Kenya has not completely cast away its elders. It is true that many of the traditional values of rural life -- respect for elders among them -- have faded as Kenyans have flocked to the big city.
In villages, the young people step aside in deference to the old. But on the crowded streets of Nairobi, it is every person-- young, old or middle aged -- for himself.
Then there is the case of Ester Nyambura Kaburu, a gray-haired grandmother. Her story suggests that Kenyans still have a soft spot for their elders.
When the 93-year-old Ms. Kaburu was thrown into prison last month for chopping down 12 banana plants in a dispute with her daughter-in-law, the arrest prompted a national outcry. After four days, a good Samaritan stepped forward with $64 in bail money to spring Ms. Kaburu, who is known affectionately as "Cucu." "A carnival mood gripped the jubilant Gituria villagers who erupted in fervent prayers of thanksgiving upon Nyambura's release," said one newspaper account.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Daniel arap Moi, left, president of Kenya, says when he leaves political life, so should all other gray-haired Kenyans. Simeon Nyachae, right, a gray-haired former finance minister, may be one of Mr. Moi's targets. (Reuters); (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: Rebuilding Downtown 

 BODY:
Virtually everyone in New York City, and indeed most of the country, understands the importance and urgency of rebuilding downtown Manhattan. In the aftermath of the terrorist attack, it is vital to reaffirm the city's status as a premier financial capital and restore hope to a battered neighborhood.
 Among New York's senior political figures, there is an emerging consensus that a special commission or authority should be created to oversee the reconstruction. The stars in New York's fractious political firmament are in unusually close alignment at this time of emergency. The task now is for Gov. George Pataki and Mayor Rudolph Giuliani to transform this moment of harmony into a workable plan. 
 Step one is to create a commission with the necessary powers to get the job done quickly and correctly. As some of the candidates for mayor pointed out over the weekend, it is critical that this body include representation of both the state and the city. An equal number of members from each might be best, with a tie-breaking chairman who was mutually acceptable to both sides.
Part of the authority's or commission's job will be aesthetic and, to some extent, spiritual -- defining the scale and scope of the restored district, and designing an appropriate memorial to the World Trade Center victims. The group's basic responsibility, however, will be economic -- encouraging the construction of new buildings while making sure there are tenants to occupy them. Speed is important here. Major companies displaced by the collapse of the trade center are less likely to sign long-term leases elsewhere if they can be confident that space downtown will be available in a timely manner.
A package of financial incentives will almost certainly be required to persuade the anchor tenants to return. The devastation displaced nearly 100,000 workers and removed at least 15 million square feet of prime office space, or the equivalent of 15 Empire State Buildings, from the market. The city and state have so far done an extraordinary job of meeting the needs of the smaller firms needing less than 50,000 square feet. But the key to downtown's rebirth will be the big players -- Merrill Lynch, Citigroup, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, American Express, Lehman Brothers -- that need acres of contiguous space.
The commission may be able to dip into the $20 billion in federal emergency relief funds for some of these purposes, but it would be a mistake to rely too heavily on that source. With the cleanup alone costing $30 million a day, and expected to go on for months, much of that $20 billion will be spent on clearing the rubble, replacing infrastructure like the PATH and subway stations and readying the land for development. A more reliable way of persuading the old businesses to return would be to deploy the traditional array of economic devices -- tax credits, loan guarantees and the like -- that states and cities use to lure and retain businesses.
History suggests that all this is doable. People have been predicting the demise of the financial district for almost 40 years. The World Trade Center itself helped lead an earlier revival in the 1970's, even as law firms and investment banks were migrating to central Manhattan. In the early 1990's, a recession left empty one of every four floors of downtown office space, nearly all of which were full by the end of the decade. The district will never be the same. But there is every reason to believe that if our elected leaders and the best minds in the financial and architectural communities are willing to seize the moment, it can be made even more vibrant than it was before Sept. 11.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE INVESTORS; 
No Big Rush To Buy or Sell By Wall Street Professionals

BYLINE:  By RIVA D. ATLAS with JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

 BODY:
Stocks are at their lowest levels in three years, inspiring some intrepid bargain hunters to start buying selectively. But several money managers said late Friday and over the weekend that they were approaching the coming week cautiously, not planning on buying aggressively in case the market dropped further.
 Over the weekend, the malaise extended to consumers as well, with fewer than normal at movie theaters, restaurants and stores. 
 In one hopeful sign for the financial markets, several portfolio managers said they were trying to hold on to stocks they regard as too cheap to discard. "I'm not going to let big fund managers and market makers panic me out of any stocks I'm fully confident in," said Timothy P. Vick, senior portfolio manager for Arbor Capital Management of Anchorage. 
But for the most part, nearly two weeks after the attacks, major investors were still recovering from their shock and still hesitant. "Times of duress are poor times for investors to make decisions," said John C. Bogle, founder of the Vanguard Group, a leading mutual fund company. "I wouldn't plunge in now, but I wouldn't plunge out either." 
Some investors are just starting to become focused. "I lost a personal friend and an investor in my fund," said Neil J. Weisman, general partner of Chilmark 21st Century Capital, a Saddle River, N.J., hedge fund. "I used to talk to him every morning between 7 and 7:30, no matter where I was in the world."
Still, Mr. Weisman said he was beginning to consider some stocks. "I probably will stick my toe in the water over the next few weeks," he said. "A lot of stocks in industries obviously impacted are down already." While he would not touch airlines, he said that hotel companies might be worth a look.
Timothy M. Ghriskey, a former portfolio manager for Dreyfus who left to run the Ghriskey Capital Partners hedge fund, also remains cautious. "Everybody wants the stock market to go up," he said. "But calling a market turn is a fool's game."
Still, Mr. Ghriskey is starting to look at consumer stocks that do well in a downturn, including Anheuser-Busch, Coca-Cola, Procter & Gamble and Gillette.
Battered insurance stocks are also attracting cautious interest. "There was an over-reaction in the insurance area last week," said A. Michael Frinquelli, a partner in Renaissance Fund Advisors, which focuses on the industry. He likes the Reinsurance Group of America, Annuity and Life Re, Allstate and Jefferson-Pilot.
Michael F. Price, former chairman of the Franklin Mutual Series funds, who now runs MFP Investors, where he manages over $1 billion, has a conservative 30 percent of that in cash. But he did buy some stocks on Friday, and will probably purchase more in the coming weeks. "There is some value here, but you have to be conservative," he said. 
Or, as one manager of a leading hedge fund, who is keeping more than half his money in cash, said: "My advice to the public is don't be heroic. Sit tight until things settle down. If you can't withstand another 20 percent decline you shouldn't own stocks."
Executives were blaming continuing unease over the attacks and the resulting decision by several studios not to open new films for a steep drop in attendance this weekend.
Another factor may have been the Friday night telethon, which offered a broader roster of film and pop-music superstars than the theaters, said Paul Dergarabedian, chairman of Exhibitor Relations, which monitors box-office performance.
Attendance was expected to drop significantly the previous weekend but a slate of new films led by Keanu Reeves in "Hardball" had earnings more than 40 percent higher than the comparable weekend a year ago.
This weekend, however, performed more to those initial expectations. The top 12 films earned an estimated $44.2 million, roughly 15 percent less than the previous weekend and 7 percent below the same weekend last year.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's urgings for New Yorkers to spend money received only a limited response. At La Metarie, a Greenwich Village restaurant, business was off about 30 percent, only slightly better than last weekend, when traffic in the neighborhood was restricted. "Still very, very slow," said Josue Elmalem, the maitre d'hotel, explaining that the attack compounded a slowdown he blamed on the stock market's earlier retreat.
Around Los Angeles, stores said business was off sharply. At Macy's in Sherman Oaks, shopping this weekend was estimated down by about half. "They're worrying about the economy and they're worried about what's going to happen next," said Rosie Bally, an employee there.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SPECIAL FORCES; 
Eerie Quiet as 'Screaming Eagles' Await Battle Orders

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: FORT CAMPBELL, Ky., Sept. 23 

 BODY:
The grim drumbeat of war seemed oddly distant today from this sprawling Army post straddling the border of Kentucky and Tennessee.
 Soldiers played golf on the base's sun-drenched course. Rocket-launching helicopters squatted on the desolate airstrip. The hallways inside the white-clapboard command center were dark and quiet. 
 Yet behind Fort Campbell's just-another-weekend calm, its 24,000 troops have been steeling themselves for battle, packing equipment, honing rifle skills, readying loved ones for the deployment orders they all consider inevitable.
"You take a look at this global problem with terrorism and it's pretty evident that most soldiers in combat units will probably be involved," said Maj. Gen. Richard A. Cody, commander of the fort and its 101st Airborne Division.
Indeed, history suggests that the 101st, which specializes in riding to battle in Black Hawk and Chinook helicopters, escorted by sleek Apache gunships, will be among the first to go overseas if ground troops are needed for the United States war on terrorism. 
The Screaming Eagles, as the 101st is known, helped storm Normandy in 1944, and the exploits of its Easy Company are celebrated in the Stephen E. Ambrose book and HBO series "Band of Brothers."
In 1991, a squadron of Apache attack helicopters from the 101st commanded by General Cody, a lieutenant colonel at the time, fired some of the first shots of Operation Desert Storm, the Persian Gulf offensive.
And Black Hawk pilots from the 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment flew the ill-fated 1993 mission in Mogadishu, Somalia, where 18 soldiers were killed in the fiercest firefight involving United States troops since Vietnam.
"It's clear to me and the troops that something big is going to happen," General Cody said. "A lot of people will be involved. The Army will be involved. This division will be involved."
"But it's not going to happen tomorrow morning," he added.
About the only thing to pierce Fort Campbell's tranquil facade today was the heightened security. Throughout the base, soldiers in black berets and armed with M-4 rifles stood guard at new checkpoints draped with barbed wire. They were just a tiny part of the newly expanded, 2,800-soldier detail protecting the 65-square-mile post.
Soldiers and their families said the closing of most gates and tighter security at the main entrance since the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon had caused hourlong traffic jams along Route 41A. But few were complaining. 
"I'm glad it's there," said Darla Fabunan, 28, whose husband is a staff sergeant with the 160th Special Operations Aviation Regiment, known as the Night Stalkers.
"He doesn't tell me much about what he's going to do," Ms. Fabunan said of her husband. "I just figure that if he comes home and grabs his bags, he's going."
That is the nature of the 101st. One of the division's three brigades is always prepared to depart on 36 hours' notice, its equipment already packed and loaded onto pallets that would go inside the cavernous bellies of Air Force cargo planes.
"The eerie calm here is just normal operations," said Maj. Paul Fitzpatrick, a base spokesman. "We're always good to go."
In addition to the 101st and 160th, Fort Campbell is home to the Fifth Special Forces Group, which has trained extensively on the Arabian peninsula and in South and Central Asia.
Though General Cody said the division had yet to receive deployment orders from Washington, its troops have not been standing still. A 90-soldier infantry company will be going to the Persian Gulf region for a training exercise this week. Another 3,600 soldiers will board buses and head south in a few days for exercises at the Joint Readiness Training Center at Fort Polk, La.
General Cody said both exercises had been scheduled at least a year ago. But these days, any troop movements on base cause a stir in the nearby towns of Oak Grove, Ky., and Clarksville, Tenn., where many residents and business owners worry that a huge mobilization will devastate the local economy, as happened in the Persian Gulf war.
"When the guys left in 1990, you could practically hear a giant sucking sound," said Yvonne Chamberlain, a real estate agent in Clarksville. "Business dried up, restaurants closed, there were foreclosures all over."
The residents have veiled their anxiety with American flags, "God Bless America" banners and the routines of small-town life.
For First Sgt. Emanuel Azan, that meant playing in the over-30 soccer league at Heritage Park under the brilliant Saturday afternoon sun. Looking carefree as a surfer in his sunglasses, he said he was itching to go to war.
"I'd be the first to board the plane," Sergeant Azan said. "My wife, she don't like it. But she understands it's what I do."
General Cody called the impending conflict "a very different fight," which initially will probably involve small-scale, search-and-destroy missions carried out by Special Operations troops like Army Green Berets.
At some point, he said, large numbers of ground troops are likely to be needed. But as in the gulf war, when American troops massed on the Iraqi border for months, the mobilization will not happen overnight, he said. 
"I told the troops, 'This is a marathon, not a sprint,' " he said. "There is no point in wearing ourselves out."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE CONSUMERS; 
Recession's Harbinger Is a Missouri City Not Prone to Boom or Bust

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, Mo., Sept. 23 

 BODY:
The economy is sinking in this, the biggest city in central Missouri. Since the terrorist attacks on New York and the Pentagon, Mary and Bill Hires's notions of buying anything nonessential have evaporated. 
 Ms. Hires, 69, whose husband was a professor at the University of Missouri here before he retired, was putting a bag into her van in the Wal-Mart parking lot near Columbia's new southwestern subdivisions. "We felt very secure," she said. "We were at the point of getting into the 21st century." 
 They planned to replace their old television set and install a satellite dish antenna. "We were going to spend a little more money on personal pleasures," Ms. Hires said. "We don't have that feeling now. The antenna costs $50 a month. We don't need that." 
Priorities here are shifting with the economy.
"We have been thinking of getting a new car next summer," said Anita Bruzzese, 42, a writer and mother of two boys, 6 and 12. "We still have that on the agenda. But I promise you it won't be a gas guzzler." Shuttling children to school, she said, "it's one mom in each car. We're talking about carpooling. " 
For decades, the economy of Columbia has been unusually resilient. Driven by its colleges and universities, its hospitals and insurance companies, it tends to resist the worst of the booms and busts that plague layoff-prone manufacturing towns. For years, it has had one of the lowest unemployment rates in the nation, rarely exceeding 2 percent. 
But last week, even Columbia started showing signs of tumbling into a recession. People are buying what they need, they say, but little of what they once wanted. They are shredding their prosperity-nurtured plans for bigger homes, bigger cars, new appliances and a higher standard of living. They have stopped applying for credit cards. 
As Columbia goes, so, almost certainly, most of the nation is going.
To declare a recession, the government requires six months' evidence of reduced consumer and business spending, and that has yet to show up. But within the banking system, evidence is building that consumers are acting on their post-attack sentiments and scripting a recession.
Thirty miles south of Columbia, in the state capital, Jefferson City, is the Midwest Independent Bank. It is what is known as a bankers' bank, or a correspondent bank. It has no tellers or A.T.M.'s. Its purpose is to provide financial services to more than 300 mostly small banks in Missouri, Nebraska and Iowa. 
By watching the loans and transfers the banks make to one another each day, Midwest Independent can spot signs of a surging or chilling economy almost instantly. It can tell when the customers of other banks start to retreat from stores, fall behind on credit card payments or stop applying for loans. 
Nearly two weeks after the terrorist attacks, Camden R. Fine, the bank's president, sees an already slowing economy slowing even more. He said one compelling sign was that affiliated banks were transferring less money through his bank. Last week transfers dropped to an average of 265 a day from a rate of 300 in the weeks before Sept. 11. 
"Everything has changed," said Mr. Fine, who also owns a small bank in Ashland, between Columbia and Jefferson City. "Prior to the attacks, housing was strong, tourism was slowing, but it wasn't in the dumps. Now you have loan demand slowing. People are more cautious about withdrawing money, and they're adding to their deposits." 
Consumers appear to be shunning anything frivolous. Near Columbia, at the Kingdom City exit off Interstate 70, sales at the barnlike Ozarkland souvenir store have stalled. "People are sad," said Sharon Brown, assistant manager. They ask for only one item, American flags, and the store ran out of them within hours of the attacks, Ms. Brown said. 
In Columbia, at Starrett Fine Jewelers on Broadway, Michael Oetting, the manager, said: "Standard bridal and anniversary jewelry, they're back to normal. Spontaneous purchases, they're not." 
At Summit Travel on Broadway, Jerry Price, president, has cut his five agents' hours by 20 percent. "The phones have been very quiet," he said. "It causes us to be wary about our future."
Mr. Price's travails echo across the economy, in his agents' diminished incomes and in spending for supplies and services that he has curbed. "For a small-business person," he said, "this is a crisis." 
Home sales, too, have plunged. "The people that didn't have to move, they've just gone away," said Sarah Mackey, a broker at Gaslight-Gundaker GMAC Real Estate.
"I had several buyers who were just in the starting phase," Ms. Mackey said. They had talked to their banks about mortgages and were beginning to look for bigger and better homes. "They just went away," she said. 
"It's the middle class that's getting squished the most," she said. She said some of the more expensive houses, those priced at more than $200,000, are selling because wealthier buyers have cash, and homes for less than $90,000 are selling because low-income buyers can get government-subsidized mortgages. 
Phil Gravitt, 39, was stuffing cash into his wallet as he left a branch of Boone County National Bank. He is in the construction business, specializing in building the concrete foundations for the forests of subdivisions that have grown up around Columbia. Like many people here, he says he believes that burrowing in is what the terrorists want.
"I'm not going to stop going on living and enjoying life, or the terrorists have won," Mr. Gravitt said. But like many people, too, he is making compromises. "I take hunting and fishing trips to Colorado and South Dakota," he said. "But I'm going to stay around home and stick with the family." 
With fewer consumers taking money out of banks for loans and spending, Mr. Fine at the Midwest Independent Bank says an immense sea of money is sloshing around in bank coffers.
Part of the reason is that at the same time consumers and businesses have been borrowing less and saving more, the Federal Reserve in Washington has been pouring money into the economy to thwart fearful consumers' runs on banks and assure that when they do want to borrow, they can get the money. 
By Wednesday last week, M.I.B. banks that normally borrow from one another to keep their accounts balanced stopped lending and borrowing altogether. They all had plenty to lend, and none needed to borrow. As a result, they chopped the interest rate they charge one another from 3 percent to zero. 
"They're sitting with excess funds, and they can't find anybody to buy them," Mr. Fine said. "I've never seen zero. That's unprecedented." By week's end, the rate was still below 1 percent.
Once it becomes clear that the rock-bottom rates are here to stay, the same banks can be expected to cut rates throughout the economy, reducing them on credit cards, car loans and home mortgages. Precedent shows that low rates can eventually reignite the economy. 
In Columbia last week, the standard fixed-rate, 30-year home mortgage was stuck at a little above 7 percent. But on Friday, General Motors dealers began offering five-year car loans for no interest at all to reliable buyers. Ford followed suit. Such deals might revive consumers.
"I have a friend in Bolivar, Mo., who has a G.M. dealership," said Doug Collins, 48, a cable splicer for Verizon who drives a 1996 Chevrolet truck. "I'm going to see if what I heard is true," he said. "I might buy a new truck."

GRAPHIC: Photos: "I had several buyers who were just in the starting phase," said Sarah Mackey, a real estate broker in Columbia, Mo. After the attacks, she said, "they just went away." Camden R. Fine, below left, a Columbia banker, said, "People are more cautious about withdrawing money." (Photographs by L. G. Patterson for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: CULTURE; 
New Look for Entertainment In a Terror-Conscious World

BYLINE:  By JOHN LELAND and PETER MARKS 

 BODY:
For executives at MGM, the release of a forthcoming movie called "Gangster" is problematic. It has action and suspense, mobsters and international terrorists.
 Once this was the stuff of box office dreams. But the tragedy of Sept. 11 changed all that. Now the makers of "Gangster" and dozens of other films, television shows, plays, books, musical recordings and video games are trying to find their places in a shifting cultural landscape. 
 The self-scrutiny is unprecedented in scale, sweeping aside hundreds of millions of dollars in projects that may no longer seem appropriate. Like the calls to curb violence in popular entertainment after the 1999 shootings at Columbine High School in Colorado, the reaction may be helpful in the short term. But creators and producers are just beginning to grapple with more difficult, long-range questions of what the public will want once the initial shock from the terrorist attacks wears off. 
Many in the industry admit that they do not know where the boundaries of taste and consumer tolerance now lie, much less where they will be in a year or two.
In the short run there are immediate questions. After such tragedy and insecurity, conveyed in vivid television images, is it responsible -- or commercially viable -- to deal in fantasy violence or the romance of the outlaw? In a climate of mourning and fear, is there a place for humor and escapism, fashion and pleasure? 
"People realize that it is not the time to move forward with the frivolous, exploitative action films," said David Ladd, an independent producer and former MGM executive. "There has been a certain complacency, I believe, in the audience, to be titillated by a certain kind of movie, whether it's on the comedy side or the action side, and I believe that this incident has made everyone a lot more thoughtful."
The new piety strikes an odd note: taste is not what some of these people do best. Industries that have robustly defended depictions of mindless carnage or the degradation of women are suddenly drawing the line in seemingly arbitrary ways, policing even incidental references to the World Trade Center.
All fields of culture are feeling the uncertainty. Playwrights and novelists are reassessing their subjects. Fashion houses, architects and industrial designers, buffeted by both the tragedy and the sinking economy, are rethinking the role of irony, luxury and security.
"That sort of ironic, hip attitude is going to have to undergo revision," said Jonathan Galassi, the publisher of Farrar, Straus & Giroux. "Any sort of sense of cynicism and self-absorption -- nobody is going to be interested in that."
Rock and rap performers, who have been sliding into gaudy irrelevance, are hoping to re-engage the public. "Music was in a very stagnant place before the attack," said Antonio Reid, president and chief executive of Arista Records. "We have good records but not meaningful records. Maybe the attack will jolt writers to speak to the times we're living in." 
First, though, the businesses are scrambling not to offend. Studios have put off the openings of action films like Arnold Schwarzenegger's "Collateral Damage" and a Tim Allen comedy, "Big Trouble," which involves a bomb on an airplane.
Television series are holding back episodes that are now viewed as cutting too close to the bone. And television writers are reformulating pitches for next season.
Bryce Zabel, chairman-elect of the Academy of Television Arts and Sciences and a longtime television writer and producer, said he had been scheduled to pitch an idea last week to the USA Networks for a mini-series called "World War III." "Obviously this show died when the victims died," he said.
Now he is reaching for story ideas from the heart. "Maybe more character-oriented, something to do with romance or fantasy," he said.
Even an artist as respected as Stephen Sondheim is not immune. The Roundabout Theater Company has withdrawn plans for a Broadway revival of Mr. Sondheim's 1991 musical, "Assassins," because it portrays the killers of American presidents. The McCarter Theater in Princeton, N.J., has pulled from its season a dark 25-year-old play by Richard Nelson, "Vienna Notes," which has references to a terrorist act.
There is a daunting momentum to such caution. On an MTV message board, a viewer described the singer Alicia Keys as "the bomb," a vernacular compliment. "Someone said, 'Take that off,' " said Judy McGrath, president of MTV Group.
Even the World Wrestling Federation has shown a new sensitivity, decking its performances with American flags and removing a theme song called "Bodies." (It's about dancers, not corpses.) "We're in a gray area in terms of what's right and wrong," said Stuart Snyder, the company's chief operations officer.
This self-policing threatens to yield a culture of blandness, leading some to conclude that cultural comfort food is all the nation may be willing to stomach. "We're going to go right back to Doris Day movies, I can feel it in the bones of the country," said Robert Brustein, a theater director and a critic for The New Republic. "It's escapism."
Comedians and satirists already feel the squeeze; after the tragedy, being funny almost seems treasonous, said Steve Levitan, creator of "Just Shoot Me," an NBC sitcom. "And when you laugh at something, you feel guilty."
Even the unmodulated speech of the Internet is tempering its sarcasm. Last spring Modern Humorist, a satirical Internet magazine, published "My First Presidentiary," a savage paperback sendup of President Bush. This week on its Web site it posted the sort of heartfelt message that might have once been used to sell war bonds.
"You probably wouldn't guess that the creeps behind Modern Humorist are the sort who wave flags and sing 'America the Beautiful' with strangers in the streets," wrote the editors, Michael Colton and John Aboud. "But that is what we have been doing, in unity with others."
Television viewers watched last week as one wiseacre talk show host after another engaged in a kind of public purging. "I'm sorry to do this to you; it's another entertainment show beginning with an overwrought speech of a shaken host," the comedian Jon Stewart said on "The Daily Show," which returned on Thursday after more than a week off.
Eventually the late-night hosts will move on from grief; by the end of the week, David Letterman was beginning to joke around, but only in the gentlest ways.
"It's not that irony is dead," said Mr. Aboud. "It's just that feelings and honesty are in."
But others are resisting a retreat to softness. George Steel, who heads Columbia University's Miller Theater, a haven for adventurous contemporary music, had second thoughts about opening the season on Friday with "Blood on the Floor," a raw, jazz-infused work. In the end he decided that music lovers could make up their own minds. "To cancel it or replace it with something more palatable would be to infantalize the audience," he said.
Tony Kushner, the Tony-winning playwright of "Angels in America," has a new play, "Homebody/Kabul," about a family's search for an Englishwoman lost in Afghanistan. It is scheduled to begin performances in late November at the New York Theater Workshop, whose artistic director, James Nicola, said he had every intention of proceeding.
"It is all the more important now to be thinking about Afghanistan, to explore what we don't know about it and why we don't know what we don't know," Mr. Kushner said.
It is not clear whether any of the current foment will prove substantive or lasting.
"There'll still be explosions and violence in movies," said Edward Zwick, who directed the 1998 film "The Siege," about terrorists in New York. "It's naive to think otherwise."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: CHARITY; 
Air Cargo Industry Losses Put Paychecks in Jeopardy

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
For Nibardo Osores, the sound of planes flying over his house in Richmond Hill, Queens, always meant that business was good. But Mr. Osores, 53, a cargo handler at Kennedy International Airport, does not ear as many planes these days. With air traffic declining, he has lost work hours and has been warned that he will be laid off by his employer, Swisscargo, if the company's flight schedule is reduced.
 While much has been reported about the difficulties the air travel industry is facing after the attack on the World Trade Center, air cargo companies face problems as well, as the number of international shipments dwindle. 
 What for six years was a steady job is now a day-to-day question mark for Mr. Osores, who calls his office each morning at 10 o'clock to see if they need him to work his shift that day, from 1 to 8 p.m.
With monthly mortgage payments to make and two children to feed, Mr. Osores, who earns $9.80 an hour, needs a paycheck every week, he said. His wife, Hilda, 53, worked as a seamstress at a T-shirt manufacturer in Richmond Hill until July, when the company, MG Textiles and Sportwear, closed the factory. She was paid by the piece, stitching T-shirts together and earning as much as $300 a week last year.
What remains is the $1,429 monthly mortgage payment on the couple's three-bedroom vinyl-sided house in Richmond Hill. "I have a lot of financial responsibilities," Mr. Osores said, "especially the mortgage of this house. If you don't pay on time, they add a late charge, that's $60 to $70 a month."
The family got in touch with Catholic Charities of the Diocese of Brooklyn and Queens last week after Mr. Osores had spent a week without work. It was the first time that the family had to ask for help from a charity. "It was a hard decision to call for assistance," Mrs. Osores said.
"There's a big possibility they're going to apply for unemployment benefits," said Rosa Orihuela, a social worker from Catholic Charities who is helping the family. The charity is one of 10 supported by The New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund.
Ms. Orihuela would help the family apply for unemployment benefits if necessary. In the meantime, Catholic Charities will pay the family's mortgage for a month. The agency also provided food for the Osoreses from a pantry at the Queens South Family Center in Hollis, which stocks canned juices, fruits and vegetables, cereal and pasta. "It's not only the mortgage they have to worry about," Ms. Orihuela said. "It's all the bills. At least we can alleviate some expenses."
Mr. Osores said he had not asked his children, Isaac, 15, a sophomore at Richmond Hill High School, and Noemi, 12, a seventh grader at Middle School 226 in South Ozone Park, to help out by finding part-time work, and had not told them about the family's financial troubles. Isaac wants to become a scientist, and Noemi a psychologist or a chef, and Mr. Osores does not want them to be distracted from their studies.
So to ensure that the bills are paid on time, the two parents are looking for other types of employment. Mrs. Osores, who is originally from Ambato, Ecuador, a small town about 75 miles south of Quito, is looking for another job as a seamstress. "I have a lot of experience at many machines," she said. "I came to this country 30 years ago, and I take experience at many fabrics."
For his part, Mr. Osores plans to look for a new job outside the airline industry. "I have experience as a driver," he said, then, looking at his wife and smiling, added, "I cook, too."

HEADLINE: E-Commerce Report; 
Online travel agencies brace to weather the air travel slump.

BYLINE:  By Bob Tedeschi 

 BODY:
BEFORE Sept. 11, online travel agencies like Expedia, Travelocity and Priceline were among the few e-commerce companies that had defied the dot-com trend by keeping their stock prices relatively high and achieving profitability, even amid a softening travel market. 
 Now, in light of the grim events of Sept. 11 and their business and economic aftermath, online travel executives are wondering whether their industry can remain the standard-bearer for e-commerce -- or, for that matter, whether most Internet travel companies can even remain in business. 
 Rosenbluth International's Biz Travel.com was the first online travel company to fold in response to the severe decline in air travel, shutting its doors on Friday. Analysts said some other travel sites would probably follow. 
Given their cash reserves, the biggest full-service Internet travel agents -- Expedia, Travelocity and Orbitz -- will probably sustain their businesses through next year, analysts said, if consumers return to the airports even in modest numbers, as they seem to be doing. Indeed, investors acknowledged such optimism late last week, as they began buying back shares of Expedia, Priceline and Travelocity after rounds of heavy selling. (Orbitz is privately held by several major airlines.) 
But if these companies are able to reward their investors' faith, it may be partly because they had already begun diversifying their businesses, to reduce their reliance on airline ticket commissions, which have plummeted in recent years. 
According to Tom Underwood, an analyst with the investment firm Legg Mason, more than half of Expedia's profits now come from nonairline-related sales. "Travelocity's a little more dependent on air," he said, "but they're also getting a significant portion of their revenues from hotels, rental cars and advertising." 
In balancing their revenue sources, these sites have also refined their approaches to selling their products, including airline tickets. 
Rather than simply selling standard fares of airline tickets or hotel rooms at published rates for commission, online travel agencies have increasingly bought blocks of airline, hotel and cruise ship inventories that the suppliers have had difficulty selling. The sites can then offer customers low prices on those products, while still earning more than twice what they would make through a standard travel agent commission (which is now $10, in the case of airline tickets). 
In the short term, this approach may not help sites earn more from airline ticket sales, analysts said, as consumers who do not feel safe flying will not be persuaded to book a flight simply because it is $50 cheaper. That is especially true if airlines continue to shrink the number of flights, because the block-purchase model depends on the airlines' having excess inventory to sell cheaply. 
But for hotel and rental car packages, the supply -- and demand -- could be greater. 
"It's certainly clear that anybody who was planning to hold a conference has generally pushed it out to next year, so there's a very large number of hotels scrambling to fill an awful lot of rooms in the fall," said Erik Blachford, senior vice president of Expedia. "We're in a reasonably good position to not only help the hotels fill the rooms, but also give our customers some really good rates." 
Even if the demand for airline tickets remains depressed, some analysts said airline ticket sales on the travel sites could actually grow. Mr. Underwood said airline bookings for online travel agencies before Sept. 11 had been growing by about 35 percent over last year. 
"Even if you say the industry will be down 25 percent, just to pick a number," he said, "there'll still be the same migration to online bookings, so Internet bookings will still be up." 
Some other analysts agree that travelers will continue to turn to Web sites in increasing numbers. Henry Harteveldt, an online travel analyst with Forrester Research, a consulting firm, said online travel sales might not reach the $16.7 billion his firm had previously predicted for this year. But he still expects the total to be more than the $12.2 billion of last year. 
Mr. Harteveldt predicted a gradual end to the lingering confusion over so-called e-tickets -- in particular, whether they are now acceptable at airports. E-tickets refer to electronic receipts that can be printed out by a buyer of online tickets -- whether from the person's own computer or, in many cases, from kiosks at aiports. Since the attacks, some airports have required people with e-tickets to check in at airline counters for official documentation, but generally speaking, Mr. Harteveldt said, "e-tickets are just as useful now as before the attacks."
Given that consumers will want to research trips -- be they alternatives to longer flights or replacement trips for those postponed in September -- Mr. Harteveldt said they would probably rely heavily on the Internet. "Also, the typical household that buys leisure travel online earns about $72,000, so they have the economic capability to travel," he said, compared with less-affluent families in the current economy.
"So suppliers, who a couple weeks ago were trying to minimize their work with online travel agencies, will want to work with them now to put together promotional programs and offers," Mr. Harteveldt said. "The travel sites will be suppliers' new best friends." 
Terrell B. Jones, chief executive of Travelocity, foresees the situation playing out similarly. "The normal response of the air, car and hotel industry in coming out of a strike situation, or the gulf war, is to stimulate travel through promotion and price," he said. "I suspect it'll happen again, and we're right in the middle of that." 
In the meantime, nearly every online travel site is searching for ways to cut costs, to account for both the dramatic drop in revenues and some unusually large checks they have had to write. For instance, for every flight canceled, the online agencies have to return the commissions they were paid by the airlines. Moreover, some sites, like Travelocity, have had to pay overtime to their customer service teams for the work in the days after the attacks. 
According to Jeffrey G. Katz, chief executive of Orbitz, those cost-cutting measures at his company have included 17 layoffs, or about 10 percent of the work force. "I'm actually optimistic that things will come back more quickly than a lot of people have said, but it's still going to be a rough period," Mr. Katz said. "And we want to operate at a cost level that's consistent with the revenue level."
Echoing the strategies of other online travel site executives, Mr. Katz said the company would reduce marketing expenditures by "as much as 50 percent, since you can't market if the market isn't there." 
Mr. Katz also predicted that there would be "some opportunistic acquisitions" by travel sites with good cash reserves. "Nobody will escape the impact of this, but the second- and third-tier players will be in a very difficult spot," he said. "I think you'll see them disappearing." 
In the midst of such bleakness, some online travel executives said they hoped the coming holiday season would invigorate bookings. "Maybe this is a season where people will want to come together," said Mr. Jones, of Travelocity. "We'll have to wait and see." 
Of course, even such guarded optimism is fragile, given the possibility that last week's attacks may not be the last. If there are further terrorist incidents, said an analyst who spoke on condition of anonymity, "the return to leisure travel will be longer than anyone's anticipating now."
