HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE SPENDING; 
In the Computer Sector, a 'Blanket of Hesitation'

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
For the last two decades, spending on information technology in the United States has grown at two to three times the rate of the economy and never declined, even in economic recessions. But even before the Sept. 11 attacks, information technology spending, which grew 11 percent last year, was slowing.
 Now projections are being trimmed further, down to 3 percent growth, according to estimates by the International Data Corporation in a revised "worst-case scenario" that the research firm says is increasingly likely. 
 The $450 billion information technology industry, which animates much of the modern economy, is struggling with the impact of the attacks, rethinking its priorities and spending plans, and searching for any lessons to be learned from the tragedy. 
The immediate impact is lost sales from the brake on travel, shopping and investment decisions. Yet there is already the beginning of a rise in the equipment replacement and recovery business because of the World Trade Center disaster. The information technology costs of recovery and relocation after the attacks will be $15.8 billion over three years or more, predicts Computer Economics, a research firm.
But those added sales of hardware, software and services for local recovery, industry analysts say, will be dwarfed by the decline in the fortunes of the industry as a whole as the economy slows further. "The business disruption and the hit to consumer confidence overshadow everything else," said John Gantz, director of research for the International Data Corporation.
Sales of hardware, like mainframes and personal computers, will be hit hardest, Mr. Gantz said, while software and especially services should be more resilient.
The current quarter, ending Sept. 30, will be a rough one. Typically, corporate customers wait until the last few weeks of a quarter to make decisions about large computer and software purchases -- decisions that in many cases have been reversed in the last two weeks.
Technology companies have already begun warning that sales and earnings will probably slide. The Oracle Corporation, a leading supplier of corporate database software, cautioned securities analysts last Monday about the worsening outlook. Before the terrorist attacks, Oracle executives believed that the weakness in technology spending had probably bottomed out.
"But now, everything is a wild card," said Jeff Henley, Oracle's chief financial officer. "We have no idea of how negative things will be in sectors like airlines and hotels."
The EMC Corporation, a major supplier of data storage equipment, warned on Thursday that it would lay off 2,000 workers, or 10 percent of its payroll, and report a loss for the third quarter. "The business world is simply covered in a blanket of hesitation," said Joseph M. Tucci, EMC's president. 
Until the attack, the hopes of the ailing personal computer industry were pinned on the arrival of Microsoft's new Windows XP operating system in October. In the past, when the Microsoft Corporation has introduced a major upgrade of its Windows operating system, the industry standard, the result has been a surge in demand for new personal computers, peripheral equipment and other software.
But now, with consumer confidence shaken, any rebound in PC sales is in doubt, according to Rob Enderle, an analyst at the Giga Information Group, who says that the PC industry may not recover until 2003.
Microsoft, however, intends to spend heavily to prove the pessimists wrong. Windows XP will be introduced on Oct. 25, as scheduled, backed by a $250 million marketing campaign. "Not only the PC industry but the whole country is looking forward to anything that can help jump-start the nation's economy," said James Cullinan, the lead product manager for Windows XP.
With many people skittish about traveling, there are cancellations and delays for computer conferences, at least for those scheduled for the next few weeks. The Internet World conference at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York, for example, has been moved from early October to early December.
The biggest American computer conference, the Comdex trade show in Las Vegas, is going ahead as planned in mid-November. Kim Myhre, Comdex's president, says his six keynote speakers -- including Bill Gates, the chairman of Microsoft, and Lawrence J. Ellison, the chief executive of Oracle -- all still planned to come.
Security will probably be tighter and the crowds may be somewhat smaller at Comdex, typically attended by 200,000 people, Mr. Myhre said. "Travel is a huge issue," he said, "and so much depends on what happens in the wider world in the next two months."
Indeed, for the industry, as for the economy itself, so much depends on what political and military -- and possibly terrorist -- events lie ahead.
What does seem certain, though, is that priorities will shift somewhat. A larger share of the information technology budgets will be spent on backup storage, recovery services and decentralized operations.
"One lesson," said Howard Anderson, senior managing director of YankeeTek Ventures, a technology investment firm, "was that the more centralized you are, the more vulnerable you are." 
The same thinking lay behind the disaster preparation for the Year 2000, or Y2K, software problem. The investments made to handle that problem helped explain why so many of the banks and brokerage firms housed in or near the World Trade Center were able to get up and running again within a few days from other locations. 
Yet recovery plans are likely to be redefined. Such plans have usually focused on computers and software. "But now it's going to be about people and getting the information and knowledge that's in their craniums onto the corporate network," said Gary Beach, publisher of CIO Magazine, a trade journal.
In conversations over the last few days, Mr. Beach said, technology executives at companies have told him that they increasingly want to insure that critical business information is housed not just in employees' heads, but also, as much as possible, in corporate databases. That sentiment will probably heighten interest in a field called knowledge management, which combines tools like e-mail search programs, collaboration software and data-mining technology.
Spending seems certain to increase on computer security and encryption software. Some experts have long warned that the large computer networks that handle things like banking transactions and airline traffic are susceptible to attacks by technically adept terrorists, and those fears are now heightened. Other niches of the industry could also benefit. The use of videoconferencing technology could grow, for example, if companies curb business travel permanently and seek an alternative.
In a way, the attacks confirmed the wisdom of the Internet's architects, who designed a decentralized system that could withstand nuclear attacks.
A Silicon Valley executive, Eric E. Schmidt, chairman of Google Inc., a Web search service, was in New York on Sept. 11, and he noticed that text messages sent over the Internet to wireless BlackBerry hand-held devices, which send and receive e-mail, had arrived in the attacks' immediate aftermath, while cellphone service had been sporadic. 
"This was about as close as you get to a nuclear attack," Mr. Schmidt said, "and the Internet withstood the test."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE JOURNALISTS; 
Terror Experts Use Lenses of Their Specialties

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

 BODY:
Since Sept. 11, the words "terrorism expert" have been used to describe about three dozen academics, diplomats, former military officers and intelligence officers who have appeared on television news programs or been quoted in print.
 What the two tidy words do not express is the unruly collection of disciplines and political and commercial interests that has been the primary source for journalists covering terrorists. After every terrorist incident, some professors and soldiers, spies and diplomats, security experts and political partisans put out reams of fact and conjecture. 
 Early reports can be strikingly accurate. But as one expert, Brian Jenkins of the RAND Corporation, who has studied terrorism since the early 1970's, said, "There's an awful lot that comes out after an incident part in the early days that is unconfirmed, rumors, just misinformation." 
"When you're on the inside looking at it come out," he said, "you say, 'How did anyone get that idea?' " 
The job of sorting out what is known from what is believed or wished, and then trying to make sense of events to an often-bewildered audience falls to a small cadre of journalists who make terrorism their beat. Right now, they are at the core of what may be the most important story of their careers. They can illuminate why it happened, who the country will fight and what Americans need fear.
Like their sources, they arrived at this hybrid beat through many doors. Through experience covering the Middle East and Iran, like Robin Wright of The Los Angeles Times and Judith Miller of The New York Times. Through the police beat, like John Miller of ABC News, who spent years covering the mafia for New York television stations. Through personal interests, like Peter Bergen of CNN, who has been fascinated with Afghanistan since he was a teenager. Through intelligence coverage, like Vernon Loeb of The Washington Post.
Beyond news organizations in the United States, there is the BBC in Britain, which has cultivated knowledge on terrorist movements. Al-Quds al-Arabi, a London-based Arabic newspaper, and Ha'aretz in Israel have also made such coverage routine. Rahimullah Yusufzai of The News of Pakistan, a part-time correspondent for ABC, the BBC and Time, covers Afghanistan -- whose Taliban government has sheltered Osama bin Laden -- as a local story.
And Al Jazeera, a five-year-old, state-financed satellite news station in Qatar that provides CNN-type coverage, has been the first port of call for opponents of the governments in Saudi Arabia, Egypt or Libya, from peaceful dissidents to Mr. bin Laden. Bin Laden representatives sent Al Jazeera his denial of responsibility for the New York terror -- not to mention a videotape of him at his son's wedding last year.
Information about terrorists, Mr. Jenkins said, tends to be filtered through different prisms. "The Paul Revere agenda is: 'The terrorists are coming, the terrorists are coming. We've been warning for years. There are cells in this country.' "
He added, "I'm not saying that's wrong," noting the early results of the investigations of the attacks.
In the second place, he said: "There is the 'you ain't seen nothing yet' apocalyptician school. These include the people who have for a number of years been raising the threat of chemical, biological weapons, weapons of mass destruction."
He said, "It is a legitimate concern," but at the moment, in the face of low-technology attacks, he sees it as a distraction.
Finally, Mr. Jenkins said, "There is the Osama bin Laden fan club," which makes the chief suspect in the Sept. 11 attack "the James Bondian villain at the center of evil." He added, "I am not letting bin Laden off the hook," but he thinks that the investigation "will find something far more complex than simply bin Laden. We are dealing with a network of relationships."
In contrast to Mr. Jenkins, who emphasizes the chaotic and complex nature of modern terrorism, Steven Emerson sees clear financial and operational patterns from one terrorist incident to the next. He has been one of the most visible experts on television. He is a repository of a vast amount of information -- he says he has fielded 1,000 calls, many from news organizations, since Sept. 11 -- but his analyses make him one of the most controversial highly visible experts. 
In 1994 he produced a widely debated PBS documentary, "Jihad in America." It won him accolades and fury, particularly from Arab-Americans. 
That fury escalated when, immediately after the Oklahoma City bombing in 1995, he told CBNS News, "This was done with the intent to inflict as many casualties as possible. That is a Middle Eastern trait, and something that has been generally not carried out on this soil until we were rudely awakened to it in 1993" -- the year of the first World Trade Center attack. On Saturday, Mr. Emerson said that he was reflecting investigators' first take on that attack. 
In 1996 and 1998 Mr. Emerson told Congress that the United States should expect more terrorist attacks.
But it is not so much his general warnings about American-based terrorists -- which the current investigation bears out -- as his efforts to link individual Muslim scholars or charities to terrorists that have earned him Arab-American enmity. 
Mr. Emerson said, "I'm very antiterrorist. I don't make any bones about it. I don't think the media has done its job in the last five years covering the deception of some of these groups in the United States who feign moderation and still are militant." 
However controversial he is, he is still widely quoted, by USA Today and The New York Times, among others.
Experts have institutional agendas in addition to intellectual ones. Pentagon sources tend to see things through the prism of military action, Israeli intelligence sources through the lens of their domestic terrorism, Saudi sources through the interests of their monarchy, and so on. Closer to home, law enforcement sources tend to view terrorist groups through the prism of organized crime.
ABC's John Miller has a police background and sees close parallels to organized crime. "Though you keep an open mind and realize you are operating in a different terrain," he said, "it still boils down to having a boss, an underboss, a consigliere, captains and crews."
Robin Wright of The Los Angeles Times draws her views from her years abroad. "The last bloc of countries to hold out against democratic reform are in the Islamic and Arab world," she said. "The whole militant Islamic movement emerges out of that. To cover and understand extremism and terrorism, you have to understand the context." She added, "I get real tired of a whole lot of so-called terrorism experts who have never lived in the Middle East and never known a terrorist. They thumbsuck from inside the Beltway."
For reporters who choose to get their information in Washington, however, there is expertise in agencies ranging from the State Department to the National Security Council (and the alumni of both) to the Defense Intelligence Agency. Mr. Miller trusts these sources. But, he warns: "The intelligence community generally favors the individual organization that they've already collected the most information on. It shows they were prepared and informed. If something comes out of left field, that implies that it wasn't on their radar screen."
He added that even if experts had jumped to conclusions right after the attack, "So far it doesn't seem that any of their conclusions were baseless." By contrast, journalists and law enforcement officials investigating the loss of T.W.A. Flight 800, devoted resources primarily to checking the likelihood of a terrorist bombing, and paid less attention to the possibility of a catastrophic structural failure -- the eventual explanation.
Sometimes, the experts depend on the journalists as much as the journalists depend on them. A good deal of the public information on Mr. bin Laden comes from the journalists who went to Afganistan to interview him, including Mr. Bergen and his former CNN colleague, Peter Arnett; Mr. Miller; Mr. Yusufzai, of Time Magazine; and Jamal Ismail, of Al Jazeera.
How does one make contact with terrorist networks? "It's complicated," Mr. Bergen said. "You have to meet the right people and do a lot of hanging out. You're in Kabul, Jalalabad, Kandahar. And you have to have met the right people previously, to make anything happen." Journalists and terrorist go-betweens spend weeks trying to ensure that they are not being duped.
Mr. Jenkins cautioned that journalists are trained to make sense of events and create a narrative. That imperative, he warns, could be inadvertently misleading. "Journalists tell coherent stories," he said. "Reality is far less coherent. In the interest of a coherent story, they may tell the wrong story."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE STRATEGY; 
U.S. Seeks Afghan Coalition Against Taliban

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 

 BODY:
The Bush administration is backing efforts to build an internal coalition in Afghanistan against Osama bin Laden and his Taliban supporters. Such a coalition could collect crucial intelligence, provide political support and cooperate militarily in the war on terrorism.
 The United States has stepped up contacts with the Northern Alliance, a coalition also known as the United Front, which has been fighting the Taliban. Officials said there were plans for the United States to provide it with financial support. 
 The group controls only a sliver of territory in northern Afghanistan, and it suffered a grievous setback when its military leader was assassinated, just days before the attacks in the United States on Sept. 11. But it has fought back by carrying out an attack in Kabul and stepping up other operations in the north. 
Recognizing the complex ethnic mix of Afghanistan, the United States has also initiated contacts with the Pashtuns, the dominant tribe in the south.
There has been enormous attention given to the need to build an external coalition involving nations like Britain, Saudi Arabia, Pakistan and others in the region. This external coalition is important. Britain, for instance, is expected to join the military operation.
Forging an internal coalition of ethnic groups that could increase pressure on the Taliban government is just as crucial, though the effort to meld together different tribes and factions in a country that has long been at war could be very complex. 
One reason for the effort is military. The United States needs allies inside Afghanistan who can help track Mr. bin Laden and those Taliban leaders who harbor him, and can provide information on possible attack targets, as well as a possible base of operations in the country for American forces. They could also do some of the fighting. 
There are key political reasons as well to build a coalition inside Afghanistan. The administration is trying to counter the impression that the fight against Mr. bin Laden is a war against Afghanistan or Islam. 
A plan for bringing stability to Afghanistan is also needed to attract help for the United States military campaign. To encourage that cooperation, Washington wants to offer the groups a role in governing Afghanistan after the conflict. A plan for bringing stability for the nation is also important to persuade Pakistan and other neighbors to cooperate. The last thing Washington wants is a chaotic situation that creates a haven for terrorists and destabilizes the neighboring countries. 
Today, Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld indicated that the United States was trying to encourage defections within Taliban ranks, and that those people could be part of a new governing structure for Afghanistan.
"Some of the Taliban say, 'Well, it could get uncomfortable supporting those people, so I think I'll shift sides,' " Mr. Rumsfeld said today.
Efforts to form a grand coalition involve the 86-year-old former king of Afghanistan, Mohammad Zahir Shah, who lives in Rome. The exiled king is a Durrani Pashtun, like the Taliban leaders. The thinking is that he could serve as the symbolic head of a broad group that would include other Afghans who are not Pashtuns. 
Mostapha Zahir, the 37-year-old grandson of the king, said in a telephone interview from Rome that the king was willing to serve as a rallying point for the Afghans but had no intention of trying to re-establish the monarchy. 
He said the king planned to meet in Rome this week with commanders from the Northern Alliance and other groups. 
There are, however, many obstacles to the effort to form a grand coalition, including tensions among the ethnic groups. Dr. Abdullah Abdullah, foreign minister of the Northern Alliance, recently blamed Pakistan for regional instability. Pakistan has close ties to the Pashtun tribes that would supposedly be in the grand coalition. 
John Moore, who until last year was the chief Middle East analyst at the Defense Intelligence Agency, said: "People have talked about this as a great alliance, but that's going to be subject to fractious politics. This is not going to be an easy or quick process."
Influential lawmakers here have been briefed on the administration's emerging strategy to encourage the creation of a pan-Afghan coalition to combat the Taliban government. 
"It could be very useful if it can hold together," said Senator Carl Levin, a Michigan Democrat who heads the Armed Services Committee. "In the past, there have been such differences among the groups, it's been difficult. It'll take a special effort, and I'm glad the administration is looking at it."
Washington's efforts to encourage an anti-Taliban coalition are coming in the midst of continuing military preparations. Administration officials said a C.I.A. reconnaissance drone had crashed in Afghanistan. The Taliban claimed on Saturday that they had shot it down, but American officials said the unmanned aircraft was gathering intelligence and might simply have crashed. 
The Northern Alliance, one of the anti-Taliban groups, is dominated by Tajiks and Uzbeks, and has 10,000 to 15,000 fighters. It draws financial support from Iran and weapons from Russia. It lost its military leader, Ahmed Shad Massoud, when two suicide assassins, posing as journalists, set off a bomb in his presence. He died of the wounds several days later. 
American intelligence officials now say the attack on Mr. Massoud was orchestrated by Mr. bin Laden. The aim was to decapitate the leadership of the primary anti-Taliban resistance, they say, therefore depriving the Bush administration of a potential ally in any retaliation.
Dr. Abdullah and the Northern Alliance's new military chief, Muhammad Fahim, also met in the Tajik capital, Dushanbe, with the head of the Russian general staff, Gen. Anatoly Kvashnin. 
As for relations with the Americans, Muhammad Eshaq, the Washington representative of the Northern Alliance, said there had been intense contacts with the Bush administration. The administration plans to offer financial assistance, officials say, but Mr. Eshaq said it had not yet done so. 
Nonetheless, the Pentagon seems to be counting on the Northern Alliance's help. Mr. Rumsfeld has talked openly about a military collaboration with the alliance. 
"These folks, they know the lay of the land," Mr. Rumsfeld said on Friday, referring to the Northern Alliance. "They know, in some cases, some targets that are useful; they have ideas about how to deal with the Taliban. I think that one has to say that they can be useful in a variety of ways."
There was concern in the administration that Mr. Rumsfeld's comments could complicate Washington's dealings with other factions, including the dominant Pashtun group, which has close ties to Pakistan. So today Mr. Rumsfeld made the point that opponents of Mr. bin Laden might also include "tribes in the south."
A coalition would help the United States balance the interests of its outside partners. The Iranians and Russians, for instance, are supporting the Northern Alliance. The Iranians also have ties to the Hazaras, another minority. 
"There is a coalition dimension to this, so we want to make clear that we are working with several groups," a United States official said. "We are not only reaching out to the Pashtun leaders; there are tribes and leaders reaching out to us."
A final reason for the administration's attempts to forge relations with disparate groups inside Afghanistan is its desire to portray the impending military campaign as a fight against terrorism, and not against the Afghan people or against Islam. It is not only a public relations consideration, but also a factor in picking targets and devising the war plan. 
"It is important to avoid actions at all cost that will unify the Afghans in support of bin Laden and against a foreign invader," said Karl F. Inderfurth, who was the senior State Department official responsible for South Asia in the Clinton administration.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ENERGY MARKET; 
Military Plans Must Ensure Oil Flow

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE 

 BODY:
Oil, long among the abiding interests of the United States in the Middle East, will unavoidably help to shape the Bush administration's planning of the war on terrorism, according to experts on the industry and the region.
 Some analysts consider it almost unseemly to bring up such matters when deliberating on a response to the killing of thousands of Americans. But the reality, they acknowledge, is that the White House is already analyzing how various forms of retribution for the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks could affect American oil supplies. 
 In the short run, it looks as if supplies are safe. In the immediate wake of the attacks, leading oil nations like Saudi Arabia and Kuwait gave assurances that the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries would keep output stable. 
Ultimately, though, a great deal hinges on how the American retaliation unfolds. Arab allies of the United States are themselves eager to uproot terrorist networks, like the one run by Osama bin Laden, because they have long feared that such groups could topple their governments.
Yet if they align themselves too closely with the antiterrorist efforts and Washington unleashes a wide campaign that hits many Islamic countries, moderate Arab governments could be destabilized by uprisings.
"If the United States wants a broad coalition of allies, it needs to have a narrow list of targets," said Raad Alkadiri, a Middle East specialist at the Petroleum Finance Company, a consulting firm in Washington. "If they have a broad list of targets, they will have a narrow list of allies. That's exactly what the administration is wrestling with now."
In the run-up to an OPEC meeting on Wednesday in Vienna, analysts said, the United States let the cartel know that it would like output to rise so that prices would fall in the face of recession. But OPEC fears that this could cause a price crash by supplying more oil as the demand for it drops.
Most analysts think that Saudi Arabia, OPEC's de facto leader, and others will assure the United States behind closed doors that they will do what is necessary, informally, to keep prices on the low side. Oil for November delivery ended trading in New York on Friday at $25.97 a barrel.
The United States has become so widely disliked in Arab countries in the Middle East that governments there risk credibility with their own people by aligning too closely with it. American might and wealth, when compared with the political weakness and poverty of much of the Islamic world, has kindled some of that resentment, a range of diplomats and analysts said. Yet more than anything, they said, Arabs are frustrated with American policy in the Middle East -- in particular what they consider the unquestioning support for Israel in the Palestinian uprising. 
And many Arabs blame the American thirst for oil for miring them in shaky economies run by corrupt leaders.
"The resentment grows when people see democracy is fine, dissent is fine in the United States, but is denied people in the Middle East," said Hanny Megally, executive director of the Middle East and North Africa division of Human Rights Watch.
For now, the United States appears likely to focus on targets in Afghanistan as the Bush administration works to determine what the next steps might be.
Asked whether the administration was considering how any retribution might affect oil supplies, a spokeswoman for the Energy Department directed questions to the State Department. Representatives there did not return calls seeking comment.
But oil industry analysts who have spoken to administration officials said that the United States and the Persian Gulf nations had agreed that as many tankers as possible must soon sail with Middle East oil for the markets to be convinced that OPEC assurances were sincere. So far, that appears to have happened, the analysts said. 
If Washington indeed opts for a wide-ranging response to the terrorist attacks, hardly anyone expects Arab nations to embargo their oil exports, as they did in 1973, in response to American support of Israel in the Middle East war. A decade of low oil prices -- and the producing countries' overspending -- have made oil revenue critical to their budgets. 
A full-scale bombing of Iraq could remove two million barrels a day of oil from the global market. In the past, Saudi Arabia and other gulf nations have made up for interruptions of the flow of Iraqi oil, and they might do so again. But they also might have to back away from open support of the United States.
Iraqis have lived under economic sanctions for a decade, and many Muslims think that Iraq has suffered enough, Middle East experts said. 
The Bush administration has indicated that it might use the existing American military presence in Saudi Arabia as part of any attacks. But those units, there since the end of the gulf war in 1991 and financed in great part by a now-struggling Saudi budget, have been considered an affront to the sensibilities of many Muslims and to national sovereignty by many Saudi citizens, diplomats and analysts said. The Bush administration must take pains to consult with the Saudi government about how American troops on its soil will be used, analysts said. 
"The Saudi monarchy is already considered an enemy by those we might be bombing," said Charles W. Freeman Jr., ambassador to Saudi Arabia during the gulf war, "so we should consult them if we will be placing them in jeopardy."
An unintended consequence of wide-ranging American attacks on Islamic countries could be that through popular uprisings, copycats of the radical Taliban leaders in Afghanistan could rise to power in the gulf region, where two-thirds of the world's known oil reserves are concentrated. 
"We have a dual interest here," said Bill Richardson, energy secretary in the Clinton administration. "We must have a significant impact on bin Laden's network, and we have to preserve the stability of regimes like Saudi Arabia, which is our principal national security and energy ally in the region."

HEADLINE: Penguin Putnam Chief Plans to Step Down 

BYLINE:  By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK 

 BODY:
Phyllis Grann, one of the most commercially successful editors and publishers in the book business, is leaving her position as chief executive and president of the Penguin Putnam books division of the media company Pearson at the end of the year, people close to the company said.
 Over four decades in book industry, Ms. Grann's nose for page turners has built her a reputation as the queen of the best-seller list. The long roster of best-selling authors she has published includes Tom Clancy, Patricia Cornwall, Dick Francis, Robin Cook, Nora Roberts, John Sandford, Steve Martini, A. Scott Berg and Amy Tan. Last year, more than 106 of the companies books appeared on the New York Times best-seller list. 
 Ms. Grann was among the first in the industry to champion a strategy of heavy marketing and promotion to help books stand out in the ever-expanding sea of bookshelf space at superstores, general merchandise discounters and eventually online retailers. She emphasized publishing a smaller number of titles with more marketing support than other publishers had. She often signed contracts with authors for several books at once, and many became best sellers.
Her departure from Penguin Putnam is expected to set off a flurry of activity around the book publishing industry as other publishers try to lure away the house's top authors. People at the company, however, said her successor will come from inside.
Marilyn Ducksworth, a spokeswoman for Penguin Putnam, also declined to comment. 
The reasons for Ms. Grann's departure were unclear. Pearson, which is based in London, also owns The Financial Times of London, The Economist, a large educational publishing division and some Internet operations. Marjorie Scardino, who was named chief executive of Pearson in 1997, has been under pressure from investors to improve profitability. Its shares have fallen more than 75 percent from their peak in March 2000. Consumer book publishing, however, is among the most profitable parts of the company.
Last year, Pearson acquired Dorling Kindersley, a publisher of illustrated and children's books, for about $435 million, and in May 2001, Ms. Scardino named John Makinson, Pearson's chief financial officer, as chairman of its Penguin Group, the worldwide consumer books division, which includes Penguin Putnam in the United States. Mr. Makinson was charged with continuing the integration of Pearson's book publishing operations with the recently acquired Dorling Kindersley as well as integrating the Putnam Group more closely with its British parent. 
Ms. Grann started her career in August 1958, in the mailroom at Doubleday, eventually becoming the secretary to William Morrow's president, Lawrence Hughes. Mr. Hughes encouraged her to become an editor. In 1970, she was hired to edit mysteries at Simon & Schuster and later ran its Pocket Books paperbacks division. In 1976, she was hired as editor in chief of the G.P. Putnam division of Putnam Berkeley. In 1987, she became chief executive of Putnam Berkeley, then owned by the entertainment company MCA. 
Pearson's Penguin Group acquired Putnam Berkeley from MCA, then part of Seagram, in 1996. After the acquisition, she exerted so much influence that some Penguin editors said their company was "putnamized."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Chief at Penguin Putnam Is Planning to Step Down
Phyllis Grann, one of the most commercially successful editors and publishers in the book business, is stepping down as chief executive and president of the Penguin Putnam books division of Pearson, the media company, people close the company said.
 Over four decades, Ms. Grann's nose for page turners has built her a reputation as the queen of the best-seller list. She was among the first in the industry to champion a strategy emphasizing heavy marketing and promotion to help books stand out. Page C2. 

Deutsche Bank to Acquire Scudder
Deutsche Bank has agreed to buy Scudder Investments, the United States asset management unit of Zurich Financial Services, for about $2.5 billion in cash and assets, executives involved in the discussions said. Deutsche Bank will pay $1.2 billion in cash for Scudder and give Zurich its 75.9 percent stake in an insurance business. A10.

A Test for U.S. Communications
So far, the reviews are mixed on how the publicly available communications networks performed during the terrorist attacks. And there are lessons that the public, communications executives and policy makers should learn. The star performers were online: e-mail, instant messaging and bulletin boards. But Internet news sites and the wired and wireless telephone networks could stand improvement. And it is clear that there need to be new ways to set up emergency information systems. New Economy. C4.

Forecast Lowered for Tech Spending
Even before the terrorist attacks, information technology spending, which grew 11 percent last year, was slowing. Now projections are being trimmed further, down to 3 percent growth, according to estimates by the International Data Corporation. C5.

Oil Will Play Big Role in Response
Oil, long among the abiding interests of the United States in the Middle East, will unavoidably help to shape the Bush administration's planning of the war on terrorism, according to experts on the industry and the region. C11.

Travel Web Sites Brace for a Slump
Before the attacks, online travel agencies were among the few e-commerce companies that had achieved profitability. Now, online travel executives are wondering whether their industry can remain the standard-bearer for e-commerce or, for that matter, whether most Web travel companies can even remain in business. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C8.

Emphasis on Hard News Returns
In the aftermath of the attacks, news executives who had talked about veering toward softer subjects sound as if the events of Sept. 11 had shaken them from a daze in which their focus was lost. Hard news, even foreign news, is back in vogue. C10.

An End, or an Extension, to Irony
In the magazine business, naming a new cultural moment or the latest turn in popular taste is how reputations are made. The most common pronouncements after the attacks have been that an epoch defined by irony and cynicism has finally come to an end. The most prominent early prognosticator was Graydon Carter, editor in chief of Vanity Fair. Others, however, say the return to the business of making such pronouncements itself suggests, ironically, that the city's media business might not have changed so much after all. C9.

Advertising Forecasts Are Lowered
The deterioration of the outlook for the economy after the attacks is leading advertising analysts to reassess their estimates for ad spending this year and next. In almost every case, they are predicting no growth or steeper cuts. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C12.

No Cable Decision Made at AT&T
At its annual strategic review, AT&T's board discussed at least five options for spinning off or selling the company's cable television unit but did not approve a specific plan, people close to the board said over the weekend. C2.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED; 
A Snapshot Gives Bush 90% Approval

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 23 

 BODY:
Ninety percent of Americans approve of the way President Bush is handling his job after the Sept. 11 terror attacks, the highest rating for a president ever recorded by the Gallup polling group, USA Today and CNN reported today.
 The 90 percent rating, measured in a poll of 1,005 adults on Friday and Saturday, outranks the previous record, a rating of 89 percent garnered by Mr. 
Bush's father, former President George Bush, at the end of the Persian Gulf War in 1991. 
 The current poll had a margin of sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points, so the difference between the two approval ratings is statistically insignificant. 
 The younger Bush had an 86 percent rating in a survey conducted last week, just after terrorists slammed hijacked airplanes into the twin towers of the World Trade Center in Manhattan and into the Pentagon, outside Washington, leaving an estimated 6,800 people dead or missing. A fourth hijacked plane crashed in Pennsylvania.
President Bush ended the official mourning period today, presiding over a ceremony to hoist the American flag to full staff for the first time since the attacks.
The Gallup organization said the poll showed the highest presidential approval rating in the six decades it has been posing the question to Americans.

HEADLINE: In America; 
Leading America Beyond Fear

BYLINE:  By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The past several days have been, despite the agony, among America's finest. New York's remarkable response to the catastrophic attack at the World Trade Center has been well documented. But also, above the tragic din, at the very highest levels of government, have come the essential voices of sanity.
 Americans turned on their televisions last Thursday night and watched as George W. Bush, in the nation's hour of need, delivered a near-perfect speech. With the obscene toll of those lost in downtown Manhattan climbing above 6,000, and with hysterical rumors circulating about imminent additional attacks, Mr. Bush went before a joint meeting of Congress and somehow got things exactly right. 
 He dispensed with the cowboy-in-the-saloon rhetoric. There was no bombast in the speech, no cries of wanted dead or alive, just a perfectly modulated sense of absolute resolve.
"After all that has just passed," he said, "all the lives taken and all the possibilities and hopes that died with them, it is natural to wonder if America's future is one of fear. Some speak of an age of terror. I know there are struggles ahead and dangers to face.
"But this country will define our times, not be defined by them. As long as the United States of America is determined and strong, this will not be an age of terror. This will be an age of liberty here and across the world."
For Mr. Bush, who seldom wanders into the precincts of eloquence, it was a splendid moment. He expressed the collective anger of the nation, declared that the U.S. would mount a sustained global assault against terrorism, and bolstered the sense of national unity that flowered in the aftermath of the attack.
And he did that while assuring the world that it is not the Muslim people who are the enemies of America, but the terrorists who have perverted the tenets of a proud religion, and also the regimes that give them sanctuary.
That tone was maintained yesterday by Secretary of State Colin Powell during an interview on "Meet the Press." Choosing his words carefully in a volatile atmosphere that included serious talk about the possibility of a world war, Mr. Powell said: "Let's not assume there will be a large-scale war. I don't know that we should even consider a large-scale war of the conventional type."
It was important, said Mr. Powell, to follow the president's lead. "The objective that the president has focused on in this first instance is Al Qaeda, Osama bin Laden and his presence in Afghanistan. And then we will consider all other options and all other sources of terrorist activity and go after it in an appropriate way."
Common sense should tell you it would not be wise in the coming weeks to be hanging out with the Taliban. But Mr. Bush and Mr. Powell have also made it abundantly clear that the U.S. will not be able to bomb the terrorists into submission. The president was wise to ask for patience as more complex responses are fashioned. Provoking a wide and futile war would be as insane as the attack on the trade center.
The president and the secretary of state have shown, so far, that the United States is as shrewd and intelligent as it is powerful. A successful fight against terrorism will require international cooperation and the continued unity of the American people. Neither of those elements can be maintained if the U.S. is seen as waging war on innocents abroad.
If it turns out that we are to engage in a large-scale war, then the nation is being prepared in an odd way. Toward the end of yesterday's interview, Secretary Powell said: "We've got to get back to work. We've got to get back to our ballgames. We've got to get back to our theaters. We've got to get this economy moving again. And that will be the best answer to what happened."
The citizens of a nation on the verge of a major global conflict are not generally counseled to run out and pick up theater tickets. The campaign against terrorism will be ugly, brutish and by no means short. But such a campaign is a far cry from a world at war.
Targeting terrorists rather than innocents will be the key to success as the U.S. and its allies respond to the savage events of Sept. 11. If that is done well, a wider war can be avoided and Americans may have reason to hope that the worst is actually behind them.

HEADLINE: Primary Candidates Urge Voters to Turn Out as an Act of Defiance 

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Two days before the rescheduled New York City primaries, some of the mayoral candidates invoked the World Trade Center disaster in their campaigns yesterday, asserting they had skills that made them particularly well suited to lead the city through this crisis. They urged New Yorkers to defy the terrorist attack by turning out to vote tomorrow.
 Michael R. Bloomberg, a Republican making his first run for any public office, said his experience creating and running a private company made him a "mayor for tough times." His Republican opponent, Herman Badillo, noted his long experience as a member of Congress and in City Hall, saying, "This is not the time for on-the-job training." 
 Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker, said in a televised address that he had been, with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, at the center of efforts over the past 12 days to help the city respond to the bombing. Fernando Ferrer, another Democrat, compared the devastation in Lower Manhattan to what he found in the Bronx when he took over as borough president 14 years ago, suggesting that his years in the Bronx had prepared him for what he might face as mayor. 
Alan G. Hevesi, a Democrat, said that his skills as city comptroller made him particularly qualified to lead City Hall through difficult budgetary times. And Mark Green, the fourth major Democrat, noted that one of his central campaign themes before Sept. 11 had been unifying New York; he argued that his theme was particularly crucial now.
The remarks came in a day of interviews and speeches on three New York City television stations, starting at 6:30 a.m., which were entirely devoted to a discussion of how the candidates now viewed the job of mayor given the way the city had been changed. 
In interviews on WCBS and WABC, and in prepared statements delivered on WNBC, the candidates offered a variety of proposals for what City Hall should do. They also made an effort to make sure that voters were aware that the primary -- which was originally supposed to be held on Sept. 11, the day of the attack -- was going ahead tomorrow.
Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Vallone both said they would want Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani to head a rebuilding authority to oversee the reconstruction of Lower Manhattan. Mr. Badillo said he would give Mr. Giuliani any position he wanted in his administration, but would like to see him be in charge of overseeing security programs intended to assure the safety of New Yorkers.
Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Vallone said that the city should give subsidies to Broadway theaters and possibly hotels to help them survive what promises to be a difficult stretch ahead, given the downturn in tourism.
Mr. Vallone, Mr. Badillo and Mr. Hevesi all said that the city should, despite the impending huge reconstruction projects ahead, press ahead with its application to bring the summer Olympics to New York in 2012. Mr. Badillo and Mr. Vallone went further, telling Marcia Kramer on WCBS-TV that other cities that had been bidding for the Olympics should step aside to permit New York City to hold it, as a patriotic gesture that would improve both the economy and the spirits of this city.
Mr. Green said he supported the idea of pursuing the Olympics, but only "were I persuaded that the public funding would be modest and the private funding would be substantial." Mr. Ferrer was particularly skeptical of the idea of holding the Olympics.
More than almost anything, the candidates talked about the need for New Yorkers to turn out tomorrow, reflecting concern that Democrats and Republicans are either unaware that the primary has been rescheduled or are too distracted to turn out.
"We must vote," Mr. Bloomberg said in a televised address on WNBC. "Think of it as lighting a candle for the 6,000 missing."
And at an appearance at the Abyssinian Baptist Church yesterday morning, Mr. Green said: "It's awkward, diverting, but essential that we have an election on Tuesday."
He added, "Whomever you vote for, America wins. If we stay as one people, black, white, Christian, Jew, Muslim, we will again rise from the ashes and continue to be in this new century a city of hope."
The candidates have been severely restricted in their ability to campaign since the attack. For one thing, they are concerned about appearing political during such a tough time. In addition, the city's Campaign Finance Board essentially froze the campaign in place on Sept. 11, ruling that the candidates could not spend any more money, other than to get out the vote.
The primary is being restaged. Votes that were cast before the polls closed on Sept. 11 will not count, so New Yorkers who voted on that day will need to return on Tuesday if they want to participate. Absentee ballots cast before Sept. 11 will count toward the result. In addition, New Yorkers who live in parts of Manhattan where the polling places were destroyed can pick up absentee ballots at the Board of Elections today.
As memories of the attack grew further away and the primary grew closer, there were signs of exchanges among the candidates, if indirect ones. Mr. Green disputed a suggestion by Mr. Ferrer that New York, in rebuilding, scatter office buildings across the city.
"The financial services center was centralized in Lower Manhattan," Mr. Green said. "That is the heart of financial services and American business."
And Mr. Badillo took indirect note of Democrats who had been critical of the Police Department, saying: "It's not time for people who have been bashing the uniformed services."
All the candidates acknowledged that their vision of what they would do as mayor had been changed by the attack.
Mr. Hevesi said that his call for raising teacher salaries would have to be slowed down. And he noted that "we'll have to rethink how we build an affordable housing program," given that most of the candidates had planned to use revenues from leasing the World Trade Center to pay for housing.
He also said that the city would need to invest in new tourist advertisement programs to revive the tourism industry.
Mr. Vallone appeared to step back from his commitment to spare the Parks Department from any cuts, though he stressed the importance of city recreation programs, particularly now. 
Mr. Bloomberg argued strongly against raising taxes to help the city through this period. Mr. Green said he thought a tax increase would be unnecessary because "I am hopeful that Washington and the state, with generous gifts and bonding authority, will help us."
But mostly, yesterday was a day in which the candidates struggled to figure out how to adapt what had been their earlier campaign themes to this very new political environment.
Mr. Vallone asserted that he had played a crucial role in City Hall's response to the attack.
"Let me take this opportunity to report briefly to you on what I have been doing," he said in his televised address. He added: "I have been doing my job, which is to govern. I've been working closely with the mayor and the City Council and emergency officials, striving to put the city we love on the road to reconstruction and renewal."
Mr. Bloomberg said: "I am a business leader with experience in both good and bad economic times, in creating jobs, in crisis management, in managing thousands of people worldwide, in dealing with billion-dollar budgets, and conflicting priorities. That is why my experience is right for now." 
And Mr. Ferrer, asked how he would deal with the crisis, responded: "I faced some of these problems when I walked into my office 14 years ago as borough president -- albeit on a far smaller scale, nothing of this dimension."
Finally, the candidates offered some tough words directed at the terrorists. "We will show the world," Mr. Bloomberg said on WNBC. "We will cower to no one! This is America and we are New York!" (The exclamation points were included in the text of his remarks issued by his office).
Mr. Vallone, speaking animatedly to Ms. Kramer, said: "We're going to show these characters they picked the wrong city in the wrong time in the wrong place, and we're going to get back at them in a way they'll never understand."

HEADLINE: The Right Time for Talking 

 BODY:
Over the weekend, New York City voters finally had the opportunity to reassess the candidates for mayor in tomorrow's primaries. At televised public appearances, the contenders attempted to explain how they would govern a city that is so different from the one that existed before the original Election Day, Sept. 11. Their comments demonstrated how important it is now to take a second look at the men who want to lead New York. 
 The tasks for our next mayor will be far different from the ones we, or they, envisioned before the attack. Instead of building new housing, his first priority will have to be reconstructing the financial center in Lower Manhattan. While the city's schools still must be improved, there will be less money available for new programs and teacher salaries. The Police Department, under fire and demoralized two weeks ago, is now filled with pride and grief over its lost officers. 
 Some of the candidates seem to have made the transition more successfully than others. Both Public Advocate Mark Green and Comptroller Alan Hevesi outlined thoughtful plans for quickly rebuilding Lower Manhattan, improving security and renewing the city's businesses, infrastructure and services, while adjusting the budget to these new priorities. Mr. Green and Mr. Hevesi have obviously spent some time interviewing experts and studying the ways other cities have responded to catastrophic destruction. As the two men took pains to make clear, they have also done what they could to aid in the recovery operation at the World Trade Center and to comfort the victims' families.
Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, and City Council Speaker Peter Vallone have been less successful so far in demonstrating how to move New York forward. Mr. Ferrer's ideas about Lower Manhattan seemed vague and confusing. Mr. Vallone spent much of the last two weeks at Mr. Giuliani's side, and it would perhaps be unfair to expect him to have come up with as detailed an agenda. But he submitted a hastily conceived plan for a commission to oversee rebuilding that gives the city exclusive control, even though the state and the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey will be crucial players in the process. At a time of stress, it becomes particularly important that the city's leaders take time for reflection before they act. 
Until Sept. 11, the overriding issue in the Republican primary had been public fascination with the wealth and spending of Michael Bloomberg. Now, many Republicans are wondering if they could find a way to keep Mayor Rudolph Giuliani in office, despite term limits. Mr. Giuliani should concentrate on continuing to provide the city with leadership for the rest of his term. The city does not need to be thrown into the chaos that would come with an attempt to somehow change the rules of an election at this late date. 
One point on which all the candidates were right last weekend was the importance of voting in tomorrow's primaries. As many pointed out, that is the best way to honor the fallen and triumph over terrorism.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE REGION; 
End of Sanctions May Ease Pakistanis' Despair Even as the Afghans' Grows Worse

BYLINE:  By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, Sept. 23 

 BODY:
The Bush administration's decision to ease economic sanctions on Pakistan came as a much-needed boost today to Pakistan's government, steadying some of the nervousness that had been mounting since Pakitan's military leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, pledged his backing for American plans for a military thrust into neighboring Afghanistan. 
 President Bush's decision, which also lifted sanctions on India, imposed after both countries tested nuclear weapons in 1998, was announced in Washington on Saturday night. The step was quickly greeted by high-ranking officials here as an early token of the rewards General Musharraf has promised this impoverished nation of 140 million as he seeks support for his commitment to Mr. Bush's plans for a war on international terrorism. 
 "This will be of great assistance to the common man," said Shaukat Aziz, the finance minister, who has wrestled with the burden of a rising foreign debt that has for years kept Pakistan at constant risk of default, as well as unemployment so severe that, by a recent estimate, for every job that becomes available there are 2,000 people awaiting work. 
Mr. Aziz said one effect of Mr. Bush's move would be to help Pakistan gain relief on debts of almost $37 billion, through Washington's influence with international lending agencies like the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. 
But even as the government here held out the prospect of Pakistan's turning the corner on years of deepening social despair, other developments pointed toward the hazards that await Washington as it plans what may be its first war in Asia since Vietnam.
In Afghanistan, reports indicated that the Taliban government that has harbored Osama bin Laden was beginning its own preparations for war, ordering troop reinforcements along the border with Pakistan, building new bunkers and installing antiaircraft batteries. 
The hard-line Islamic clerics who lead the Taliban showed signs, too, of fostering a new wave of hunger and helplessness among Afghanistan's 26 million people, by issuing a decree threatening death to any relief worker caught using a satellite telephone.
The Afghan people, heavily dependent of foreign assistance, have suffered from two decades of unrelenting war and several years of drought. Over the weekend, United Nations officials estimated that fear of American military strikes had propelled more than a million people into a new exodus from cities like Kandahar and Kabul.
The order barring satellite phones appeared to be part of a Taliban hunt for "spies" helping to prepare an American attack, a concern so much on the mind of the movement's leading clerics that they provided an Islamic justification for summary execution of any suspect in a religious decree, or fatwa, that they issued last week. 
The decree specified that "if Muslims, Afghans and non-Afghans, extend cooperation to the infidels during an American attack, or assist them to carry out espionage activities, they will be considered foreign aggressors, and their murder will be an obligation."
At a time when relief supplies inside Afghanistan were already desperately low, it was not clear how, if at all, the relief agencies could continue to coordinate their operations with their supply bases in Pakistan without satellite phones.
Aid efforts have already been on a precarious footing after most agencies withdrew their foreign staff members when the Taliban authorities arrested a group of relief workers, including two Americans, in Kabul in August and accused them of proselytizing for Christianity, an offense that carries the death penalty. They are still being held. 
Some relief agencies saw the Taliban's move barring satellite phones as an attempt to create an even deeper crisis for which the United States could be blamed, further inflaming passions that have been aroused across the Muslim world by the prospect of American strikes.
Nowhere have such sentiments been so closely watched by the United States as in Pakistan, which was chosen as the key partner for the American war plans because of its relatively modern ports, roads and air bases, and because its 1,400-mile frontier with Afghanistan provides a launching platform along the Afghans' eastern and southern borders.
After relentless American pressure for him to cooperate, General Musharraf has begun to breathe easier in recent days as Islamic militant groups failed to draw the vast crowds they had hoped for at protests staged in almost every city and town. Mr. Bush's decision would give him still more maneuvering room. 
Although four people were shot dead by the police at a demonstration in Karachi on Saturday, and Islamic groups have provided local and foreign television networks with vivid footage of American flags and effigies of President Bush being burned, the limited scale of the protests have encouraged the government to hope that it can avoid much wider turmoil as American military planning proceeds. 
Still, it was a measure of how sensitive the political situation here has become that Finance Minister Aziz felt the need to deny accusations by Islamic groups that General Musharraf had betrayed Pakistan by agreeing to help the United States in a war with a neighboring Muslim country, Afghanistan.
"There's no question of a payback," Mr. Aziz said today. Instead, he characterized the American decision as the Bush administration's finally heeding pleas Pakistan had repeatedly made since the sanctions were imposed. 
The first round of sanctions came in 1990, when Washington acted to punish Pakistan for developing nuclear weapons. The second round came after India set off a nuclear blast in 1998, and Pakistan quickly followed suit. 
The finance minister said that one of the most important benefits for Pakistan would be that the Bush administration could now support Pakistan on measures pending before the I.M.F. that had the potential to kick-start the economy here, in particular measures to relieve the foreign debt. 
Immediately after General Musharraf pledged his cooperation to the United States, Pakistan, facing a Sept. 30 deadline for debt repayments, doubled its request for relief, to $5 billion, in the expectation that Washington would push the package through international financial institutions. Officials here said easing the nuclear-related sanctions would also allow Washington to renew some forms of aid, arms sales and export credits. 
The sanctions for the nuclear tests were applied in equal measure to both countries, but because Pakistan's economy is far smaller and weaker than India's, and because the sanctions dropped by President Bush did not include other measures imposed after General Musharraf seized power in a military coup in October 1999, the effects were felt more severely here. That was underscored today when India's finance minister, Yashwant Sinha, greeted the lifting of sanctions as a "good thing," but called the step "a minor issue as far as the Indian economy is concerned." 
Indeed, India's distemper over the growing American cooperation with Pakistan presents another problem to be confronted by the Bush administration. While Pakistan was still hesitating over Washington's demands for cooperation in its war against terrorism, India jumped in with what was billed as an unconditional offer of the use of Indian airspace and air bases. 
In his television address, General Musharraf alluded to that offer, saying that Pakistan, had it refused, might have risked isolation in its confrontation with India over Kashmir, and even an Indian attack on its nuclear installations.
By the end of last week, Indian officials, including Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, had begun to complain that Washington had shunned the Indian offer and sided with Pakistan, which India has accused of being a terrorist state for backing Muslim insurgent groups fighting Indian rule in Kashmir. 
At the same time, other troubles were building inside Afghanistan, as the Taliban sought to further muddy the waters over Mr. bin Laden. Today the Taliban said they had been unable to trace the fugitive to tell him that a meeting of Muslim clerics had urged him to leave the country "of his own free will."
"We still have not been able to deliver the clerics' message to him, because we could not find him," said the spokesman, Abul Hai Mutmaen. 
Asked if the world's most wanted man was still in Afghanistan, he replied: "I cannot say."

HEADLINE: Nations in Pacific Rim Are Supporting Airlines 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Sept. 24 

 BODY:
Threatened by a wholesale grounding of airplanes, governments around the Pacific Rim pledged today to help airlines that are hobbled by soaring insurance rates and sharply reduced coverage for terrorist acts.
 Hong Kong, Singapore, South Korea, Australia and New Zealand all said they would bridge a sudden shortfall in insurance coverage by their air carriers after the terror attacks on New York and Washington. 
 The moves, similar to recent government rescue packages in the United States, Britain and Germany, came hours before the insurance industry said it would limit coverage to $50 million a flight for death, injury and property damage on the ground for crashes, hijackings or other disasters.
That figure is far below the threshold of minimum protection required by most airlines, and it could have grounded planes worldwide on Tuesday. Airports, whose coverage is also threatened, would also have closed. 
Even as Hong Kong announced its aid package, two local carriers, Cathay Pacific Airways and Dragonair, said they had negotiated a new policy with insurers that would allow them to continue flying without public assistance.
Cathay Pacific and Dragonair are the first Asian airlines to obtain new insurance in this turbulent environment. But their executives were not crowing because the high cost of the coverage will almost certainly drive up ticket prices.
"It's very expensive," said Antony Tyler, director of corporate development at Cathay Pacific. "One way or the other, it's going to be reflected in fares. It's too early to say when or how much."
The escalating costs come as passenger traffic, especially to and from the United States, has sharply dropped. Singapore Airlines said its advance reservations to New York and Chicago were off 10 percent. Weak bookings led United Airlines to cancel some flights from Hong Kong to Los Angeles and New York.
"We've got a stronger balance sheet, and we're financially more robust than the American airlines," Mr. Tyler said. "But there's no doubt we're going to be hurt. We're in for very difficult times ahead."
The measures announced today are temporary -- generally lasting six months -- but some analysts said uncertainty over American military retaliation may oblige governments to back their airlines indefinitely.
"If you have a worsening of the situation, it might have to continue," said Jean-Louis Morisot, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs in Singapore. "This situation is as bad as we could possibly have imagined."
Unlike their American peers, most Asian and Pacific carriers have not announced layoffs or widespread cancellations. Mr. Morisot said the absence of such measures here so far was less a reflection of Asia's strength than of its uncertainty about how deep the downturn will be.
Some smaller carriers say they might escape the worst fallout. Philippine Airlines, which was nearly shut down in 1998 and has requested state aid to maintain its insurance, is nevertheless optimistic about its prospects.
"We're hoping that this problem will blow over," the airline's president, Avelino Zapanta, said today in an interview with a Philippine television station. "We have faith in the resilience of Filipino travelers, which make up more than 50 percent of our total traffic."
The lack of obvious distress among Asian airlines has made these rescue efforts more contentious than the $15 billion plan approved by Washington. In Hong Kong, members of the legislature challenged officials about why they were offering aid for six months. Such questions resonate here because the government prides itself on not meddling in the private sector.
Antony Leung, the financial secretary, said the territory had to intervene because the airport was one of the engines of the economy. Hong Kong International Airport is the world's busiest international airport in cargo traffic and No. 5 in passengers. Without the extra help, Mr. Leung said, it would have lost $1.25 billion in insurance coverage against damage to its facilities.
"Many people's jobs would be on the line," he said. "We are facing exceptional times, and we are taking exceptional measures."
Some Hong Kong legislators criticized insurance companies for seeking to capitalize everywhere in the world for a terrorist attack that took place only in the United States. "The insurance industry has hijacked the global economy, and we have to surrender," said Cyd Ho, a member of the legislature.
But Jim Eckes, the managing director of Indoswiss Aviation in Hong Kong, said Asia was a prime target for the kinds of airborne attacks that struck New York and Washington. In 1995, he noted, terrorists were foiled in a plan to place bombs on a dozen American airliners in East Asia.
"Any Asian country with serious political problems faces the possibility of terrorism and suicide hijackings," Mr. Eckes said.

HEADLINE: ARTS IN AMERICA; 
As Tourism Halts in New Orleans, Musicians Play On

BYLINE:  By Stephen Kinzer 

DATELINE: NEW ORLEANS, Sept. 21 

 BODY:
Life has suddenly become hard in the Big Easy, with many restaurants and night clubs empty, hotels losing millions of dollars in canceled reservations, and Bourbon Street stiller than anyone can remember.
 "It is truly a ghost town," said Sharon Litwin, executive director of the Louisiana Philharmonic Orchestra, as she surveyed a hotel lobby where there were more employees than guests. "It's something I've never seen and no one here has ever seen." 
 The orchestra is trying to help people deal with the jumble of emotions that welled up after this month's stunning wave of terror. At its opening night concert, just two days after the attacks on New York and Washington, the program was changed to include the contemplative adagio movement of Beethoven's Symphony No. 9. 
Over the days that followed, members of the orchestra formed small groups to play in lobbies of office buildings. They distributed copies of a statement pledging "to redouble our effort to keep beauty and harmony and music in our beloved community."
Crowds of people stopped to watch and listen. Tears glistened in more than a few eyes.
"When people left our opening night concert, you could see they had shed so much of their weight," Ms. Litwin said. "After that, the musicians decided they wanted to go out into the community to bring the gift of music to stressed-out people."
"For a long time, those of us in the arts community have had to sell arts as an economic engine or a way to bring new business to town or with some other excuse," she continued. "Not this time. I think everyone who heard our musicians this week came away with a deep appreciation for the intrinsic power of music. It did what music is supposed to do: it touched your soul, it soothed, it calmed."
On Thursday night the orchestra traveled to Zephyr Field, a minor league baseball park in Jefferson Parish, a few miles from New Orleans. The musicians played for a crowd of 7,000 people who had just watched President Bush's speech to Congress on a large-screen television in center field.
This time the music was welcome but little more than incidental. As in countless places across the United States, people had come mostly to be with one another. The stadium was awash in American flags, candles and signs reading "God Bless America." Grief, frustration, fear and rage were among the emotions.
Waves of applause washed across the crowd each time a speaker mentioned American soldiers, police officers or firefighters. People also cheered Hasan Krad, a local Muslim leader who teaches at Dillard University, when he asked God to give American leaders "the wisdom to punish only those who are guilty."
In the crowd Wayne Chalona, a biology professor and World War II veteran, said the events of Sept. 11 were "more than you can comprehend."
"Life has changed for America," Mr. Chalona said. "It's never going to be the same again. Terrorists can strike anywhere, anytime."
Many of those at the ballpark were young, ranging from small children dressed in red-white-and-blue smocks to teenagers. "I'm still scared," said Corey Newell, a 16-year-old high school student who was wearing baggy shorts and carrying a candle. "We have to get them before they get to New Orleans. But I don't know if we can."
Behind the last row of seats, Jefferson Parish's president, Tim Coulon, stood with the fire chief, whose badge was covered with a black stripe. Mr. Coulon described the evening's gathering as "a kind of giant funeral, with people mourning and feeling great sorrow and disbelief."
"The secondary goal of the terrorists was to beak our confidence and spirit, and to some extent they've succeeded," he said. "People are feeling a great fear. They want to be assured that this won't happen in Louisiana, but no one can give them that assurance."
Fear has seemingly cast a pall over the streets of New Orleans, which depends as much as any city in the United States on the tourist trade. Thousands of cooks, waiters, chambermaids, bartenders and others whose jobs rely on tourism have been told either not to report for work until further notice or to come less often than before.
The well-regarded restaurant Dominique's is now open three nights a week instead of seven. Others have followed suit.
A convention of the National Business Aviation Association that was to have brought more than 30,000 people here this week was canceled. Hotels that expected occupancy rates over 90 percent found themselves below 10 percent.
Three conventions scheduled for October, expected to attract more than 50,000 people, are to proceed as planned. But as people who serve tourists looked out over deserted streets, they wondered how many people would leave home at such a moment.
"It's dead; it's a desert," said Mohammed Ihmed, a taxi driver who was born in Egypt but has lived in New Orleans for more than a decade. "If this keeps up for a few more weeks, I'm going to look for another job."
Mr. Ihmed, who wears wraparound sunglasses and whose friends here know him as Mo, said he had not faced any threats, curses or other unpleasantness recently because of his Arab background. "Actually, it's been the other way," he said. "People are calling me and saying: 'We know you, we love you, you're our friend. Don't think that anything has changed between us.' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: The audience sang along to patriotic songs at a concert by the Louisiana Philharmonic Orchestra at Zephyr Stadium in Jefferson Parish. (David Rae Morris for The New York Times)
