HEADLINE: Behind the Scenes, Soldiering On; 
For Theater's Supporting Family, a New Kind of Uncertainty

BYLINE:  By ROBIN POGREBIN 

 BODY:
It was when the television at the bar turned from CNN to baseball that Joe Allen knew things were beginning to inch back toward normal. But normalcy is still a long way off for Mr. Allen -- who owns the restaurant that bears his name on West 46th Street, a popular theater hangout -- and the hundreds of other people who make up Broadway's back-office operations, extended family, support system.
 Will the tourists return? Will old shows close? Will new shows come in? The questions affect everyone from the makers of wigs, shoes and marquees to restaurateurs, fight directors, ticket sellers and those who write advertisements or publish programs: all of whom depend for their livelihoods on the Great White Way. 
 Broadway has seen its share of hard times. But veterans say this downturn -- in which ticket sales were off $3 million to $5 million last week, four shows have closed, one show has canceled and warhorses like "Les Miserables" and "Phantom of the Opera" are at risk because they depend on tourists -- is the most dramatic because the duration is so uncertain. 
"In 27 years I've never seen anything like this," said Wayne Sapper, the president of King Displays, a sign and graphics company started in 1938 that specializes in theater marquees.
Mr. Sapper is proceeding with work on the marquees for "The Women," scheduled to start previews on Oct. 12 at the American Airlines Theater, and "Noises Off," due to begin performances on Oct. 16 at the Brooks Atkinson Theater. But he said he was concerned that he would soon have to "paint out," meaning take down signs for shows that prove to be casualties of this crisis.
"I remember when Kennedy was assassinated," Mr. Sapper said. "In three weeks people were back. Even during the gulf war. Theater's always been recession-proof. People didn't have a lot of money to travel, they would come to the theater. Now people are afraid to come out. It's a whole different set of circumstances."
At a time when audiences may have a lower tolerance for watching violence, a theatrical fight director like Rick Sordelet might have reason to worry about the demand for his services. But drama, Mr. Sordelet said, is about conflict, and when words fail, people resort to "physical dialogue," at least onstage. While a show like the forthcoming Broadway musical "Reefer Madness," which he worked on, has falling bodies, body parts and blood, Mr. Sordelet said the audience would be able to make the distinction between goofiness and gore.
"Just because this thing happened doesn't mean the world will be repulsed by violence," he said. "If anything, they will want to understand it better."
To stanch the industry's financial losses, people who work on Broadway -- including actors, stage managers, stagehands, musicians, wardrobe personnel and others -- have agreed to a 25 percent reduction in pay for four weeks. Sam Vasili of Sam Vasili Shoe Repair, which has long shod performers in Broadway shows, falls into that category because he is part of wardrobe.
"We're trying to do the best we can to stay in business," he said. "I'm going to have a difficult time. We lost like 70 percent of the theatergoers. We have to pray we will get all those people back."
Yesterday the League of American Theaters and Producers announced a marketing program to try to bring people in New York region back to Broadway and help the associated businesses that are struggling. The campaign includes advertisements featuring "I <heart> New York Theater"; radio commercials featuring Nathan Lane, Matthew Broderick and Kevin Spacey; and a television commercial to be filmed in Times Square featuring the casts of every current Broadway show in costume singing "New York, New York."
The Theater Development Fund, which runs the half-price ticket booths, is searching for a temporary downtown location to replace its booth at 2 World Trade Center. 
The fund is also organizing a theater relief effort to help get shows through this period. John Breglio, chairman of the development fund, said the moment could be an opportunity for a large-scale reassessment of how the business of Broadway might work better. "Maybe now it will force all of us to start looking at the basic principles of how we operate," Mr. Breglio, an entertainment lawyer, said. "It will never be business as usual. Hopefully it will be business. But it has to be business in a different way."
It is with Broadway's support services in mind that organizations like the Theater Development Fund are trying to establish long-term guards against a disabling falloff in business.
"It's the theater business; we always are on the cusp of failure, even in the best of times, shows have a 99 percent chance of not making it," Mr. Breglio said. "This is a whole new level of uncertainty. But if there's any business that is used to dealing with high risk, it's this business. It's just a greater degree."
Perhaps most difficult is precisely that state of uncertainty. Things are not as bad as they could get if another calamitous event strikes or tourists stay home or theatrical investors steer clear indefinitely. 
Even outside New York City, ticket sales for touring companies like "Kiss Me, Kate," are suffering. "It's been not so hot so far," said Roger Berlind, a producer of "Kate," which was saved from closing on Broadway on Sunday by an 11th-hour agreement by the cast and crew to take a pay cut. 
"The reaction is pretty scary in big cities," Mr. Berlind added. "L.A. is taking a hit. London is a problem. We're just trying to soldier through all this. It's so depressing. I wish Giuliani would take over my business."
For now Broadway's behind-the-scenes population is sitting tight, bracing even while trying to conduct business as usual. Paul Huntley is preparing hair and wigs for various productions -- including "Hedda Gabler," the new musical "Thou Shalt Not" and Neil Simon's new play, "45 Seconds From Broadway" -- hoping that an evening in the theater will prove to be a necessity.
"We are just trotting ahead bravely," he said. "Being English, I'm old enough to have known the war. People rally round, and the entertainment business is their escape."
Some say the doomsayers have spoken too soon; people are still in the shock and mourning phase, and the true test of whether they return to seeing shows is yet to come. "Theater is something that has survived two world wars, recession, depression, assassinations, market crashes," said Philip Birsh, the president and publisher of Playbill magazine. "We need to have some real data, some real time go by."
Theater is getting an inordinate -- perhaps disproportionate -- amount of attention, Mr. Birsh said, because its results are immediately apparent; seats are empty. "We should allow people's patterns to return -- their patterns have been disrupted," he said. "Once people are satisfied that there are not going to be more incidents, they will get back to these patterns, and one of those patterns is they love theater and will return."
Others fear that the business will never be the same, if only because the terrorist attacks have left people permanently changed. "I'm fairly nervous," said Mr. Allen, the restaurant owner, because of one poll's findings that a large number of people say "they would only fly if they absolutely had to."
"We're kind of joined at the hip with the theater business," he said, "and certainly tourism affects the theater."
To some extent the nightly crowd at Joe Allen is made up of locals -- actors, stagehands and resident theatergoers. But people from out of town are nevertheless essential. "The tourists fill in the cracks," Mr. Allen said. "They'll be missed, you can be sure of that."

HEADLINE: Group Sees Slow Growth For Tourism 

BYLINE:  By DON KIRK 

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, Sept. 24 

 BODY:
Opening its conference here today, the World Tourism Organization put the best face on what it acknowledged were "difficult times," predicting 1.5 percent growth in worldwide tourism this year despite sudden drops after the terrorist attacks in the United States.
 "In the short term, the industry was severely hit," said Francesco Frangialli, secretary general of the organization, opening an assembly held every two years. This one is attended by representatives of 118 of the group's 135 member nations. 
 Mr. Frangialli said the industry had been expected to post a 3 percent gain for the year before the attacks. Now it foresees double-digit drops in the last quarter of 2001 and the first quarter of 2002, compared with the quarters a year earlier. 
The tourism industry must deal with the searing images of four hijacked planes plunging to earth as suicide missiles. Mr. Frangialli and other delegates at the meeting expressed guarded optimism.
"We have had the experience of overreaction before," Mr. Frangialli said. "A lot depends on military developments and the global economy. But we maintain our vision for the long term of 1 billion tourist arrivals in the year 2010 and 1.5 billion in 2020."
The impact of the terror attacks would have been far worse, he said, if they had come during the summer tourist season. "For many countries, the peak season is over," he said.
The tourism organization, a United Nations-affiliated body based in Madrid, issued an analysis of the impact of the attacks before the opening ceremony of the conference. Seoul and Osaka, Japan, were chosen as sites for the conference because the final rounds of the World Cup soccer tournament will be held in South Korea and Japan next year; the meeting shifts to Osaka on Friday.
The issue of terrorism and the impact of the attacks was the consuming topic for delegates. Because the airline industry was already slumping before the attacks, the question now is "how long will we feel the effect," said Peter Shackleford, regional representative for Europe. "If it's a blip, we can cope with it. If it's longer, it will be difficult."

HEADLINE: Leading Index Fell in August For First Time Since March 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 

 BODY:
The index of leading economic indicators fell in August for the first time since March, a decline that is likely to be extended after the terrorist attacks on New York and Washington.
 The Conference Board's index, a gauge of economic activity over the next three to six months, fell 0.3 percent, after rising 0.4 percent in July. The August decrease reflected fewer hours worked in factories and a decline in consumer expectations. 
 The economy, which expanded in the April-June quarter at the slowest pace in eight years, was showing no signs of picking up before Sept. 11. The attacks may cause growth to contract by damping consumer, investor and business confidence, analysts said. Companies like Federated Department Stores and Honeywell International have already trimmed sales forecasts, in anticipation of slower demand.
"The index showed the economy was already weak before the crisis, and the attacks will now dump it into recession," said Steven A. Wood, chief economist at FinancialOxygen Inc. in Walnut Creek, Calif. The economy was last in recession from July 1990 to March 1991, according to the National Bureau of Economic Research in Cambridge, Mass.
To help prevent a recession, investors are expecting the Federal Reserve policy makers to lower the benchmark overnight borrowing rate to a 39-year low of 2.5 percent at their next meeting on Oct. 2, judging from trading in Fed funds futures contracts. Central bankers cut the target rate on overnight loans between banks to a seven-year low of 3 percent last week.
The Conference Board compiles its leading indicators index from eight previously reported economic statistics and estimates on new orders for consumer and capital goods. Seven of the 10 indicators showed weakness in August.
Analysts expected a 0.1 percent decrease, after the previously reported 0.3 percent July rise.
Falling stock prices, faster delivery times, a narrower spread between yields on 10-year Treasury notes and the Fed's overnight rate, a rise in jobless benefit claims and a drop in building permits also contributed to the August decrease.
Two indicators, factory orders for nonmilitary capital goods and orders for consumer goods, were unchanged. Another, an increase in the money supply, pointed to strength.
The Conference Board's consumer confidence index for September, to be reported Tuesday, will probably show a drop to its lowest reading in more than five years, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Apartment Rents and Prices Tremble, but Don't Plummet 

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
Despite dire predictions about plummeting apartment prices, and despite the bad economic news since the World Trade Center attacks, Manhattan's real estate rental and sales prices have not gone into free fall. 
 "While it would be ludicrous to say it is business as usual, the market does seem to be rolling along, although at a slower pace," said Frederick W. Peters, president of Ashforth Warburg. 
 Mr. Peters, along with other real estate executives, said he expected some "downward pressure on prices" -- price cuts -- in current deals. 
Brokers said they had already seen price reductions of 10 to 15 percent on the costliest apartments before the disaster: the $8 million Fifth Avenue duplex going under contract for $7 million, for example. They added that less expensive apartments still appeared to be selling at or near the asking price, except those below Canal Street, where there was virtually no activity at all. 
For the most part, closings have gone on, although there have been isolated instances of buyers walking away, effectively handing their 10 percent deposit to the sellers, who then try to sell the apartment all over again.
"We only had one person walk away," said Alan Rogers, chairman of Douglas Elliman, the city's largest real estate brokerage firm. "But he left $500,000 behind."
In general, agents say they worry most about new business, not existing deals. 
"I don't think New York has seen anything like this since the mid-70's," Mr. Peters said. "There's an uncertainty about what will happen next."
Barbara Corcoran, president of the Corcoran Group (who yesterday announced the sale of her company), said she had told a roomful of shell-shocked brokers last Friday that they should tell their customers to make offers.
"I was suggesting that some buyers are so psychologically low now that they might be having a hard time buying anything," she said last night. "I told them to let the buyer make an offer. Let the buyer set the market."
But she said that rumors that prices were already down as much as 30 percent were absurd. She also said it was premature to say that the seller's market, which peaked 18 months ago, had tipped into a buyer's market, although some brokers were saying privately that it was probably true.
Meanwhile, some would-be buyers are taking advantage of the uncertainty, or are trying to. Ellen Rubin, who owns a public relations firm, said she was staying with her boyfriend in her father's Park Avenue apartment after being evacuated from her TriBeCa rental. She wants to keep looking for an apartment to buy, in the same area. "But to be perfectly honest," she said, "my first thought about apartment-hunting was, 'Now I can really get a deal.' "
Several agents told tales of buyers with signed contracts, which are usually binding, who approached the seller after the tragedy and tried to renegotiate the price downward. (Their threat was to walk away from the deal.)
"We had eight people trying to renegotiate last week," said Scott Durkin, chief operating officer of the Corcoran Group. "And guess what? Three were successful."
Mr. Durkin said landlords reduced the prices of 1,500 of their rental apartments -- from Upper East Side brownstones to luxury towers -- last week from $50 to $200, far more than the 400 such price reductions in the week before the attack. But executives at two of the city's largest rental agencies, Feathered Nest and CitiHabitats, questioned that figure, adding that any reductions they had seen were on apartments that were overpriced to begin with.
Andrew Heiberger, president of CitiHabitats, said that calls from people seeking apartments had been cut in half last week. But that was a lot better than the week before. After what he called "the initial jolt," deals did go through.
"When the planes hit the World Trade Center, we had 300 deals in progress," he said. "They disappeared for a week. Then maybe 250 re-emerged and the contracts were signed."
Yet there are not many contracts, sales or rental, being signed downtown these days. Not surprisingly, brokers cite the shock of the attack and the neighborhood's inaccessibility. "People are streaming out of downtown," said Nancy Packes, president of Feathered Nest. "And they are going uptown. Uptown, the rental market is strong." 
While most agents say it is too soon to judge the long-term strength of Manhattan's real estate market, there was one interesting statistic from one of the city's largest mortgage brokers.
Melissa Cohn, president of Manhattan Mortgage, said that some of her business last week was people refinancing their properties because of low interest rates.
"But 15 out of 27 of those new deals were people who had just decided to buy something," Ms. Cohn said. "And that surprised even me."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Television networks wonder how much lower prices for commercial time could go.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
AS the broadcast television networks belatedly begin the 2001-02 prime-time season, they are anxiously trying to determine if the prices they charge for commercial time -- already softening before the events of Sept. 11 -- will weaken further.
 The season officially started last night, a week later than planned because regular programming had been replaced by coverage of the terrorist attacks on the Pentagon and World Trade Center. As the networks introduce their new and returning series, they wonder how hard they will be hit by deferrals or cancellations of the estimated $6.7 billion worth of commercial time that agencies bought on behalf of advertisers before the season began in the so-called upfront market. 
 The networks are also concerned about how well demand will hold up for the remaining commercial time that they sell as the season progresses, in what is known as the scatter market.
"The question is, as in all things, where is the economy?" said Jon Mandel, co-managing director at MediaCom Worldwide in New York, a media services agency that is one of the nation's largest buyers of TV commercial time. 
But in this instance, he added, forecasting is complicated by "this overlaying malaise" related to the anger and grief caused by the assaults, as well as by the inability to predict what may happen next as the United States military prepares to respond. MediaCom is part of the Grey Global Group. 
It is difficult to determine at this point if the decisions being made by agencies and their clients are spurred by worries "about an economic downturn," said Joe Mandese, editor of Media Buyer's Daily, a newsletter published by Brill Media Holdings in New York, or by "tactical moves relating to a crisis."
"Because it's hard to tell, that leaves a high level of uncertainty," he added, "and uncertainty in this type of environment is not good."
The sluggish economy had already significantly slowed demand for spots during prime-time programming. The estimated $6.7 billion worth of commercial time sold before the start of the 2001-02 season was down 14.1 percent from the record $7.8 billion sold in the upfront market before the start of the previous season.
As a result, prices for 30-second commercials declined by an average of 15 percent to 20 percent from last season, according to an annual survey by the trade publication Advertising Age. The survey is the subject of a front-page article in the issue published this week.
"The networks are all in the same boat," said Wayne Friedman, the Los Angeles bureau chief of Advertising Age, published by Crain Communications, who wrote the article.
The aftermath of the attacks is raising issues about the content of programs, he added, which may force agencies to rethink media plans.
"Sitcoms may seem too trivial to viewers, who may ask 'Why are we watching this?' " Mr. Friedman said. "If there are any accidents in reality shows, as there was in 'Survivor' last season," he added, "advertisers may say, 'Hey, wait a second; I don't want to be in this.'
"Though viewers may want to watch something a little more serious," Mr. Friedman said, "there might be problems with terrorist-themed episodes of shows like 'The Agency,' '24' and 'Alias.' " He was referring to new dramas on CBS, Fox Broadcasting and ABC, respectively.
"But in the patriotic fervor we're in," he added, "maybe if they catch the bad guys, that's something we'd want to see."
The weakened demand for TV commercial time can be seen in the results of the Advertising Age survey of the prices being charged by the largest broadcast networks for 30-second spots. The most expensive prime-time commercial during the 2001-02 season is $445,000, according to the survey, on "Survivor: Africa" on CBS. By comparison, the most expensive 30-second spot during the 2000-01 season, according to the survey last year, was $620,000, on "ER" on NBC. (See chart.)
While NBC remained the network with the most expensive average price for each 30-second commercial, the survey reported, at $158,400, that compared with $198,864 that NBC commanded as first in that category in the 2000-01 season. NBC is owned by the General Electric Company.
Fox, owned by the News Corporation, follows NBC in the survey at $154,600, an increase from $150,310 compared with last season. After Fox came ABC, part of the Walt Disney Company, at $149,700, compared with $193,409; and CBS, a division of Viacom, at $129,000, compared with $190,114.
The survey also gave average prices for each 30-second spot on the two smallest networks, which were not included last year: WB, owned by AOL Time Warner and the Tribune Company, $66,000, and UPN, also owned by Viacom, $37,400.
The lowest price for a 30-second commercial on any of the largest broadcast networks, according to the survey, is $13,300, during the "UPN Friday Movie."
So far, Mr. Mandel said, "our clients have basically stuck with the program" in terms of what they indicated they wanted during the upfront market. "Close to 95 percent have stayed with their spending," he added.
Still, the fourth quarter, which begins on Monday, "is going to be ugly," Mr. Mandel said, "with the networks being undersold" and "the new season being a mess because a lot of shows won't have had the proper promotion as a result of the delay" in starting the 2001-02 season.
But in a paradox, he added, "If the ratings fall, many advertisers will have to spend more to get the ratings they originally wanted," which would benefit the networks.
Mr. Mandese said that to this point, he had not heard of any advertisers "seeking to get more releases than normal" from the commitments they and their agencies made in the upfront market.
"The networks do want to be accommodating" in helping advertisers get out from commitments that now seem ill-advised, he added, "but on the other hand, they do need revenue to stay in business."
In some instances, spending is being shifted to the fourth quarter from the third quarter without difficulty.
For example, the Pontiac division of the General Motors Corporation had planned to introduce a divisional marketing campaign during the CBS broadcast of the Emmy Awards on Sept. 16, but the show was postponed after the attacks. Now, said Leah Haran, a spokeswoman for Pontiac in Detroit, as CBS reschedules the Emmy broadcast for Oct. 7, the campaign will begin then. The campaign is being created by the Troy, Mich., office of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, part of the Bcom3 Group.
In other instances, spending has proceeded as planned. The Taco Bell division of Tricon Global Restaurants went ahead and introduced TV spots last Tuesday as part of a new campaign carrying the theme "Think outside the bun." The campaign is being produced by the San Francisco office of Foote, Cone & Belding, part of the FCB Group division of the Interpublic Group of Companies.
And Ocean Spray Cranberries moved forward last week with two campaigns, both from Arnold Worldwide in Boston, part of the Arnold Worldwide Partners unit of Havas Advertising. One campaign was for a new white cranberry juice drink, which appeared on the West Coast, where the product is initially available. The other, for the flagship red cranberry juice drink, reviving the theme "Crave the wave," appeared in most of the country.

HEADLINE: Corcoran Sells Realty Firm She Founded 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW ROSS SORKIN and JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Barbara Corcoran, the powerhouse Manhattan real estate broker, agreed yesterday to sell the firm she founded, the Corcoran Group, Manhattan's second-largest independent residential real estate company.
 The buyer is a real estate company jointly owned by the franchising conglomerate Cendant Corporation and the private investment firm Apollo Management. 
 Ms. Corcoran, a 51-year-old former receptionist, started her current real estate firm with just $1,000 and seven agents in 1973 selling apartments on the Upper East Side. This deal allows her to cash out at a time when many in the real estate industry say the market may have just passed its peak and may be heading downward. 
The deal was announced late today. While neither side would divulge how much was paid for the Corcoran Group, a person close to the negotiations said the price was about $70 million.
Ms. Corcoran said she decided to sell the company because "not being national was shortsighted."
She added: "The local business has changed. And we couldn't grow as aggressively as we wanted without help."
Ms. Corcoran said she plans to stay at the company and remain the chairwoman. "I can't imagine doing anything else," she said in a telephone interview. She refused to say whether she had signed a long-term management contract. A person close to the negotiations said she did.
The buyer, NRT, is the largest franchisee of Cendant's many real estate brokerage brands like Century 21, Coldwell Banker and Era. Cendant, which also owns businesses like Avis car rental and the Days Inn hotel chain, started NRT in 1997 jointly with Apollo Management, which is run by Leon Black, the deal maker of the big junk bond firm Drexel Burnham Lambert, now defunct.
Other Manhattan real estate brokerage firms have begun consolidating, led by Insignia/ESG's $75 million purchase of Douglas Elliman in 1997 and Brown Harris Stevens's $9 million purchase earlier this year of the Halstead Property Group.
Industry analysts said that Ms. Corcoran made changes in the leadership of the company last year, signaling her interest in selling before the end of the six-year rise in the residential market. She promoted two senior managers, Pamela Liebman and Scott Durkin, to run the company.
It is unclear what effect the deal will have on the Corcoran Group's well-known perquisites, like company-sponsored dog runs for brokers in Central Park and free food at brokerage offices.
Several companies had flirted with buying Corcoran over the years, but encountered resistance from Ms. Corcoran, who associates said was waiting to sell at the top of the market. In 1997, Ms. Corcoran dismissed rumors that her firm would be sold soon, but acknowledged the benefits given industrywide consolidation.
"My hat is off to her on her timing," said Alan Rogers, the chairman of Douglas Elliman, Corcoran's primary competitor. 
Mr. Rogers said that given Cendant's reputation for maximizing profits, he and other brokers will have an easier time hiring Corcoran agents who do not want to be associated with franchises like Coldwell Banker and Century 21.
In recent years, Ms. Corcoran has pulled back from the day-to-day operations of the firm, which employs 700 brokers who work out of dozens of roomy offices from Brooklyn Heights to Madison Avenue. Ms. Corcoran has sought to project a luxury image for her firm, and she is seen as an international leader in real estate, often speaking in New York, Los Angeles and London.
She is known throughout the industry as a shrewd businesswoman, luring top brokers from other firms. Other brokers tend to follow her lead. Manhattan brokers did not begin to move into neighborhoods like Harlem, Fort Greene and Downtown Brooklyn until after Ms. Corcoran had opened offices in those places in recent years.
In the late 1980's, she was among the first advocates of the limited sharing of listings among brokers in Manhattan, and pushed for the creation of a Web site last year that would include residential sales and rental listings from hundreds of Manhattan firms. 
Manhattan is the only major metropolitan area without a system of sharing all listings, as a multiple listing service is known. But her efforts have been credited with changing the culture of Manhattan real estate.
Not all of Ms. Corcoran's efforts have been successful. A notable failure was the spinoff of corcoran.com, a Web site she thought would expand her firm internationally. The site had listings from Costa Rica to Sweden, but personnel problems and the downturn in the Internet economy were harmful. Last year, corcoran.com was folded back into the Corcoran Group.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Energy Prices Decline; Stocks Rise on Optimism
Oil and natural gas prices plunged on fears that a worldwide recession would cut energy demand. But stocks worldwide soared on optimism that the recession would be brief and that the United States economy would eventually shrug off the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11.
 The price of a barrel of crude oil dropped $3.96, or 15 percent, to $22.01, in trading in New York. The drop marked the biggest one-day decline since 1991. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 367.63 points, or 4.5 percent, after closing Friday with its biggest weekly loss since the Depression. Page A1. 

Money-market funds have long been the first stop for investors in troubled times. But a number of conservative investments have served as havens recently. C11.

Southwest Meets Challenge Again
Southwest is seen by analysts as the only airline with a chance to post a profit this year after the terrorist attacks in the United States. Many in the industry are watching to see whether Southwest and its chairman, Herb Kelleher, can negotiate the recent changes in how airlines operate in the aftermath of the attacks. Investors clearly think it can, and they believe the Southwest franchise to be as valuable as the rest of the industry combined. C6.

Luring Back Frightened Travelers
A number of hotels and resorts are lowering rates and offering deals in hopes of luring back customers who canceled air travel plans. C4.

AOL Time Warner to Miss Estimates
AOL Time Warner announced that it would miss its financial goals for the year, largely because the terrorist attacks aided the erosion of the advertising market. C8.

Bethlehem Steel Names a Chairman
Bethlehem Steel said that it had hired Robert Miller Jr., a noted turnaround expert, as its chairman and chief executive. C2.

Attempt to Bar Sotheby's Witness
Lawyers for A. Alfred Taubman, the indicted former chairman of Sotheby's, asked a judge to bar the appearance of a witness expected to offer crucial testimony against him. C2.

Speculation in Publishing Industry
The departure of Phyllis Grann, president and chief executive of Penguin Putnam books, became a subject of speculation among publishers and literary agents. C16.

Charter Chief to Step Down
Charter Communications, the nation's No. 4 cable television provider, which is controlled by the Microsoft co-founder Paul G. Allen, announced that its chief executive, Jerald L. Kent, would leave the company at the end of the year. It was not clear why Mr. Kent had resigned. Investors were surprised by the move, and shares of Charter fell $3.19, to $12.81. C10.

Napster Settles Copyright Lawsuit
The Internet music service Napster said that it had agreed to pay $26 million to settle a copyright lawsuit with American songwriters and music publishers. C10.

SBC Offers to Acquire Prodigy
SBC Communications offered to acquire the 58 percent stake it does not already own in Prodigy Communications for $384 million. C10.

Leading Indicators Fall in August
The Conference Board's index of leading economic indicators fell 0.3 percent in August, the first time since March, a decline that is likely to be extended after the terrorist attacks. C2.

Pacific Rim Supporting Airlines
Threatened by a grounding of airplanes, governments around the Pacific Rim pledged to help airlines. World Business, Section W.

Corcoran Group Will Be Sold
Barbara Corcoran, the Manhattan real estate broker, agreed to sell the Corcoran Group to a company jointly owned by the Cendant Corporation and Apollo Management. A20.

HEADLINE: Publisher Sells Assets 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: PALO ALTO, Calif., Sept. 24 

 BODY:
Standard Media International, publisher of the defunct high-technology magazine The Industry Standard, sold its customer list and other remaining assets today in bankruptcy court. 
 The company said it sold its subscriber list to AOL Time Warner for $500,000 and most other remaining assets to the International Data Group, its main investor. The total value of the sale was $1.4 million plus certain assumed liabilities. 
 Standard Media, which has laid off most of its staff but has continued to publish a bare-bones Web site since closing the magazine, said it was still unclear whether it would continue to maintain a Web site in the future.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE DISPLACED; 
Towers' Former Neighbors Await All-Clear

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

 BODY:
A quarter-century ago, a band of artists dared to do the unthinkable. They looked at the crumpled walls, shattered windows and dripping plaster of an abandoned 19th-century office building in the financial district and saw a home.
 They rebuilt walls. Fixed the boiler. Got the elevators to work again. They turned 125 Cedar Street, on a wisp of a street a block south of Liberty, into an urban homestead with artists and professionals. A block away, two enormous sentinels stood watch: the twin towers of the World Trade Center. 
 Peter Davies, who ran an antiques gallery from his apartment, liked to sit on his rooftop deck and stare at the south tower, its lights "going on and off like a light show." Because it appeared windowless from his angle, he said, "it was more like living next to a monument than an office building." 
The people of 125 Cedar lived through the 1993 trade center bombing and before that a string of bombings in the financial quarter linked to Puerto Rican nationalist groups. Now and then, urban renewal threatened to wipe clean the building.
But the Sept. 11 attack has finally thrown them out, indefinitely, and left them and thousands of other people whose homes are in the restricted area of the financial district in limbo.
Debris and ash, and possibly parts of a plane or the south tower, rained down on 125 Cedar Street, but somehow it still stands and, by early reckoning from city and utility officials, appears structurally sound.
Its location in the off-limits zone has kept the residents of 125 Cedar Street out of their homes except for brief visits, escorted by sympathetic police officers, to retrieve some belongings.
They have camped in the apartments of friends and relatives. They talk to relief agencies and fill out forms. They wrestle with emotions, wondering if it seems petty to worry about getting back to their apartments when thousands of people lie buried almost in their front yard.
But most have summoned the will to come back when the area reopens.
"We are not going to let people drive us out," said Patricia Moore, another longtime resident of the tightly knit community of 23 lofts. "It's the spirit of New Yorkers."
The mayor's Office of Emergency Management has cordoned off a 36-block area surrounding the trade center as off limits to anyone except those involved in emergency rescue efforts. A chain-link fence has gone up, and Richard Sheirer, the director of the office, said he could not say when residents, numbering more than 3,000, could return for good.
Apart from safety and security concerns, much of the area, including 125 Cedar, has no gas or electricity, he said last week.
Last night, more than 300 residents of the off-limits zone turned out for a meeting to ask when they could go home. They reacted angrily -- some stormed out -- when a representative from the mayor's office said he could not tell them.
Sometimes residents can get in for 10 or 15 minutes, or less, by showing photo identification and accompanying a sympathetic police officer; sometimes they are turned away.
Some have recovered passports, legal papers, checkbooks, clothing, and, in the case of 125 Cedar, artwork. Many others have not.
The Federal Emergency Management Agency has promised financial assistance, and many residents of the zone had renters insurance, although some companies have said their displacement aid will stop in two weeks.
This state of homelessness has taken a psychological and emotional toll -- from both the displacement from their homes and the harrowing escapes from the building as debris rained down -- that they find hard to explain to people. The image of the towers falling and the loss of life nag at their consciences.
"You see all these people missing," said Mary Dierickx, an architectural preservation consultant who has lived in the building for 22 years. "How sorry can you feel for yourself?" Mary Petrillo, a video artist, asked, "How insane is it that we all survived?"
Patricia Moore, a fashion designer, finds it hard to concentrate at work. "I have no energy," she said.
Mr. Davies stomped out fires on his roof after the planes crashed into the towers. On a later visit, he said, he found a Raggedy Ann doll on his terrace that he figures must have come from one of the planes.
Returning for a short time, Andy Jurinko, a professional photographer and painter, discovered an ash-covered computer on his living room floor. "We had no computer," he said. It must have smashed through the window as the tower fell.
Tenants of 125 Cedar say a straw poll by e-mail and phone of the 50 or so people living there showed all but 2 vowed to come back. To understand why they would want to return to such a place, consider its history.
Most tenants pride themselves on living in a quirky place that they restored on their own. In exchange for cheap rents and a lot of loft space, they agreed to do most of the renovation. Legal entanglements with the owner at the time followed. That experience forged strong bonds among the tenants that exist today.
Grocery shopping meant a trip to Hoboken, N.J., on the train. Decent restaurants required a trek several blocks north to TriBeCa or beyond.
Their neighbors back then were mainly street vendors and Wall Street commuters. At night, with the streets and office towers empty, the tenants still felt safe because security guards patrolled the trade center. Besides, they reasoned, how dangerous could it be with the heavily guarded Federal Reserve Bank a few blocks away?
"It was so quiet and serene," said Kathleen Moore, a curator at the American Museum of Natural History, "and the guards in the trade center were like my doormen."
Cedar Street is a narrow passage, so their grand windows -- most apartments have 17 windows -- looked out on the south tower and 4 World Trade Center.
Ms. Moore found the towers beautiful, in their own way.
"It's not that we loved those buildings per se," she said, "but every morning I would sit in my kitchen and watch the sunrise. The light hit the side of the trade center and reflected in my kitchen. It was very golden. It in many ways was the most serene place I could imagine living in New York. It was like being in the country."
Other residents arrived when Battery Park City opened in 1982. In recent years, several former office buildings have been converted to apartments, bringing more neighbors.
But the tenants of 125 Cedar prefer to think of themselves as distinct, one of the originals, a family. On the rainy Friday after the attack, 15 of them walked together through the streets of Lower Manhattan in a desperate, and futile, trek to pass various checkpoints to their homes.
They are still awaiting answers, as is the building's owner for the last five years, Samson Management.
"We know nothing," said Arnold Goldstein, who owns Samson. Mr. Goldstein said that he was seeking engineering reports from the city and that the company planned to conduct its own. But given that "we sustained no direct hit," he said, he was optimistic that any damage could be repaired. 
Once they do go back, there is the question of how to live next to the site of the worst terrorist attack in history.
"The building was tacky inside; it had terrible decor," Mr. Davies said. "But it was my favorite building to live beside."

125 Cedar Street
This is the first article in an occasional series on the residents of 125 Cedar Street in the aftermath of the World Trade Center attack.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Oil and Gas Prices Tumble, But Stocks Soar Worldwide

BYLINE:  By ALEX BERENSON and JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Oil and natural gas prices plunged yesterday on fears that a sharp worldwide recession would reduce energy demand. But stocks worldwide soared on optimism that the recession would be brief and that the American economy, the world's leader, would eventually shrug off the attacks of Sept. 11.
 The price of a barrel of crude oil skidded $3.96, or 15 percent, to $22.01, in trading in New York yesterday, falling to its lowest level since October 1999. It was the biggest one-day decline since the Persian Gulf war in 1991. 
 The Dow Jones industrial average, which on Friday recorded its biggest weekly loss since the Depression, gained 368.05 points, or 4.5 percent, yesterday. Stock markets in Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Hong Kong and South Korea also rose strongly. 
In its refined forms, including gasoline and jet fuel, oil runs much of modern life. The sharp drop in its price reflects concerns by energy traders that manufacturing and transportation will be depressed in coming months, even as oil production remains roughly constant.
"There is a conviction that the global economy will be in a recession, not a slowdown," said Sharif Ghalib, editor of research and special projects at the Energy Intelligence Group in New York.
Falling energy prices may actually aid economic growth worldwide by lowering costs for businesses and consumers, who use heating oil, natural gas and gasoline to heat their homes and fuel their cars. 
In the short term, at least, lower oil prices may make it easier for policy makers to respond to the economic slump. In managing economies, governments and central banks must balance the risks of inflation and recession.
If oil prices remain low, keeping inflation in check, the Federal Reserve and its counterparts worldwide can cut interest rates more aggressively, and governments may be more willing to spend.
While oil traders were focused on short-term prospects, stock market investors looked to economic conditions and the outlook for corporate profits next year. After the sharp decline in stocks last week, investors said that some stocks had fallen to attractive prices, especially if a recession proves as short as it is steep.
In Washington, President Bush continued the administration's efforts to bolster confidence and to suggest that markets will eventually respond to the economy's underlying strengths.
"There is no question the attacks have affected America, but I think when the investors sit back and take a hard look at the fundamentals of the economy, they'll get back in the market," Mr. Bush told reporters in the Rose Garden.
"I think that consumers will realize life is going on," he said. "We'll come out of this, and we'll come out of it strong."
Market strategists from Goldman, Sachs; Bank of America Securities; and Credit Suisse First Boston told investors yesterday to move money into stocks, suggesting that the recent sell-off had been overdone.
"I would characterize myself as being very bullish," said Doug Phillips, president of Trusco Asset Management, which manages $45 billion. "I would be switching money from bonds into stocks."
The federal government and Federal Reserve will probably act together to assist the economy over the next several months, prompting a vigorous recovery next year, Mr. Phillips said.
The Fed, which has already cut short-term interest rates once since the attack, is expected to do so again, lowering borrowing costs for businesses and consumers. The government is poised to spend tens of billions of dollars on the military and reconstruction, further aiding economic growth.
The long-term impact of falling energy prices is less than clear. Philip Verleger, an economist with the Brattle Group in Washington, estimated that a $1 drop in the price of a barrel of crude oil would cut costs to consumers worldwide by $28 billion.
But James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at J. P. Morgan, said falling prices might help oil consumers in the United States, Europe and Asia, but in the long run they would hurt oil producers, who in turn buy products and services from the industrialized world.
"It's kind of a wash," Mr. Glassman said.
Since the terrorist attack, there have been fears that American military retaliation in Afghanistan or elsewhere in the Middle East or Central Asia might disrupt the flow of oil. The United States has been working, however, to build a coalition that includes oil-producing nations like Saudi Arabia.
Now traders seem to be betting that production will hold steady, while demand will shrink, at least in the short term. Airlines worldwide are using less jet fuel as they cut back on flights. 
"Initially, people thought it would be a Gulf war scenario, when prices shot to $41 a barrel," said Mark Keenan, an oil trader with Prudential Bache in London. "But there's been a lack of fresh news on the war. Meanwhile, you have a constant barrage of economic doom."
The prices of energy products dropped across the board. Home heating oil fell almost 14 percent, to 61.06 cents a gallon, the lowest since November 1999. Natural gas, which cost almost $10 per million British thermal units nine months ago, fell 9 percent yesterday, to $1.91 per million B.T.U.'s, the first time below $2 in two and a half years. Jet fuel dropped almost 14 percent, for a 28 percent decline since airlines were grounded Sept. 11.
Michael Rothman, senior energy analyst at Merrill Lynch, argued that the oil sell-off was an overreaction. The demand for crude oil will continue to grow modestly, even if a slowdown globally cuts economic growth to under 2 percent, he said. He also said that traders and investors were not allowing for the possibility of a disruption in the supply of oil if Iraq was drawn into the conflict.
"The risks are the greatest to the upside, not the downside," he said.
The fall in oil prices, just two days before the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is to meet in Vienna, leaves OPEC with one of its most difficult choices in recent years. The group has reduced production several times as the economy has slowed, but is now under pressure to keep output steady. If the organization cuts production to buoy oil prices, it could aggravate the risks of a global recession. But if it leaves production steady, the decline in prices will cost its members revenues.
Mr. Rothman said the organization, which has set a goal for prices of $22 to $28 a barrel, needed to take action to keep prices steady.
"Given where prices are now, OPEC has to reaffirm their view about maintaining a mid-20's market price," Mr. Rothman said. "If they don't take steps to defend the bottom of their trading range, the risk is people are going to think that prices are not low enough."
But Mr. Ghalib of the Energy Intelligence Group said "there is no thought of cutting back production because that would convey the wrong signal."
"It is in their own self-interest to try to keep prices lower to offset some of the decline in the economy," he added.
The S.& P. 500 index, which includes the largest United States companies, rose 37.65 points, or 3.9 percent, to 1,003.45, while the Nasdaq composite index gained 76.21 points, or 5.4 percent, to 1,499.40. General Electric, the world's largest company by market value, led the gains, adding $3.90, or more than 12 percent, to $35.20. G.E. said Friday that it would meet estimates for its profits this year and in 2002.
As the stock market rallied, the yields rose on the closely watched 10-year Treasury note, which helps set mortgage rates, and on the 2-year note, which has been a haven for worried investors.
Many institutional investors said they were optimistic that yesterday's gains were the start of a bigger rally, especially if the United States escaped further terrorist attacks. Investors now have $2.2 trillion in money market funds, according to AMG Data Services. If even a small portion of that cash was moved into stocks, it could lead to substantial gains, said Kent Simons, manager of the $1.5 billion Neuberger & Berman Focus mutual fund. Meanwhile, stocks have fallen to attractive levels for long-term investors, Mr. Simons said.
"There's an enormous amount of cash and buying power on the sidelines, and valuation levels that certainly discounted a recession," he said.
The stock rally came even as UBS PaineWebber released a Gallup survey that showed that investor sentiment had fallen from a score of 86 in August to 63 in September. The drop was much more pronounced among younger investors than older investors, UBS PaineWebber said.
Bill Keithler, manager of the $2.5 billion Invesco Technology fund, said that widespread investor pessimism was a crucial ingredient in a rally, since stocks generally rise at times when the outlook seems bleakest. A declining market flushes out investors who for psychological or financial reasons cannot bear to watch their holdings fall in value, and encourages traders to sell stocks short in the hope of making a short-term profit.
As those investors sell, the slide accelerates. Eventually, the market is left with investors who do not want or need to sell their holdings. "When you have significant numbers of people give up, that have sold their stock, that are out of the market, you really begin to see an easing of the selling pressure," Mr. Keithler said.
Then any piece of good news can cause a strong rally by encouraging traders to cover their short sales and establish new long positions, Mr. Keithler said. "There's a significant chance that the lows we saw last week will hold up," Mr. Keithler said.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE RED CROSS; 
Agency Offers Up to $30,000 to Each Victim's Family

BYLINE:  By DAVID BARSTOW

 BODY:
Families of those who have been reported dead or missing in the World Trade Center and Pentagon attacks will receive immediate lump-sum grants of as much as $30,000 from the American Red Cross, the organization announced yesterday.
 The payments are meant to cover funeral costs and short-term living expenses. They represent the first massive transferal of donations to victims' families and are part of a huge surge of charity in response to the attacks. 
 With as many as 6,453 feared missing or dead at the World Trade Center, and another 189 killed at the Pentagon, Red Cross officials estimated that the total size of the grants will exceed $100 million, roughly half the $200 million in donations pledged to the organization since Sept. 11. 
The size of the payments -- intended to cover three months of living expenses -- will vary, based on the size of each family's rent or mortgage, funeral costs and the number of dependents. Chris C. Thomas, a spokesman for the Red Cross, estimated that for a spouse with two children, the payments would range from between $15,000 and $20,000. For very large families, he said, the payment amounts could reach $30,000.
"The American public has responded in an overwhelming way to these crimes," Mr. Thomas said.
The Red Cross will give families $3,000 outright for the first dependent and $600 for each additional dependent. It will also pay three months of rent or mortgage payments up to $5,000 a month, plus all other reasonable expenses, such as food, utilities, telephone and funeral costs. Living expenses need only be estimated, not demonstrated with receipts or bank statements.
"Tell us what you need, and if it's reasonable we'll help you," Mr. Thomas said. 'We're not going to be interrogators or auditors. We've tried to make this as simple as possible."
To obtain the help, families will be required to fill out a one-page application form available through World Trade Center employers, local Red Cross chapters and New York City's Family Assistance Centers. Families will be eligible for the grants regardless of any other payments they may have received from their employers, unions, insurance companies or relief agencies, he said.
"I'm certain that as the months go on that other needs for this money will arise," Mr. Thomas said, adding that checks will be issued within 24 hours after verifying the family's eligibility through the city's official registry of dead and missing.
Red Cross officials said they were untroubled by the chance that the victim count might be imprecise for the time being. City officials have conceded that the list of the missing could shift significantly in the days ahead.
In the days since the attacks, an enormous wave of charitable giving has stunned even veteran disaster officials. From telethons to seven-figure corporate pledges to church bake sales, hundreds of millions of dollars have been raised. Yet relief agencies are still struggling to come up with efficient methods to distribute the money, and some families have found even the smallest payments held up by bureaucracy and confusing eligibility rules.
The Red Cross plan was conceived after Howard W. Lutnick, chief executive of Cantor Fitzgerald L.P., the bond trading firm that lost more than 600 of its employees, including his brother, made a plea for immediate help during a meeting last Tuesday with Dr. Bernadine Healy, president and chief executive officer of the American Red Cross.
Mr. Thomas said that for now, the payments will not be offered to the families of those who died when United Airlines Flight 73 crashed in Pennsylvania. Those families, he said, have already received substantial assistance from the airline.
Relief officials also cautioned that large gaps remain in assistance for others. Ken Curtin, an official for the Federal Emergency Management Agency, pointed out that the payment plan excluded those whose jobs disappeared with the World Trade Center. Many secretaries, food service employees and janitors are also facing severe hardships, he said.
"The immediate cash crunch," he said, 'is now on those who are unemployed and have no cushion."

HEADLINE: It's Back to Politics, So New Jersey Candidates Talk Taxes 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 24 

 BODY:
The campaign for New Jersey governor was back in full swing today, as Bret D. Schundler unveiled a sweeping tax cut proposal for elderly homeowners while his Democratic rival, James E. McGreevey, released a new television advertisement in which he discusses the recent terrorist attacks.
 Mr. Schundler, speaking at retirement communities in Ocean County, said that if elected, he would cut the school portion of elderly homeowners' property tax bills in half over three years. He said that would save 648,000 households an average of $1,226 each. 
 The plan would replace three existing programs for elderly homeowners, according to Bill Guhl, Mr. Schundler's spokesman: the Homestead Rebate, which sends a $750 check to those who pay more than 5 percent of their income in property taxes; an annual property tax deduction of $250 for the elderly; and a credit toward income taxes of $50.
Many people in retirement communities in Ocean County and other parts of New Jersey pay little in school taxes because there are few children in the local schools. That would suggest that some could stand to lose under Mr. Schundler's plan, because half of what they now pay in school taxes is less than what they receive under the Homestead Rebate and the other programs.
But Mr. Guhl said the existing tax-cut programs would not be completely retired. "If you were in a situation where you would get more money from the Homestead Rebate and the other two programs, then you'd take the higher of the two," he said.
Mr. Schundler said his plan would be phased in over three years, at a net cost of $414 million in addition to the $484 million that he said the three existing programs now cost the state.
His plan is more generous than what Mr. McGreevey has proposed for elderly homeowners: an easing of the income and residency requirements for the state's property-tax freeze program. Mr. McGreevey introduced that idea in March, and said today that he was "glad to see Mr. Schundler join our effort to provide tax relief to New Jersey seniors." But he also asserted that Mr. Schundler's other ideas would only wind up driving up property taxes by billions of dollars.
In any case, it is unclear how easily New Jersey will be able to afford any new tax cuts, especially given growing expectations that the state's economy, and government revenues, will suffer greatly in the aftermath of the attack on the World Trade Center.
Mr. Guhl acknowledged the possibility of a deepening recession, but he said that Mr. Schundler still believed that state revenues would continue to grow and that he would be able to find efficiencies to pay for the new tax cut -- which, in turn, would stimulate the economy by giving citizens more money to spend.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY 

 BODY:
 INTERNATIONAL A3-12

French Search for Cause Of Chemical Explosion
Local and national officials tried their best to quash fears that the explosion on Friday of one of France's largest petrochemical plants, in Toulouse, was an act of terrorism. The city's prosecutor, Michel Breard, insisted, "It is 99 percent certain that it was an accident." The blast left 29 people dead, at least 10 missing, and more than 2,500 injured. A3

Bosnian to Surrender to Hague
The commander of Bosnia's Muslim-led army in the first year of the 1992-1995 war, Sefer Halilovic, is to surrender to the United Nations war crimes tribunal at The Hague. The court has indicted him in the killings of Bosnian Croats in a southern village in 1993, his lawyer said. He will fly today to The Hague. A12

Coalition Likely in Poland
Poland's political future became murkier, with more complete tallies from Sunday's election indicating that the victors, the Democratic Left Alliance of former Communists, will not be able to control Parliament without a partner. That partner would be likely to make demands that could slow both entry into the European Union and moves to slash the budget deficit. A12

British Official Angers Israel
Israeli officials were furious over what they saw as a suggestion by Jack Straw, the British foreign secretary, that frustration over the Israeli-Palestinian conflict might excuse terrorism. In response, Mr. Straw issued a statement to explain his comments reported in the Iranian press and said, "There is never any excuse for terrorism." A8

House Votes to Pay U.N. Dues
The House voted to release $582 million that the United States owes in back dues to the United Nations, ending a long-running squabble with the organization at a time when the Bush administration says international cooperation is needed to battle terrorism. A8

World Briefing A10

NATIONAL A14-16

Explosions at Coal Mine Kill at Least 4 People
Two gas explosions nearly half a mile beneath the earth in Brookwood, Ala., on Sunday killed four coal miners and left nine of their rescuers missing and presumed dead in what could be the nation's worst mining calamity in 17 years. A14

Senator to Seek Re-election
Senator Fred Thompson, Republican of Tennessee, said the terrorist attacks on New York City and the Pentagon had persuaded him to run for re-election next year. The decision came as a relief to Republican strategists, who worried that they would have had difficulty keeping the seat in the party if he had retired. A14

HEADLINE: Bethlehem, In Trouble, Picks Chief 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, struggling to remain afloat in an industry that has had 18 bankruptcies since 1998, said yesterday that it had hired Robert Miller Jr., a noted turnaround expert, as its chairman and chief executive. Duane R. Durham, who had held those titles since April 2000, will be president and chief operating officer. 
 Mr. Miller, who is known as Steve, will concentrate on negotiating with Bethlehem's lenders and unions, while Mr. Durham will focus on day-to-day operations. 
 "He'll focus on making and selling steel, and I'll focus on the external communities," Mr. Miller said. 
Both men face formidable tasks. Most steel companies are operating at a fraction of capacity because of the general economic slowdown and a continuing flood of imports that have driven steel prices lower. Even at newer companies like AK Steel and Nucor, which make steel from scrap in low-cost minimills, sales and earnings have eroded. 
But Bethlehem has been particularly hard hit. The company makes steel from scratch, which entails high fuel and environmental costs. And it is carrying a disproportionate number of retirees on its books. The company's current work force numbers 13,300, but it has 74,000 retirees, whose health care costs alone amount to $280 million a year. 
Until the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, most steel executives expected that Washington would provide legal and legislative relief to the industry. Now, many worry that the government will be loath to take protectionist action against countries it wants as allies in the fight against terrorism.
"You just can't predict Washington's mind-set right now," said one, who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
Wall Street has all but abandoned Bethlehem, which has been losing money since 1998. According to Charles L. Hill, director of research at Thomson Financial/First Call, only 3 analysts cover the company, 9 follow U.S. Steel and 11 cover Nucor. Bethlehem's revenue was $4.2 billion last year, yet its market value has dropped below $150 million.
Still, investors did register a weak vote of confidence in Mr. Miller. Shares of Bethlehem rose 16 cents, to $1.29. Mr. Miller bought 10,000 shares himself. 
Bethlehem is not in an immediate fiscal crisis. It recently negotiated $550 million in financing from GE Capital, and it is close to receiving $200 million from other sources. Moreover, it said it had buyers for about $150 million worth of railroad and mining assets. 
"This company is in better shape than the market's perception would indicate," said Michelle G. Applebaum of Salomon Smith Barney.
Still, Mr. Miller insisted that cash infusions were not a long-term answer. "Borrowing money does not solve the cost and import problems," he said. "Bethlehem Steel cannot be turned around without the help of our union and our government." 
Mr. Miller, a lawyer by education, was on the receiving end of a whirlwind courtship. He said he received his first call from a Bethlehem director last Thursday and had completed his interviews by Sunday.
He certainly has turnaround credentials. He was the Chrysler Corporation's vice president for finance in 1979 and is widely credited with negotiating the complex financial agreements that kept Chrysler solvent. Since then, he has, with varying degrees of success, worked on salvaging such disparate companies as Waste Management, Aetna and the Federal Mogul Corporation, where he remains nonexecutive chairman until the end of the year. "I'm listed in the Yellow Pages under 'Flaming Disasters,' " he said with a laugh. 
Maybe so, but he has garnered a reputation as an island of calm amid chaos. "He's an astute financial engineering guy who always maintains his composure," said Gerard R. Roche, chairman of the executive search firm Heidrich & Struggles, who placed Mr. Miller in several of his turnaround jobs. 
Even if Mr. Miller keeps Bethlehem afloat, it might not remain independent for long. "This industry is so fragmented that consolidation must take place," Mr. Durham said. Although he would not rule out the possibility that Bethlehem could be an acquirer, the company's finances -- and stock price -- make it more likely that it would be bought.

HEADLINE: Saudi Arabia's Moment 

 BODY:
The United States has few more important -- or skittish -- partners in its war against terrorism than the oil-saturated kingdom of Saudi Arabia. Even more than the Persian Gulf war, when Saudi Arabia was directly threatened by Iraqi forces on its border, this new campaign will test the political, economic and military ties that have long made America and Saudi Arabia uneasy allies. 
 As President Bush assembles and tries to hold together a coalition of disparate nations, he will have to be mindful of Saudi sensibilities -- not only because of traditional Saudi anxieties about aligning itself too closely with the West, but because the kingdom has an unusual role in this conflict. Osama bin Laden comes from a prominent Saudi business family. A principal aim of his worldwide campaign of terror is to evict American troops from Saudi soil and end Washington's decades-long commitment to the defense of Saudi Arabia and its royal family. 
 Washington should not hold back in seeking Saudi assistance in dismantling the bin Laden terror network. Saudi Arabia possesses an array of assets that can be critical in the war against terrorism, including great influence in the Islamic world, longstanding relations with Afghanistan's Taliban leadership and modern air bases. The Saudi royal family must put its considerable strengths to work in the American-led campaign. 
History, geography and geology have made Saudi Arabia a fault line between civilizations. It is torn between conservative Islamic traditions and a modern global economy fueled by oil and money and defended by American military power. The kingdom is home to two of Islam's holiest sites, Mecca and Medina, and is governed, at least officially, by the precepts of the puritanical Wahabi strand of Sunni Islam. But for generations, political power in Saudi Arabia has been monopolized by an extended royal family. Saudi kings and princes have been worldly in their foreign policy and business dealings, sometimes ostentatiously corrupt in their personal lives and unyieldingly hostile to political debate and representative institutions.
Now they must rise to the challenge of navigating the kingdom's participation in a fight against terrorists who murder Americans in the name of a twisted interpretation of Islamic purity. Saudi Arabia is one of the few governments to have recognized the Taliban government of Afghanistan. Like the two other nations that did so, it needs to use what influence it has with the Taliban's leaders to insist that they hand over Mr. bin Laden. 
If, as is likely, such calls go unheeded, Riyadh should give Washington the permission it seeks to use air bases on Saudi territory to launch and direct whatever military actions may be needed to destroy terrorist bases and training camps in Afghanistan. It should also cooperate with American intelligence agencies in rooting out terrorist cells and financial networks operating in Saudi Arabia itself. By its actions, it can demonstrate to other Muslim nations that Washington is leading an international campaign against terrorism, not, as some wrongly claim, a Western battle against the Islamic world. Saudi Arabia feels especially vulnerable to the strains of this crisis. But it is also particularly well placed to help build the broadest possible coalition against terror.

HEADLINE: AOL, Blaming Terrorist Attacks, Says It Will Fall Far Short of Its Goals 

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
AOL Time Warner Inc., the world's biggest media company, announced yesterday that it would badly miss its financial goals for the year, largely because the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks exacerbated the erosion of the advertising market.
 Ever since America Online agreed to acquire Time Warner early last year, executives from the companies have trumpeted their relative independence from advertising. 
 Asked in an interview three months ago to describe his vision for AOL Time Warner, Gerald M. Levin, the company's chief executive, replied with a single word: "subscriptions." Stable and predictable, subscriptions are meant to be AOL Time Warner's financial bedrock. 
But while subscriptions may provide AOL's foundation, it became clear yesterday that many of the company's upper reaches were still made of advertising.
Twenty-four percent of AOL's revenue comes from advertising. Of the biggest publicly traded media companies, the comparable figure is lower only at Vivendi Universal of France.
But 24 percent is still much more than zero, which is essentially why AOL will miss its goals. Through the late summer, the advertising market, weak as it was for most of the year, failed to show significant signs of recovery. The attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon dashed hopes for a turnaround this year as advertisers worried about sending inappropriate messages and about wasting money on consumers far from a buying mood.
"Prior to Sept. 11, the company had not yet seen an improvement in the overall advertising environment," AOL said in a statement yesterday. "Due to the events of Sept. 11, it has further deteriorated. The state of the advertising market is impacting the company's networks, America Online, publishing and cable operations."
Since the acquisition was completed in January, AOL has been predicting that it would increase revenue by 10.5 percent this year, to $40 billion from $36.2 billion in 2000, calculating as if the companies had already merged. Meanwhile, the company has said that it will increase its earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation and amortization, or Ebitda, by almost 31 percent, to $11 billion from $8.4 billion. Ebitda is perhaps the most common financial yardstick for media companies.
When AOL announced its results in July, executives appeared to back off a bit from the revenue estimate, saying that revenue could increase to "as much as" $40 billion. But the cash flow goal appeared sacrosanct. Through much of the year, AOL cut costs relentlessly to help ensure that any shortfalls in revenue would not prevent the company from reaching its profit number.
But through the late summer and into the aftermath of the attacks, the weakness in advertising proved too much to overcome. Yesterday, the company said that its revenue would increase by only 5 percent to 7 percent. As for Ebitda, the company said it would increase by only about 20 percent, to about $10.1 billion.
Those are significant downward revisions, but many companies, both within the media sector and outside it, would love to post 5 percent revenue growth and 20 percent Ebitda growth this year.
Last week, Viacom Inc., which owns the CBS television network and cable networks including MTV, said that its Ebitda this year would be only "slightly higher" than last year's. As recently as July, Viacom was predicting Ebitda growth for this year of as high as 24 percent. About half of Viacom's revenue is generated by advertising.
AOL made its announcement after major markets closed. During the day, the company's shares rose by $2.65, to $32.50. In after-hours trading, the shares fell as low as $31.27.
In addition to the effects of the advertising slowdown, AOL said that its results would also be hurt by increased costs incurred by its news operations while covering the attacks and their aftermath. An AOL spokesman would not comment on how much of the shortfall could be attributed to the news-related costs, but those costs appeared small compared with the effect of the advertising slump.
In statements, AOL's top executives barely touched on their company's financial situation.
"No financial impact can compare to the terrible suffering and loss of life inflicted by the vicious attacks of Sept. 11," Mr. Levin said. "The AOL Time Warner family is fully committed to continuing to do everything in our power to assist those who have been affected."
Stephen M. Case, AOL's chairman, said, "The bottom line is -- despite this tragedy and the resulting economic effects -- our unique mix of assets give us confidence that we can generate strong earnings growth next year and into the future."

HEADLINE: Trains Need Help, Too 

 BODY:
Stranded travelers made a fortuitous discovery when the airlines shut down after the terrorist attacks: The country still has an intercity rail system. Amtrak scrambled to provide additional service to accommodate the surge in demand. In the Washington-New York corridor, Amtrak's stylish new high-speed Acela Express trains are especially busy because of the continued shutdown of Washington's Reagan National Airport. 
 Congress has acted admirably to help the troubled airlines. But it should also make a commitment to improve passenger rail. Amtrak, which receives about 1 percent of all federal transportation spending, needs an immediate infusion of cash to beef up security throughout its system and to accelerate much-needed capital improvements along the Northeast corridor, where its fast trains are hampered by antique infrastructure. 
 Congress must also adopt a more sensible long-term strategy. For three decades it has grudgingly subsidized Amtrak, spending enough money to keep it alive but never enough to build an attractive service. Also, Amtrak is required to serve many communities where it does not make a profit, even while facing a Congressional mandate that it become self-sufficient by the end of 2002. 
Despite these obstacles, Amtrak had been posting record ridership levels before the attacks, in part because travelers were frustrated by airport congestion. Congressional support for high-speed train service in designated corridors across the country had also been growing. Congress should now focus on investing in economically viable high-speed service in heavily traveled markets, and create a dedicated rail trust fund for Amtrak like the funds that pay for highway and aviation infrastructure projects. 
The need for high-speed trains serving shorter routes extends beyond the Northeast to the Midwest, Texas and California. The Pacific Northwest from Portland to Vancouver is already benefiting from improved service. And Florida's voters last year gave a green light to developing new high-speed links between the state's largest cities.
Air travel is still projected to grow in the long run, intensifying gridlock. The current slowdown should not blind Congress to the need to upgrade the passenger rail system.
