HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE COMPETITOR; 
Southwest Manages to Keep Its Balance

BYLINE:  By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

DATELINE: DALLAS, Sept. 24 

 BODY:
A decade ago, the airline industry was in its worst recession to that point, brought on by the Persian Gulf war, a broad economic slowdown and brutal fare cuts. But Southwest Airlines, then a regional carrier in the process of going national, managed to make money even as the rest of the industry lost more than $6 billion over two years.
 To analysts, Southwest, now much larger, is once again the only airline with a chance to post a profit this year after the terrorist attacks. "It's a worthy goal, at this point, to be profitable for the year," says Gary C. Kelly, Southwest's chief financial officer. "But that's not a prediction." Unlike other major airlines, Southwest has not announced layoffs or schedule cutbacks, though flights will be eliminated if business does not pick up. 
 In an effort to put travelers back in the sky, Southwest could begin a national broadcasting ad campaign as soon as this week. It will include new fare sales on some flights, according to industry officials. Many in the industry are watching to see whether Southwest can smoothly negotiate the changes in how airlines operate in the aftermath of the attacks.
Investors clearly think it can, and they believe the Southwest franchise to be as valuable as the rest of the industry combined. Though the seventh-largest airline by such measures as total miles its passengers travel and revenue, Southwest's total stock market value, $10.5 billion, is roughly the same as that of the nation's other major carriers added together. Since the attacks, Southwest's stock has fallen 20 percent, far less than other airlines'.
What remains to be seen is how much heightened security may impede Southwest's vaunted efficiencies, especially its quick "turn times," or its ability to get planes back into the air after only about 20 minutes on the ground, compared with 45 minutes for most other airlines. Also in question is whether Southwest's many short-distance flights will be most hurt as travelers opt to take a train or drive. So far, Mr. Kelly said in an interview on Friday, the airline's return to the skies shows that such apprehensions appear to be "totally false."
In fact, the industry's current crisis points up Southwest's strength compared with that of other airlines that now appear dependent on the federal bailout for survival. Part of that resilience is because the company focuses on less-congested airports where it can be one of the largest carriers and yet avoid costly delays.
But most investors' current relative loyalty comes from the airline's strong finances and low costs. Between cash on hand and its available credit line, Southwest has more than $1.4 billion. At the same time, flying a full schedule last week with, at most, perhaps half its normal load of passengers, its daily cash burn was no more than $5 million, according to Mr. Kelly, a fraction of the industry's losses.
What's more, should the federal bailout not provide enough cushion, Southwest has 200 planes -- about $5 billion worth, in theory -- that could be mortgaged.
It is also the most efficient airline, although it may take a while to see whether that distinction will be affected by the new security measures after customers return.
Before a recent Southwest flight from Dallas, a ticket agent called over an inspector who searched one traveler's roller bag being checked as luggage. The inspector put on gloves, opened the bag and removed everything. She opened the toilet kit, carefully examining a disposable razor cartridge. After asking another inspector whether it was all right to keep it in the luggage -- it was -- she then repacked the bag.
All told a three- or four-minute procedure -- repeated for several passengers -- that could slow check-in times on Southwest's normally busy schedule, which includes flights to some destinations every half-hour.
Samuel C. Buttrick, an analyst with UBS Warburg who recommended Southwest stock last week, said he had been "encouraged by Southwest's ability to maintain quick turns." But he also added that the bulk of the new security rules "fall on passengers, and as loads rebuild bottlenecks could develop."
Mr. Kelly said that new security measures would not hurt Southwest's turn times. "We're checking in customers in minutes, not hours, though admittedly, the loads are light," he said, adding that the airline has been able to land and get back in the air within normal operating times. 
What is less clear, Mr. Kelly said, is if it will cost more to add security and keep tight schedules, which may depend on whether security is taken over by the federal government. "The security procedures alone may lead to increased security costs; that's all in play," he said.
Industrywide, analysts say load factors -- the percentage of seats occupied by paying customers -- have dropped to about 30 percent to 40 percent. Some say Southwest's loads may be at the low end of that range, partly because the airline has yet to cut its flight schedule. Mr. Kelly said loads are "down consistent with the rest of the industry," but he declined to be more specific.
Betsy R. Snyder, an analyst at Standard & Poor's, said that customers' shying away from short flights "could have an impact," but that since Southwest has been lengthening its average flight, "the impact won't be as dramatic as it would have been several years ago."
Mr. Kelly said that based on last week's performance, "I would totally discard this notion that short-haul flights will be impacted more than long-haul flights."
While shorter flights have lost more passengers than have long-haul flights, he said, it is "not a remarkable difference."
Southwest has asked Boeing to defer deliveries on five 737's due this month, and the airline will almost certainly seek more delays. "To be blunt, we don't have a plan right now for 2002," Mr. Kelly said. "I don't see how we could."
But he said that layoffs were unlikely; before the attacks the airline was actually short of employees and had been paying a lot of overtime.
Though Southwest is not cutting back its schedules right now, it will if passenger loads do not improve, Mr. Kelly said. This will not mean ending service to any markets, but, instead, reducing the number of flights. Perhaps instead of every half-hour, he said, they would be every hour.
"We don't want to do things in the short term that hurt in the long term," he said. "But at the same time, if we can't get through the short term, we won't have a long term."

HEADLINE: Review/Fashion; 
Fashions Turn Nostalgic, in Shows Planned So Long Ago

BYLINE:  By GINIA BELLAFANTE 

 BODY:
Had you been driving on Main Street in Easthampton the Sunday after the World Trade Center attack, and were you able for a few seconds to turn off the newsreel running relentlessly in your head, you might have wondered who had chosen such a surreal moment to shoot a Ralph Lauren ad. 
 On a park bench along the clapboard-lined avenue sat a good-looking couple in the final hours of their middle age, he slouched into his denim shirt, her hair ash blond. Their lives, to borrow a phrase from Spalding Gray, did not appear "ruled by regret." If the couple resembled Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Lauren it was because they were Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Lauren. Behind them, American flags not in evidence the week before waved in unison. This time though, the flag poles hadn't been erected to sell anything. 
 At the onset of Mr. Lauren's spring 2002 show last Friday, it was hard not to long in a real way for the America of his exacting mythology. Like most of the New York designers whose shows were postponed, Mr. Lauren presented his collection intimately, in his showroom, to a small group of editors and buyers. He spoke movingly of the heroism after the crisis and the importance of keeping New York's economic life vital. It is a sentiment that has been voiced repeatedly by designers, among them Helmut Lang, who canceled his Paris show scheduled for Oct. 6, choosing to stage it in Manhattan, where he is now based, for viewing over the Internet and on CD-ROM.
But just how far the collective mind-set still is from the business of clothes became clear before Mr. Lauren's show as many in the audience talked anxiously about rumors of another terrorist attack. There was the editor who decided she would feel better if she took her family to an inn in Connecticut for the weekend, another who had borrowed a friend's lake house and a third who talked of leaving New York permanently, for Vermont maybe, or Charlottesville, Va. -- somewhere closer to Mr. Lauren's unburdened world.
Mr. Lauren's collection, had it been shown before Sept. 11, might have seemed corny. (It was designed, like all others shown last week, before the rush of events). The reference point, as for other designers, was a particular psychic slice of the 1970's -- one that evokes images of girls with lank blond hair parted in the middle and standing in fields of sunflowers. It is the 70's of Joni Mitchell's "Court and Spark," Big Sur and Transcendental Meditation, an era suddenly worthy of nostalgia. Mr. Lauren showed beautifully delicate silk, fringed ponchos and suede embroidered shawls, in a palette of cream and sand colors, with unassuming linen pants suits, which had the temporary effect of quelling the nerves.
Cynthia Rowley's show the evening before produced the same feeling. Ms. Rowley's sweet clothes always suggest a yearning for times less complicated, and you could not help looking at her with a new, less jaded eye. Anna Sui's baby-doll dresses, shown the day before, had a similar effect. 
Ms. Rowley also seemed to invoke Joni Mitchell, but with that came what one might expect from Ms. Rowley -- the eyelet and souvenir-shop prints, a shirt emblazoned with the image of Bob Hope. Even the presence of Monica Lewinsky seemed oddly quaint, calling to mind a time when the country was happily bored enough for sexual dalliance to consume whole news cycles.
The cancellation of Fashion Week on Sept. 11 was sure to have the harshest repercussions for young designers trying to build identities in a climate where many of fashion's top editors are reluctant to make long trips below Houston Street past 8 p.m. to view the work of people they know little about. Benjamin Cho, a talented designer of 24, was to have his shot at the brass ring on Sept. 12 with a show sponsored by the cosmetics label Shiseido. It was not to be. "The first day," Mr. Cho said referring to the day of the World Trade Center catastrophe, "I didn't think about my situation at all." The second day, he said, "I had my long moment of self-mourning, and on the third day I went out to the piers to volunteer."
But designers like Mr. Cho, Elisa Jimenez and the promising Michael Soheil, among others, did not ultimately go unnoticed. Vogue underwrote a group presentation for young independents on Friday in Carolina Herrera's Seventh Avenue showroom. It presented the unusual and somewhat exhilarating spectacle of Anna Wintour, Vogue's editor in chief, and other major editors and buyers taking in clothes they would otherwise dispatch minions to examine. Mr. Cho's truncated mohair jumpsuit and dress with a bodice made of ribbons were among the most inspiring looks in the group show.
Adding heft to the event were Josh Patner and Bryan Bradley of Tuleh, who showed two perfect, fitted coats among their looks and an A-line tweed suit executed without cliche in the Jackie-meets-Audrey school.
Narciso Rodriguez presented a capsule version of his collection on Thursday afternoon. Its dark colors, corset looks and angular, asymmetrical silk skirts were reminiscent of Mr. Lang's aesthetic. Somber clothes for somber times.

HEADLINE: Washington Talk; 
With Bipartisan Zeal, Rival House Leaders Bond

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 

 BODY:
After years of hostility, frosty exchanges and seemingly intractable distrust, Speaker J. Dennis Hastert and the House Democratic leader, Richard A. Gephardt, have bonded.
 The two sit side by side on television talk shows, something they had never done before last week. They huddle at least once a day on Capitol Hill to talk business. They even go out in public together, sharing the limelight and speaking in dulcet tones about unity and cooperation. 
 All this bipartisanship has translated into a string of legislative victories in the aftermath of the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks. Working with Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, and Senator Trent Lott, the Republican leader, the two men have cobbled together compromises on a $40 billion emergency spending bill; a resolution on the use of force; and, last Friday night, a large bailout for the airline industry.
But as Mr. Gephardt told his restive colleagues on the House floor on Friday, "bipartisanship is hard."
Already, things are growing more complicated for the two leaders, and the negotiations will only get harder. In the days and weeks to come, lawmakers must strike a balance between civil liberties and counterterrorism, agree on how to improve the economy and figure out a way to help 100,000 laid-off airline workers. All are issues that will test their ideological convictions.
The strain of so much bipartisanship is beginning to show in the stalwarts of both parties. Last week, a bill to bail out the airlines came close to unraveling. Several angry Democrats were pushing to include a measure to extend unemployment benefits and health insurance to the laid-off airline workers. Republicans, including Representative Tom DeLay, Republican of Texas, the majority whip, wanted to go slow on a provision to protect the airlines from liability, which could end up costing the government billions of dollars.
All of a sudden, said a senior Republican leadership aide who was in the room, "you were further away from the event" and "the passions and the need to work together were starting to ebb."
At 2 a.m. on Friday, after hours of negotiations among lawmakers, Mr. Hastert overrode Mr. DeLay and several others in the room and declared that because all four top House and Senate leaders supported the bill, it would advance.
"The four of us down here are for doing this, so let's go," a senior Democratic aide quoted Mr. Hastert as saying.
The next day, some Democrats criticized Mr. Gephardt for his decision to move ahead with only a promise from Mr. Hastert that Congress would address the worker issue separately. They did not trust Republicans to keep their word, aides said. To allay their concerns, Mr. Gephardt met with Democrats for six hours.
"You can't get everything you want," he told his colleagues. "Bipartisanship means you get some things you want and you give back some things you really want."
Mr. Hastert, whose colleagues were not entirely happy with the bill either, took the unusual step of going to the House floor to say he would consider proposals to help the workers. The bill passed, with 46 Democrats and 6 Republicans voting against it.
How long the two men can keep their caucuses in line is anyone's guess. Looking ahead, Representative Robert Menendez, a New Jersey Democrat who is chief deputy whip, said Democrats were closely watching whether Mr. Hastert would keep his commitment to help workers.
"People are hoping we can work together," Mr. Menendez said. "But democracy is based on a conflict of ideas. Ultimately, I don't think that you will find a willingness to capitulate simply for the sake of appearing bipartisan."
Republicans have echoed that sentiment in recent days.
For now, though, the good vibrations are working. They are even spreading. President Bush gave Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Daschle big hugs the night he addressed Congress. On Thursday, the two congressmen are expected to join Mr. Bush for breakfast at the White House, with their Republican counterparts.
And Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Hastert, buoyed by their success, say they are committed to staying united.
"I think once you walk down that trail and find out that you can do these things in this way," Mr. Hastert said on NBC's "Meet the Press" on Sunday, "you can do extraordinary things."

Dennis Hastert; and Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, speaking to reporters last week at the White House. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: TRADE; 
Senate Approves Bill to Lift Barriers to Trade With Jordan

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 

 BODY:
The Senate passed legislation today that would remove all trade barriers between the United States and Jordan after the Bush administration persuaded a pivotal Republican senator to drop his objections.
 The measure commits the two nations to upholding workers' rights and environmental standards, the first time a full-scale trade agreement has passed Congress with labor and environmental provisions at its core. Its adoption illustrated how political and ideological considerations in Washington are giving way in the push to prepare for the campaign against terrorism. 
 Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, dropped his months-long effort to block the bill after calls over the last week from Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Condoleezza Rice, President Bush's national security adviser. The measure, which passed the House this summer, was approved by the Senate on a voice vote. 
Mr. Bush said he would sign it into law. The agreement, the president said in a statement, "sends a strong signal to Jordan, as well as other countries in the region, that support for peace and economic reform yields concrete benefits."
In an interview, Mr. Gramm said he dropped his objections because it was important that the United States send a signal of friendship to Jordan, an ally that could be instrumental in building support in the Middle East for military and other action against terrorists. 
Like many conservatives, Mr. Gramm has long argued that international trade agreements are the wrong vehicles to address issues like pollution standards, freedom to organize unions and workplace safety.
The bill was negotiated last year by the Clinton administration. King Abdullah of Jordan will visit Washington on Friday to discuss the anti-terrorism campaign with Mr. Bush, the White House announced today just after passage of the trade bill.
"From a foreign policy point of view, this was a must-do thing," Mr. Gramm said. "From the point of view of economic policy and long-term trade policy, this was a bad agreement negotiated by another president."
As Congress and the White House debate what steps to take to bolster the economy in the wake of the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, advocates of free trade have begun arguing that a push for more trade deals should be part of any package.
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, told the Senate Banking Committee last week that the United States should use the outpouring of international support to develop support for a new round of global trade talks. Members of the World Trade Organization are scheduled to meet in November in the Middle East nation of Qatar to negotiate a framework for the talks.
In a speech today to the Institute for International Economics, a research group here, Robert B. Zoellick, the United States trade representative, encouraged Congress to grant the president "trade promotion authority."
Such authority would give the president the right to negotiate trade deals that would be subject to yes-or-no ratification by Congress but that could not be amended by lawmakers. The main opposition has come from liberal Democrats who say trade can kill jobs as well as create them.
Moving ahead now with the administration's free trade agenda, Mr. Zoellick said, "will send an unmistakable signal, with one voice, that America will lead in the promotion of free markets and free people."
But trade politics was complex before the terrorist attacks this month and it remains so now. Mr. Gramm, for example, held up the deal with Jordan not over any concern about the merits of expanded commerce between nations; he is one of the foremost advocates of free trade in Congress. 
Rather, Mr. Gramm said he feared that including labor and environmental provisions would lead to a loss of sovereignty by the United States and subject the country to penalties for pursuing its economic self-interest.
Democrats have insisted in the last several years that the United States dissuade other nations from holding down the cost of their exports by limiting the earning power of their workers or avoiding the expense of anti-pollution efforts. 
Republicans have responded that while such goals are worthy, including them in trade agreements would be more likely to inhibit international commerce than to promote it. And many developing nations have resisted pressure to tighten labor and environmental laws.
The deal with Jordan was an attempt to find a middle ground. It commits both countries not to weaken or to fail to uphold their own existing labor and environmental standards, but does not impose any new standards on them. Should a dispute arise, the two governments have said they will seek to resolve it through negotiations. 
If negotiations were to fail, the dispute would be subject to a settlement procedure between the two countries.
Jordan is one of only four countries, along with Canada, Mexico and Israel, to gain relatively unrestricted access to the United States market. Beyond the deal with Jordan, the United States has made labor and environmental issues part of side agreements in some trade pacts, and is experimenting with innovative arrangements with developing nations like Cambodia.

HEADLINE: Liberals' Ideology Challenged by Urge to Fight Terrorism 

BYLINE:  By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
For many liberals in New York, these are confusing times, as they try to balance their ideals about what the nation should be with their fears of a crisis that threatens to dwarf issues like civil liberties and racism.
 Some believe that Americans for now have to put aside their differences on issues like supporting the president or accepting racial profiling in order to identify terrorists. Others argue that the worst outcome of the terrorist attacks would be for Americans to follow authorities blindly into war or to tamp down their criticism of social ills. 
 In dozens of interviews across the New York area, ordinary men and women, as well as those active in organizations working for social change, talked about what it meant to be liberal after Sept. 11. 
"We have to cherish our rights as leftists, as liberals," said Maurice Berger, 45, a cultural and social critic who lives on the Upper West Side and is a senior fellow at the New School University. "I don't want to see the country turn its back on civil liberties, when people's phones are tapped or people are pulled off planes because their skins are dark." 
But Betsy Llanos, 32, a sales clerk at the Columbia University bookstore, who calls herself "very liberal," said, "We wouldn't have so many problems if we would inspect these people from other countries."
New York City has historically voted Democratic and has been more supportive of abortion rights, labor unions and gays than much of the rest of the nation. 
It is a measure of the times that with the mayoral primary today -- and the efforts to extend Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's tenure -- even many liberals say Mr. Giuliani has been great in the last two weeks.
"If we knew that we were going to have a tragedy like this every six months, I'd love to have Giuliani," said Bill Rosenthal, a Hunter College professor who was attending a peace rally at Columbia University yesterday. "People are forgetting what happened before Sept. 11 and the problems we had," he said, mentioning his particular dislike of Mr. Giuliani's school budget cuts.
Many liberals are worried that patriotism will be narrowly identified as the province of some groups or some political ideologies. At the New York Urban League in Harlem, its president, Dennis M. Walcott, said there were many blacks and dark-skinned Hispanics proudly waving flags and yet wincing at the idea that Arab-Americans could be racially profiled the same way they are.
On the Columbia campus, some students who think of themselves as liberal said they sensed a change in acceptance of public criticism of the country or President Bush. 
"Three weeks ago, it was O.K. to be a dissident" said Jason Paez, 20, a junior majoring in economics. "Now, it's our duty to stand together. We are facing a lot worse than a president with a low I.Q. and delusions of grandeur."
Many who are otherwise dovish said their feelings about military response were complicated because the enemy is not so clear and this time the personal losses hit so close to home.
"I think if you raise the political consequences of the attack, people see you as heartless," said Andrew Stettner, the executive director of Jews for Racial & Economic Justice.
Mr. Stettner said that although he saw a continuing robust liberal commitment to civil liberties, "I've been surprised that a lot of people are willing to support a level of military action that they would not have accepted before."
Along those lines, Judith Stallwert, 51, a secretary in Montclair, N.J., said, "In college, I joined movements against the war in Vietnam, but I don't think I would join protests this time, for this war. I don't want to see people die and I don't want to raise my children during a horrible time. On the other hand, I don't want my grandchildren to one day live in a world with terrorism and fear."

HEADLINE: A Nation Challenged 

 BODY:
 THE NATION'S RESPONSE

ASSETS FROZEN AND BANKS WARNED -- President Bush ordered an immediate freeze of all assets in the United States of suspected Islamic terrorist groups and individuals. Banks worldwide were warned of sanctions if they do not cooperate. A1

WHO WAS SINGLED OUT -- Administration officials said that the 27 individuals and organizations whose assets were frozen include the top lieutenants to Osama bin Laden and the entities most directly tied to his Al Qaeda network. B4

THE SEARCH FOR ACCOMPLICES -- Two weeks after the terrorist attacks, investigators say they have not yet identified any knowing accomplices or uncovered a broad support network in the United States that assisted the hijackers, a senior law enforcement official said. A1

PILOTS WANT WEAPONS -- The nation's largest pilots' union will propose that cockpit crews be permitted to carry handguns to foil hijackers. The head of the Federal Aviation Administration said she is open to the idea, but that it posed practical problems. A1

CROP-DUSTERS GROUNDED -- The Federal Aviation Administration grounded crop-dusting planes for a second day after investigators were told that at least one of the suspected hijackers had asked about agricultural planes at a rural Florida airport. B5

A FORENSIC CHALLENGE -- Doctors are gearing up for the largest effort in the annals of forensic medicine: identifying the dead in the World Trade Center attacks. F1

ANTITERRORISM MEASURE FALTERS -- The Bush administration's hope that Congress would rush through antiterrorism legislation with little debate withered as members of the House and Senate decided to spend more time considering the proposal, especially to ensure it does not go too far in limiting civil liberties. B7

ON THE DIPLOMATIC FRONT

CRUCIAL SUPPORT FROM RUSSIA -- President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia offered the United States broad support for antiterrorist operations in Afghanistan. The announcement provided crucial support to the international coalition that the White House seeks to build in the wake of this month's terrorist attacks. A1

PREPARING TO BRIEF NATO -- As President Bush pressed his case against terrorism with foreign governments, Deputy Defense Secretary Paul D. Wolfowitz prepared to brief NATO defense ministers in Brussels on the overall American strategy to root out the terrorist network. B2

SOUNDING OUT THE REBELS -- American diplomats and Russian generals are courting Afghanistan's rebel alliance. B1

A CALL FOR GLOBAL ACTION -- Secretary-General Kofi Annan called on the United Nations for new instruments against terrorism, saying that only the organization of all the world's states could give "global legitimacy" to a long-term struggle against that "heinous crime." B3

PAKISTAN AND U.S. MEET -- Military officers from United States and Pakistan talked in Islamabad, Pakistan, about ways of using the country's air bases, ports and other sites in the war President Bush has promised against international terrorism. B1

A FLOOD OF REFUGEES -- Hundreds of thousands of Afghans may be on their way to Pakistan. They are a panicked horde expecting a military attack by the United States. B3

WHEAT FOR FLEEING AFGHANS -- The Bush administration announced that it would send 10,000 tons of wheat to feed refugees who are fleeing Afghanistan. B4

THE NATION'S MOOD

WAR SENTIMENT IS STRONG -- Americans favor going to war even if that means thousands of casualties for the nation's military, yet they say that the United States should wait until it is certain who is responsible for the attacks, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. A1

NEW REALITIES IN THE CAPITAL -- In Washington, car trips that took 20 minutes now last three hours. Stores have sold out of gas masks, but meat and milk are plentiful. B6

SHORT-TERM RELIEF FOR VICTIMS -- Families of those reported dead or missing in the attacks on the World Trade Center will receive immediate grants of up to $30,000 from the American Red Cross, the organization said. B8

LIVES THRUST INTO LIMBO -- A band of artists and professionals who made their home a block from the World Trade Center in a 19th century office building they had refurbished are among the homeless. B1

A CHANGE IN RADIO'S TONE -- Vitriol, venom and unfiltered rage are still riding the airwaves of the nation's talk radio stations, but in recent days a huge audience has also heard something that is not usually associated with the medium: restraint. A16

IN THE MARKETPLACE

OIL SLUMPS, STOCKS SURGE -- Oil and natural gas prices plunged on fears that a sharp worldwide recession would reduce energy demand. But stocks worldwide soared on investor optimism that the recession would be brief. A1

NO MAJOR FARE SALES YET -- Despite a plunge of as much as 50 percent in passenger air traffic, the nation's major airlines have been reluctant to lower fares in the wake of the terrorist attacks. Some bargains are being offered on the Internet by travel wholesalers and by small carriers, but the large fare sales that many industry analysts predicted have not yet materialized. C1

SAVINGS ON HOTELS AND CRUISES -- A growing number of hotels, resorts and cruise lines around the country are cutting rates and offering special deals. C4

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE POLL; 
Poll Finds Support for War and Fear on Economy

BYLINE:  By RICHARD L. BERKE and JANET ELDER 

 BODY:
Americans favor going to war even if that means thousands of casualties for the nation's armed forces, yet they say that the United States should wait to act until it is certain who is responsible for the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, the latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.
 The survey painted a portrait of a nation unsettled about the terrorist attacks -- and is expecting more of them -- at the same time it is worried about the state of the economy. For the first time since 1990, a majority of Americans say the economy is worsening. Six in 10 say the nation is in a recession and 2 in 10 saying the nation is near one. 
 President Bush's ratings continue to soar, as is common for presidents in times of crisis, with people giving him impressive marks for his leadership and judgment under pressure. Eighty-nine percent approve of the way he is doing his job, up from 50 percent in late August. 
Yet there are suggestions in the poll that Mr. Bush is buoyed because people hold a high regard for his advisers. Asked whether they had more confidence in Mr. Bush or his advisers, 70 percent said they had equal confidence in both. But of those who chose one or the other, 22 percent expressed greater confidence in Mr. Bush's advisers, and only 5 percent said they had more confidence in the president.
Many people, particularly those in big cities, worry about another terrorist incident in the United States. Even so, people overwhelmingly express confidence in the government's ability to protect them.
But, clearly, Americans' way of life has been altered. Despite security measures the government has taken, about a third of people say the attacks have made them less likely to travel by airplane any time soon. Eight in 10 say Americans will have to forfeit some of their personal freedoms to make the country safer, an increase even from a week ago.
And more than 7 out of 10 Americans consider themselves very patriotic, a substantial rise since the question was last asked a decade ago.
The attacks have enhanced peoples' feelings about New York City even though tourism has been depressed. Eighty-four percent of Americans say they have a good image of the city, up from 61 percent when the question was last asked in early 1998. Sixty-one percent of people who do not live in New York City said they would take a trip there in the next six months if they could afford it or had the time off.
And there was near unanimity about the performance of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, with 95 percent approving how he has handled the attacks, a rating that surpasses that of President Bush.
The ardor for military force, the nervousness about terrorism in this country and the fears of a recession are reminiscent of American sentiments in March 1991, when the nation was at war in the Persian Gulf. It was then that the elder President George Bush drew the highest approval rating of his presidency, a level matched by his son in this poll.
The nationwide telephone survey of 1,216 adults was conducted Thursday through Sunday. Most people were questioned after Mr. Bush delivered his speech to a joint meeting of Congress on Thursday night. The margin of sampling error is plus or minus three percentage points.
The willingness of Americans to accept that there could be significant casualties among the military, as well as among civilians in other countries, underscores the public's determination to root out terrorists. During the gulf war, 4 of 10 people said the United States should not continue sending troops to the region if it cost many American lives.
Now, if there is a war against terrorists, 28 percent say they expect fewer than 1,000 American soldiers to lose their lives; 28 percent put the number at 1,000 to 5,000, and 27 percent predicted higher casualties.
While 92 percent of Americans said the United States should take military action, many respondents emphasized in follow-up interviews that the nation should not be in too much of a hurry to retaliate.
"I would like to see quick justice, but if you jump the gun and attack the wrong person, it's not going to accomplish anything," said Ryan Clark, 19, a forest firefighter in Lewiston, Idaho. "You have to be at least somewhat certain who it is before anything takes place."
But Mr. Clark insisted that he was not squeamish about American casualties, saying, "It's never a good thing for lives to be lost in a conflict, but some casualties now would be better than a whole lot later on."
Diane Stevens, 49, a real estate broker from Washington, Conn., also called for patience, saying, "We should wait and get as much data as we can before we plunge into World War III, because that's where it's going to go."
The public seems to agree with Mr. Bush's assertion that there are great complexities in battling terrorism and that a military campaign would be protracted, and probably far more onerous than those in the past. Americans say the United States will have to dispatch ground troops, cruise missiles and even plot assassinations to eliminate those responsible for the attacks on Sept. 11. Again, perhaps, reflecting Mr. Bush's remarks, 65 percent said military action should be aimed at the terrorists and countries harboring them, while only 27 said it should be limited to the terrorists.
Eighty-four percent of respondents said the United States would win a war, and 8 percent said they did not think the United States would win.
Mr. Bush said last week that he wanted to get Osama bin Laden "dead or alive," and for a majority Mr. bin Laden is either the person they hold most accountable for the attacks or one of them. Asked who they thought was responsible, 45 percent said Mr. bin Laden; 13 percent said Mr. bin Laden and others; 6 percent said Mr. bin Laden and Saddam Hussein of Iraq; 36 percent offered other possibilities like terrorists in general or the Taliban rulers of Afghanistan. And 20 percent said they did not know.
Americans are more likely to blame lax security at airports for the attacks than they are lapses in the nation's intelligence or backlash from United States policy in the Middle East. Asked if the government had done enough to make the country safe since the attacks, 61 percent said the government had and 30 percent said it had not.
For all their uneasiness about the economy, relatively few people said they had altered their spending or investments after the attacks. Four in 10 Americans said the country was in a recession before the attacks, and two in 10 said the attacks led the country to economic turbulence.
"I don't think we're in a recession yet," said Jodii Guilbeau, 31, a homemaker from Kendrick, Ind., "I think we're dangerously close any time there's uncertainty."
But, Ms. Guilbeau said, the national crisis "hasn't altered our spending plans at all."
In question after question, it was clear that Mr. Bush enjoys the public's full backing. For now, at least, old animosities have faded as Democrats, Republicans and independents alike, have rallied behind the president. Ninety percent approve of the way Mr. Bush has handled the attacks, and 81 percent say he has explained clearly enough how his administration is responding. Eighty-one percent said Mr. Bush has displayed good judgment under pressure, up from 45 percent in June.
Antoine Valdetero, 73, a minister in Jennings, La., said he feared that the country would be attacked again. "We are a very vulnerable nation," Mr. Valdetero said. "I am Christian, and I have hope."
Jane Guthrie, 53, an editor in Newton, N.J., said she was concerned that no one detected the terrorists.
"The intelligence community has been chopped off at the knees for a long time," Ms. Guthrie said, "and we should have remained very vigilant. Somewhere we got too complacent and lax, like 'it couldn't happen here,' but it has."

How the Poll Was Conducted
 The latest New York Times/ CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted on Thursday through Sunday with 1,216 adults throughout the United States.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was randomly selected by a computer from a complete list of more than 42,000 active residential exchanges across the country.
Within each exchange, random digits were added to form a complete telephone number, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and number of telephone lines into the residence and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to geographic region, sex, race, age, marital status and education.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all American adults.
For smaller subgroups the margin of sampling error is larger.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll.
Variations in the wording and order of questions, for example, may lead to somewhat different results.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE OVERVIEW; 
BUSH FREEZES ASSETS LINKED TO TERROR NET; RUSSIANS OFFER AIRSPACE AND ARMS SUPPORT

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER and JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 24 

 BODY:
President Bush ordered an immediate freeze today of all assets in the United States of suspected Islamic terrorist groups and individuals and gave the treasury secretary broad new powers to impose sanctions on banks around the world that provide them access to the international financial system.
 Announcing his executive order this morning in the Rose Garden, Mr. Bush reached beyond American borders and said that any foreign banks that did not cooperate with American investigators could be cut off from doing business in the United States. 
 Mr. Bush's plan to punish foreign financial institutions that handle terrorists' money echoes his threat to other nations that harbor terrorists: if the banks choose to harbor terrorists' money, they will be treated as hostile entities. 
"We're putting banks and financial institutions around the world on notice," Mr. Bush said. "We will work with their governments, ask them to freeze or block terrorists' ability to access funds in foreign accounts. If they fail to help us by sharing information or freezing accounts, the Treasury Department now has the authority to freeze their banks' assets and transactions in the United States."
In effect, a foreign bank that refused to cooperate would find itself unable to operate in the United States.
Among the 27 individuals and organizations on a list attached to the order were three charities that the government believes knowingly or unwittingly channeled money to Osama bin Laden and his Al Qaeda network. The groups were Makhtab al-Khidamat, the Wafa Humanitarian Organization and the Al Rashid Trust. Page B4. 
"Money is the lifeblood of terrorist operations," Mr. Bush said. 
"Today, we're asking the world to stop payment," Mr. Bush said, calling the move "a major thrust of our war on terrorism."
Officials said the listed groups were the most prominent with identified links to Al Qaeda.
But there are questions about what the president can expect with the financial crackdown. The demand that overseas banks release information about accounts reportedly controlled by terror groups could run afoul of domestic confidentiality laws. Past attempts to crack down on the assets of terrorists and drug lords have had just limited success.
In 1998, President Bill Clinton issued an executive order that sought to freeze the assets of Mr. bin Laden and Al Qaeda, though it did not include many of the other organizations linked to Al Qaeda that were on the list today. Moreover, Mr. Clinton's administration never openly threatened sanctions against countries and overseas financial institutions that did not join a crackdown.
Of the groups or individuals cited today, one-third had been previously identified by the United States in connection with terrorism. The others were new.
One difficulty in using such economic sanctions against terrorism is that the amounts of money used to conduct terrorist activities may be a few drops in the trillion-dollar torrent that rushes through the world financial system each day. 
The bombing of the World Trade Center in 1993 cost an estimated $20,000, and the F.B.I. has said it believes that the attacks on Sept. 11 were conducted for $200,000 in training, airfare and living expenses.
Mr. Bush declined to talk about the evidence behind his list. He said it was based on "clear evidence, much of which is classified."
The White House refused to discuss what it knew about the links between the charities, for example, and Al Qaeda. Mr. Bush deflected calls for details, insisting that "we will not jeopardize the sources."
"We will not make the war more difficult to win by publicly disclosing classified information," he said.
But White House officials acknowledged that they did not believe that Mr. bin Laden maintained significant assets in the United States and that they did not have a clear idea how his activities were financed.
The Clinton administration began tracing funds to Mr. bin Laden and Al Qaeda in 1998. That effort did not locate any assets held here. 
Mr. Bush said his order was much more sweeping. He cited a number of related groups operating in places like Egypt, the Philippines, Somalia and Yemen. 
Two of the proscribed groups are generally believed to have ties to Pakistan. An Islamic militant group, Haraka Ul Mujahidin, is based in Pakistan, and it is widely believed to conduct terrorist activities against India in Kashmir.
Several groups, including Abu Sayyaf of the Philippines, the Armed Islamic Group of Algeria and Al Jihad of Egypt, are well-known Islamic militant organizations that the State Department had already classified as terrorist groups, meaning that the Treasury Department should already have taken action to seize their assets.
Other new targets appear to be suspected associates of Mr. bin Laden. Two, Tariq Anwar al-Sayyid Ahmad and Tharwat Salah Shihatah, have been sentenced to death in Egypt for plotting to overthrow the Egyptian government, according to Middle East news reports.
Mr. Bush is betting that by giving Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill the power to shut out foreign banks from the American market, he can force cooperation. Under the wording in the order, Mr. O'Neill can act against terrorists' associates, as well as financial intermediaries, even if it is not possible to prove complicity. Under the order, if a bank's offices and equipment are used by terrorists, the United States could seize the bank's assets in this country.
The treasury secretary already has the power to impose penalties on domestic and foreign banks that do business with Colombian drug cartels. But the secretary has not had the authority to threaten banks with similar sanctions if they provide services to terrorists.
Although it seems highly unlikely that Western banks or even secretive offshore financial centers would willingly provide services to terrorists, the new order could pressure banks around the Persian Gulf elsewhere in the Middle East to guard against even unwitting terrorist ties for fear of losing access to the international system.
It is unclear how much money the order will affect. The Treasury Department gave no estimates. In all likelihood, Mr. bin Laden's organization has kept its funds in places that are as difficult to find as the reclusive terrorist himself.
French and Swiss officials said they were acting against suspected terrorist financiers who operated in those countries. The European Commission directed its finance, justice and interior ministers to stop financing terrorist activities, though it was not clear whether Europe would immediately focus on the 27 groups and individuals listed here.
As Mr. Bush focused on the financial war, the Pentagon nearly completed its deployment of roughly 50 bombers and surveillance aircraft, including U-2's from Beale Air Force Base in California and RC-135's from Offutt Air Force Base in Nebraska, to within easy striking distance of Afghanistan, military officials said today. Many of the planes are at a field on Diego Garcia, the British island in the Indian Ocean.

HEADLINE: MARKETING; 
The Web Doesn't Sell Cars but Lets Buyers Build Their Own

BYLINE:  By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
ALONG with the purveyors of other consumer goods, carmakers have been extolling their products on Web sites for some time. There are also independent sites that profess to give unbiased views of what the automotive marketplace offers. Both kinds of sites provide information and offer various ways of buying vehicles.
 Does that mean that shoppers use the Internet to buy cars without going through a dealer? 
 Not exactly.
There are many reasons for this. Many states, for example, allow car sales only through dealers and bar discount online price offers from manufacturers. Even if direct online sales were allowed, a carmaker could hardly bypass its dealers and still retain their loyalty.
Moreover, car buyers "still want a local, permanent presence," said Baba Shetty, an analyst with Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass. People want a test-drive and want to "look someone in the eye and shake their hand," she said.
These revelations have not led carmakers to give up on the Internet. Instead, their Web strategies are structured to develop leads for dealers -- to engage people and get them into showrooms, actually or virtually. While accepting the limits on Web sales, carmakers are also experimenting with expanding sites by offering data on models, options, prices and, in some cases, inventory.
The companies' efforts to corral browsers who might be buyers often start with advertisements on the independent sites where they go to do research on models, prices and options -- like Kelley Blue Book (www.kbb.com), Edmunds (www.edmunds.com), Carpoint.com (owned by Microsoft) and Autobytel .com. Some sites, like Kelley and Edmunds, are linked to manufacturers' sites, like GMBuyPower.com of General Motors. 
That is because G.M. and the independent sites have an alliance, said Olga Purington, the G.M. alliance manager for Kelley and Edmunds. The manufacturer pays the sites for ads that may pop up as a consumer shops for G.M. cars or comparable vehicles, and for a prominent link to its site to appear when the consumer is ready to buy.
Such affiliate relationships between carmakers and third-party sites are common. But because the third-party sites are supposed to be impartial, the links cannot overtly favor one carmaker over another. That means that fancy promotional gadgets and interactive offerings are on the company sites, which do not have the same limitations.
So, which manufacturer sites are the best? Web sites are revised frequently. Model years change annually, usually prompting a revamping of the sites each fall. Nevertheless, for the 2000 model year and the 2001 model year just ending, Forrester Research, J. D. Power & Associates, a Los Angeles consulting firm, and Gomez, another consulting firm that analyzed the models, rated a number of Internet sites above average. These sites include Mercedes-Benz (www.mbusa.com), Saturn (www .saturn.com), Honda (www.honda 2001.com) and Dodge (www .4adodge.com).
These and other highly rated sites share many features, the most important being a "configurator," which allows people to configure and then see images of the models that interest them by features and pictorially, sometimes in three dimension.
The Saturn site is representative of many. Visitors to the site who click the rubric Shop & Buy are taken to a screen with other links that permit them to put a car together by choosing among Saturn's models and options. The car they create is pictured with features as they are chosen, in color. Each feature is priced, and additional links allow visitors to compare the car they are building with other Saturn models.
There are price and affordability calculators, too, which consumers can use to determine the payments on their dream vehicle. There are even links to independent Web sites that quote used-car prices, so that consumers can get an idea of the value of any trade-in. Finally, there are links that allow consumers to find their closest dealer, and to continue the sales process there, at the price quoted on the Web site.
Other sites take the process further. As with Saturn, prices are listed, though state regulations usually allow only the dealer's invoice and sticker prices, or "average" local prices, putting off any additional price negotiations until the dealer and customer meet. (With its "no haggle" policy, Saturn does not have to contend with this issue.)
But these sites do something else -- they allow consumers to find out whether their dream car is actually on a lot or whether it needs to be built.
FOR example, GMBuyPower .com (which does not include Saturn) permits buyers to see whether a particular car exists. And DaimlerChrysler recently began posting dealer inventory on its Web sites for its Chrysler lines, www .4adodge.com, www.chrysler.com and www.jeepunpaved.com. The vehicles on the lots of five-star dealers are listed by vehicle identification number and the manufacturer's suggested retail price. Information is accessible by building a virtual car and looking for a close match, or by searching a list of cars on the lot by model and feature. 
Another site, FordDirect.com, works similarly. The site, a joint venture between Ford Motor and some of its dealers, has been online since April. It operates through dealers in only 26 states, and is too new to have been included in the Forrester or J. D. Powers studies.
The manufacturers' Web sites boast impressive visitor numbers, like 1.7 million monthly visits to Honda's site, said Erin Pinto, a spokeswoman. According to Tom Folger, the director of relationship marketing and Internet for Saturn, half a million visits have been made to its site. Roughly a million unique visits have been made to the Mercedes-Benz site every month, according to a company spokeswoman, Liz Hamill. In June, the first full month during which all three Chrysler sites began offering their version of what Ms. Hamill called "dealer inventory transparency," 70,000 people sent price requests to dealers, said Freda Bane, the group's interactive e-strategy senior manager.
About 17 to 20 percent of visitors to the Chrysler sites bought a vehicle, Ms. Bane said. The industry calls this the closing ratio. 
That's better than most automotive sites, said Chris Denove of J. D. Powers. But it is still lower than the average for walk-in customers, which he said was 20 to 25 percent.
Does that mean that the Internet-generated sales leads will never equal those arising from actual showroom visits?
No, said Mike Devereux, the director of business development for e-GM, the Internet business unit of G.M. He is managing a test partnership between Autobytel.com, the independent Web site, and Chevrolet dealers in the Washington area, providing online shoppers with pricing and vehicle availability information. 
The test began in May and will continue through October. According to Mr. Devereux, G.M. tried it because "not everyone is comfortable with a manufacturer's Web site or a dealer's Web site." 
How many cars have been sold? Mr. Devereux declined to give exact numbers, but he said that the closing ratio was about 25 percent, the same for dealer walk-ins. That's higher than anything else G.M. is doing on the Internet. "We are very pleased with this test," Mr. Devereux said. "It proves definitively that different consumers want different things."

HEADLINE: BY THE BOOK; 
An Old-World Explorer

BYLINE:  By AMANDA HESSER 

 BODY:
IN America, Greek cuisine seems to exist on two planes. There is its old form, steeped in "classics" like moussaka, baklava and seemingly anything stuffed into phyllo layered with butter. And there is the new form, which tends toward a Mediterranean diet and foods that appeal to modern diners, like tangy tzatziki, eggplant caviar and expensive fish grilled and sprinkled with olive oil. It seems implausible that one country could have such vastly different styles of cooking.
 But it does, as you will read in Diane Kochilas's fabulous new book, "The Glorious Foods of Greece" (William Morrow, $40). What American chefs have failed to do is fill in the gap between that hearty moussaka and that lean fish with the richly varied cooking from Greece's island and mountain regions. Ms. Kochilas does this with such clarity and depth that you feel you have happened upon a new cuisine. 
 Like the cookbook writers Paula Wolfert and Lynn Rossetto Kasper, she explores a cuisine by traveling down seemingly every lane and alley in a region, knocking on doors, peeking into obscure tavernas and asking questions.
Ms. Kochilas begins with the food of the Peloponnesus, a peasant cuisine full of one-pot meals, then takes you through Roumeli and Epirus, home to many cheeses and savory pies, which were created as portable foods for shepherds. From there, she travels through Macedonia, where peppers and leeks color the culinary landscape, and Crete, a model of Mediterranean cooking, with its fresh fish and vegetables.
The recipes are superb and enlightening. As against the many books on supposedly humble Tuscan food, which have you buying expensive mushrooms and olive oils, Ms. Kochilas's book resonates with the economy and simplicity of Greece's regional cuisines by calling for common vegetables and inexpensive cuts of meat. It is the rich cuisine of a poor people. There are no airs. Just flavor.
Many of the short headnotes and sidebars are filled with useful information. You learn that Greek cooks turn to chervil much as French cooks reach for thyme. That egg-lemon sauce can be made by two methods, one using whole eggs, the other separating them and folding in the whipped whites.
Ms. Kochilas has a perceptive cook's eye, and it shows in her recipes. In a dish of giant beans with celery, the beans are first simmered, then baked until soft. "This is the whole secret to this dish," she writes. "The beans have to soak properly and cook enough so that they are creamy, almost the texture of roasted garlic, without disintegrating." From this, you immediately know what to look for. 
Tomatoes are rarely peeled, seeded and chopped, but grated, a sure sign of old country cooking. You simply rub the tomato on a coarse grater, and in less than a minute, you are left with just the stem and skin in your hands, the rest of the tomato reduced to a juicy pulp at the bottom of a bowl. 
The great delight of the book for me, though, was coming across dozens upon dozens of recipes that I had never heard of before. There is fresh pasta with garlic, in which the pasta and three heads of smashed garlic cloves are boiled together. You drain the cooked pasta and garlic and toss it with olive oil. Artichokes (have you ever seen artichokes on a Greek menu?) are stewed with tomatoes, wild fennel and rice, and rolled in an egg-lemon sauce.
A dish that I will make again and again is from the Aegean Islands. A small amount of pork sausage is simmered with red onions, dill, fennel, green beans and mint. The vegetables meld into a fragrant tomato broth. The sausage flavors the dish and retreats to the background. Lamb sausages cooked with peppers and tomato had the same kind of reserved brilliance. A parsley and onion dip for crudites had the makings of a green sauce, with parsley, red onion, oil and vinegar pureed in a food processor. The pivotal ingredient was bread, which gave it a texture that was creamy, a little springy and tamped down the sharpness of vinegar.
The best dish of all was tagliatelle with sheep's milk yogurt and caramelized onions from Kassos, on the Dodecanese Islands near Turkey. You drain the yogurt, then mix it with a little of the pasta cooking water. When the pasta is cooked (until it is soft, writes Ms. Kochilas, not al dente), you toss it with the yogurt, then sprinkle it with grated aged sheep's milk cheese and a dollop of caramelized onions. It is as dull looking as could be, but one of the most subtle, delicious things I have ever tasted.

PASTA WITH YOGURT AND CARAMELIZED ONIONS, FROM KASSOS
Adapted from "The Glorious Foods of Greece"
Time: 45 minutes, plus 2 hours to drain yogurt

2 cups sheep's milk yogurt
5 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil
6 cups coarsely chopped onion
Sea salt
1 pound tagliatelle
1 cup coarsely grated kefalotyri cheese or pecorino Romano.

1. Line a colander with cheesecloth, and set over a bowl or in the sink. Add yogurt, and let drain for 2 hours.
2. Heat olive oil in a large nonstick skillet over medium-high heat, and add onion. Reduce heat to medium low, and cook, stirring frequently, until onions are soft and golden brown, 20 to 30 minutes.
3. Meanwhile, fill a large pot with water, and bring to a boil. As it heats, season with enough salt so that you can taste it. Add pasta, and cook until soft, not al dente. Combine drained yogurt with 1/2 cup cooking water, and mix well. Drain pasta, and toss with yogurt mixture.
4. Divide among 4 bowls. Sprinkle generously with cheese, and top with caramelized onions and their juices.

Yield: 4 servings.

STEWED VEGETABLES WITH SAUSAGE, FROM LIMNOS
Adapted from "The Glorious Foods of Greece"
Time: 1 hour 10 minutes

1/2 pound mild pork sausage, removed from its casings
2 medium red onions, chopped
1 fennel bulb, chopped
1 1/2 pounds green beans, trimmed
2 large firm, ripe tomatoes, grated on a coarse grater into a bowl
1/3 cup snipped dill
1/3 cups chopped mint
Kosher salt
Freshly ground black pepper
3 1/2 tablespoons extra virgin olive oil.

1. In a large pot over medium heat, brown sausage meat, breaking it up into 1-inch to 2-inch pieces. Add onions and fennel, and cook together until they are softened, about 5 minutes.
2. Add beans to pot, together with tomatoes, dill and mint. Season with salt and pepper, and toss to coat in the pork fat. Add olive oil and enough water to come about halfway up vegetables. Reduce heat to low, cover pot, and simmer until all ingredients in stew are soft, about an hour. Serve warm or at room temperature.

Yield: 4 servings.

HEADLINE: Gucci Warns That Results Are Suffering 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER 

DATELINE: LONDON, Sept. 25 

 BODY:
A growing list of luxury goods makers, which had been largely untouched by the developing economic slowdown, are reporting that demand has fallen sharply since the terror attacks on the United States.
 The latest, and among the most severe, report came today from the Gucci Group, which warned of a 13 percent fall in profit this year. 
 Analysts said Gucci's forecast could be more negative than those of some rivals' because it has had more time to assess the impact on its business. When LVMH Moet Hennessy Louis Vuitton warned that its profit growth for the year would slow to 5 percent from 10 percent, it did so just two days after the attacks. 
"Despite what was looking like a recession in the United States, luxury companies were still doing quite well," Scott Weldon, a Deutsche Bank analyst in Paris, said. "Sept. 11 has changed everything."
Gucci said sales would probably be $2.3 billion to $2.4 billion, below the $2.45 billion it once predicted.
Sales have been hit by an erosion in consumer confidence, leading shoppers to postpone buying expensive items, and by the sharp falloff in tourism, which has cut traffic in shops in resort areas. 
Domenico De Sole, the chief executive, said that before Sept. 11, Gucci thought it would raise its profit target for the year. The second quarter was better than expected, he said, with much of the growth coming from strong sales of leather jackets, pants and accessories.
Yves Saint Laurent, which Gucci bought in 1999 and is trying to turn around, recorded an operating loss of $13.2 million in the quarter, on sales that fell 11 percent, to $21.6 million, because the company had ended some licensing deals. Mr. De Sole said Saint Laurent "has turned the corner" and that sales were far above expectations in August.
Not all investors are convinced. "What we've seen with Y.S.L. is encouraging, but turnarounds are always difficult to predict, especially in a tough economic environment," said Scilla Huang Sun, manager of a luxury goods fund at the Clariden Bank in Zurich.
Gucci shares fell 2.35 percent, to 87.15 euros ($79.83) in Amsterdam.
On Friday, regulators in the Netherlands, where Gucci is incorporated, approved a deal Gucci struck earlier this month to be acquired in stages over three years by Pinault-Printemps-Redoute, which analysts said would act as a floor under the stock. The Dutch said Gucci must obtain a $234 million letter of credit to compensate minority sahreholders if Pinault backed out.

HEADLINE: Downtown: A Triumph to Reopen, a Struggle to Fill Tables 

BYLINE:  By MARIAN BURROS 

 BODY:
FOR more than a week, most of the restaurants in TriBeCa and the financial district -- including some of the city's most vibrant and popular -- were completely shut down, or devoted to feeding rescue workers and the stalwart people who remained in the neighborhood.
 Over the weekend, and particularly by Monday, they made their first attempts to return to business as usual. Deliveries were back to normal, and people were making an effort to come downtown. Le Zinc reopened almost immediately. Chanterelle reopened Friday. So did Capsouto Freres and Pico. TriBeCa's best-known places -- Nobu, Nobu Next Door, Montrachet and Tribeca Grill -- opened on Monday. 
 Now what the restaurants need are customers -- and a business plan to keep them afloat until those customers are back in force. Some, like Chanterelle, have reduced prices. Others have dreamed up creative ways to get their customers below Canal Street, where cars are still prohibited: Pico is offering a shuttle from Canal and Greenwich Streets.
Many restaurants have had to lay off workers or reduce hours, among them City Hall at 131 Duane Street, which let 10 dining room workers go and cut down on the kitchen staff's hours.
But some restaurants may already be lost. Morton's of Chicago on West Street is closed indefinitely. And some restaurants, already in trouble because of the downturn in the economy, may not be able to weather the storm. Chuck Hunt of the New York State Restaurant Association said: "With decline in sales there are some restaurants that will not make it. This probably could not have happened at a worse time."
On Monday, restaurants like Grace and F. illi Ponte said they lost 90 percent of their business last week. Optimism about the future has not disappeared, however. Harry Poulakakos, owner of Bayard's in Hanover Square and Harry's, in the same building, said: "Because of holidays our industry may recoup a little faster. Personally, my problem is my labor. I may have to cut down a little, but overall I'm going to ride it out. It's going to take a little time."
Fred McKibbin, an owner of Grace at 114 Franklin Street, said he was grateful that this week his business was off by just 50 percent. 
All are hoping that low-interest government loans and and postponement of tax payments will help them through the huge drop-off in business.
Some restaurants are both open for business and feeding workers at the World Trade Center site as well as offering them free meals in the restaurants. At Capsouto Freres, at Washington and Watts Streets, there is a buffet table for the police and for Con Ed and telephone workers. 
"I did my first souffle last week, and for me it was like the reopening of the stock exchange was for New York," said Jacques Capsouto, one of the owners.
That souffle now costs $6.50 instead of $8, and the prices on the still- limited menu have been reduced by 25 percent. Prices at Pico, 349 Greenwich Street, are reduced by $2 or $3. The $84 prix fixe menu at Chanterelle, 2 Harrison Street, has been joined by a $35 three-course menu.
Monday night, TriBeCa was quiet, and looking down West Broadway, the still smoldering ruins and the eerily lighted sky where the World Trade Center once stood were sharp reminders of why. A few sightseers wandered about, but most of those on the street lived in the neighborhood or were on their way to a restaurant. People were free to move about the area below Canal and above Duane as well as in the financial district east of Broadway. The police were not letting anyone through the barricades at Duane Street without proper identification. "We just want to go to that restaurant down on the corner," one man said to an officer. "Sorry, sir, why don't you try one of the restaurant up there," he said, pointing north. 
Cars and taxis are not allowed below Canal Street, though the barrier may be moved farther south at any time. The Franklin Street subway stop, in the heart of TriBeCa, is open. The subway stops at Wall Street and Bowling Green are also open. The subway is the quickest route, and many restaurants are within a few blocks of the subway stops.
The Wall Street area was quieter, the few people on the street rushing to the subway.
David Waltuck, the chef at Chanterelle in TriBeCa, had nothing better to do at 6:45 than shoot the breeze with some of his employees. Three tables of diners told the story, but by the end of the evening, the restaurant had fed 60 people. 
Some restaurants are trying to conduct business without the normal telephone service. Henry Meer, who owns City Hall, has arranged to have calls forwarded to his other restaurant, the Cub Room. David Bouley, who has spent the last week feeding rescue workers, hopes to open Bouley and Danube on Friday, temporarily using cellphones for reservations (646-232-0321 and 917-929-9950).
In the financial district, lunch business has been steadily increasing. Vine, at 25 Broad Street, reported three customers on Sept. 17, 150 on Monday. But dinner business is nonexistent, said Julie Menin, an owner. 
Mr. Poulakakos reported that lunch at Harry's was also strong. At 55 Wall Street in the Regent Wall Hotel, where the ballroom was used to feed workers after the attack, the electricity and gas are back on, the restaurant is open for business and everyone is waiting for it to return to normal.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
Even with oil prices down, OPEC is expected to maintain production levels.

BYLINE:  By Neela Banerjee 

DATELINE: VIENNA 

 BODY:
FACING stiff international pressure to keep oil prices low as the global economy slumps, the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries is expected to maintain current production levels when it meets today at its headquarters here.
 The campaign to keep prices tamped down -- which would serve the interests of the United States -- puts OPEC in a bind, analysts here said. 
 Oil prices have fallen sharply in the last week, particularly a 15 percent drop on Monday and a further decline of 0.9 percent yesterday, and that has OPEC, a 10-member cartel of major producers, worried. Nonetheless, analysts said, the producers risk grave political effects if they cut back production now to shore up prices, because the move might be seen as coldly opportunistic in the wake of the attacks in the United States and the shocks these set off through much of the world economy. 
"If OPEC cuts production now, it will look exceedingly insensitive, politically and economically," said Lawrence Goldstein, president of the Petroleum Industry Research Foundation. "What OPEC is going to do is do nothing." 
After the attacks, Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and other OPEC members regarded as American allies pledged to keep oil supplies stable to show their solidarity with the United States as it embarks on a protracted campaign against terrorism. On the political front, the Saudis and the United Arab Emirates announced over the last few days that they were severing diplomatic ties with the Taliban, the radical Islamic leadership in Afghanistan. 
In the last two years, OPEC has struck a balance that provided stable oil supplies to importing countries and high revenue to its members by successfully modulating production to meet changes in global demand. For months, oil prices have remained between $25 and $30 a barrel. 
Now, even though crude oil prices settled yesterday at $21.81 a barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange, down from $22.01 on Monday, the earliest that analysts expect OPEC to decrease output is during its next meeting scheduled in November.
The oil market's volatility has begun to chip away at the cohesion that allowed OPEC to manage supplies and prices so ably over the last year. Some members, like Algeria and the Emirates, said the group would look for ways to buoy prices at about $25 a barrel. But Saudi Arabia, the de facto leader of OPEC and the world's largest oil producer, indicated that the organization would let current production levels of more than 23 million barrel a day stand.
"OPEC is an organization of the world, and we are extremely preoccupied and concerned about the world economy," the Saudi oil minister, Ali al-Naimi, told reporters here yesterday. "But we recognize that OPEC doesn't really control the price. You know who determines the price. It's the market."
OPEC reduced daily output several weeks ago by one million barrels a day, and analysts said the impact of that decision had yet to be felt in the world markets. 
The high level of oil supplies now is partly a result of most OPEC members' producing above their official quotas, according to Mehdi Varzi, an independent oil analyst. Given the constraints that OPEC now faces, its only option, Mr. Varzi and other analysts said, is to tighten discipline and make sure that members stay within those lower production levels. 
Fear of a crash in the commodity prices of crude oil could be the best incentive. "I think what they've seen the last two days has really shocked them," Mr. Varzi said.
