HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE UNEMPLOYED; 
Disaster's Aftershocks: Number of Workers Out of a Job Is Rising

BYLINE:  By TERRY PRISTIN and LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
More than 100,000 New York City workers are likely to find themselves unemployed, at least temporarily, as a result of the World Trade Center disaster, according to government estimates released yesterday. 
 Already, 10,800 people who have asked the New York State Department of Labor for unemployment assistance have attributed their situation to the terrorist attack on the twin towers and its fallout throughout the economy. 
 Some of the people who are out of a job -- janitors, hotel cashiers, store clerks -- worked in or near the towers. Many more -- waiters, limousine drivers, flight attendants -- worked far from ground zero but are economic victims of the aftershocks like the steep drop in tourism. 
And the fate of many in other occupations -- printing, securities, the garment industry -- will depend on the stock market and on how quickly the city's economy rebounds, economists and labor analysts said.
Even before the disaster, the city's economy, once red-hot, had cooled significantly. In August, New York City companies employed 8,200 fewer people than in July, according to the city comptroller's office, which said it was the steepest monthly decline in five years. The unemployment rate jumped to 5.8 percent in August; it was 5.0 percent the month before. 
"In all likelihood, the city was showing signs of recession before this happened," said Barbara Byrne Denham, a private economist.
But the disaster will add significantly to the ranks of the unemployed. About 75,000 people who worked in the city are likely to apply for unemployment insurance because of the disaster, Emily S. De Rocco, an assistant secretary of labor, said yesterday at a news conference in Washington.
An additional 37,500 are expected to receive special unemployment benefits under the Disaster Unemployment Assistance program that will be available to those who worked in the five boroughs of New York City and are not eligible for regular unemployment insurance payments. 
In total, about 700,000 of the almost four million jobs in the city have been affected in some way by the devastation at ground zero, said Stuart Roy, a Department of Labor spokesman.
Not only have many people lost their jobs, but companies that continue to operate have also lost everything from phone service to a week's revenues. People who are paid on commission lost income, while some people simply could not get to work because of transportation problems.
The new unemployment figures are based on estimates from the New York State Department of Labor, which tried to forecast how much federal aid the city might need. The state's unemployment insurance fund has more than a billion dollars in it, and it can draw upon federal help should that become necessary, Mr. Roy said.
People who qualify for unemployment insurance are eligible for as much as $405 a week for up to six months. Those who are not eligible for unemployment insurance -- because, for example, they are self-employed -- can apply for the disaster unemployment assistance program, which provides the same amount of money. A family in which the breadwinner has died because of the disaster may also be eligible; all benefits are awarded on a case-by-case basis.
Of course, some workers will find themselves in demand in the coming months. Construction workers, for example, are very likely to be in short supply. Demand for security guards also appears to be rising.
But many New Yorkers worked at places that no longer exist, in jobs that no longer exist. 
Among them are 2,000 janitors, security guards, porters and window cleaners who worked in the World Trade Center or in surrounding buildings that were destroyed or shut down. Of these, 350 were on duty during the attack, and 26 died.
Their union said many of these survivors may be able to find work eventually. Last week, the union, the Building Service Workers Local 32BJ, reached an agreement that requires contractors to give these workers first choice when new jobs become open.
"There's a strong possibility of absorbing all of these people in the next few months," said Bill Meyerson, a union spokesman.
Worse off, perhaps, were about 1,000 people who worked in the four hotels in and around ground zero. Their prospects of finding new jobs are dim, because even before the attack, the hotel business was already reeling from a decline in business travel.
Since Sept. 11, of course, tourism has taken a nose dive. About 600 members of Local 6 of the Hotel and Restaurant Workers were laid off before the attacks, and 1,200 more have been let go since, said John Turchiano, a union spokesman.
Until Sept. 11, Daniel Mensah, 35, was holding down two jobs and sending money home to Ghana for his wife and three children. At night, he waxed and stripped floors and shampooed carpets at the Millennium Hilton, next to the trade center. During the day, he mopped and swept at the Muse Hotel in Midtown.
Last week, he said, Muse employees were warned to expect layoffs, prompting Mr. Mensah's wife to urge him to move to another state. But he said he chose to stay and take his chances. "My feeling for New York is too great," he said.
Expecting a long dry spell, the union local and the Hotel Trades Council have set aside $2 million in relief for the displaced workers and have assured workers that they will get medical coverage for a year. And the hotels have pledged to spend $5 million to help workers laid off.
Restaurants that rely heavily on tourists or are in or near the financial district, beyond the reach of taxis and private cars, are also cutting back on staff. At City Hall, the name of a three-year-old restaurant on Duane Street, Henry Archer Meer, the chef and owner, said he had reduced his staff of 115 employees by 25, and was doing without 15 of his 22 waiters by operating one shift instead of two.
The tourism drought has also hurt companies that transport people to airports. "The day they destroyed the World Trade Center, they destroyed our business," said Steven P. Ellis, the sales director of XYZ 2-Way Radio Service, a car service based in Park Slope, Brooklyn.
XYZ drivers are independent contractors, who own their Lincoln Town Cars. Mr. Ellis said at least 25 of the 425 drivers had decided to search for other work.
But they are lucky compared to people like Inocencio Tecalero, 18, who worked as a deliveryman for Candy's, a restaurant in the financial district that will be closed for months. Mr. Tecalero, who earned $8 a hour, is the sole support of his seven brothers and sisters in Mexico.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Hotel and restaurant workers who lost their jobs near the World Trade Center met yesterday to collect information about unemployment and other disaster relief benefits. HEADLINE: BASEBALL; 
Runs, Hits and Healing at Stadium

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG

 BODY:
The fans knew it was supposed to be business as usual last night. But there were more than a few things that just did not feel quite right to them.
 Rick Fortune remarked to his co-worker at MetLife that the crowd at this game, the first Yankees home game since the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11, seemed sparser than it should have been 30 minutes before the opening ceremonies. Patrick Maly, Fortune's co-worker, pointed out the police officers roaming the highest tiers of Yankee Stadium, something he never noticed in previous regular-season games. Then there were the gray storm clouds, which reminded the two men of billowing smoke. 
 And the video display flashed a picture of the Manhattan skyline, complete with the World Trade Center towers.
"Look, there's fireworks going on behind that," Fortune, 41, said of the video segment. "I don't know if that's politically correct. They've got to do something about that."
But for all the slightly off-kilter things the two men noticed, they still agreed on one thing. "We're just happy that baseball is starting up again," Maly said. "Everybody's a little depressed."
It was a sentiment that was voiced yesterday by the flag-waving fans throughout Yankee Stadium in the hour before the game. Sure, they had come for the spiritual succor. They had come for the sense of community. But deep, deep in their hearts, they had come with hopes of seeing their home team trounce the Tampa Bay Devil Rays in a game where 21 could prove to be the magic number for Roger Clemens and the Yankees, who needed one victory to walk away with the American League East title.
"I don't know what is better -- Clemens going for his 21st win, the Yankees clinching the division or just being here on this special night," Robert Glew, 35, of Rye, N.Y., said. "I wonder if I'll be able to hold myself together."
On Sunday, the Stadium was the site of a somber memorial in which clerics from different religions -- and people like former President Bill Clinton and Oprah Winfrey -- tried to provide public comfort.
The mourning was far from over, but the healing took a different form last night.
"A lot of people like to go to church to feel together with the city, with different people," said Richard G. Cirino, 49, a Manhattan public school teacher. "I get that same feeling here at Yankee Stadium, and I expect that feeling today."
Laura Prichard, a lifelong Yankees fan, drove more than two hours with her neighbors from Walden, N.Y., to attend her first game at the Stadium this season.
"We hadn't been to a game all year, and we felt it was important to come and show our support to the economy," she said. "But more importantly, it'll show to Americans that we can come out to a gathering like this and not be afraid."
Her neighbor, Anne Pompeo, sauntered up with a hot dog for her 12-year-old son, Stephen.
"I don't have any problem with coming," she said. "I think more people should come to New York to support this. The more people who get out, the better for the economy."
Several rows away, one fan was thinking more about the record books than about matters of commerce.
"I'm just happy to watch the Yankees play," said Anthony Fonseco Jr., 18, of the Bay Ridge section of Brooklyn. Referring to the fact that Clemens was pitching, he added: "I'm going to watch history. I want to get emotions out, to scream and cheer and stuff like that. And I get to express it through the Yankees."

HEADLINE: Antiunion Measure Passes in Oklahoma 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: OKLAHOMA CITY, Sept. 25 

 BODY:
Oklahoma voters today approved a measure that makes the state the 22nd to ban labor contracts requiring workers to pay union dues.
 With 98 percent of the vote counted, the measure was ahead with support from 54 percent of the voters. 
 "I am excited for Oklahoma," said Gov. Frank Keating, a Republican who supported the measure. "This is the first step in the liberation of Oklahoma's economy."
Jimmy Curry, head of the Oklahoma A.F.L.-C.I.O. and an opponent of the measure, said the labor movement would "back up and regroup." 
The vote came after the most expensive election campaign in state history, pitting business and labor interests in a rematch of a battle 37 years ago over the issue. Unions won the battle in 1964 by fewer than 25,000 votes. Until today, no state had passed such a measure since 1986.
Supporters argued that Oklahoma was losing jobs because companies shied from states without such laws, and that workers should be allowed to choose whether they wanted to support a union.
Opponents said requiring all workers to pay dues was fair because federal law mandates that unions represent all workers in a union shop, including nonmembers.
Less than 9 percent of Oklahoma workers are in jobs covered by union contracts.

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK PRIMARY: THE CITY COMPTROLLER; 
With Berman Set to Concede, Thompson Seems to Be Victor

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON

 BODY:
William C. Thompson Jr. appeared to have won the Democratic primary for city comptroller last night, edging out Herbert E. Berman in a tight and hard-fought race. 
 Although only a small percentage of electoral districts were reporting unofficial results late last night, Mr. Berman's staff conceded that his bid had failed, and said he had tried to call Mr. Thompson. 
 Mr. Thompson said that official results would not be available until today, but added, "It looks really good."
In a statement, Mr. Berman said: "We ran a great race. The focus now must be on the future and on rebuilding New York." The winner of the Democratic primary is almost certain to become comptroller because there will be no serious competition in November; no Republican is seeking the office.
The campaign ended with a last-minute push by Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who recorded a message urging New Yorkers to vote for Mr. Berman, a longtime city councilman. The messages were delivered by telephone on Monday to about a quarter-million households, said Carolyn Daly, a spokeswoman for the Berman campaign.
The comptroller is likely to assume an increasingly important role in the city government, which is being buffeted fiscally by the weakening economy and the aftermath of the World Trade Center disaster.
"The comptroller has an important role in issuing debt, which is going to be very important as we raise capital as we rebuild the city" said Charles Brecher, the research director of the Citizens Budget Commission, a civic watchdog group. The comptroller also scrutinizes contracts, audits programs and manages pension funds.
Still, the candidates had trouble attracting voters' attention, and their contest became one of the season's most acrimonious.
Mr. Berman unleashed negative television advertisements and mailings criticizing Mr. Thompson's moral fitness for the job; Mr. Thompson responded with an advertisement suggesting that Mr. Berman is in the pocket of real estate developers.
Mr. Berman contended that Mr. Thompson, the former president of the Board of Education, turned a blind eye to problems with the school construction program, which is billions of dollars over budget. Mr. Thompson said that Mr. Berman, as chairman of the City Council's Finance Committee, was also responsible for overseeing the program.
On the issues, there was little to differentiate the two men. Both said think the city should have a prudent budget, for example. And both vowed to invest pension-fund dollars in housing programs.
Mr. Thompson, who is black, was endorsed by many black leaders, including former Mayor David N. Dinkins and the Rev. Al Sharpton. A big majority of black voters -- about 80 percent -- supported Mr. Thompson in the primary, according to voter surveys conducted by Edison Media Research. A smaller percentage of white voters favored him.
Mr. Berman was endorsed by many city officials who had worked with him over the years, including former Mayor Edward I. Koch and Harrison J. Goldin, the former city comptroller. Mayoral voters who backed Peter F. Vallone, the City Council president, were also likely to choose Mr. Berman, according to the voter survey.

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK PRIMARY: NASSAU COUNTY; 
Democrats In Nassau Nominate An Outsider

BYLINE:  By AL BAKER and ELISSA GOOTMAN

DATELINE: MINEOLA, N.Y., Sept. 25 

 BODY:
In an upset, Thomas R. Suozzi defeated his party leadership's candidate today and won the Democratic primary for Nassau County executive, bringing him a step closer to the helm of one of the state's wealthiest but most financially troubled counties.
 Mr. Suozzi, the four-term mayor of Glen Cove, decisively beat Thomas P. DiNapoli, a longtime assemblyman from Thomaston who received the party's backing in May and collected endorsements from labor unions and Democratic elected officials including New York's senior United States senator, Charles E. Schumer. 
 But Mr. Suozzi, running as an outsider, raised more money and campaigned more vigorously. Until the World Trade Center attack brought the race to a near-standstill, he used a dizzying series of appearances at train stations, supermarkets and festivals to stress his experience as an executive who had guided his city out of its own fiscal morass. 
In unofficial returns, with all of the election districts reporting, Mr. Suozzi had 54 percent of the vote, compared with 46 percent for Mr. DiNapoli.
Voter turnout, about 24 percent of enrolled Democrats, was higher than expected. There had been predictions that turnout would be low in the wake of the terrorist attack.
"I dedicate this victory to those thousands of heroes who carried us through during these past two weeks," Mr. Suozzi told a wildly cheering crowd of 500 supporters tonight at a catering hall in Carle Place, referring to the trade center rescue efforts.
"I will work harder and longer until we break the back of the machine politics in Nassau County," he said. "We will make Nassau County the best county in the country."
Mr. DiNapoli conceded shortly after 11 p.m., telling supporters who packed a Plainview catering hall that he had spoken with Mr. Suozzi and wished him well. Mr. DiNapoli said the large voter turnout made him proud. "I feel wonderful," he said. "I feel like the best people of this county lined up behind me."
For Mr. Suozzi (pronounced SWAH-zee), the victory represents more than a chance to face Bruce R. Bent, a multimillionaire financier and political newcomer nominated by the Republicans. The November election may make political history: this is considered the Democrats' best chance in decades to seize the office from a once-mighty Republican machine whose grip on this suburban Long Island county -- and its hundreds of patronage jobs and millions of dollars in contracts -- has weakened in the midst of the financial crisis.
If elected, Mr. Suozzi, 39, would be the first Democratic leader of the county since 1970, and only the second Democrat ever to hold the powerful position.
The county's financial woes so tarnished Thomas S. Gulotta, the Republican county executive since 1987, that even after he announced he would not seek re-election this year, he left a void no leading county Republicans were willing to fill. In the last county elections, in 1999, Democrats won control of the Nassau Legislature for the first time.
Though the Democratic primary -- which some nicknamed the battle of two Toms -- threatened to be fractious and bruising, it was ultimately bereft of personal attacks and deep philosophical schisms. Instead, voters had to focus on differences in the candidates' personalities and experience in making a decision.
Mr. Suozzi, the son and nephew of former Glen Cove mayors, had been running for the seat for two years. He raised more money than his opponent -- about $2 million to Mr. DiNapoli's $1.5 million -- and started spending it earlier to get his message out.
The message was simple: that Mr. Suozzi could straighten out Nassau County's finances because he had done it in Glen Cove. As mayor, he improved the city's finances and credit rating, raised taxes in his first year and revitalized the downtown and waterfront areas.
In the days leading up to the primary, Mr. Suozzi's campaign seemed to gain momentum. He won the endorsements of the editorial boards of both Newsday and The New York Times, and was endorsed by former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo -- all moves that helped lift his campaign, Mr. Suozzi said tonight.
"Everything was against us -- the endorsements, the organization, even, for a period of time, the weather," Mr. Suozzi said in an interview. "We won this race because we had the better message. Both of us proved to people that politics doesn't have to be anything but an exchange of ideas."
"I have two goals in the next few days," he added. "One, to make sure the Democrats are together, and two, to start the Republicans for Suozzi Committee."
Mr. DiNapoli, 47, the son of middle-class Republicans, stressed his lifelong dedication to public service, his 15 years in the State Assembly and his ability to unite disparate factions. His allies said they had urged him to enter the race so he could use his relationships with state and federal government officials to help repair Nassau's budgetary woes.
In a brief interview after his concession speech, Mr. DiNapoli said he did not know what had gone wrong. "We haven't had a chance to look at the breakdown, so I really don't know what happened," he said. 
An aide to Mr. DiNapoli said the high turnout helped Mr. Suozzi, because while Mr. DiNapoli focused on the most dedicated Democratic voters, Mr. Suozzi appealed to party members who do not normally vote in primaries.
On the Republican side, even party officials acknowledge that their candidate will face an uphill battle, given the county's state of fiscal disarray after years of ironclad Republican rule.
When no leading Republicans came forward to replace Mr. Gulotta, that opened the door for Mr. Bent, 63, a political novice who received the backing of the famously hierarchical Republican Party in May, only after he had received the county Conservative Party's endorsement. Mr. Bent has vowed to do the job for a $1-a-year salary should he win.
"The message of our campaign is that career politicians have brought Nassau County to the brink of financial disaster and one more politician will push it over the brink," said Michael D. Dawidziak, Mr. Bent's campaign consultant, who said he considered both Democratic candidates to be political insiders.
"I think once this message gets out there, I think his numbers will bounce like a trampoline," Mr. Dawidziak said of Mr. Bent. "If you want to call that an uphill battle, O.K., but I love going uphill that fast."
At Mr. Suozzi's victory party tonight, there was no band, out of respect to the victims of the trade center attack. But from the lectern, the candidate sang a song his father, Joseph A. Suozzi, used when he ran unsuccessfully for county executive in 1958 (to the tune of the "Colonel Bogey March," the marching air whistled in the movie "The Bridge Over the River Kwai").
"Suozzi, you know he'll do his best," he sang. "Suozzi, he always passes the test. So remember, in November, to vote for Suozzi because he's the best."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: NOTEBOOKS; 
New Jobs for the Displaced

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
A partnership between New York City's labor unions and its business community to find jobs for people who used to work at the World Trade Center is already bearing fruit.
 After receiving letters and phone calls from business and labor leaders, companies throughout the New York area have promised to provide more than 2,000 jobs for janitors, secretaries, Windows on the World restaurant employees and other workers who lost their jobs when the trade center was destroyed. 
 Toys "R" Us has pledged more than 800 temporary holiday jobs and has said that in hiring for its new Times Square store it would give priority to former trade center workers. New York City's nonprofit hospitals have offered to make 500 positions available to displaced workers. And the Pfizer Corporation, promising that there will be many more to come, has already hired a dozen former trade center workers for posts including computer programmer, administrative assistant and maintenance worker.
"We think this is a great way to help in a time of crisis," said Michael D'Ambrose, an executive vice president at Toys "R" Us.
Employers with jobs to offer are asked to call a hot line, 212-558-2250. Former trade center workers who are looking for jobs should call a different number, 212-558-2261. STEVEN GREENHOUSE

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE AIRLINES; 
Unions at Airlines Assail Management For Denying Benefits

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Labor-management relations in the airline industry, rocky before Sept. 11, have grown rancorous, with unions enraged at what they say are moves by several carriers to use the national emergency to deny pay or benefits to workers idled as air travel stalls.
 American Airlines, a unit of the AMR Corporation, said yesterday that the airline's finances had been hurt so badly by the terrorist attacks that it could not afford to pay severance benefits to the thousands of workers that it planned to lay off. 
 Union officials quickly criticized American, asserting that the least the airline could do after Congress approved a multibillion-dollar bailout was to make good on its commitments to its workers.
"It's outrageous that American would ask the workers to support them on getting this massive federal bailout and then turn around to slap the workers in the face by failing to honor its commitments," said Edward Wytkind, executive director of the transportation trades department of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. 
Karen Watson, an American spokeswoman, insisted that the company was honoring its contract and was merely invoking an emergency clause that she said allowed the company to suspend certain commitments under extreme circumstances.
"The reason for using these provisions is because of the dire financial condition of the industry," Ms. Watson said. "We're furloughing 20,000 employees because of the 20 percent reduction in our flight schedule, which of course occurred suddenly. Right now the issue is the survival of the company."
Several union officials and airline workers, meanwhile, said that United Airlines, owned by the UAL Corporation, was leaving some workers in limbo by not calling them to work but not laying them off, either. US Airways, they added, was citing emergency conditions to override a no-furlough clause in certain union contracts.
Since the terror attacks, which briefly grounded all aircraft and have left airlines running reduced schedules of half-empty flights, the carriers have announced plans to eliminate nearly 80,000 jobs. Delta Air Lines has scheduled a news conference for today and it is expected to announce more than 10,000 layoffs.
At American, Ms. Watson, the spokeswoman, declined to say how much the airline would save by not making its severance payments; union officials estimated that tens of millions of dollars would be saved. The laid-off workers generally will qualify for unemployment insurance. American's plan to withhold severance benefits was first reported yesterday by The Los Angeles Times.
Some union officials said that they would ask Congress to enact a law requiring American to make good on its severance commitments as a condition for receiving its part of the $15 billion in cash and loan guarantees approved by Congress and signed by President Bush last week. 
Dissatisfied that the bailout bill did not provide any protections for airline workers, union officials also want Congress to enact an additional 52 weeks of unemployment insurance for laid-off aviation workers, above and beyond the 26 weeks that is typically provided. And they want Congress to guarantee at least 12 months of federally financed health insurance for all laid-off aviation workers.
On Monday, Donald J. Carty, American's chief executive, said that he would take no pay for the rest of the year and urged American employees to agree to voluntary cuts in pay.
Last year, according to the airline's proxy statement, Mr. Carty earned $772,500 in salary plus a bonus of $1,351,875.
Union officials complained that United was invoking an emergency clause, known as force majeure, for the month of October, citing it in telling many employees that they would have no work and no pay for at least several weeks next month, although those workers would not be officially laid off. 
While unhappy with this development, union officials voiced less anger at United's approach than American's, because they said United apparently was trying to weather October with as few long-term layoffs as possible.
Chris Brathwaite, a United spokesman, declined to discuss details of the airline's job reductions. 
Pat Friend, president of the Association of Flight Attendants, said US Airways had invoked an emergency clause to skirt no-furlough provisions in the contract.
US Airways executives acknowledged that they were relying on the emergency clause. However, US Airways, which has announced plans to eliminate 11,000 jobs, said it would make good on its severance obligations .
In a statement issued Monday, US Airways said, "The terrorist attacks of Sept. 11 have had a catastrophic effect on the airline industry, and US Airways now finds itself in the position of having to struggle for its very survival."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Donald J. Carty, American's chief executive, said that he would take no pay for the rest of the year. (Ted S. Warren)(pg. C6)

Greenspan and Rubin Oppose 2 Stimulus Ideas
Influential economic advisers and key members of Congress expressed opposition to two of the main Republican proposals for stimulating spending to bolster the economy.
 Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and Robert E. Rubin, the former treasury secretary, advised Congress against cutting the capital gains tax or reducing corporate income taxes. Page A1.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE BENEFITS; 
House Republican Leaders Balk at Any Help for Laid-Off Workers

BYLINE:  By LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 

 BODY:
House Republican leaders balked today at the idea of helping thousands of laid-off workers by extending unemployment compensation and health care benefits despite a commitment last Friday by Speaker J. Dennis Hastert to consider such legislation.
 "The model of thought there, and quite frankly, the model of thought that says we need to go out and extend unemployment benefits and health insurance benefits and so forth is not I think one that is commensurate with the American spirit here," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader. He said a higher priority was to pass an economic stimulus bill. 
 Representative Tom DeLay, the majority whip from Texas, seemed no more enthusiastic about the Democratic plan, which was first proposed last Friday when Congress approved the $15 billion airline industry bailout. The idea was rejected by Republicans in a late-night negotiation session. 
"Sometimes people jump out too quickly on an issue," Mr. DeLay said, referring to Democrats. "They want to develop an issue."
The idea of unemployment help has generated more interest from the White House, at least for now. President Bush plans to travel to Chicago on Thursday to thank airline workers, and some are hoping he will offer them some sort of assistance. At a breakfast meeting today, Democratic leaders said Mr. Bush told them he had directed the Department of Labor to review the administration's options.
"He acknowledged this was a problem," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the Democratic leader, who today introduced one of several bills to help laid-off workers.
John Feehery, Mr. Hastert's spokesman, reiterated that the speaker planned to keep his commitment to Democrats and "move forward on this in a bipartisan way." But, he added: "I'm not sure where it's going to go. I don't think a decision has been made."
As for the reluctance among some Republican leaders to move a workers' bill, Mr. Gephardt said they would face the same pressures as Democrats when laid-off employees ask them, "What about us?"
"I'm not sure in the end they won't have to move something," he said.
Immediately after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, the government ordered all airplanes grounded, a decision that left the airline industry in financial disarray. Since then, the airlines and aerospace companies have said they will lay off more than 100,000 workers. Ronald Reagan National Airport, adjacent to Washington, has been shuttered since the attack, putting thousands of airport workers there in limbo.
On Friday, Congress approved the bailout for the airline industry to help it recover. The bill included a provision allowing airline executives to keep collecting their large salaries, which angered Democrats. On Monday, the chairman of American Airlines, Donald J. Carty, said he would forgo his salary for the rest of the year and asked other executives and nonunion workers to volunteer to take pay cuts. This week, American announced it would not pay severance to the 20,000 workers it planned to let go.
Democrats were infuriated when Republicans refused to include a bill to help workers as part of the initial bailout bill, and criticized their own leaders for agreeing to move the legislation to the floor without an employee assistance measure.
A number of them were assuaged by a commitment made by Mr. Hastert that Congress would consider proposals addressing the issue. But many remained distrustful of the promise, and they now feel as if their suspicions were warranted.
"That's why we wanted to do it last week," said Representative George Miller of California, the senior Democrat on the House Education and the Work Force Committee, who opposed the bailout bill. "Of course, we got rolled. Once you give away what they want, why should they give you what you want."
"Our leadership needs to play tougher next time," Mr. Miller added.
Hoping to put pressure on Republicans, both Mr. Gephardt and Mr. Daschle said they planned to attach a workers' aid bill to legislation on aviation security. Mr. Daschle, as majority leader of the Senate, could do that easily. The idea, though, is opposed by Senate Republican leaders, who say it will only complicate passage of a bill that will make Americans feel safer on airplanes.
"We have indicated to the White House and to our Republican colleagues that it would be very difficult for us to pass the airline security bill without attaching some legislation that allows us to address the myriad of problems we're facing with unemployed workers," Mr. Daschle said. "We addressed airline problems last week. We've got to address employee problems very soon."

HEADLINE: BOLDFACE NAMES 

BYLINE:  By James Barron

 BODY:
Fear of Flying
 Former President BILL CLINTON has not stopped flying since the attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon: he left for Chicago on a United Airlines flight from La Guardia Airport on Monday. But former President JIMMY CARTER has canceled a trip to monitor the parliamentary elections in Bangladesh on Sunday. And Gov. JESSE VENTURA of Minnesota is keeping the body at home: he has called off a trade trip to China next month. 
 "Minnesota, like every other state in the country, must address the economic impact of these tragedies," he said. "Now is not the time for me to be out of the country for an extended period of time." His spokesman said that the decision was made without consulting the State Department, although a check of other governors found nine who had canceled or postponed foreign trips.

Out of Context
She would have been noticed if she had worn a swimsuit. The much-photographed HEIDI KLUM, who has appeared on the covers of Esquire, Mademoiselle and French Vogue this year, was among those who served lunch on Monday to law enforcement officials at Pier 92, a command post and refuge for rescue workers.
Not until yesterday did city officials spread the word that Ms. Klum had gone unrecognized in her jeans, denim shirt, American Red Cross apron and Office of Emergency Management cap.

Personal Nonappearances
There are talk-show guests who are canceling, and talk-show guests who are not. STANLEY TUCCI, the star of two films that were scheduled to open on Friday and that have been delayed ("Sidewalks of New York" until November; "Big Trouble" until next year) canceled an appearance on "Live With Regis and Kelly." But KEVIN COSTNER flew to New York from California for a Monday-night taping of the cable series "Inside the Actors Studio," on which the questioner is JAMES LIPTON, the dean of the Actors Studio Drama School at New School University.
Mr. Costner had a one-liner ready: "I've never before been on the dean's list."
But CATE BLANCHETT, who was to be the guest on "Inside the Actors Studio" next month, has taken herself off Dean Lipton's list.
"She is in England and is deeply concerned about flying," Mr. Lipton told the audience on Monday. Ms. Blanchett's spokeswoman said that it was so, and that besides, Ms. Blanchett was six months pregnant. She will still do some interviews to promote the BARRY LEVINSON film "Bandits," which is scheduled to open Oct. 12, when she would have been in New York. But she will do them over a satellite hookup from London.

Truth Is Stranger . . .
The musical -- which is the debut of HARRY CONNICK JR. as composer and lyricist -- is Zola relocated to post-World War II Louisiana, but CRAIG BIERKO was talking about the World Trade Center on Sept. 11. At a preview of "Thou Shalt Not" (an adaptation of Zola's "Therese Raquin,") at the Plymouth Theater yesterday, he said that he had landed in New York early in the morning of the 11th after a red-eye flight from Los Angeles and hurried home to take a nap before rehearsing.
He had slept for about an hour when the stage manager called to say that the rehearsal had been canceled, and why.
"I ran downstairs to my living room and opened the blinds and I saw one of the towers had gone down," Mr. Bierko said. "Couldn't believe what I saw. Still can't believe what I saw.
"Turned the television on and watched the tower coming down. I thought it was a videotape, the first tower coming down. But it was a live shot of the second tower coming down. I turned around and watched the second tower actually fall."

HEADLINE: PRO BASKETBALL; 
Jordan Makes Official What Most Expected

BYLINE:  By MIKE WISE

 BODY:
In the revised N.B.A. Encyclopedia released last winter, Michael Jordan wrote in his foreword about "a very strong connection between the present and the past."
 Jordan, the former player turned executive, added: "I also believe very strongly that the love of the game is what links the past and the future, and I am determined to make sure that the players of today do not forget that. That will be my assist." 
 Who knew back then that his words would spring to life once more, that he would be falling away after a jump shot, his right wrist slightly cocked, trudging up and down an N.B.A. court? Yesterday it happened. In an announcement that had been expected for some time, Jordan gave the Washington Wizards the go-ahead to include his name on their 2001-2 roster. 
Jordan, considered by many to be the greatest player in league history, signed a two-year contract with the Wizards, the team announced yesterday. He will earn $1 million for this coming season -- the veteran minimum exception for a 10-year player -- and said he would donate that money to relief and victim-assistance efforts for the terrorist attacks of Sept 11.
"Although I am energized by my impending return to the court, I am deeply saddened by the recent tragic events and my heart goes out to the victims and their families," Jordan said in a statement released by the team. "Out of deep respect for them, I will not participate in media interviews before the start of training camp on Oct. 1."
Just like that, Jordan -- who sat on a podium in Chicago in January 1999 to announce his second retirement -- was back for a second time. About to face off with Vince Carter and Kobe Bryant. At 38 years old. 
Jordan all but confirmed more than two weeks ago that he would play for the Wizards this season, ending his three-year retirement. The official announcement came yesterday, amid great interest in Washington, where the 19-63 Wizards of a season ago suddenly became re-energized and a potential threat in the Eastern Conference.
"Michael has always brought joy to basketball fans around the world," the N.B.A.'s commissioner, David Stern, said, "and in these difficult times, we can all use a little more joy in our lives."
To play again, Jordan had to relinquish both his ownership and executive positions with the Wizards. In compliance with league rules, he plans to divest his roughly 8 percent ownership with Lincoln Holdings, which includes his ownership position in the Wizards, the Washington Capitals and the MCI Center. Jordan will also resign as the Wizards' president of basketball operations, a position he has held since January 2000. 
As to the reasons for his returning, Jordan said: "I am returning as a player to the game I love because during the last year and a half, as a member of Washington Wizards' management, I enjoyed working with our players, and sharing my own experiences as a player. I feel there is no better way of teaching young players than to be on the court with them as a fellow player, not just in practice, but in actual N.B.A. games.
"While nothing can take away from the past, I am firmly focused on the future and the competitive challenge ahead of me."
Abe Pollin, the Washington Sports and Entertainment chairman and the franchise's patriarch, said the team's excitement at Jordan's return was tempered by the national mood in the aftermath of the attacks. "The greatest player in the history of the game is joining my team, and for that I am extremely honored and pleased," Pollin said. "Michael has expressed his wishes that we focus on the national events of today rather than basketball. I concur and will certainly honor his wishes."
Jordan was prepared to announce his decision Monday but put it off because of a sponsorship conflict between EA Sports, which manufactures a video game with Jordan's likeness, and Jordan's management team. The N.B.A., which has a separate licensing agreement with Jordan dating to 1992, helped resolve the issue. 
His decision changes the N.B.A. landscape in many ways. Wizards preseason games will suddenly attract a host of national news media, covering the team as if Jordan were a campaigning politician. NBC will also make changes in its N.B.A. programming, most likely beginning with Washington's visit to Chicago on Jan. 19 -- a game that will now most certainly be televised.
"We're excited that Michael is returning," said Dick Ebersol, the NBC Sports chairman. "It will be fun to watch the greatest player ever match up against the N.B.A.'s new generation of stars." 
He added, "Any possible scheduling changes will be considered and discussed with the N.B.A. in the next week to 10 days."
Ebersol said he did not believe Jordan's return would have any impact on the current negotiations between the N.B.A. and the network on a new television contract. Jordan will be approaching 40 when the new deal begins for the 2002-3 season. But many industry analysts say his marquee value can only help in rough economic times.
Jordan's financial impact will be felt in many ways. 
"At a time when there isn't a lot of good news, this is great news," said Brandon Steiner, the president of Steiner Marketing, which matches up individuals with companies for endorsements. "Because of the filter-down effect he brings to the marketplace, I always felt like I should write Michael a commission check.' 
The announcement caps a nearly yearlong quest for Jordan, who began playing basketball in January to lose weight. As his workouts intensified and it became clear in mid-April that he was interested in a comeback, Jordan retreated to his home in Chicago and began working out under the guidance of his longtime personal trainer, Tim Grover.
Pickup games were arranged over the next few months, first against college-level talent and then against N.B.A. all-stars. As the games grew more competitive -- Jordan sustained two cracked ribs and battled tendinitis for much of the summer -- the whispers gradually became proclamations. He could still play.
Jordan first retired in October 1993 after leading the Chicago Bulls to three titles. He attempted to play professional baseball, and spent time with the Birmingham Barons in the minor leagues. He then made his first comeback in March 1995 with a fax simply stating, "I'm back!"
He proceeded to lead the Bulls to three more titles and retired again in January 1999, shortly before the start of the lockout-shortened season. He said he was 99.9 percent certain that he would not return.
But he apparently held on to that one-tenth of 1 percent, gripping the slight window of opportunity the way he once palmed a basketball.
"I am especially excited about the Washington Wizards, and I'm convinced we have the foundation on which to build a playoff-contention team," Jordan said in the statement. "The opportunity to teach our young players and help them elevate their game to a higher level, and to thank the fans in Washington for their loyalty and support, strongly influenced my decision."

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ADVISER; 
Clinton's Fiscal Chief Has the Ear Of Congress

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN and RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 

 BODY:
Needing advice about economic policy in the wake of the terrorist attacks, the Senate Finance Committee summoned the chairman of the Federal Reserve and a treasury secretary to a closed-door meeting this morning.
 The Fed chairman, of course, was Alan Greenspan. But the treasury secretary, Robert E. Rubin, has been out of office for nearly two and a half years and is now chairman of the executive committee of Citigroup, one of the world's biggest banking companies. 
 Mr. Rubin is not only of a different political persuasion than the current occupant of the office, Paul H. O'Neill, he has also arguably been more influential in shaping a response to the country's mounting economic woes -- at least in Congress -- than anyone in the Bush administration. 
As treasury secretary under President Bill Clinton, Mr. Rubin helped give Democrats a claim to being the party of budgetary responsibility, guided the world through several international financial crises and won the respect of investors on Wall Street and even Republicans on Capitol Hill. Along with Mr. Greenspan, Mr. Rubin is credited with helping to shape the economic policies that fueled the 1990's boom, though it began before he took office.
Mr. Rubin and Mr. Greenspan have worked together since early in the Clinton administration, when Mr. Rubin promised that the White House would not put political pressure on the Fed about interest rates; he also vowed that it would heed Mr. Greenspan's call and make reducing the federal budget deficit its top economic priority. The two then worked together to manage the Mexico debt crisis in 1995 and the global financial crisis a few years later.
In recent weeks they have teamed up again, appearing together twice on Capitol Hill to warn against rushing into legislation that carried a heavy long-term economic cost.
Flying to the Washington area from New York on Citigroup's corporate jet, Mr. Rubin has also shuttled in and out of other Congressional meetings, including a session last week with the House Ways and Means Committee.
In this crisis, Mr. Greenspan, as always, plays the role of economic sage to a Congress that invests considerable authority in him. Mr. Rubin has been cast by his party as a senior statesman at a time of national unity and the embodiment of Democrats' argument that they can manage the economy as well as Republicans. 
"Rubin's name has become synonymous with paying attention to economic fundamentals," said Representative Robert T. Matsui, Democrat of California. "You just mention his name -- Democrat or Republican -- and people know what you mean."
But just as Mr. Greenspan maintains a philosophical, if not political, agenda built around free markets and low taxes, Mr. Rubin is by no means above the fray concerning taxes and spending.
His push for fiscal restraint stems in large part from his Wall Street perspective that a happy bond market delivers low interest rates.
Even before the terrorist attacks, Mr. Rubin's was a leading voice among Democrats seeking to roll back some longer-term elements of the tax cut Mr. Bush signed into law in June, warning that it imperiled the nation's fiscal health and risked driving rates up.
Along with Mr. Greenspan, Mr. Rubin "threw a cold towel" on Republicans who sought a capital-gains tax cut after the attacks, said Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan, the senior Democrat on the House Ways and Means Committee.
Mr. Rubin declined to comment on his role in the current deliberations about how to deal with the economy. But it has not escaped the notice of Republicans or Democrats in Congress that he has often been more visible on Capitol Hill than Mr. O'Neill, whose reviews as treasury secretary have been mixed from both sides of the aisle.
"I'm a big Bob Rubin fan," said Jack Welch, the former chairman of the General Electric Company. "I like what he says generally. But we have to be sure we don't get into thinking only about what worked yesterday, and we desperately need to keep a bipartisan focus."
Some Republicans said Mr. Rubin's influence has limits. While saying he appreciated Mr. Rubin's role in the debate, Representative Phil English, Republican of Pennsylvania, said that Mr. Rubin was wrong to rule out further long-term tax cuts because they might drain future surpluses and push interest rates up.
"A long-term tax cut will have an impact on the budget, but it will also have a long-term impact on growth and jobs," Mr. English said.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE ECONOMY; 
CONGRESS GETS PLEA TO DROP TAX BENEFITS FOR INVESTORS AND WIDEN ECONOMIC RELIEF

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 

 BODY:
Influential advisers and key members of Congress expressed opposition today to two of the main Republican proposals for stimulating an already weakened economy as new figures suggested that the terrorist attacks would inflict heavy damage on jobs, spending and the business outlook. 
 Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, and Robert E. Rubin, the former treasury secretary, advised Congress against cutting the capital gains tax, the favored approach of many Republicans on Capitol Hill, or reducing corporate income taxes, the idea mentioned by the Bush administration. 
 Mr. Rubin, who served under President Bill Clinton, and Mr. Greenspan told a closed-door meeting of the Senate Finance Committee that those two types of tax cuts would not give the economy the kind of punch it might need to rebound quickly, senators and aides said later. Some senior Republicans said the chances of either proposal now making it into law had dimmed. 
Mr. Rubin's appearance on Capitol Hill today was his third meeting with lawmakers since the terrorist strikes, underscoring his unusual role as a Democratic shadow minister in shaping the debate over how to respond to the economy's troubles. In some ways, in fact, he has been more visible in Washington than the current treasury secretary, Paul H. O'Neill. Page B8. 
The economic news today was not encouraging. The Conference Board reported that in the 10 days this month before the terrorist attacks on the World Trade Center and the Pentagon, consumer confidence had registered its sharpest decline since the last recession. The drop suggested to analysts that the economy was flirting with a recession or was in one even before suffering from the fallout of the attacks.
Other figures showed a steep falloff last week in retail sales. And new estimates suggested that 100,000 people in New York might lose their jobs, at least temporarily, because of the devastation in Lower Manhattan and its effects on the city's industries. Wall Street firms prepared their employees for the likelihood of smaller bonuses, and perhaps layoffs.
On Capitol Hill, both parties struggled with how to balance increasing pressure to address the economy's deterioration with the possibility that economic stimulus already in the pipeline would be enough to support a rapid recovery. 
Congress continued to consider what other steps it might take, including providing a tax rebate to all or most workers, expanding the unemployment insurance program, increasing the minimum wage or bailing out needy industries. But both the administration and Congress seemed to heed Mr. Greenspan's repeated call not to rush into anything before the extent of the damage to the economy becomes clearer.
The Federal Reserve has already cut interest rates eight times this year and is expected to do so again next week. The tax cut signed into law by President Bush earlier this year will help, economists said, as will $40 billion in emergency spending passed by Congress after the attacks and a $15 billion package to bail out the airline industry and bolster airport security.
In their meeting with the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Rubin recommended that any tax cuts be temporary and designed to give consumers and perhaps businesses a swift boost without creating long-term budget problems, according to accounts of the session from members of both parties.
The most obvious way to meet those criteria, members of Congress said, would be another tax rebate for individuals plus some breaks for businesses that invest in new equipment and factories.
Mr. Greenspan said any stimulus package would have to be sizable to be effective, perhaps as much as $100 billion, at the high end of what Congress has been considering, members of the committee said. In a public statement later, the Fed said Mr. Greenspan intended that figure to include the emergency spending that Congress has already approved for relief and rebuilding. By that benchmark, Mr. Greenspan seemed to be suggesting that further stimulus might have to amount to an additional $40 billion to $60 billion.
The chairman of the committee, Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, and its senior Republican, Senator Charles E. Grassley of Iowa, said after the meeting that they agreed with the general framework set out by Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Rubin. Mr. Grassley said in an interview that he had reluctantly concluded that now was not the right time to press for a capital gains tax cut.
Asked about the administration's position, Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, said the need for new tax cuts and spending, their scale and composition "remain under review."
House Republicans said they had not given up on cutting the capital gains tax. Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader, said that a capital gains cut was still under consideration and that the White House had made a strong case for reducing corporate tax rates.
In the days immediately after the attacks, many Republicans in Congress rallied around a capital gains cut as a way to bolster investment and restore Wall Street confidence. 
The Bush administration never embraced that plan. Instead, Mr. O'Neill and Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser, have told lawmakers that they support permanent cuts in corporate tax rates, a step also favored by many corporations.
But, Mr. Greenspan, a Republican whose clout on Capitol Hill is unrivaled on economic issues, and Mr. Rubin, now a top executive of Citigroup who has re-emerged in the last week as a kind of eminence grise for the Democrats, teamed up today to steer the finance committee in a different direction. Mr. O'Neill declined an invitation to attend the session so he could be at the White House for a National Security Council meeting and a meeting with the Japanese prime minister.
The message from Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Rubin, senators and their aides said, was that any tax cuts should be temporary, and that they not lead the financial markets to push up long-term interest rates out of fear that the government's long-term fiscal health would be put in jeopardy. Government budget analysts and private economists were scaling back their forecasts for the federal budget surplus in the coming year, saying it could be $25 billion to $50 billion instead of the $176 billion previously projected.
Mr. Greenspan restated his support for reducing or eliminating the capital gains tax in the long run, but he said it was not the best way to deal with the economy's short-term problems. Mr. Rubin said he opposed cutting the capital gains tax, but agreed that such a cut now would not give the economy the kind of immediate jolt that might be needed, people who were in the meeting said.
The committee discussed but did not decide on several other tax-cutting options. Among them was a tax rebate, which Democrats would like to cover all workers, even those at the low end of the income scale who did not qualify for the rebate checks sent out this summer under President Bush's tax cut. 
Another topic of discussion was speeding the schedule under which companies can write off the value of their investments in factories and equipment, which could encourage businesses to invest more.
"There was a general feeling in the room that, whatever it is, on both the consumption and investment side, if there is anything, it should be short term," Mr. Baucus said. 
Mr. Grassley agreed with Mr. Baucus's characterization, but said there were still divisions between the parties about what any additional short-term tax cuts would look like. He said Republicans would prefer that any further tax reductions for individuals work the same way as this summer's rebates, and go only to people who pay federal income taxes. 
Such an approach excludes about 34 million working people who are subject to the payroll taxes that finance Social Security and Medicare but do not earn enough money to pay any federal income taxes. Democrats said they wanted any tax cut to cover all working people.

HEADLINE: A NATION CHALLENGED: NARCOTICS; 
Afghanistan Remains a Major Drug Trader Despite Taliban Ban on Poppy Growing

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Sept. 25 

 BODY:
The Taliban government in Afghanistan has earned tens of millions of dollars from the export of heroin and other narcotics since it proclaimed last year that it was ending opium poppy cultivation, American officials say. Cutting off this important source of revenue is part of the Bush administration's economic campaign against the regime, the officials said. 
 The Taliban won international acclaim in July 2000 when its leaders banned the growing of opium poppies. Many of the nation's impoverished farmers counted on the harvest to feed their families, and the Taliban used tax proceeds from it to buy arms. 
 United Nations inspectors who have toured the country say that poppy cultivation has, in fact, been largely eradicated in areas under the Taliban's control, a finding confirmed by American narcotics experts who visited Afghanistan in June. 
But the Taliban did not destroy existing stocks of narcotics. A United Nations panel noted in May that Afghan opium poppy production had leaped to 4,600 tons in 1999 from 2,500 tons in 1998, and was 3,100 tons in 2000 before the ban on cultivation, raising the question of whether the Taliban was stocking up.
American experts now aiding the Bush administration's effort to muster an international coalition against terrorism and the Taliban protectors of Osama bin Laden, the prime suspect in the Sept. 11 terror attacks, say that enormous quantities of opium and of heroin itself have been hidden around the country, and have continued to be sold since the ban.
Before declaring an end to poppy cultivation, Afghanistan produced some 75 percent of the world's supply of opium, international narcotics experts said.
"The ban on poppy cultivation has been very effective in Taliban-controlled areas," one American official said. "But we believe the stockpile from last year is still funding the Taliban. Opium and heroin are a major source of the Taliban's income."
The Bush administration would now like to cut off that money.
"We will be using all instruments of our power against them, and one major area is their finances," a senior Defense Department official said. "Drugs are very important to that."
Another senior official familiar with the military planning said that targeting stockpiles of opium, the raw ingredient for heroin, and laboratories was difficult and not a principal aim of the military campaign. But he said that Washington has not ruled out military force. 
"It may be one of the hardest things to go after," he said. "It might be more efficient to use law enforcement and other instruments." 
In trying to fight Afghanistan's drug trade, the United States might win new cooperation from Iran, Russia and the central Asian states, which face mounting problems with addiction and narcotics crime.
The Taliban have relied on revenues from the drug trade for years and have used the proceeds to buy weapons to fight the Northern Alliance, the rebel group variously estimated to control 5 to 15 percent of Afghanistan's territory. 
At first, the Taliban was taxing poppy cultivation and charging fees for narcotics production, American officials say. A United Nations report estimated that the Taliban earned $15 million to $27 million annually from taxes levied on opium production, an estimate that did not include any proceeds from trading drugs. An American official estimated that the total annual revenue was $40 million to $50 million.
Then the Taliban announced an end to opium cultivation. But the narcotics trade flourished as drug traffickers continued to export opium and heroin. "The amount of heroin that has been seized has not changed," Mohammad S. Amirkhizi, a senior official at the United Nations Office of Drug Control and Crime Prevention in Vienna, said in a telephone interview. "The amount of opium seized only shows a 30 percent decrease in Iran and not in other cases. That shows that stocks are still available."
A former American official said intelligence experts have never established a direct link between the trade and Mr. bin Laden. Two senior Congressional aides with access to intelligence reports said Mr. bin Laden does not actually traffic in drugs, but makes money off the heroin trade by hiring out his fighters to guard laboratories and escort drug convoys moving through Iran to Turkey, where often the opium base is processed into heroin. 
In recent days, there has been concern that the Taliban may escalate the drug war by increasing the export of drugs and suspending the ban on poppy cultivation. The price of opium within Afghanistan has plummeted, according to the United Nations Office of Drug Control and Crime Prevention, which says the price for a kilo of opium in Afghanistan was $700 on Sept. 11. By Sept. 18, it was $180. By Sept. 24, the price had dropped to $90.
United Nations officials said the price decline may reflect problems in exporting drugs in a region that may soon be ringed with troops and combat aircraft. But another theory is that the price has dropped because the Taliban may end their ban on poppy growth in response to an American military strike or find they cannot enforce the ban as the planting season resumes in a few weeks.

HEADLINE: The Interrupted Primary 

 BODY:
New Yorkers finally completed the primary election yesterday that was interrupted by the terrorist attacks on Sept. 11. For many, the very exercise of voting, going back to finish what was started, offered some comfort and pride. Another necessary piece of our democratic infrastructure remained intact, ready for probable runoff elections on Oct. 11 and a general election Nov. 6. 
 For two weeks now, New Yorkers have been telling one another that their world has changed. Nevertheless, the vast majority of those who went to vote yesterday said in exit polls that they were sticking to the candidates they supported before the World Trade Center attack. Education remained the biggest concern among the electorate on the Democratic side, followed by the economy. Terrorism and the need to rebuild Lower Manhattan ranked lower on the voters' list. 
 The two apparent runoff candidates for the Democratic nomination for mayor, Public Advocate Mark Green and the Bronx borough president, Fernando Ferrer, have different styles of leadership and very different agendas when it comes to rebuilding the city. In the 16 days before the anticipated runoff, Democrats will have to evaluate them in light of the new challenges that post-terrorist New York poses. Flexibility and firmness seem particularly important now. And all promises for expensive new programs should be viewed skeptically in light of the faltering economy and wounded tax base.
On the Republican side, Michael Bloomberg easily won the party's mayoral nomination and must now begin to define himself for the larger general electorate. Mr. Bloomberg has been describing himself as the man most likely to continue the legacy of Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. That will be a more complicated pitch if Mr. Giuliani decides to somehow insert himself as a candidate. We hope the mayor drops the idea. An attempt to repeal the term-limits law and find a slot for him on the ballot would force a complicated and bitter debate, the last thing New York City needs at this time of crisis. The mayor's international reputation right now is too sterling, and the need for his attention over the next few months too great, to allow either to be diluted.
The city's election machinery tends to be creaky even in the best of times, and the fact that voters managed to cast their ballots was yet another example of adversity bringing out the best in New Yorkers. Mayor Giuliani helped by providing higher wages for poll workers. The city's Board of Elections deserves credit for scrambling to put together this emergency election in two short weeks despite a range of computer problems because of the attack in Lower Manhattan, where its offices were located.
Trying to vote and to run for public office while the city is in shock from an unprecedented tragedy has been difficult for everyone. Now, as New York City returns to life, its politicians must engage in a full public campaign that gives voters a chance to figure out who can best lead a different city.

HEADLINE: THE NEW YORK PRIMARY: THE OVERVIEW; 
FERRER AND GREEN HEAD FOR RUNOFF IN MAYORAL RACE

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

 BODY:
Struggling to choose a new mayor precisely two weeks after a terrorist jet attack devastated the World Trade Center, New York City Democrats yesterday apparently extended the primary contest an additional 16 days by sending two candidates, Mark Green and Fernando Ferrer, into a runoff for their party's nomination, according to a survey of voters leaving the polls.
 There was no ambiguity on the Republican side: Michael R. Bloomberg, the billionaire communications entrepreneur, trounced his opponent, Herman Badillo, to become the Republican mayoral candidate in the general election on Nov. 6. 
 The outcome on the Democratic side -- with turnout as depressed as the spirits of many New Yorkers, on a gray day in which the smell of fire still hung in the downtown air -- appears to mean that a contest that had stopped midvote on Sept. 11 would continue through a runoff on Oct. 11. None of the Democrats appeared to win more than 40 percent, which would have eliminated the requirement for the second round of elections. 
As it was, the four Democrats had been awkwardly grappling with how to campaign, or whether to campaign at all, in a city that had been traumatized by the terrorist attack, which occurred less than three hours after the polls opened on the first primary day. They had been grappling with the increasing popularity of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani as he has guided New York through this crisis, and with suggestions by Mr. Giuliani that he was looking for a way to circumvent the term limits law that had prevented him from running for a third term.
In a survey of voters leaving the polls yesterday, two-thirds of the Democrats declared that they approved of the way the Republican mayor was handling his job. And roughly 40 percent of the Democrats said that if a way were found to put Mr. Giuliani's name on the ballot in November -- and Mr. Giuliani's aides are looking for one -- they would vote for him over any of the Democrats who have spent the better part of the past four years preparing for this vote.
William C. Thompson won the Democratic nomination for city comptroller, defeating Herbert E. Berman, who conceded.
In apparently winning a spot in the runoff, Mr. Ferrer mobilized a growing Hispanic population in New York as he succeeded at assembling a coalition of black and Latino voters behind his attempt to become New York's first Puerto Rican mayor. More than half the black voters and almost three-quarters of Latino voters chose Mr. Ferrer, the survey found. Blacks and Hispanics made up nearly half the primary electorate, the survey said.
Mr. Ferrer, who has been the Bronx borough president for 14 years, faces another longtime fixture in New York government, Mr. Green, who is finishing his second term as the public advocate.
They defeated Alan G. Hevesi, the city comptroller, and Peter F. Vallone, the City Council speaker, according to the survey.
Mr. Ferrer, smiling broadly, sang along with Frank Sinatra to a recording of "New York, New York," as a crowd of supporters waved small American flags in front of him. Before declaring victory, he asked them to join him in a moment of silence for the victims of the attack.
Mr. Ferrer, who had run a campaign talking about his advocacy for "the other New York," spoke last night of bringing the city together, going so far as to praise Mr. Giuliani, who has been one of his favorite targets. "My friends, you can be sure of one thing: Together we are going to rebuild New York," he said. 
"The people of our city said something more with their votes today," Mr. Ferrer said. "They said that even as we recover from this tragedy, we must not forget that there are other pressing problems facing New Yorkers. Problems we must not ignore. The towers have crumbled. But our commitments have not. They remain strong."
Mr. Green took the lectern last night as Mr. Ferrer was talking, in a departure from usual political protocol, and in the midst of the 11 p.m. news. And he took clear aim at Mr. Ferrer's campaign theme about the "other New York," saying that the central theme of his campaign would be unity.
"That will be the basis of my campaign: We are one New York and one city," he declared.
"Our campaigns must be utterly focused on the future," he said. "We have to, and I am confident we will, avoid the kind of petty personal attacks that divert the public. The public demands and has the right for us to have a conversation about how we will rebuild New York."
Mr. Hevesi, in conceding last night, said that he had lost the race, at least in part, because "I made some mistakes, they came back to bite me, in this campaign, and we never recovered from it." He added, "I know we are really good in government; we weren't as good in politics."
Mr. Vallone declined to concede last night, noting that there were still votes left to be counted.
"New York is a city of five boroughs, not one," he said. "And the returns from the other four boroughs are not in yet, so this is not a concession speech." Noting what happened in Florida last year, he said with a grin, "Doesn't this city deserve to have every vote counted? I think so."
In a Green-Ferrer runoff, Mr. Green would appear to be in a strong position, though it remained to be seen if Mr. Ferrer's performance might result in what his aides have long predicted: galvanizing an unusually strong turnout among Hispanic and black voters. The survey of voters found that, given that choice, Mr. Green was favored by about half of all the Democrats who showed up yesterday, compared with 40 percent who supported Mr. Ferrer. The survey showed that Mr. Green is best positioned to pick up most of the votes that went to Mr. Hevesi and Mr. Vallone. Nearly 60 percent of Mr. Hevesi's supporters, and about 50 percent of Mr. Vallone's supporters, said they would support Mr. Green over Mr. Ferrer.
On the Republican side, Mr. Bloomberg, standing in front of an American flag, and in a room that included many of his high-priced political consultants, declared that the pause in campaigning that took place because of the attack on the World Trade Center was about to come to an end. And he argued that he was best suited, given his experience in business, to rebuild New York.
"My experience has prepared me for these rough and difficult days ahead," Mr. Bloomberg said. Mr. Badillo conceded about 11:30 last night.
In another sign of Mr. Giuliani's popularity, in the Republican primary there were indications that many voters had decided to write in a candidate. Those votes will not be tallied immediately, but it is most likely that the name most written in was Mr. Giuliani's.
The unofficial early results were slow in being reported last night, in part because the terrorist attack had damaged the computer system used by the Police Department to report the results. The Board of Elections said the official results for all races might not be completed before Sunday. 
The primary came on an intermittently rainy day in New York. Voters trickled to the polls along streets draped with American flags, and past memorials of candles and posters, some of which were streaked blurry by the rain.
The campaign headquarters last night -- usually a place of loud bands, balloons, banners, bustling bars, cheering and blaring television sets, at least on the winners' side -- were relatively sedate, reflecting these strange times. Mr. Bloomberg did not even rent a ballroom. Instead, he delivered a victory speech from his campaign headquarters on East 56th street. Rather than a platform filled with television cameras, there was only one, providing a feed to all interested television stations.
This was, in the context of New York's history, an unusually significant election even before the attack on Sept. 11. New Yorkers are electing virtually an entirely new city government -- mayor, public advocate, city comptroller and most of the City Council -- because the city's term limits law has forced an exodus of incumbents. And the election signaled, or so it seemed, the end of Mr. Giuliani's era in New York.
A Democratic runoff would take place over the next 16 days; the vote is on Oct. 11, a Thursday. Each of the Democrats would be allowed to spend an additional $2.6 million on hisr runoff campaign. 
In normal times, the fact that the Democratic primary has apparently come down to two candidates competing for a nomination that has historically been tantamount to winning the mayoralty itself would presage a fierce two weeks of campaigning. Democrats outnumber Republicans in New York by six to one, and Mr. Green last night described the eventual Democratic nominee as "the presumptive next mayor," a characterization that Mr. Bloomberg would no doubt dispute. 
But both Mr. Green and Mr. Ferrer have proven to be mild candidates already this year. And there will be resistance to the two of them changing their tone, assuming there is a runoff. Aides to both said it would be unseemly, during such bleak times, to engage in politics as usual.
Setting the table for a likely runoff, Mr. Green had already begun addressing how he would govern the city during this crisis, outlining ways to rebuild Lower Manhattan and improve security. It is a theme that he said he would stick to in the days ahead.
"Democrats and all voters should select the person who has the best leadership skills to unite and rebuild New York," Mr. Green said before the polls closed, sitting on a yellow couch in his suite on the 44th floor of the Sheraton Hotel, next to his wife, Deni, and his children, Jonah and Jenya. "That's urgent, and we have done so much to talk to the voters of New York that I am serene and confident."
Mr. Ferrer had not provided specific proposals for how he would govern the city under these newly changed circumstances. But he has emphasized that he would not abandon the central appeal of his campaign -- to represent the interests of New Yorkers who, he said, did not benefit from the good economic times under Mr. Giuliani. .
Mr. Green has a financial advantage in a runoff: he has already raised enough money to spend the maximum allowable in a runoff under the city's campaign finance law. By contrast, Mr. Ferrer would need, in the days ahead, to spend time raising money to be financially competitive with Mr. Green.
And Mr. Ferrer's promise to represent New Yorkers who did not benefit from the improvement in New York's fortunes over the past eight years was reflected in the economic standing of voters who supported him. Almost half the voters who said their annual income was $30,000 or less voted for Mr. Ferrer, according to the survey. Voters who made over $100,000 a year were divided between Mr. Vallone and Mr. Green.

How Voter Survey Was Conducted
The Election Day survey was based on questionnaires completed by voters as they left voting polls throughout New York City yesterday. Questionnaires were available in English or Spanish.
The poll was conducted by Edison Media Research of Edison, N.J.
The results are based on 1,097 Democratic primary voters and 205 Republican primary voters, in 40 randomly selected election districts across the city. 
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20, the results from such surveys should differ by no more than plus or minus 4 percentage points for Democrats, and about 15 points for Republicans, from what would have been obtained by seeking to interview all primary voters who turned out in New York City yesterday. 
Results based on smaller subgroups have a larger potential sampling error. In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of voter opinion on Election Day, like the reluctance of some voters to take time to fill out the questionnaire, may introduce other sources of error into the survey.
