HEADLINE: Campaigns In New Jersey Are Adapting To Attacks 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER

DATELINE: TRENTON, Sept. 25 

 BODY:
The candidates for New Jersey governor are quickly adapting their campaigns to the terrorist attacks of Sept. 11, but in slightly different, if characteristic, ways.
 The candidates, Bret D. Schundler and James E. McGreevey, have both released advertisements acknowledging the attacks, the suffering of the victims and their families, and the sacrifices of rescue workers. Both have also come forward with modest proposals for improving New Jersey's defenses against terrorism and its readiness for future emergencies. 
 Mr. Schundler has been bolder in his response and, in the eyes of state officials who have criticized him, has moved too quickly. But if Mr. McGreevey has moved more cautiously, that, too, may have its risks. 
Today, Mr. McGreevey, the Democrat, called for the creation of an antiterrorism task force in the state attorney general's office and urged that the federal government take over airport security or allow states to step in to ensure the safety of airline passengers.
Among other things, Mr. McGreevey, the mayor of Woodbridge, said New Jersey should conduct a thorough review of its emergency management system and, at a minimum, add a physician to its emergency operations group so that the network of trauma centers and other hospitals could be kept better informed during a crisis.
Mr. McGreevey's remarks -- after a closed meeting with a predominantly Democratic group of business and hospital executives and former state and federal government officials -- came four days after Mr. Schundler, the Republican candidate and former mayor of Jersey City, released a more extensive proposal.
Mr. Schundler's eagerness to display leadership soon after the attack led to a damaging gaffe when he criticized aspects of New Jersey's response during an interview in which he described his own ideas. He later apologized, although he disputed the thrust of the resulting news article.
Mr. McGreevey, meanwhile, began running a TV commercial today in which he says that "for all of us," the Sept. 11 attacks are incomprehensible, but that "we're also seeing America at her best," because everyone is "coming together, united behind our president and our great nation." He assures viewers that "we'll meet this challenge" and "move forward, building our economy, improving our schools and making sure that Jersey's safe."
Mr. McGreevey's ad was produced by Greer, Margolis, Mitchell, Burns & Associates Inc. of Washington, along with Message and Media, a New Brunswick firm. The Greer, Margolis firm is also representing Mark R. Warner, the Democratic candidate for governor of Virginia, the only other statewide race in the country this year. In a TV ad that began running Sept. 18, Mr. Warner makes a similar speech, seated, as is Mr. McGreevey, in front of an American flag.
"We've all been touched by this tragedy," Mr. Warner says. "But America shines through as we stand united in support of President Bush and our military." He adds that Virginians "must meet the challenges of the future: ensuring the safety of our people, building a strong economy and providing our children with the opportunity to succeed."
Mr. Schundler's campaign manager, Bill Pascoe, accused Mr. McGreevey today of lifting Mr. Warner's script. "I guess now we know that when Joe Biden came in to campaign for Jim McGreevey, he didn't just bring in campaign cash, he brought sage advice gleaned from years of experience on the campaign trail," he said, referring to Mr. Biden's 1988 campaign for president, in which he was caught plagiarizing a speech by a British politician.
A spokesman for Mr. McGreevey, Richard McGrath, said the resemblance between the ads was merely proof that "great minds think alike" and had nothing to do with the shared consulting firm. "Jim McGreevey was affected by this terrible tragedy in the same way as millions of Americans," he said. "So it shouldn't be surprising that his response was on a similar wavelength as other public leaders'."
Mr. Schundler has been saving what money he has raised by buying less-expensive newspaper ads. In a full-page ad today in The Star-Ledger of Newark and other newspapers, he wrote that New Jersey would play an important part in the struggle "to preserve freedom" and said its next governor must, too.
